It is not clear whether the existence of such a ring homomorphism $\sigma$ is part of the previous literature on the subject, in part due to the tendency to use ambiguous integral modular form notation, such as $c_{4}$, for topological modular forms, such as $B$ and $\widetilde{B}$.

With these changes, and our final normalization of the classes $\nu_{k}$, the products with 2-power torsion elements in $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$ are somewhat more regular. Our conclusion is given in Theorem 9.54 and Tables 9.8 and 9.9. These give the products $x y$ for $x$ a $T$-module generator of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$ other than $x=1$, replacing each $B_{k}$ with $\widetilde{B}_{k}$, and $y$ a 2-power torsion ring generator of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$, other than $y \in\{\eta, \nu, B, M\}$. Furthermore, the rows for $x \in\left\{\widetilde{B}_{k}, C_{k}, D_{2 j+1}\right\}$ are omitted, because all products in these rows are zero, with the exception of

$$
\eta_{i} \widetilde{B}_{j}=\eta \widetilde{B}_{i+j}
$$

Here $\widetilde{B}_{k+8}$ is interpreted as $\widetilde{B}_{k} M$, for $k \geq 0$. The remaining multiplication tables then "only" have 38 rows and 14 columns.

One bit of ambiguity remains: Having chosen $\nu_{1}, \nu_{2}$ and $\nu_{4}$, with $\nu D_{4}=2 \nu_{4}$, there are unique choices for $\nu_{5}$ and $\nu_{6}$ satisfying $\nu_{1} \nu_{5}=2 \nu \nu_{6}$ and $\nu_{2} \nu_{4}=3 \nu \nu_{6}$. We then have $\nu_{4} \nu_{6}=s \nu \nu_{2} M$ in $\pi_{246}(\operatorname{tmf}) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 4$ for some sign $s \in\{ \pm 1\}$. We have not determined this sign $s$, which is independent of the choice of $\nu_{1}, \nu_{2}$ and $\nu_{4}$. If $s=1$, then the relation $\nu_{i} \nu_{j}=(i+1) \nu \nu_{i+j}$ holds for all $i$ and $j$.

Mahowald noted (cf. [76, Prop. 8.7]) that multiplication by $\epsilon$ agrees with multiplication by $B$ on the $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$. This is equivalent to the assertion that $\widetilde{B} \cdot y=0$ for all $y \in \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})=\left(\nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}, \bar{\kappa}\right)$. We prove in Corollary 9.55 that $\widetilde{B}_{k} \cdot y=0$ for all $0 \leq k \leq 7$ and $y \in \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$, thus generalizing Mahowald's assertion. (The honorary case $\widetilde{B}_{k} \cdot \nu_{3}=0$ is not made explicit in our tables, but $\eta_{1}^{3} \widetilde{B}_{k}=\eta^{3} \widetilde{B}_{k+3}=4 \nu \widetilde{B}_{k+3}=0$.)

# 0.8. Duality 

Working for a moment over $\mathbb{Z}[1 / 6]$, with 2 and 3 inverted, the compactified moduli stack $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$ is equivalent to the weighted projective stack associated to the graded ring $\mathbb{Z}[1 / 6]\left[c_{4}, c_{6}\right]$, cf. $[\mathbf{6 2}, \S 4.6]$. Its cohomology satisfies Serre duality with respect to the dualizing sheaf $\Omega \cong \omega^{\otimes-10}$, corresponding to $1 / c_{4} c_{6}$, meaning that there is a perfect pairing of finitely generated free $\mathbb{Z}[1 / 6]$-modules

$$
H^{s}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{e l l} ; \omega^{\otimes k}\right) \otimes H^{1-s}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{e l l} ; \operatorname{Hom}\left(\omega^{\otimes k}, \Omega\right)\right) \longrightarrow H^{1}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{e l l} ; \Omega\right) \cong \mathbb{Z}[1 / 6]
$$

Hence the descent spectral sequence has $E_{2}$-term concentrated in the rows $s=0$ and $s=1$, with

$$
E_{2}^{0,2 k}=H^{0}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{e l l} ; \omega^{\otimes k}\right)
$$

linearly dual to

$$
E_{2}^{1,-20-2 k}=H^{1}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{e l l} ; \operatorname{Hom}\left(\omega^{\otimes k}, \Omega\right)\right)
$$

This implies that $\pi_{n}(\operatorname{Tmf})[1 / 6]$ is linearly dual to $\pi_{-21-n}(\operatorname{Tmf})[1 / 6]$, and can be refined to the spectrum level statement that $\operatorname{Tmf}[1 / 6]$ is Anderson self-dual in the

sense that

$$
\Sigma^{21} \operatorname{Tmf}[1 / 6] \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\operatorname{Tmf})[1 / 6]
$$

Here $I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)$ denotes the Anderson dual of $X$, see Section 10.4. Vesna Stojanoska extended this result to the primes 3 and 2, by first establishing Anderson self-duality for covers $\operatorname{Tmf}(2)$ of $\operatorname{Tmf}[1 / 2]$ and $\operatorname{Tmf}(3)$ of $\operatorname{Tmf}[1 / 3]$, and then applying descent for the natural actions by the groups $G L_{2}(\mathbb{Z} / 2)$ and $G L_{2}(\mathbb{Z} / 3)$ of order 6 and 48, respectively. The argument for $p=3$ appeared in $[\mathbf{1 6 1}]$, while part of the argument for $p=2$ appeared in $[\mathbf{1 6 2}]$.

The computation of the sheaf cohomology of $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$ can also be interpreted as saying that there is a homotopy fiber sequence

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \longrightarrow \operatorname{Tmf} \longrightarrow \Sigma^{-1} \operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)
$$

where $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$ is the iterated homotopy cofiber in the square
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Formulated in terms of connective covers, Anderson duality implies an equivalence of $t m f$-modules

$$
\Sigma^{20} t m f \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

In Chapter 10 we turn the argument around, and first establish the above equivalence after completion at 2, and then use an argument of John Greenlees and Stojanoska [67] to glue tmf and its Anderson dual together to obtain Anderson self-duality for $T m f$.

We obtain the equivalence above by descent along the map $\iota^{\prime}: \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3) \simeq$ $B P\langle 2\rangle$, corresponding to a separable (in the sense of $[\mathbf{1 5 0}, \S 9.1]$ ) extension $T M F \rightarrow$ $T M F_{1}(3)$ of degree 8 inside the $G L_{2}(\mathbb{Z} / 3)$-Galois extension $T M F \rightarrow T M F(3)$. The calculation of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ as a $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-module from Theorem 9.27 shows that there is a top class $C_{7} / B M$ in $\pi_{-20}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$, corresponding to a bottom class in $\pi_{20}$ of the Anderson dual. We can represent the latter homotopy class by a $t m f$-module map

$$
a: \Sigma^{20} t m f \longrightarrow I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

We show in Theorem 10.6 that $a$ is a 2-adic equivalence. For the proof we use the finite CW spectrum $\Phi=\Phi A(1)$ from Lemma 1.42, which we may take to be SpanierWhitehead self-dual, with $\bmod 2$ cohomology realizing the double $A(2) / / E(2)$ of $A(1)$. For any such spectrum $\Phi$ there is an equivalence $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle$. Smashing $a$ with the equivalence $\Sigma^{-12} \Phi \simeq D \Phi=F(\Phi, S)$ we obtain a map

$$
\Sigma^{8} B P\langle 2\rangle \longrightarrow I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

which can be verified to be an equivalence by an inspection of homotopy groups. This completes the proof of Anderson duality for $T m f$ at $p=2$. To be precise, we formulate our Theorem 10.6 in terms of the perhaps more familiar Brown-Comenetz duality functor $X \mapsto I(X)$, saying that there is a 2 -adic equivalence of $t m f$-modules

$$
\Sigma^{20} t m f \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

where $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$ is defined to be the iterated homotopy cofiber of a cubical diagram, similar to the square in the definition of $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$. However,

$I\left(X / 2^{\infty}\right) \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)$ after 2-adic completion for any spectrum $X$, by Lemma 10.10, so the two formulations are equivalent.

Recall that the $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ repeats $M$-periodically, and is generated by finitely many classes of finite additive order in the range $0 \leq *<192$. The $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{n}(t m f)$ for $0 \leq n<192$ usually contributes classes of finite additive order in $\pi_{n-191}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$, and appears in Pontryagin dual form as $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{190-n}\left(I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)\right) \cong \pi_{170-n}(t m f)$. Hence Anderson self-duality for $t m f$ is visible as a Pontryagin self-duality in most of the $B$-power torsion $\Gamma_{B} N_{*} \subset \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$, with the finite group in degree $n$ being Pontryagin dual to the finite group in degree $170-n$.

However, there is one systematic family of exceptions. The $B$-power torsion classes $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle$ in degree $n=3+24 k$, for $0 \leq k \leq 6$, occur in $\pi_{n-191}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ as the quotients of torsion-free extensions by $\mathbb{Z}\left\{C_{k} / B M\right\}$. Hence these classes contribute under Anderson duality to the $B$-periodic, 2-torsion free part of

$$
\left.\pi_{191-n}\left(I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)\right) \cong \pi_{171-n}(t m f)\right)
$$

and are not visible in $\pi_{170-n}(t m f)$.
Conversely, the $B$-torsion free part of $N_{*}$ is a direct sum of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules $k o[k]$, with bottom class $D_{k}$ in degree $n=24 k$. For $1 \leq k \leq 7$ the relation $B \cdot D_{k}=d_{k} B_{k}$ in $k o[k]$ implies that $\pi_{n-192}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ contains a finite group $\left\langle B_{k} / B M\right\rangle \cong \mathbb{Z} / d_{k}$. Its Pontryagin dual appears as $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{191-n}\left(I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)\right) \cong \pi_{171-n}(t m f)$, namely as the summand $\left\langle\nu_{7-k}\right\rangle$.

Thus, the duality of $t m f$ is most visibly reflected in the part $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ of $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ consisting of the $B$-power torsion classes that are not in degrees $* \equiv 3$ $\bmod 24$. Here $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)=\Theta N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]$, with $\Theta N_{*}$ concentrated in degrees $* \not \equiv 3$ $\bmod 24$, and there is a perfect pairing

$$
(-,-): \Theta N_{170-n} \otimes \Theta N_{n} \longrightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

for all $n$. The remaining $B$-power torsion is not Pontryagin self-dual, but interacts as explained above with the non-free part of the $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-torsion free quotient of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$. This is illustrated in Figures 10.1 and 10.2, where $\Theta_{n} N_{*}$ and $\Theta_{170-n} N_{*}$ are shown above and below the "fold line", respectively. The exceptional classes $\nu_{k}$ in degrees $* \equiv 3 \bmod 24$ appear just outside of the mirror symmetric parts of these pictures.

We introduce the notations $M / x^{\infty}$ and $\Gamma_{x} M$ in Section 10.2, and review the Brown-Comenetz duality functor $I$ and prove the 2-complete duality theorem for $t m f$ in Section 10.3. We review Anderson duality and convert our duality theorem into a 2-complete self-duality theorem for $T m f$ in Section 10.4. In Section 10.5 we convert the spectrum level duality theorem for $t m f$ into several algebraic duality statements, summarized in Theorem 10.26. In particular, we verify the claims made above about additive extensions in $\pi_{*}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$, which lead to a less ad hoc Definition 10.18 of the $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-module $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f) \cong \Theta N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]$, where $\Theta N_{*}$ is Pontryagin self-dual. Finally that self-duality is spelled out in Theorem 10.29 and Table 10.1. As a rule of thumb, cf. Remark 10.30, classes $x$ and $y$ of order 2 in $\Theta N_{*}$ are dual when they formally multiply to $(\eta \nu \epsilon \kappa)_{6}$.

# 0.9. The sphere spectrum 

In Chapter 11, we discuss the mod 2 Adams spectral sequence for the sphere spectrum. Using the $H_{\infty}$ ring structure on $S$, and the proven Adams conjecture, we

readily determine the full pattern of differentials originating in degrees $t-s \leq 29$. See Theorems 11.52, 11.54, 11.56 and 11.59. By means of a comparison of Adams spectral sequences along the maps

$$
S \xrightarrow{i} C \eta \xrightarrow{1 \wedge i} C \eta \wedge C \nu
$$

we show in Theorem 11.71 that there is a hidden $\eta$-extension from $h_{1} g$ detecting $\eta \tilde{\kappa}$ to $P d_{0}$ detecting $\eta^{2} \tilde{\kappa}$. This is equivalent to Mimura's result [129, Thm. B] that $\epsilon \kappa \neq 0$ in $\pi_{22}(S)$, but our proof is entirely stable. These methods quickly give the graded ring structure of $\pi_{*}(S)$ for $* \leq 28$, see Theorem 11.61.

We need some of this information about $\pi_{*}(S)$, in the smaller range $* \leq 22$, when we determine the Adams differentials for $t m f$ in Chapter 5. Furthermore, once we have fully determined the differential structure for $t m f$, we can easily use naturality along

$$
\iota: S \longrightarrow t m f
$$

to determine the remaining Adams differentials for $S$ originating in the larger range $t-s \leq 48$. In particular, this leads to simple proofs of the differentials $d_{2}(v)=h_{0} z$, $d_{3}(r)=h_{1} d_{0}^{2}, d_{3}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=h_{0}^{5} r, d_{3}(z)=0, d_{3}\left(P h_{5} c_{0}\right)=0, d_{3}\left(h_{0}^{5} Q\right)=h_{0} P^{4} d_{0}$, $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}+h_{0}^{7} h_{5}\right)=P^{2} d_{0}, d_{4}\left(P d_{0} e_{0}\right)=P^{3} d_{0}, d_{4}\left(P^{2} d_{0} e_{0}\right)=P^{4} d_{0}, d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=d_{0} P d_{0}$, $d_{4}\left(h_{0} h_{2} h_{5}\right)=0, d_{4}\left(P h_{2} h_{5}\right)=0, d_{4}(N)=0$ and $d_{5}\left(f_{1}\right)=0$. We therefore also document this extended calculation. This leads to a complete description of the $E_{\infty}$-term for $t-s \leq 48$, and of the graded ring $\pi_{*}(S)$ for $* \leq 44$, in the theorems referred to above. We choose to stop at this point because our methods do not seem to simplify the determination of the group structure of $\pi_{45}(S)$, which is due to Tangora [166, p. 583].

We also study the Adams spectral sequence for the homotopy cofiber $\operatorname{tmf} / S$ of $\iota$, using the long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms

$$
\cdots \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \xrightarrow{\iota} \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(H^{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / S), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
$$

to obtain information about the $t m f$-Hurewicz homomorphism $\iota: \pi_{*}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f)$. In particular, we show $\iota(\{q\})=\epsilon_{1}$ in degree 32 and $\iota(\eta\{u\})=B \epsilon_{1}$ in degree 40 , both of which involve a shift in Adams filtration. Finally, we show in Theorem 11.89 that for $* \leq 101$ (and for $*=125$ ) the tmf-Hurewicz image of $\pi_{*}(S)$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ equals the sum of the well-known $k o$-Hurewicz image in $\pi_{*}(k o)$, the group $\pi_{3}(S) \cong \pi_{3}(t m f)$, and the self-dual part $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ of the $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$. According to Mark Behrens, Mahowald and J.D. Quigley [27] this remains true in all degrees.

# 0.10. Finite coefficients 

Having determined the differential structure in the Adams spectral sequences for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C 2, \operatorname{tmf} / \eta=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \eta$ and $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \nu$, it is relatively easy to determine the graded abelian group structure of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2), \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ and $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$, together with the action of $\eta, \nu, B$ and $M$ on these $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ modules. With a few exceptions, we accomplish this in Chapter 12. At this point it is also relatively easy to calculate $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / B)$ and $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} /(B, M))$, the latter being Anderson self-dual, and $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} /(2, B))$ and $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} /(2, B, M))$, where the latter is Brown-Comenetz self-dual. Here $\operatorname{tmf} /(2, B) \simeq \operatorname{tmf} \wedge M(1,4)$ and $\operatorname{tmf} /(2, B, M) \simeq \operatorname{tmf} \wedge M(1,4,32)$, where $M(1,4)$ and $M(1,4,32)$ are generalized Moore spectra of types 2 and 3, respectively. For these calculations it is convenient

to use two modifications of the classical Adams spectral sequence, which we review in Section 12.6. The first, which we call the delayed sequence, also plays a role in the analysis in Chapter 11 of Steenrod operations in the Adams spectral sequence for an $H_{\infty}$ ring spectrum. The second, which we call the hastened sequence, was used by Behrens, Hill, Hopkins and Mahowald [26] in their construction of the self-map $v_{2}^{32}: \Sigma^{192} M(1,4) \rightarrow M(1,4)$ needed to construct $M(1,4,32)$.

# 0.11. Odd primes 

We conclude Part III of this book with Chapter 13 on the case of odd primes, which essentially amounts to the case $p=3$.

Following their construction of the Lubin-Tate spectrum $E_{n}$ as an $A_{\infty}$ ring spectrum, with an action by the extended Morava stabilizer group $\mathbb{G}_{n}$, Hopkins and Miller (ca. 1990) first calculated the homotopy fixed point spectral sequence for $E O_{p-1}=E_{p-1}^{\mathrm{x} F}$, where $F$ is a maximal finite subgroup of $\mathbb{G}_{p-1}$. For $p=3$ there is an equivalence $E O_{2} \simeq L_{K(2)} T M F$, so the Hopkins-Miller calculation also amounts to the determination of the descent spectral sequence (and the AdamsNovikov spectral sequence) for $T M F$ at $p=3$. These calculations were reviewed by Goerss, Hans-Werner Henn, Mahowald and Charles Rezk in [64, §3], and by Lee Nave in $[\mathbf{1 3 7}, \S 2.2]$.

We instead calculate the mod 3 Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$, formed in the category of $t m f$-modules, following Baker-Lazarev [20] and Hill [68]. We use the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence from Chapter 2 to give a direct calculation of the Adams $E_{2}$-term, and use the $H_{\infty}$ ring structure to directly obtain the Adams differentials. We use the equivalence $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi \simeq \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)$ to determine the hidden $\nu$-extensions. Thereafter we determine the product structure on $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$, establish the Brown-Comenetz and Anderson duality theorems, and discuss the tmfHurewicz image. The introduction to Chapter 13 gives a more detailed overview.

# Part 1 

The Adams $E_{2}$-term

.

# CHAPTER 1 

## Minimal resolutions

The first author's computer program ext can calculate minimal resolutions and lift chain maps for finite modules, and for finitely presented modules, over the $\bmod 2$ Steenrod algebra $A$ and its subalgebra $A(2)$, in finite ranges of degrees.

### 1.1. The Adams $E_{2}$-term for $S$

The classical $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for the sphere spectrum $S$ is a strongly convergent algebra spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}(S)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(S)_{2}^{<}
$$

with $E_{2}$-term given by Ext over the Steenrod algebra $A$, and abutment the 2completed homotopy groups of spheres.

The $A$-module component of the program ext will calculate a minimal resolution

$$
\ldots \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{2} \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{1} \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{0} \xrightarrow{\epsilon} \mathbb{F}_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ by free $A$-modules $C_{s}$, in a finite range of filtration degrees $s \geq 0$ and internal degrees $t \geq 0$. As part of the calculation it will choose a basis $\left\{s_{g}^{*}\right\}_{g}$ for each $A$ module $C_{s}$, indexed by non-negative integers $g \geq 0$, in a well-defined deterministic order of non-decreasing internal degrees. By minimality the coboundaries in the induced cocomplex

$$
\ldots \stackrel{\delta}{\longleftrightarrow} \operatorname{Hom}_{A}\left(C_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \stackrel{\delta}{\longleftrightarrow} \operatorname{Hom}_{A}\left(C_{1}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \stackrel{\delta}{\longleftrightarrow} \operatorname{Hom}_{A}\left(C_{0}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \leftarrow 0
$$

are zero, so $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{A}\left(C_{s}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$.
Definition 1.1. For $s, g \geq 0$, let $s_{g} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{A}\left(C_{s}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ be the cocycle that is dual to the $g$ 'th generator $s_{g}^{*}$ of $C_{s}$, i.e., the homomorphism that takes the value 1 on $s_{g}^{*}$ and maps the other basis elements to 0 . The internal degree $t$ of $s_{g}$ is equal to the internal degree of the generator $s_{g}^{*}$.

The result of such a calculation for $s \leq 100$ and $t \leq 200$ is shown in Figures 1.1 to 1.8. The charts use Adams indexing, with the topological degree $t-s$ on the horizontal axis and the filtration degree $s$ on the vertical axis. The dot with label $g$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)$ corresponds to the generator $s_{g} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, and these give a basis for $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ as a bigraded $\mathbb{F}_{2}$-vector space, in this range of bidegrees.

A small part of the minimal resolution $\left(C_{*}, \partial\right)$, with $0 \leq s \leq 6$ and $0 \leq t \leq 22$, is shown in Table 1.2. Here we use the Milnor basis for $A$, with $S q^{\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{r}\right)}$ dual to $\xi_{1}^{i_{1}} \cdots \xi_{r}^{i_{r}}$ in the monomial basis for the dual Steenrod algebra, cf. Section 3.1.

Example 1.2. The class $0_{0}=1$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{0,0}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is the algebra unit. For each $i \geq 0$ the class $1_{i}=h_{i}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{1,2^{i}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is dual to the algebra indecomposable $S q^{2^{i}}$ in $A$. For each $s \geq 0$ the class $s_{0}=h_{0}^{s}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s, s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ detects $2^{s} \in \pi_{0}(S)_{2}^{<}=\mathbb{Z}_{2}$.

More precisely, it contains a list of the internal degrees of the free $A$-module generators $s_{0}^{*}, s_{1}^{*}, \ldots$ of $C_{s}$, together with expressions for the boundaries $\partial\left(s_{q}^{*}\right)$ in $C_{s-1}$, as linear combinations of the corresponding free $A$-module generators of $C_{s-1}$. The coefficients of these linear combinations lie in $A$, and are encoded in an efficient machine readable

In the resulting file hDiff.s the coefficients in $A$ are expressed in terms of the Milnor basis. Yoneda composition of $s^{\prime}$ - and $s^{\prime \prime}$-fold $A$-module extensions defines a pairing

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s^{\prime \prime}, t^{\prime \prime}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s^{\prime}+s^{\prime \prime}, t^{\prime}+t^{\prime \prime}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

taking $x \otimes y$ to $x y$. For varying $s^{\prime}, s^{\prime \prime}, t^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime \prime}$ these make $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ a bigraded commutative algebra over $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. The Hopf algebra structure on $A$ also leads to a tensor product of $A$-modules and an induced pairing of Ext-groups, which we have already noted coincides with the Yoneda pairing.

The program ext can extract the Yoneda product $h_{i} y$ from the structure of the minimal resolution, for each $i \geq 0$ and for any cocycle $y=s_{g}$. In Figures 1.1 to 1.8 the nonzero multiplications by $h_{0}$ are shown as solid vertical lines from $y$ to $h_{0} y$, the nonzero multiplications by $h_{1}$ are shown as solid lines of slope 1 from $y$ to $h_{1} y$, and the nonzero multiplications by $h_{2}$ are shown as dashed lines of slope $1 / 3$ from $y$ to $h_{2} y$. We omit to show the $h_{i}$-multiplications for $i \geq 3$, as they would make the charts too crowded to be legible.

More generally, ext can calculate the Yoneda product $x y$ of two cocycles $x=$ $s_{g^{\prime}}^{\prime}: C_{s^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ and $y=s_{g^{\prime \prime}}^{\prime \prime}: C_{s^{\prime \prime}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ by lifting $y$ to a chain map $\tilde{y}: C_{*+s^{\prime \prime}} \rightarrow C_{*}$, and then expressing the composite $x \circ \tilde{y}: C_{s^{\prime}+s^{\prime \prime}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ as a linear combination of cocycles $s_{g}$, with $s=s^{\prime}+s^{\prime \prime}$. It is thereby possible to determine the indecomposable quotient of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, within the machine calculated range.

REMARK 1.5. In Table 1.1, the $(t-s)$ - and $s$-columns give the Adams bigrading $(t-s, s)$ of the class $x$, while the $s$ - and $g$-columns specify the cocycles $s_{g}$ corresponding to $x$ in the representation of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ given by the minimal resolution chosen by ext. In later tables the class $x$ will sometimes correspond to a

![img-30.jpeg](img-30.jpeg)

Figure 1.10. Indecomposables in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ for $24 \leq t-s \leq 48$
sum $s_{g_{1}}+s_{g_{2}}$ of cocycles, in which case we will write " $g_{1}+g_{2}$ " in the $g$-column. The dec.-column lists any decomposable class in the same bidegree. The rows are lexicographically ordered by topological degree $t-s$, by filtration $s$, and by the generator index $g$. The $\iota(x)$-column gives the restriction to $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ as will be explained in Lemma 1.15. The $d_{2}(x)$-column gives the Adams $d_{2}$-differentials on these algebra generators, which will be established in Theorem 11.52.

The names in the $x$-column are those inherited from the May spectral sequence calculations of May and Tangora [165, App. 1]. In particular, the Adams periodicity operator $P$ is given by the Massey product $P x \in\left\langle h_{3}, h_{0}^{4}, x\right\rangle$ when $h_{0}^{4} x=0$, and $P^{2}$ is given by $P^{2} x \in\left\langle h_{4}, h_{0}^{8}, x\right\rangle$ when $h_{0}^{8} x=0$. The program ext can evaluate Massey products of the form $\left\langle h_{i}, x, y\right\rangle$, once the cocycle $y$ has been lifted.

We will adopt the indexing scheme from [165] and [45, Def. VI.1.8], where we set $a_{0}=a$ and $a_{i+1}=S q^{0}\left(a_{i}\right)$ for many classes $a$. Here $S q^{0}$ is a Steenrod operation acting on $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, which we discuss in Section 1.3 and Chapter 11. An exception to this scheme occurs for $a=g$, in which case $g_{0}$ refers to a May spectral sequence class that supports a differential, so that the classes in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ start with $g=g_{1}$.

Proof. We will make no formal use of this proposition, other than to introduce notation, and will therefore allow ourselves to assert that the claim can be verified by machine computation.

In more detail, the indecomposable quotient of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ can be calculated in a finite range as explained in Remarks 1.3 and 1.6. In most cases an indecomposable is the only nonzero class in its bidegree, and this lets us recognize its corresponding ext-cocycle directly from the minimal resolution. The remaining eight cases for $t-s \leq 48$ are $f_{0}, n, e_{1}, y, f_{1}, Q, P u$ and $B_{2}$. Six of these are defined modulo a single decomposable class, as indicated by the dec.-column in Table 1.1, while the remaining two indecomposable classes, $Q$ and $P u$, are both in the same bidegree.

We specify $n$ to be the nonzero class in its bidegree satisfying $h_{0} n=0$, i.e., the class of the ext-cocycle $5_{13}$. We specify $P u$ by the Massey product $P u=\left\langle h_{3}, h_{0}^{4}, u\right\rangle$, which is the class of the cocycle $13_{15}$, with zero indeterminacy. This class is then also characterized by the conditions $h_{0} P u=0$ and $h_{1} P u \neq 0$. In the same bidegree we specify $Q$ by the conditions $h_{0} Q \neq 0$ and $h_{1} Q \neq 0$, which means that $Q$ is the class of $13_{14}$. The third nonzero class in that bidegree is sometimes denoted $Q^{\prime}=Q+P u$. It is characterized by $h_{0} Q^{\prime} \neq 0$ and $h_{1} Q^{\prime}=0$, and is the class of $13_{14}+13_{15}$. These choices of classes $n, P u$ and $Q$ are compatible with those made in [165, App. 1].

The decomposable ambiguity in the remaining five generators has little effect on our calculations, and could be left unspecified. However, for definiteness we choose to use the results of $[\mathbf{4 6}]$ to pin down specific ext-representatives for all but one of these indecomposables, using the Steenrod operations $S q^{i}$ acting on $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. Hence, we set

$$
f_{0}=S q^{1}\left(c_{0}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad y=S q^{2}\left(f_{0}\right)
$$

as in [45, §VI.1], together with $e_{1}=S q^{0}\left(e_{0}\right)$ and $f_{1}=S q^{0}\left(f_{0}\right)$. Using direct cochain calculations, similar to the ones in the proof of Proposition 1.21, [46] show that with these choices $f_{0}$ is represented by the cocycle $4_{6}, e_{1}$ is represented by the cocycle $4_{16}, y$ is represented by the cocycle $6_{16}$, and $f_{1}$ is represented by the cocycle $4_{19}$.

The final indecomposable in this range of degrees is $B_{2}$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=$ $(48,7)$. With our methods we can only specify it modulo the decomposable $h_{0}^{2} h_{5} e_{0}=$ $7_{23}$, i.e., as $7_{22}$ or $7_{22}+7_{23}$. This is equivalent to setting $B_{2}=\left\langle h_{2}, h_{0}^{3}, g_{2}\right\rangle$, since this Massey product contains $7_{22}$ and has indeterminacy generated by $7_{23}$. For simplicity we will set $B_{2}$ to be the class of $7_{22}$, and indicate this uncertainty with a question-mark in the chart for $E_{2}(S)$. Note, however, that the indeterminacy in $B_{2}$ disappears at the $E_{3}$-term, due to an Adams differential $d_{2}\left(h_{5} f_{0}\right)=h_{0}^{2} h_{5} e_{0}$, and therefore has no visible consequence after this point.

\end{array}
$$

exhibit $3_{1}$ as $2_{0} \cdot 1_{2}=h_{0}^{2} \cdot h_{2}$, as $2_{1} \cdot 1_{1}=h_{1}^{2} \cdot h_{1}$, and as $2_{2} \cdot 1_{0}=h_{0} h_{2} \cdot h_{0}$. Each cocycle in filtration 2 is then seen to be decomposable, but in filtration 3 the cocycles $3_{3}, 3_{9}$ and $3_{19}$ are seen to be indecomposable. Return to A and use cocycle S 33 , cocycle S 39 and cocycle S 319 to create these cocycles, go to A/S and run dolifts 040 maps to lift them, and repeat.

REMARK 1.7. The classes $h_{i}$ and $P^{i} h_{1}$ are indecomposable for all $i \geq 0$, so the algebra $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is not finitely generated. This is in contrast to $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, which is finitely generated as an algebra.

# 1.2. The Adams $E_{2}$-term for $t m f$ 

The topological modular forms spectrum $t m f$ is an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum with $\bmod 2$ cohomology $H^{*}(t m f)=A / / A(2)=A \otimes_{A(2)} \mathbb{F}_{2}$, where $A(2)=\left\langle S q^{1}, S q^{2}, S q^{4}\right\rangle$ is the finite subalgebra of $A$ generated by the $S q^{2^{i}}$ for $i \leq 2$. The classical $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ is an algebra spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}(t m f)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s, t}\left(H^{*}(t m f), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(t m f)_{2}^{s}
$$

It is strongly convergent to the graded homotopy ring $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{2}^{s} \cong \pi_{*}(t m f) \otimes \mathbb{Z}_{2}$, because $t m f$ is connective and of finite type. The $E_{\infty}$ ring structure on $t m f$ makes $H^{*}(t m f)$ a cocommutative $A$-module coalgebra, which in turn induces the bigraded commutative algebra structure on $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(H^{*}(t m f), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. It is this algebra structure on the $E_{2}$-term that carries over to the subsequent $E_{r}$-terms and makes $E_{r}(t m f)$ an algebra spectral sequence.

The $A$-module coalgebra structure on $H^{*}(t m f)=A \otimes_{A(2)} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ is induced from the evident $A(2)$-module coalgebra structure on $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. The change-of-algebras isomorphism

$$
E_{2}(t m f)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(A \otimes_{A(2)} \mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

cf. Lemma 2.1, takes the algebra structure on the left hand side to the pairing on the right hand side that is induced by the tensor product of $A(2)$-modules. This is, in turn, equal to the Yoneda product in Ext over $A(2)$.

The $A(2)$-module component of the program ext will calculate a minimal free $A(2)$-module resolution

$$
\ldots \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{2} \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{1} \xrightarrow{\partial} C_{0} \xrightarrow{t} \mathbb{F}_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, in a finite range of filtration degrees $s \geq 0$ and internal degrees $t \geq 0$. As part of the calculation it will choose a basis $\left\{s_{g}^{*}\right\}_{g}$ indexed by non-negative integers $g \geq 0$ for each $A(2)$-module $C_{s}$. By minimality, $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{A(2)}\left(C_{s}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$.

Definition 1.8. For $s, g \geq 0$ let $s_{g} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{A(2)}^{t}\left(C_{s}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ be the cocycle that is dual to the $g^{\prime}$ th generator $s_{g}^{*}$ of $C_{s}$. Here $t$ is the internal degree of that generator.

Adams-indexed charts of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 192$ are shown in Figures 1.11 to 1.18. The dot with label $g$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)$ corresponds to the cocycle $s_{g} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. A small part of the minimal resolution $\left(C_{s}, \partial\right)$, with $0 \leq s \leq 6$ and $0 \leq t \leq 22$, is shown in Table 1.4.

REMARK 1.9. To make these calculations, go to the directory A2, and let tmf.def be a text file containing the numbers 10 . This defines the $A(2)$-module with a single $\mathbb{F}_{2}$-generator in internal degree 0 , necessarily with trivial action by each $S q^{i}$. Use newmodule tmf tmf.def to create the module subdirectory tmf. Go to this subdirectory, and run dims 0240 \& (taking a couple of minutes) to calculate the minimal resolution for $0 \leq s \leq 40$ and $0 \leq t \leq 240$. When dims is finished, use report to extract data from the calculation. Thereafter use
chart 016024 Shape himults Ext-A2-0-24.tex Ext-A2-F2 pdflatex Ext-A2-0-24.tex
to obtain the Adams chart in Figure 1.11. Then use
chart 4202448 Shape himults Ext-A2-24-48.tex Ext-A2-F2 pdflatex Ext-A2-24-48.tex

to obtain the Adams chart in Figure 1.12. Running the command seeres creates the file resolution, giving humanly readable formulas for the boundary operators $\partial: C_{s} \rightarrow C_{s-1}$, as shown in Table 1.4.

Example 1.10. The class $0_{0}=1$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{0,0}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is the algebra unit. For $0 \leq i \leq 2$ the class $1_{i}=h_{i}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{1,2^{i}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is dual to $S q^{2^{i}}$ in $A(2)$. For each $s \geq 0$ the class $s_{0}=h_{0}^{s}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ detects $2^{s} \in \pi_{0}(t m f)_{2}^{i s}=\mathbb{Z}_{2}$. The next algebra indecomposable in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is $3_{2}=c_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{3,11}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, in Adams bidegree $(t-s, s)=(8,3)$.

Remark 1.11. We use the same notation $s_{g}$ for ext-calculated cocycles in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ and in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, so it must be understood from the context whether we are working over $A$ or over $A(2)$. The unit map $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ induces a morphism of Adams spectral sequences that is given at the $E_{2}$-term by the restriction homomorphism

$$
\iota: \operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(A / / A(2), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

associated to the inclusion $A(2) \subset A$. This homomorphism takes $c_{0}=3_{3}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{3,11}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ to $c_{0}=3_{2}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{3,11}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. The homomorphism $\iota$ preserves the filtration degree $s$, but does typically not preserve the generator index $g$.

In more detail, the indecomposable quotient can be calculated in a finite range as explained in Remarks 1.9 and 1.13. Our notation for the 13 algebra generators $h_{0}, h_{1}, \ldots, \delta, w_{2}$ follows Henriques [54, Ch. 13]. Each but one of the indecomposables is characterized by being the only nonzero class in its bidegree. The exceptional case is $\delta$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(32,7)$, which also contains the decomposable class $\alpha g$. The third nonzero class in this bidegree, which we denote by $\delta^{\prime}=\delta+\alpha g$, is thus also indecomposable. The class $\delta$ is characterized by the conditions $h_{0} \delta \neq 0$ and $h_{1} \delta \neq 0$, while $\alpha g$ satisfies $h_{0} \alpha g=h_{0} \delta$ and $h_{1} \alpha g=0$, and $\delta^{\prime}$ satisfies $h_{0} \delta^{\prime}=0$ and $h_{1} \delta^{\prime}=h_{1} \delta$. As can be seen from Figure 1.12, this means that $\delta=7_{11}, \alpha g=7_{11}+7_{12}$ and $\delta^{\prime}=7_{12}$ in the basis chosen by ext.

Whenever it is defined, the Adams periodicity operator $P$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ corresponds under $\iota$ to multiplication by $w_{1}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$.

Proposition 1.14 (Adams). For $x \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ with $h_{0}^{4} x=0$,

$$
\iota(P x)=w_{1} \cdot \iota(x)
$$

More generally, for $i \geq 0$ and $h_{0}^{4 \cdot 2^{i}} x=0$,

$$
\iota\left(P^{2^{i}} x\right)=w_{1}^{2^{i}} \cdot \iota(x)
$$

Proof. The first claim is a special case of [7, Lem. 4.5]. Using the description of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ as the cohomology of the cobar complex $\left(C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right), \delta\right)$, see Section 2.3, the classes $h_{3}$ and $h_{0}^{4}$ are represented by the cocycles $\xi=\left[\xi_{1}^{8}\right]$ and $\eta=\left[\xi_{1}\left|\xi_{1}\right| \xi_{1} \mid \xi_{1}\right]$, respectively. Let $\zeta$ be a cobar cocycle representing $x$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)$. Since $h_{3} h_{0}^{4}=0$ and $h_{0}^{4} x=0$ we can write $\xi \eta=\delta(a)$ and $\eta \zeta=\delta(b)$, for cochains $a$ and $b$ in bidegrees $(8,4)$ and $(t-s+1, s+3)$, respectively. By definition, $P x=\left\langle h_{3}, h_{0}^{4}, x\right\rangle$ is the class of the cocycle $a \zeta+\xi b$ in bidegree $(t-s+8, s+4)$, with indeterminacy $h_{3} \operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{s+3, t+4}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. (The group $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}^{4,12}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is trivial.) The restriction homomorphism $\iota$ is induced by the projection $A_{*} \rightarrow A(2)_{*}$, sending $\xi_{1}^{8}$, $\xi$ and $h_{3}$ to 0 . Hence $a$ is sent to a cocycle, and Adams [7, Lem. 4.3] checks that this cocycle represents the nonzero class $w_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{4,12}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. Thus

$$
\iota(P x)=\iota([a \zeta+\xi b])=\iota([a]) \iota([\zeta])+0=w_{1} \iota(x)
$$

The cases $i \geq 1$ are similar, using [7, Lem. 4.4].

# 1.3. Steenrod operations in $E_{2}(t m f)$ 

There are Steenrod operations

$$
S q^{i}: \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s+i, 2 t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

acting on Ext over any cocommutative Hopf algebra $\Gamma$ defined over $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ (and similarly at odd primes), see $[\mathbf{9 5}$, Ch. 2] and $[\mathbf{1 1 8}, \S 11]$. Let $W_{*}$ be the standard free $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\Sigma_{2}\right]-$ resolution of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, with $W_{i}$ generated by $e_{i}$ for each $i \geq 0$, and let $C_{*}$ be a free $\Gamma$-module resolution of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. There is a unique homotopy class of $\Sigma_{2}$-equivariant maps of $\Gamma$-module complexes

$$
\Delta: W_{*} \otimes C_{*} \longrightarrow C_{*} \otimes C_{*}
$$

covering $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, where $\Sigma_{2}$ acts freely on $W_{*}$ on the left hand side and by the symmetry isomorphism on the right hand side, while $\Gamma$ acts freely on $C_{*}$ on the left hand side and by the diagonal action on the right hand side. For each cocycle $x: C_{s} \rightarrow \Sigma^{t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ the formula

$$
a \longmapsto\left\langle x \otimes x, \Delta\left(e_{i} \otimes a\right)\right\rangle
$$

where $\langle-,-\rangle$ denotes the (Kronecker) evaluation pairing, defines a cocycle $C_{2 s-i} \rightarrow$ $\Sigma^{2 t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$. By construction, its cohomology class is $S q^{s-i}(x) \in \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{2 s-i, 2 t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. These operations satisfy $S q^{s}(x)=x^{2}$, and $S q^{i}(x)=0$ if $i<0$ or $i>s$. Furthermore, the Cartan formula

$$
S q^{k}(x y)=\sum_{i+j=k} S q^{i}(x) S q^{j}(y)
$$

and the Adem relations

$$
S q^{a} S q^{b}=\sum_{i}\binom{b-i-1}{a-2 i} S q^{a+b-i} S q^{i}
$$

hold, where $a<2 b$. In particular, $S q^{0} S q^{i}=S q^{i} S q^{0}$ for each $i \geq 0$.
Definition 1.19. For $x \in \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ we let

$$
S q^{*}(x)=\left(x^{2}=S q^{s}(x), S q^{s-1}(x), \ldots, S q^{1}(x), S q^{0}(x)\right)
$$

be the total squaring operation on $x$.
When $\Gamma=A(2)$ we can completely determine the Steenrod operations in Ext. In contrast to the case $\Gamma=A$, there are only a few sequences $\left(h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}\right)$ and $\left(w_{1}, g\right)$ of generators connected by the $S q^{0}$-operations, and $w_{2} \neq S q^{0}\left(w_{1}\right)=g$ deviates from the indexing scheme mentioned in Remark 1.5.

Theorem 1.20. The Steenrod operations in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
S q^{*}\left(h_{0}\right) & =\left(h_{0}^{2}, h_{1}\right) \\
S q^{*}\left(h_{1}\right) & =\left(h_{1}^{2}, h_{2}\right) \\
S q^{*}\left(h_{2}\right) & =\left(h_{2}^{2}, 0\right) \\
S q^{*}\left(c_{0}\right) & =\left(0, h_{0} e_{0}, h_{2} \beta, 0\right) \\
S q^{*}(\alpha) & =\left(\alpha^{2}, \gamma, 0,0\right) \\
S q^{*}(\beta) & =\left(\beta^{2}, 0,0,0\right) \\

Proof. The products $S q^{s}(x)=x^{2}$ are calculated with ext, cf. Table 3.5. The operations landing in trivial groups are obviously zero. It is well-known that $S q^{0}\left(h_{i}\right)=h_{i+1}$ for each $i \geq 0$, see e.g. [3, p. 36] or [118, Def. 11.9]. This can also be verified directly for $i \in\{0,1\}$ by the method we use in Proposition 1.21 to calculate $S q^{*}\left(c_{0}\right)$. The remaining operations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
S q^{2}(\alpha) & \in \mathbb{F}_{2}\{\gamma\} \\
S q^{2}\left(d_{0}\right) & \in \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\beta^{2}\right\} \\
S q^{3}\left(d_{0}\right) & \in \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\alpha e_{0}\right\} \\
S q^{3}\left(e_{0}\right) & \in \mathbb{F}_{2}\{\beta g\} \\

S q^{5}(\delta) & \in \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{h_{2} \beta w_{2}\right\} \\

\end{aligned}
$$

As we now show, each of these can be determined by the Cartan formula and multiplicative relations that hold in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, cf. Tables 3.4 and 3.5:

Applying $S q^{3}$ to $h_{1} \alpha=0$ gives $h_{1}^{2} S q^{2}(\alpha)=h_{2} \alpha^{2}=h_{1}^{2} \gamma \neq 0$, so $S q^{2}(\alpha)=\gamma$.
Applying $S q^{3}$ to $h_{1} d_{0}=h_{0} h_{2} \alpha$ gives $h_{1}^{2} S q^{2}\left(d_{0}\right)=h_{2} S q^{3}\left(d_{0}\right)$. Here $h_{1}^{2} \beta^{2}=0$ and $h_{2} \alpha e_{0}=h_{0} \alpha g \neq 0$, so $S q^{3}\left(d_{0}\right)=0$.

Applying $S q^{5}$ to $h_{0} \gamma=0$ gives $h_{0}^{2} S q^{4}(\gamma)=h_{1}\left(\beta^{2} g+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2} \neq 0$, so $S q^{4}(\gamma)=h_{2} w_{2}$.

Applying $S q^{6}$ to the relation $\beta d_{0}=\alpha e_{0}$ gives $\alpha^{2} S q^{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=\gamma \cdot d_{0} g=d_{0} \gamma g \neq 0$, so $S q^{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=\beta g$.

Applying $S q^{5}$ to the same relation gives $\beta^{2} S q^{2}\left(d_{0}\right)=\gamma \cdot \beta g=g^{3} \neq 0$, so $S q^{2}\left(d_{0}\right)=\beta^{2}$.

Applying $S q^{4}$ to $d_{0}^{2}=g w_{1}$ gives $g^{2} S q^{0}\left(w_{1}\right)=\beta^{4}=g^{3} \neq 0$, so $S q^{0}\left(w_{1}\right)=g$.
Applying $S q^{5}$ to the relation $c_{0} \gamma=h_{1} \delta$ gives $h_{2} S q^{5}(\delta)=h_{2} \beta \cdot h_{2} w_{2}=h_{1} g w_{2} \neq$ 0 , so $S q^{5}(\delta)=h_{2} \beta w_{2}$.

Applying $S q^{6}$ to the same relation gives $h_{2} S q^{6}(\delta)=h_{0} e_{0} \cdot h_{2} w_{2}=h_{0}^{2} g w_{2} \neq 0$, using $h_{2} \beta \cdot\left(\beta^{2} g+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=0$ and $h_{1}^{2} \cdot h_{2} \beta w_{2}=0$. Hence $S q^{6}(\delta) \neq 0$.

Applying $S q^{8}$ to $\alpha \delta=0$ gives $\gamma S q^{6}(\delta)=0$, using $\alpha^{2} \cdot h_{2} \beta w_{2}=0$. Here $\gamma \cdot \gamma g^{2}=\beta^{2} g^{3} \neq 0$ and $\gamma \cdot h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}=0$, so $S q^{6}(\delta)=h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}$.

To calculate $S q^{i}\left(c_{0}\right)$ we use a method suggested by Christian Nassau [135]. It goes back to Steenrod's second definition [159] of the squaring operations in terms of $\cup_{i}$-pairings giving chain homotopies between $\cup_{i-1}$ and $\cup_{i-1} \tau$, where $\tau$ denotes the symmetry isomorphism.

Consider a cocycle $x: C_{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ that factors as $x=y f$, with $K_{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ a quasi-isomorphism, $f: C_{*} \rightarrow K_{*}$ a chain map over $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ and $y: K_{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ a cocycle.

Here $C_{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ is the free resolution considered above, while $K_{*}$ will typically not consist of free modules. To evaluate $x \otimes x$ on $\Delta\left(e_{i} \otimes a\right)$ for $a \in C_{2 s-i}$ we can instead evaluate $y \otimes y$ on $(f \otimes f) \Delta\left(e_{i} \otimes a\right)$ :
![img-41.jpeg](img-41.jpeg)

Any choice of $\Sigma_{2}$-equivariant chain map $D: W_{*} \otimes C_{*} \rightarrow K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$ covering $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ will make the left hand triangle commute up to chain homotopy, since $\Sigma_{2}$ acts freely on $W_{*}$ and $K_{*} \otimes K_{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ is a quasi-isomorphism.

Let $D_{i}: C_{*-i} \rightarrow K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$ be given by $D_{i}(a)=D\left(e_{i} \otimes a\right)$, for each $i \geq 0$. Then $D_{0}: C_{*} \rightarrow K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$ is a chain map over $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, and $(y \otimes y) D_{0}: C_{2 s} \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ represents $x^{2}=S q^{s}(x)$. Next, $D_{1}: C_{*-1} \rightarrow K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$ is a chain homotopy from $D_{0}$ to $\tau D_{0}$, in the sense that $\partial D_{1}+D_{1} \partial=D_{0}+\tau D_{0}$, and $(y \otimes y) D_{1}: C_{2 s-1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ represents $\cup_{1}(x)=S q^{s-1}(x)$. Continuing, $D_{2}: C_{*-2} \rightarrow K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$ is a chain homotopy from $D_{1}$ to $\tau D_{1}$, in the sense that $\partial D_{2}+D_{2} \partial=D_{1}+\tau D_{1}$, and $(y \otimes y) D_{2}: C_{2 s-2} \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ represents $\cup_{2}(x)=S q^{s-2}(x)$. In general, $(y \otimes y) D_{i}$ gives $S q^{s-i}(x)$ for all $i \geq 0$.

Conversely, a diagonal approximation $D_{0}$ and a sequence of chain homotopies $D_{i}$ from $D_{i-1}$ to $\tau D_{i-1}$, for each $i \geq 1$, correspond precisely to a $\Sigma_{2}$-equivariant chain map $D$ as above. This process gives all the squaring operations on any cocycle $x$ for which we can write down a corresponding $s$-fold extension $K_{*}$. The computational efficacy of this process depends upon the size of the complex $K_{*} \otimes K_{*}$.

For later reference we record the following compatibility between the change-of-algebra isomorphism recalled in Lemma 2.1 and these Steenrod operations.

Lemma 1.22. Let $\Lambda \subset \Gamma$ be a pair of cocommutative Hopf algebras, and let $L$ be a cocommutative $\Lambda$-module coalgebra. Under the change-of-algebra isomorphisms

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s, t}\left(L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

the Steenrod operation $S q^{i}: \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s+i, 2 t}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ corresponds to the Steenrod operation $S q^{i}: \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s, t}\left(L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s+i, 2 t}\left(L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$.

Proof. Let $C_{*} \rightarrow L$ be a free $\Lambda$-module resolution. Then $F_{*}=\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*} \rightarrow$ $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L$ is a free $\Gamma$-module resolution. Let $\Delta: W_{*} \otimes C_{*} \rightarrow C_{*} \otimes C_{*}$ be a $\Sigma_{2^{-}}$ equivariant map of $\Lambda$-module complexes that lifts the coproduct $\psi: L \rightarrow L \otimes L$. Then the composite

$$
W_{*} \otimes \Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*} \xrightarrow{1 \otimes \Delta} \Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda}\left(C_{*} \otimes C_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\psi \otimes 1}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*}\right) \otimes\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*}\right)
$$

(with some twist isomorphisms suppressed) is a $\Sigma_{2}$-equivariant map $W_{*} \otimes F_{*} \rightarrow$ $F_{*} \otimes F_{*}$ of $\Gamma$-module complexes that lifts the coproduct $\psi: \Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L \rightarrow\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L\right) \otimes$ $\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L\right)$. A chase of definitions then shows that $S q^{s-i}$ applied to the $\Gamma$-module

extension of any $\Lambda$-linear cocycle $x: C_{s} \rightarrow \Sigma^{t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ equals the $\Gamma$-module extension of $S q^{s-i}(x): C_{2 s-i} \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 t} \mathbb{F}_{2}$.

# 1.4. The Adams $E_{2}$-term for $t m f / 2, t m f / \eta$ and $t m f / \nu$ 

Definition 1.23. Let

$$
\begin{aligned}

& C \eta=S / \eta=S \cup_{\eta} e^{2} \\
& C \nu=S / \nu=S \cup_{\nu} e^{4} \\
& C \sigma=S / \sigma=S \cup_{\sigma} e^{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

be the homotopy cofibers of the real Hopf map (degree two map) 2: $S \rightarrow S$, the complex Hopf map $\eta: S^{1} \rightarrow S$, the quaternionic Hopf map $\nu: S^{3} \rightarrow S$ and the octonionic Hopf map $\sigma: S^{7} \rightarrow S$. Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{tmf} / 2=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C 2 \\
& \operatorname{tmf} / \eta=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \eta \\
& \operatorname{tmf} / \nu=\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \nu
\end{aligned}
$$

We need not discuss the octonionic case, since $\sigma$ acts trivially on $t m f$ and $t m f / \sigma=$ $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \sigma \simeq \operatorname{tmf} \vee \Sigma^{8} t m f$. The defining homotopy cofiber sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S \xrightarrow{2} S \xrightarrow{i} C 2 \xrightarrow{j} S^{1} \\
& S^{1} \xrightarrow{\eta} S \xrightarrow{i} C \eta \xrightarrow{j} S^{2} \\
& S^{3} \xrightarrow{\nu} S \xrightarrow{i} C \nu \xrightarrow{j} S^{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

of spectra induce homotopy cofiber sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{2} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{i} \operatorname{tmf} / 2 \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma \operatorname{tmf} \\
& \Sigma \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{\eta} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{i} \operatorname{tmf} / \eta \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{2} \operatorname{tmf} \\
& \Sigma^{3} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{\nu} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{i} \operatorname{tmf} / \nu \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{4} \operatorname{tmf}
\end{aligned}
$$

of $t m f$-modules. Let $M_{1}=H^{*}(C 2)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, S q^{1}\right\}, M_{2}=H^{*}(C \eta)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, S q^{2}\right\}$ and $M_{4}=H^{*}(C \nu)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, S q^{4}\right\}$.

REMARK 1.24. We follow [52, Def. 2.5], writing $M_{i}$ for a minimal $A(2)$-module with nontrivial action by $S q^{i}$ from degree 0 to degree $i$.

Lemma 1.25. There are $A$-module isomorphisms

$$
\begin{aligned}

The Adams spectral sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}

for $t m f / 2, t m f / \eta$ and $t m f / \nu$, respectively, are all strongly convergent module spectral sequences over the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$. By change-of-algebras, the $E_{2}$-terms can be rewritten as

In each case the action by $E_{2}(t m f) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is induced by the tensor product of $A(2)$-modules, and agrees with the Yoneda product.

Lemma 1.36. The spectra tmf/2 and $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta$ are not ring spectra (in the stable homotopy category).

Proof. If $t m f / 2$ were a ring spectrum, then its Adams $E_{2}$-term would be a bigraded algebra over $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, with unit $i(1)$. Since $h_{0} \cdot i(1)=0$, it would follow that $h_{0} \cdot x=0$ for all $x \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{1}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. This is not the case, e.g. for $x=1_{1}=\overline{h_{1}}$, as can be seen in Figure 1.24.

Likewise, if $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta$ were a ring spectrum, then its Adams $E_{2}$-term would be a bigraded algebra. Since $h_{1} \cdot i(1)=0$, it would follow that $h_{1} \cdot x=0$ for all $x \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. This is not the case, e.g. for $x=1_{1}=\overline{h_{0}}$, as can be seen in Figure 1.28.

To discuss $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$, we let $A_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\xi_{i} \mid i \geq 1\right]$ denote the dual Steenrod algebra, reviewed in more detail in Section 3.1, and recall the following construction of sub Hopf algebras of the Steenrod algebra.

Proposition 1.37 (Adams-Margolis). For each profile function

$$
h:\{1,2,3, \ldots\} \rightarrow\{0,1,2, \ldots, \infty\}
$$

let

$$
B(h)_{*}=A_{*} /\left(\xi_{i}^{2^{h(i)}} \mid i \geq 1\right)
$$

be a quotient algebra of $A_{*}$, and let $B(h) \subset A$ be the dual coalgebra. Suppose that $h$ satisfies the condition

- $h(i) \leq j+h(i+j)$ or $h(j) \leq h(i+j)$, for all $i, j \geq 1$.

Then $B(h)_{*}$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $A_{*}$ and $B(h)$ is a sub Hopf algebra of $A$. Conversely, all quotient Hopf algebras of $A_{*}$ and sub Hopf algebras of $A$ arise in this manner.

Proof. See [12, Prop. 2.3, Thm. 2.4] or [112, Thm. 15.6].
Example 1.38. The Hopf algebra

$$
A(n)=\left\langle S q^{1}, S q^{2}, \ldots, S q^{2^{n}}\right\rangle
$$

corresponds to the function given by $h(i)=n+2-i$ for $1 \leq i \leq n+1$ and $h(i)=0$ for $i \geq n+2$. It is the minimal sub Hopf algebra of $A$ that contains $S q^{2^{n}}$.

The sub Hopf algebra $B(2,2,1)$ of $A(2)$, corresponding to the function $h(1)=$ $h(2)=2, h(3)=1$ and $h(i)=0$ for $i \geq 4$, is generated by $S q^{1}, S q^{2}$ and $S q^{(0,2)}$.

Lemma 1.39. There is an isomorphism $A(2) / / B(2,2,1) \cong M_{4}$ of $A(2)$-module coalgebras. Hence there is an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{4}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{B(2,2,1)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

of bigraded algebras.
Proof. This follows by dualization from the $A(2)_{*}$-comodule algebra isomorphism

$$
E\left(\xi_{1}^{4}\right) \cong A(2)_{*} \square_{B(2,2,1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}
$$

where $\square$ denotes the cotensor product. See Section 2.2 for a more detailed review of that construction.

Lemma 1.40 (Oka). The spectrum tmf/ $\nu$ is not a ring spectrum.
Proof. Shichirô Oka proved [139, Lem. 1.2] that the primary obstruction to extending the module action $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \operatorname{tmf} / \nu \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ over the unit map $i \wedge 1: \operatorname{tmf} \wedge$ $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf} / \nu \wedge \operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ is $2 \nu$, which is nonzero in $\pi_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$.

Alternatively, note that by the previous lemma the argument of Lemma 1.36 does not apply for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$, since the Adams $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ admits an algebra structure (over $\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ and over $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ ). However, we will see in Section 8.2 that the Adams $d_{2}$-differential does not satisfy the Leibniz rule. More specifically,

$$
d_{2}(\bar{g} \cdot \bar{g})=d_{2}\left(i\left(w_{2}\right)\right)=i(\alpha \beta g)=g^{2} \cdot \overline{h_{0} h_{2}} \neq 0
$$

(where $\bar{g} \cdot \bar{g}=i\left(w_{2}\right)$ can be verified using ext) while

$$
d_{2}(\bar{g}) \cdot \bar{g}+\bar{g} \cdot d_{2}(\bar{g})=0 \cdot \bar{g}+\bar{g} \cdot 0=0
$$

In view of Lemmas 1.36 and 1.40 it may be surprising that the $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $\operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3) \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle$ can take the form $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi$ for a finite cell spectrum $\Phi$. Here $H^{*}(\Phi)$ realizes $A(2) / / E(2)$, after restricting the natural $A$-action to $A(2)$, so that $H^{*}(\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi)=A / / A(2) \otimes A(2) / / E(2) \cong A \otimes_{A(2)} A(2) / / E(2) \cong A / / E(2)=$ $H^{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$. The $A(2)$-module $A(2) / / E(2)$ is also known as "the double of $A(1)$ ", where $A(1)=\left\langle S q^{1}, S q^{2}\right\rangle \subset A$ is the subalgebra generated by $S q^{1}$ and $S q^{2}$. The latter has rank 8 and is concentrated in degrees $0 \leq * \leq 6$. After doubling all degrees, the resulting cyclic $A(2)$-module is concentrated in even degrees $0 \leq * \leq 12$, subject to the relations that the odd-degree generators $Q_{0}=S q^{1}, Q_{1}=S q^{(0,1)}$ and $Q_{2}=S q^{(0,0,1)}$ act trivially. In other words, it is isomorphic to $A(2) / / E(2)$.
![img-43.jpeg](img-43.jpeg)

The figure above shows the generating actions by $S q^{2}$ and $S q^{4}$, and is identical to the picture for the generating actions by $S q^{1}$ and $S q^{2}$ in $A(1)$, except that the degrees have been doubled.

Remark 1.41. It is elementary to check from the Adem relations that there are precisely four $A$-module structures on $A(2) / / E(2)$ that extend the given $A(2)$ module structure, corresponding to the four possible pairs of values of $S q^{8}$ acting on the generators 1 and $S q^{4}$ in degrees 0 and 4 , respectively. In each case, $S q^{8}$ acts nontrivially on the generator $S q^{2}$ in degree 2. Up to the evident degree shift, the two $A$-module structures where exactly one of $S q^{8}(1)$ and $S q^{8}\left(S q^{4}\right)$ is nonzero are both self-dual, whereas the remaining two $A$-module structures are mutually dual. A direct cell-by-cell construction of 8 -cell CW spectra realizing each of these four $A$-modules is possible, using ext to analyze the available attaching maps, and reveals that in each case some essential ambiguity remains in how the 10 - and 12 cells are attached. We instead give the following less computational proof, which has the advantage of producing a self-dual model.

Lemma 1.42 ([76, Lem. 6.1], [114, Def. 4.2]). There exist finite $C W$ spectra $\Phi=\Phi A(1)$ with cohomology $H^{*}(\Phi) \cong A(2) / / E(2)$ realizing the double of $A(1)$. At least one such spectrum is Spanier-Whitehead self-dual, in the sense that there is a 2-adic equivalence $\Phi \simeq F\left(\Phi, S^{12}\right)$, and of the form $C \gamma$, meaning that there is a homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\Sigma^{5} C \eta \wedge C \nu \xrightarrow{\gamma} C \eta \wedge C \nu \xrightarrow{i} \Phi \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{6} C \eta \wedge C \nu
$$

(after implicit 2-completion) where $\gamma$ has Adams filtration 1.
Proof. Let $\tilde{\nu}: S^{5} \rightarrow C \eta$ be the unique lift (up to homotopy) over $j: C \eta \rightarrow S^{2}$ of $\nu: S^{5} \rightarrow S^{2}$. Its mapping cone $\Phi Q=C \eta \cup_{\tilde{\nu}} e^{6}$ is a finite CW spectrum, with cohomology $H^{*}\left(C \eta \cup_{\tilde{\nu}} e^{6}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, S q^{2}, S q^{4} S q^{2}\right\}=M_{42}$, the minimal $A(2)$-module

containing a generator in degree 0 with nontrivial action by $S q^{4} S q^{2}$. Its SpanierWhitehead 6 -dual $F\left(\Phi Q, S^{6}\right)=F\left(C \eta \cup_{\tilde{\nu}} e^{6}, S^{6}\right) \simeq C \nu \cup_{\tilde{\eta}} e^{6}$ is the mapping cone of the unique lift $\tilde{\eta}: S^{5} \rightarrow C \nu$ over $j: C \nu \rightarrow S^{4}$ of $\eta: S^{5} \rightarrow S^{4}$. Its cohomology $H^{*}\left(C \nu \cup_{\tilde{\eta}} e^{6}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, S q^{4}, S q^{2} S q^{4}\right\}=M_{24}$ is minimal with nontrivial action by $S q^{2} S q^{4}$.

The evaluation map $e: F\left(\Phi Q, S^{6}\right) \wedge \Phi Q \rightarrow S^{6}$ induces

$$
e^{*}: \Sigma^{6} \mathbb{F}_{2} \longrightarrow M_{24} \otimes M_{42}
$$

in cohomology, sending the generator to $S q^{2} S q^{4} \otimes 1+S q^{4} \otimes S q^{2}+1 \otimes S q^{4} S q^{2}$. Its Spanier-Whitehead 12-dual $c=F\left(e, S^{12}\right)$ is a coevaluation map $c: S^{6} \rightarrow \Phi Q \wedge$ $F\left(\Phi Q, S^{6}\right)$ inducing

$$
c^{*}: M_{42} \otimes M_{24} \longrightarrow \Sigma^{6} \mathbb{F}_{2}
$$

in cohomology, sending $S q^{4} S q^{2} \otimes 1, S q^{2} \otimes S q^{4}$ and $1 \otimes S q^{2} S q^{4}$ to the generator. The composite $e \circ \tau \circ c: S^{6} \rightarrow S^{6}$, where $\tau$ is the twist equivalence, has degree 3, equal to the Euler characteristic of $\Phi Q$, hence is a 2 -local equivalence. In particular, $c$ is 2-locally split injective. Direct calculation with the Cartan formula shows that the direct summand $\operatorname{ker}\left(c^{*}\right) \subset M_{42} \otimes M_{24}$ is isomorphic to $A(2) / / E(2)$ as an $A(2)$ module. Furthermore, $S q^{8}$ acts nontrivially on the generator $1 \otimes 1$ in degree 0 , but trivially on the generator $1 \otimes S q^{4}$ in degree 4 . Hence we can let $\Phi$ be the mapping cone of the coevaluation map $c$, and obtain a 2-locally split homotopy cofiber sequence as in the upper row of the following diagram.
![img-44.jpeg](img-44.jpeg)

Here the homotopy fiber map $f=F\left(d, S^{12}\right)$ of $e$ is 12 -dual to $d$, so the lower row is also a 2-locally split homotopy (co-)fiber sequence. The composite $d \circ \tau \circ f$ exhibits a 2 -local equivalence $F\left(\Phi, S^{12}\right) \simeq \Phi$.

Let $i$ be the composite map

$$
C \eta \wedge C \nu \longrightarrow\left(C \eta \cup_{\tilde{\nu}} e^{6}\right) \wedge\left(C \nu \cup_{\tilde{\eta}} e^{6}\right) \simeq \Phi Q \wedge F\left(\Phi Q, S^{6}\right) \xrightarrow{d} \Phi
$$

where the first map is the smash product of the two evident inclusions. The induced homomorphism

$$
i^{*}: A(2) / / E(2) \longrightarrow M_{2} \otimes M_{4}
$$

is surjective, with kernel isomorphic to $\Sigma^{6} M_{2} \otimes M_{4}$ and generated by the commutator $\left[S q^{4}, S q^{2}\right]=S q^{(0,2)}$. Hence the mapping cone of $i$ has $\bmod 2$ cohomology isomorphic to that of $\Sigma^{6} C \eta \wedge C \nu$, as a left $A(2)$-module. This characterizes this spectrum up to 2-adic equivalence, and yields the stated homotopy cofiber sequence. The connecting map $\gamma$ must have Adams filtration exactly 1, since

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{6} M_{2} \otimes M_{4} \xrightarrow{j^{*}} A(2) / / E(2) \xrightarrow{i^{*}} M_{2} \otimes M_{4} \rightarrow 0
$$

is short exact, but not split as an extension of $A(2)$-modules.
REMARK 1.43. The finite CW spectra $\Phi Q$ and $F\left(\Phi Q, S^{6}\right)$ are doubles of $Q=$ $C 2 \cup_{\tilde{\eta}} e^{3}$ and $F\left(Q, S^{3}\right)=C \eta \cup_{\tilde{\tilde{\eta}}} e^{3}$, usually known as the question mark and inverted

question mark complexes, respectively.
![img-45.jpeg](img-45.jpeg)

The proof of the lemma above is effectively a double of the construction given in [73, Cor. 1.7.7] of a spectrum realizing $A(1)$. A different proof can be given by doubling the construction given on pages 619-620 of [51, Thm. 1.4(i)].

Proposition 1.44 ([76, Thm. 4.3]). Let $\Phi$ be any finite $C W$ spectrum realizing $A(2) / / E(2)$. There is a 2 -adic equivalence of tmf-modules

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle
$$

extending the $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum map $\iota^{\prime}: \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow B P\langle 2\rangle$. Hence there is also a 2-adic equivalence of tmf-modules

$$
F(\Phi, \operatorname{tmf}) \simeq \Sigma^{-12} B P\langle 2\rangle
$$

Proof. Without loss of generality, we can build $\Phi$ from $S$ by attaching evendimensional cells. Since $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$ is trivial in odd degrees, there is no obstruction to extending the unit map $S \rightarrow B P\langle 2\rangle$ over $\Phi$. Any such extension $\Phi \rightarrow B P\langle 2\rangle$ then induces a $t m f$-module map

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi \longrightarrow \operatorname{tmf} \wedge B P\langle 2\rangle \xrightarrow{\sim} B P\langle 2\rangle
$$

that extends $\iota^{\prime}$. The induced $A$-module homomorphism

$$
A / / E(2) \longrightarrow A / / A(2) \otimes A(2) / / E(2) \cong A / / E(2)
$$

is the identity in degree 0 , hence is an isomorphism. Thus $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi \rightarrow B P\langle 2\rangle$ is a 2 -adic equivalence.

For the dual statement, we use that the Spanier-Whitehead dual $D \Phi=F(\Phi, S)$ is equivalent to a finite CW spectrum, with

$$
H^{*}(D \Phi) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(H^{*}(\Phi), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \Sigma^{-12} A(2) / / E(2)
$$

as an $A(2)$-module, so that the previous argument applies to $\Sigma^{12} D \Phi \simeq F\left(\Phi, S^{12}\right)$.
