# CHAPTER 2 

## The Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence

Davis and Mahowald [52] introduced a spectral sequence to calculate Ext for an $A(n)$-module $M$, in terms of Ext for a sequence of $A(n-1)$-modules $N_{\sigma} \otimes M$ indexed by weights $\sigma \geq 0$. The same spectral sequence was studied by Mahowald and Shick [106], who called it the Koszul spectral sequence. We generalize their work to the case of a pair $\Lambda \subset \Gamma$ of Hopf algebras, and clarify the origin of the multiplicative structure in the spectral sequence in the cocommutative case. Propositions 2.3 and 2.10 give additive forms of the spectral sequences calculating Ext in the categories of $\Gamma$-modules and $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules, respectively, while Theorems 2.25 and 2.24 give multiplicative forms of these spectral sequences.

### 2.1. Ext over a pair of Hopf algebras

Let $k$ be a field, and write $\otimes$ and Hom for $\otimes_{k}$ and $\operatorname{Hom}_{k}$, respectively. Let $\Gamma$ be a connected Hopf algebra over $k$, and let $\Lambda$ be a sub Hopf algebra of $\Gamma$. We follow the convention that a Hopf algebra comes equipped with a conjugation $\chi$ as part of the structure. By Milnor-Moore [128, Thm. 4.4], $\Gamma$ is free as a right $\Lambda$-module, i.e., it is isomorphic to a direct sum of suspensions of copies of $\Lambda$. Let $L$ be a left $\Lambda$-module, and give $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L$ the induced left $\Gamma$-module structure.

Lemma 2.1. There is a natural change-of-algebra isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L, k\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}(L, k)
$$

Proof. Let $C_{*} \rightarrow L$ be a free $\Lambda$-module resolution of $L$. Then $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*} \rightarrow$ $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L$ is a free $\Gamma$-module resolution of $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} L$. Hence the natural isomorphism $\operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma}\left(\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} C_{*}, k\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\Lambda}\left(C_{*}, k\right)$ of cochain complexes induces the asserted change-of-algebra isomorphism upon passage to cohomology.

Let $\Gamma / / \Lambda=\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} k$. Let $M$ be a left $\Gamma$-module, give $\Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes M$ the diagonal $\Gamma$-module structure, and give $\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} M$ the $\Gamma$-module structure induced up from the restricted $\Lambda$-module structure on $M$.

Lemma 2.2 ([14, Cor. 3.5]). There is a natural untwisting isomorphism of $\Gamma$ modules

$$
\zeta: \Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} M \xrightarrow{\cong} \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes M
$$

induced by the composite

$$
\Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{\psi \otimes 1} \Gamma \otimes \Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{\pi \otimes \lambda} \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes M
$$

Here $\psi: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma \otimes \Gamma$ denotes the coproduct, $\pi: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma / / \Lambda$ denotes the projection, and $\lambda: \Gamma \otimes M \rightarrow M$ denotes the left module action.

Proof. The homomorphism $\zeta$ is well defined because $\Lambda$ is a sub Hopf algebra of $\Gamma$. An inverse is induced by the composite

$$
\Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{\psi \otimes 1} \Gamma \otimes \Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{1 \otimes \chi \otimes 1} \Gamma \otimes \Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{1 \otimes \lambda} \Gamma \otimes M \xrightarrow{\pi} \Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} M
$$

where $\chi: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma$ is the conjugation.
Proposition 2.3. Suppose that we have chosen a sequence of $\Gamma$-modules $N_{\sigma}$, for $\sigma \geq 0$, and an exact chain complex

$$
\ldots \xrightarrow{\partial_{3}} \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{2} \xrightarrow{\partial_{2}} \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{1} \xrightarrow{\partial_{1}} \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{0} \xrightarrow{\epsilon} k \rightarrow 0
$$

of $\Gamma$-modules with diagonal $\Gamma$-action. Then there is a strongly convergent trigraded spectral sequence

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k)
$$

The $d_{r}$-differentials have $(\sigma, s, t)$-tridegree $(r, 1,0)$ and there are isomorphisms

$$
E_{\infty}^{\sigma, s, t} \cong F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M) / F^{\sigma+1} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M)
$$

for all $\sigma$, $s$ and $t$, where $\left\{F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M)\right\}_{\sigma}$ is a finite and exhaustive filtration of $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k)$.

Proof. For each $\sigma \geq 0$ we have a short exact sequence of $\Gamma$-modules

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma+1}\right) \otimes M \longrightarrow \Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{\sigma} \otimes M \longrightarrow \operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma}\right) \otimes M \rightarrow 0
$$

where we interpret $\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{0}\right)$ as $\operatorname{im}(\epsilon)=k$. These induce long exact sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \ldots \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma}\right) \otimes M, k\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma+1}\right) \otimes M, k\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s+1, t}\left(\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma}\right) \otimes M, k\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $\sigma \geq 0$. Rewriting $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}\left(\Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right)$ as $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right)$ by means of the isomorphisms of Lemmas 2.1 and 2.2, we can combine these into the following unrolled exact couple:

Here

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma}\right) \otimes M, k\right) \\
& E^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The homomorphisms $i=\delta: A^{\sigma+1, s, t} \rightarrow A^{\sigma, s, t}$ and $j: A^{\sigma, s, t} \rightarrow E^{\sigma, s, t}$ preserve the $(s, t)$-bigrading, whereas $k: E^{\sigma, s, t} \rightarrow A^{\sigma+1, s+1, t}$ has $(s, t)$-bidegree $(1,0)$ and $(t-s, s)$-bidegree $(-1,1)$. The resulting trigraded spectral sequence has $E_{1}$-term

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right)
$$

and $d_{r}$-differentials

$$
d_{r}: E_{r}^{\sigma, s, t} \longrightarrow E_{r}^{\sigma+r, s+1, t}
$$

of $(s, t)$-bidegree $(1,0)$ and $(t-s, s)$-bidegree $(-1,1)$, for each $r \geq 1$. Neglecting the internal degree $t$, the spectral sequence can be considered as a first quadrant

cohomological spectral sequence in the $(\sigma, s-\sigma)$-plane. In this grading the $d_{r^{-}}$ differential has the traditional bidegree $(r, 1-r)$.

It follows that the spectral sequence converges strongly to $A^{0, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k)$, which is filtered by the images $F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M)=\operatorname{im}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right)$ of the iterated coboundary homomorphisms

$$
\delta^{\sigma}: \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\operatorname{im}\left(\partial_{\sigma}\right) \otimes M, k\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k)
$$

This is a finite filtration in each $(s, t)$-bidegree, since $F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}(M)=0$ for all $\sigma>s$.

# 2.2. A dual formulation 

To make use of the multiplicative structure present in our main examples, it will be convenient to pass from the categories of $\Gamma$ - and $\Lambda$-modules to the dual categories of $\Gamma_{*}$ - and $\Lambda_{*}$-comodules, respectively.

Definition 2.4. Let $\Gamma_{*}$ be a connected coalgebra over $k$. Given a right $\Gamma_{*^{-}}$ comodule $M_{*}$ and a left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $N_{*}$, the cotensor product $M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*}$ is the graded $k$-vector space defined [128, Def. 2.2] as the equalizer of the two homomorphisms

$$
M_{*} \otimes N_{*} \underset{1 \otimes \nu}{\stackrel{\nu \otimes 1}{\longrightarrow}} M_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}
$$

induced by the right $\Gamma_{*}$-coaction $\nu: M_{*} \rightarrow M_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}$ and the left $\Gamma_{*}$-coaction $\nu: N_{*} \rightarrow$ $\Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}$, respectively. Given a second left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $L_{*}$, the graded $k$-vector space of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule homomorphisms $\operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is the equalizer of the two homomorphisms

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right) \underset{\nu_{*}}{\stackrel{\nu^{*}}{\longrightarrow}} \operatorname{Hom}\left(L_{*}, \Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}\right)
$$

induced by the left $\Gamma_{*}$-coactions $\nu: L_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes L_{*}$ and $\nu: N_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}$, respectively. When $M_{*}=k=L_{*}$, the two diagrams above specialize to the diagram

$$
N_{*} \xrightarrow[\nu]{\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}} \Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}
$$

with equalizer the graded $k$-vector space of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule primitives

$$
P_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(N_{*}\right)=\left\{x \in N_{*} \mid \nu(x)=1 \otimes x\right\}
$$

in $N_{*}$. Hence there are identifications

$$
k \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*} \cong P_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(N_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, N_{*}\right)
$$

Definition 2.5. The forgetful functor from left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules to graded $k$ vector spaces has a right adjoint, mapping a vector space $V$ to the extended comodule $\Gamma_{*} \otimes V$, with coaction induced by the coproduct $\psi: \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}$. By definition [57, §3], a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule is said to be injective if it is a direct summand of an extended $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule. Each left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $N_{*}$ admits an injective left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule resolution

$$
0 \rightarrow N_{*} \longrightarrow X_{*}^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta} X_{*}^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta} \ldots
$$

i.e., an exact complex where each $X_{*}^{s}$ is injective. By definition, $\operatorname{Cotor}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is the cohomology of the induced complex

$$
\ldots \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} X_{*}^{s-1} \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} X_{*}^{s} \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} X_{*}^{s+1} \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} \ldots
$$

and $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is the cohomology of the induced complex

$$
\ldots \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, X_{*}^{s-1}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, X_{*}^{s}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, X_{*}^{s+1}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta_{*}} \ldots
$$

In particular, there are canonical isomorphisms $\operatorname{Cotor}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{0}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong L_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*}$, $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{0}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right)$, and

$$
\operatorname{Cotor}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(k, N_{*}\right)
$$

for each $s \geq 0$.
The coalgebra $\Gamma_{*}$ gives rise to a dual algebra $\Gamma=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right)$, with multiplication $\phi$ given by the composite

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right) \otimes \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right) \xrightarrow{\otimes} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}, k\right) \xrightarrow{\phi^{*}} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right)
$$

If $\Gamma$ is bounded below (e.g., connected) and of finite type as a graded $k$-vector space, we can recover $\Gamma_{*}$ as the dual $\operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k)$, with coproduct given by the composite

$$
\operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k) \xrightarrow{\phi^{*}} \operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma \otimes \Gamma, k) \stackrel{\cong}{\leftarrow} \operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k) \otimes \operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k)
$$

Similarly, each left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $N_{*}$ gives rise to a left $\Gamma$-module $N=\operatorname{Hom}\left(N_{*}, k\right)$, with action $\lambda$ given by the composite

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right) \otimes \operatorname{Hom}\left(N_{*}, k\right) \xrightarrow{\otimes} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}, k\right) \xrightarrow{\nu^{*}} \operatorname{Hom}\left(N_{*}, k\right)
$$

If $\Gamma$ and $N$ are bounded below and of finite type, we can recover $N_{*}$ as the dual $\operatorname{Hom}(N, k)$, with coaction given by the composite

$$
\operatorname{Hom}(N, k) \xrightarrow{\lambda^{*}} \operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma \otimes N, k) \stackrel{\cong}{\leftarrow} \operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k) \otimes \operatorname{Hom}(N, k)
$$

(Alternatively, if $\Gamma$ is finite, i.e., finite-dimensional as a $k$-vector space, it suffices to assume that $N$ is of finite type.)

Lemma 2.6. Let $L_{*}$ and $N_{*}$ be $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules, dual to $\Gamma$-modules $L$ and $N$, where $\Gamma, L$ and $N$ are bounded below and of finite type. Then there is a natural isomorphism

$$
D: \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s}(N, L)
$$

for each $s \geq 0$. (Alternatively, the same conclusion holds if $\Gamma$ is finite and $L$ and $N$ are of finite type.)

Proof. Each $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule homomorphism $f_{*}: L_{*} \rightarrow N_{*}$ gives rise to a $\Gamma$ module homomorphism $f=\operatorname{Hom}\left(f_{*}, k\right): N \rightarrow L$, defining a duality homomorphism

$$
D: \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma}(N, L)
$$

Conversely, if $\Gamma, L$ and $N$ are bounded below and of finite type (or if $\Gamma$ is finite and $L$ and $N$ are of finite type), then we can recover $f_{*}$ as $\operatorname{Hom}(f, k)$. Under these hypotheses, $D$ is an isomorphism.

If $\Gamma$ and $N$ are bounded below and of finite type, then there exists an injective $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule resolution

$$
0 \rightarrow N_{*} \longrightarrow X_{*}^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta} X_{*}^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta} \ldots
$$

such that each $X_{*}^{s}$ is an extended $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule that is bounded below and of finite type, i.e., of the form $\Gamma_{*} \otimes V$ with $V$ bounded below and of finite type. (Alternatively, if $\Gamma$ is finite and $N$ is of finite type, then there exists such a resolution with each $X_{*}^{s}$ extended and of finite type.) The isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*} \otimes V, k\right) \stackrel{\cong}{\longleftrightarrow} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{*}, k\right) \otimes \operatorname{Hom}(V, k)
$$

shows that the dual $X_{s}=\operatorname{Hom}\left(X_{*}^{s}, k\right)$ is an extended, hence free, $\Gamma$-module. The duality isomorphisms

$$
D: \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(L_{*}, X_{*}^{s}\right) \xrightarrow{\cong} \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma}\left(X_{s}, L\right)
$$

show that the complexes with cohomology defining $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s}\left(L_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s}(N, L)$ are isomorphic.

Remark 2.7. This lemma shows that when considering Ext over one of the finite subalgebras of the Steenrod algebra, with coefficients in modules of finite type, we may pass freely between the module and comodule contexts. On the other hand, when considering Ext over the full Steenrod algebra, the bounded-below condition plays a significant role. There are interesting examples of $A$-modules of finite type that are not the dual of any $A_{*}$-comodule, such as the localization

$$
L=H^{*}\left(P_{-\infty}^{\infty} ; \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x, x^{-1}\right]
$$

of $H^{*}\left(P^{\infty} ; \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}[x]$, with the $A$-module action given by $S q^{i}\left(x^{j}\right)=\binom{j}{i} x^{i+j}$. Here $S q^{n}\left(x^{-n}\right)=1$ for infinitely many values of $n$, so the dual of $\lambda: A \otimes L \rightarrow L$ does not factor through $A_{*} \otimes L_{*} \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(A \otimes L, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. See [10, Part II] and [94].

We now specialize to the situation where $\Gamma_{*}$ is a connected Hopf algebra, and let $\Lambda_{*}$ be a quotient Hopf algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. By Milnor-Moore [128, Thm. 4.7], $\Gamma_{*}$ is isomorphic as a right $\Lambda_{*}$-comodule to an extended $\Lambda_{*}$-comodule (of the form $\left.V \otimes \Lambda_{*}\right)$. Let $L_{*}$ be a left $\Lambda_{*}$-comodule, and let $\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} L_{*}$ be the coinduced left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule. This is the equalizer of the two homomorphisms

$$
\Gamma_{*} \otimes L_{*} \xrightarrow[1 \otimes \nu]{\stackrel{\nu \otimes 1}{\longrightarrow}} \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Lambda_{*} \otimes L_{*}
$$

given by the right $\Lambda_{*}$-coaction on $\Gamma_{*}$ and the left $\Lambda_{*}$-coaction on $L_{*}$, respectively.
Lemma 2.8. There is a natural change-of-coalgebra isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} L_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(k, L_{*}\right)
$$

Proof. Let

$$
0 \rightarrow L_{*} \longrightarrow X_{*}^{0} \longrightarrow X_{*}^{1} \longrightarrow \ldots
$$

be an injective $\Lambda_{*}$-comodule resolution of $L_{*}$. Applying $\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}-$ gives an injective $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule resolution

$$
0 \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} L_{*} \longrightarrow \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} X_{*}^{0} \longrightarrow \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} X_{*}^{1} \longrightarrow \ldots
$$

Hence the natural isomorphism $\operatorname{Hom}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(k, X_{*}^{s}\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} X_{*}^{s}\right)$ induces the asserted change-of-coalgebra isomorphism upon passage to cohomology.

We will allow ourselves to write $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}$ for $\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} k$. Let $M_{*}$ be a left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule, give $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes M_{*}$ the diagonal $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule structure, and give $\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} M_{*}$ the $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule structure coinduced from the corestricted $\Lambda_{*}$-comodule structure on $M_{*}$.

Lemma 2.9. There is a natural twisting isomorphism of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules

$$
\zeta_{*}:(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{\cong} \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} M_{*}
$$

lifting the composite

$$
(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{\iota \otimes \nu} \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{\phi \otimes 1} \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*}
$$

Here $\iota:(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*}$ denotes the inclusion, $\nu: M_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*}$ denotes the comodule coaction, and $\phi: \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*}$ denotes the product pairing.

Proof. The lift exists because $\Lambda_{*}$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. An inverse is obtained by factoring the composite

$$
\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} M_{*} \xrightarrow{\iota} \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{1 \otimes \nu} \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{1 \otimes \chi \otimes 1} \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*} \xrightarrow{\phi \otimes 1} \Gamma_{*} \otimes M_{*}
$$

Proposition 2.10. Suppose we have chosen a sequence of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules $R^{\sigma}$, for $\sigma \geq 0$, and an exact cochain complex

$$
0 \rightarrow k \xrightarrow{\eta}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta^{0}}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta^{1}}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{2} \xrightarrow{\delta^{2}} \ldots
$$

of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules with diagonal $\Gamma_{*}$-coaction. Then there is a strongly convergent trigraded spectral sequence

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \Longrightarrow{ }_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)
$$

The $d_{r}$-differentials have $(\sigma, s, t)$-tridegree $(r, 1,0)$, and there are isomorphisms

$$
E_{\infty}^{\sigma, s, t} \cong F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right) / F^{\sigma+1} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)
$$

for all $\sigma$, $s$ and $t$, where $\left\{F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)\right\}_{\sigma}$ is a finite and exhaustive filtration of $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)$.

Proof. For each $\sigma \geq 0$ we have a short exact sequence of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*} \longrightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*} \longrightarrow \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma+1}\right) \otimes M_{*} \rightarrow 0
$$

Note that $k=\operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{0}\right)$. These induce long exact sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \ldots \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma+1}\right) \otimes M_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s+1, t}\left(k, \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*}\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $\sigma \geq 0$. Rewriting $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)$ as $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)$, using Lemmas 2.8 and 2.9, we obtain the following exact couple:

Here

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*}\right) \\
& E^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The remainder of the proof follows that of Proposition 2.3.

Remark 2.11. When $\Gamma$ is of finite type over $k$, and $M$ and each $N_{\sigma}$ is of finite type and bounded below, we can let $\Gamma_{*}=\operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma, k), \Lambda_{*}=\operatorname{Hom}(\Lambda, k)$, $M_{*}=\operatorname{Hom}(M, k)$ and $R^{\sigma}=\operatorname{Hom}\left(N_{\sigma}, k\right)$. Then $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}=\operatorname{Hom}(\Gamma / / \Lambda, k)$, and the spectral sequences of Propositions 2.3 and 2.10 are canonically isomorphic. If $\Gamma$ is finite, i.e., finite-dimensional over $k$, then we can omit the hypothesis that $M$ and the $N_{\sigma}$ are bounded below.

# 2.3. A filtered cobar complex 

We now give an alternative construction of the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence, starting from a filtered cochain complex. For this purpose we will use the cobar construction $[\mathbf{1}, \S 2],[\mathbf{1 4 5}, 1.6]$ to obtain functorial injective resolutions. The following discussion is dual to that of the two-sided bar construction and the associated bar complex $[\mathbf{5 6}, \S 2],[\mathbf{1 1 9}, \S 9]$.

Definition 2.12. Let $\Gamma_{*}$ be a connected coalgebra over $k$, with coproduct $\psi: \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}$ and $\operatorname{counit} \epsilon: \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow k$, let $M_{*}$ be a right $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule with coaction $\nu: M_{*} \rightarrow M_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}$, and let $N_{*}$ be a left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule with coaction $\nu: N_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes N_{*}$. The two-sided cobar construction $C^{\bullet}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is the cosimplicial graded $k$-vector space with

$$
C^{p}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)=M_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*}
$$

in cosimplicial degree $p$, coface operators $d^{i}: C^{p-1}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \rightarrow C^{p}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ given by

$$
d^{i}= \begin{cases}\nu \otimes 1^{\otimes p} & \text { for } i=0 \\ 1^{\otimes i} \otimes \psi \otimes 1^{\otimes p-i} & \text { for } 0<i<p \\ 1^{\otimes p} \otimes \nu & \text { for } i=p\end{cases}
$$

and codegeneracy operators $s^{j}: C^{p+1}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \rightarrow C^{p}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ given by

$$
s^{j}=1^{\otimes j+1} \otimes \epsilon \otimes 1^{\otimes p-j+1}
$$

for $0 \leq j \leq p$. In these formulas, each tensor power of 1 refers to the identity map of a number of copies of $M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}$ or $N_{*}$. The cobar construction is coaugmented by the canonical map $\eta: M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*} \rightarrow M_{*} \otimes N_{*}=C^{0}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ from the cotensor product. In the special case when $M_{*}=\Gamma_{*}$, viewed as a $\Gamma_{*}-\Gamma_{*}$-bicomodule, the cobar construction $C^{\bullet}\left(\Gamma_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is a cosimplicial left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule. The underlying cosimplicial graded $k$-vector space admits a cosimplicial contraction to $\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*} \cong N_{*}$.

The cobar complex $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ is the associated normalized cochain complex of graded $k$-vector spaces, given by

$$
C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)=M_{*} \otimes \bar{\Gamma}_{*}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*}=\bigcap_{j=0}^{p-1} \operatorname{ker}\left(s^{j}\right)
$$

in degree $p \geq 0$, with coboundary

$$
\delta=\sum_{i=0}^{p+1}(-1)^{i} d^{i}: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p+1}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)
$$

Here $\bar{\Gamma}_{*}=\operatorname{ker}(\epsilon)$ is the augmentation ideal of $\Gamma_{*}$. The cobar complex is coaugmented by $\eta: M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} N_{*} \rightarrow M_{*} \otimes N_{*}=C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{0}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)$. In the special case $M_{*}=\Gamma_{*}$,

the cobar complex $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ admits a cochain contraction to $N_{*}$, and in each degree

$$
C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)=\Gamma_{*} \otimes \bar{\Gamma}_{*}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*}
$$

is an extended $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule. Hence

$$
0 \rightarrow N_{*} \xrightarrow{\eta} C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{0}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{1}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \ldots
$$

is an injective resolution of the left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $N_{*}$.
The isomorphisms of cochain complexes

$$
k \square_{\Gamma_{*}} C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)\right)
$$

induce isomorphisms of graded $k$-vector spaces

$$
\operatorname{Cotor}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \cong H^{p}\left(C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right), \delta\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right)
$$

upon passage to cohomology, for each $p \geq 0$. In other words, $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right)$ can be calculated as the cohomology of the cobar complex with

$$
C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right)=\bar{\Gamma}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*}
$$

for $p \geq 0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta\left(\left[\gamma_{1}\right] \ldots \mid \gamma_{p}\right] n)= & {\left[1\left|\gamma_{1}\right| \ldots \mid \gamma_{p}\right] n } \\
& +\sum_{i=1}^{p}(-1)^{i}\left[\gamma_{1}\left|\ldots \gamma_{i}^{\prime}\left|\gamma_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right| \ldots\right| \gamma_{p}\right] n+(-1)^{p+1}\left[\gamma_{1}\left|\ldots \gamma_{p}\right| \gamma^{\prime}\right] n^{\prime \prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\psi\left(\gamma_{i}\right)=\sum \gamma_{i}^{\prime} \otimes \gamma_{i}^{\prime \prime}$ and $\nu(n)=\sum \gamma^{\prime} \otimes n^{\prime \prime}$, and these summations are implicit in the formula. More generally, for each right $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $M_{*}$, the isomorphism $M_{*} \square_{\Gamma_{*}} C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ induces an isomorphism $\operatorname{Cotor}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right) \cong$ $H^{p}\left(C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right), \delta\right)$ for each $p \geq 0$.

Remark 2.13. The cobar complex $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right)$ would be denoted $\Omega\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ in the notation of [123, p. 75], and written as $\Omega\left(\Gamma_{*}\right) \otimes_{\tau} N_{*}$ in the notation of [80, §II.3]. In the special case $N_{*}=k$, it is the construction denoted $F\left(\Gamma_{*}\right)$ by Adams [1], up to signs. The cobar resolution $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(\Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right)$ agrees with the cobar resolution of [144, Def. A1.2.11]. For right $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules, the cobar resolution $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}\right)$ is isomorphic to, but not equal to, the canonical resolution $C\left(\Gamma_{*}, M_{*}\right)$ of [45, Def. IV.1.1], cf. [119, Prop. 10.3].

We again specialize to the situation where $\Gamma_{*}$ is a connected Hopf algebra and $\Lambda_{*}$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. With notation as in Proposition 2.10, the quasi-isomorphism

$$
\eta: k \xrightarrow{\sim}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}
$$

induces a quasi-isomorphism of cobar complexes

$$
\eta: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, M_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \otimes M_{*}\right)
$$

The object on the right hand side is the bigraded total complex of a trigraded bicomplex, with $C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)$ contributing to cohomological degree $s=p+\sigma$.

Definition 2.14. For each $\sigma \geq 0$ let $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \geq \sigma$ be the subcomplex of $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}$ consisting of the terms $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\tau}$ with $\tau \geq \sigma$, and let

$$
F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)=C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \geq \sigma \otimes M_{*}\right)
$$

We obtain a filtered cochain complex

$$
\cdots \subset F^{2} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right) \subset F^{1} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right) \subset F^{0} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)=C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \otimes M_{*}\right)
$$

with filtration quotients

$$
F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right) / F^{\sigma+1} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)=C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes \Sigma^{\sigma} R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)
$$

Here $\Sigma^{\sigma} R^{\sigma}$ refers to $R^{\sigma}$ located in cohomological degree $\sigma$. The associated exact couple
![img-58.jpeg](img-58.jpeg)
gives rise to a trigraded spectral sequence with

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t} & =H^{s, t}\left(F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right) / F^{\sigma+1} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)\right)=H^{s, t}\left(C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes \Sigma^{\sigma} R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)\right) \\
& \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and differentials

$$
d_{r}: E_{r}^{\sigma, s, t} \longrightarrow E_{r}^{\sigma+r, s+1, t}
$$

characterized by $d_{r}([x])=[j(y)]$ where $k(x)=i^{r-1}(y)$. It converges strongly to

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{s, t}\left(F^{0} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)\right) & =H^{s, t}\left(C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \otimes M_{*}\right)\right) \\
& \cong H^{s, t}\left(C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, M_{*}\right)\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)$ is filtered by the images $F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)=\operatorname{im}\left(i^{\sigma}\right)$ of the homomorphisms

$$
i^{\sigma}: H^{s, t}\left(F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)\right) \longrightarrow H^{s, t}\left(F^{0} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)\right)
$$

and there are isomorphisms

$$
E_{\infty}^{\sigma, s, t} \cong F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right) / F^{\sigma+1} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)
$$

for all $\sigma \geq 0$. This is a finite filtration, since $F^{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)=0$ for $\sigma>s$.
Definition 2.15. We call

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)
$$

the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence for $\Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Lambda_{*}$ with coefficients in $M_{*}$. It is strongly convergent, with $d_{r}$-differentials of $(\sigma, s, t)$-tridegree $(r, 1,0)$.

We prove in Theorem 2.24 that this spectral sequence is monoidal, in the sense that pairings of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules lead to pairings of Davis-Mahowald spectral sequences. The dual statement for pairings of $\Gamma$-modules appears in Theorem 2.25.

Lemma 2.16. For each $\sigma \geq 0$ there is a quasi-isomorphism

$$
f^{\sigma}: \Sigma^{\sigma} \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \geq \sigma
$$

of complexes of $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules. Here $\Sigma^{\sigma} \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right)$ denotes the complex with $\operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right)$ concentrated in degree $\sigma$. The induced morphism of cobar complexes

$$
f^{\sigma}: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, \Sigma^{\sigma} \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right)
$$

is also a quasi-isomorphism.

Proof. The cohomology of the truncated complex $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*} \geq \sigma$ is $\operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right)$ concentrated in degree $\sigma$.

Lemma 2.17. In the diagram
![img-59.jpeg](img-59.jpeg)
with exact columns, the upper square commutes up to sign and the middle and lower squares commute strictly, for each $\sigma \geq 0$.

Proof. For brevity, let $T^{\sigma}=(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes \Sigma^{\sigma} R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}, Z^{\sigma}=\Sigma^{\sigma} \operatorname{ker}\left(\delta^{\sigma}\right) \otimes M_{*}$, $C^{p} N_{*}=C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right)$ and $s=p+\sigma$. The homomorphisms in the upper square are derived from the following diagram.
![img-60.jpeg](img-60.jpeg)

Start with a $(p-1)$-cocycle $x \in C^{p-1} Z^{\sigma+1}$, i.e., an element with $(\delta \otimes 1)(x)=0$ in $C^{p} Z^{\sigma+1}$. By exactness of

$$
0 \rightarrow Z^{\sigma} \longrightarrow T^{\sigma} \xrightarrow{\delta} Z^{\sigma+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

we have $x=(1 \otimes \delta)(y)$ for some $y \in C^{p-1} T^{\sigma}$, and $(\delta \otimes 1)(y)=z$ for some $z \in C^{p} Z^{\sigma}$. The image $f^{\sigma} \delta([x])$ is then the class of $z$ viewed as an $s$-cocycle in $C^{*} T^{*} \geq \sigma$. On the other hand, $i f^{\sigma+1}([x])$ is the class of $x$ viewed as an $s$-cocycle in $C^{*} T^{*} \geq \sigma$. We can also view $y$ as an $(s-1)$-cochain in $C^{*} T^{*} \geq \sigma$, with total coboundary $(\delta \otimes 1+1 \otimes \delta)(y)=z+x$. Hence $[x]=-[z]$ in cohomology, so $i f^{\sigma+1}=-f^{\sigma} \delta$.

The middle square is derived from the following commutative square, hence commutes strictly.
![img-61.jpeg](img-61.jpeg)

The lower square is derived from the following diagram.
![img-62.jpeg](img-62.jpeg)

Start with a $p$-cocycle $x \in C^{p} T^{\sigma}$, meaning that $(\delta \otimes 1)(x)=0$ in $C^{p+1} T^{\sigma}$. Letting $y=x$ as an element in $C^{p} T^{\sigma} \subset\left(C^{*} T^{*} \geq \sigma\right)^{s}$, we have $j(y)=x$ and $(\delta \otimes 1+1 \otimes \delta)(y)=$ $(1 \otimes \delta)(x)=z$ where $z \in C^{p} Z^{\sigma+1} \subset\left(C^{*} T^{*} \geq \sigma+1\right)^{s+1}$. Hence both composites in the lower square map $[x]$ to $[z]$.

Proposition 2.18. The Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence of Definition 2.15 agrees, up to signs in the differentials, with the spectral sequences in Propositions 2.3 and 2.10 .

Proof. By Lemma 2.17, the exact couples (2.1) and (2.2) agree up to signs with the exact couple (2.3).

# 2.4. Multiplicative structure 

In the setting they studied, Davis and Mahowald verified through case-by-case calculation [52, pp. 322-325] that their spectral sequence is an algebra spectral sequence. With our modified construction, this is an instance of the standard algebra spectral sequence associated to a filtered differential graded (DG) algebra.

DEFINITION 2.19. Let $\Gamma_{*}$ be a connected coalgebra over $k$, and let $M_{*}$ and $N_{*}$ be right and left $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules, respectively. Likewise, let $\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}$ be a connected coalgebra and let $M_{*}^{\prime}$ and $N_{*}^{\prime}$ be right and left $\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}$-comodules. There is an Alexander-Whitney chain map

$$
f: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}, N_{*}\right) \otimes C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{*}}^{*}\left(M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

given for $p, q \geq 0$ by the composite

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C^{p}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \otimes C^{q}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}, \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \xrightarrow{\lambda_{p} \otimes \rho_{q}} C^{p+q}\left(M_{*}, \Gamma_{*}, N_{*}\right) \otimes C^{p+q}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}, \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \stackrel{\tau}{\cong} C^{p+q}\left(M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}, \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\lambda_{p}=d^{p+q} \cdots d^{p+1}$ and $\rho_{q}=d^{0} \cdots d^{0}$ are the front $p$-coface and back $q$-coface operators, respectively, and the right hand isomorphism $\tau$ is given by a shuffle permutation. More explicitly,

$$
m\left[\gamma_{1}|\ldots| \gamma_{p}\right] n \otimes m^{\prime}\left[\gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\right] n^{\prime}
$$

in $M_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime \otimes q} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}$ maps by $f$ to

$$
\pm m \otimes m_{0}^{\prime}\left[\gamma_{1} \otimes m_{1}^{\prime}\right] \ldots\left|\gamma_{p} \otimes m_{p}^{\prime}\right| n_{1} \otimes \gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| n_{q} \otimes \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\left|n_{q+1} \otimes n^{\prime}\right.
$$

in $M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime} \otimes\left(\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}\right)^{\otimes p+q} \otimes N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}$. Here the sign is that induced by $\tau$, the iterated coactions $\nu^{q}: N_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*}^{\otimes q} \otimes N_{*}$ and $\nu^{p}: M_{*}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{*}^{\prime} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime \otimes p}$ are given on $n$

and $m^{\prime}$ by $\nu^{q}(n)=\sum n_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes n_{q} \otimes n_{q+1}$ and $\nu^{p}\left(m^{\prime}\right)=\sum m_{0}^{\prime} \otimes m_{1}^{\prime} \otimes \cdots \otimes m_{p}^{\prime}$, and the latter two summations are implicit in (2.4).

When $M_{*}=\Gamma_{*}$ and $M_{*}^{\prime}=\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}$, the Alexander-Whitney map is a chain equivalence between two injective $\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}$-comodule resolutions of $N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}$. Hence the Alexander-Whitney map

$$
f: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \otimes C_{\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for $M_{*}=k$ and $M_{*}^{\prime}=k$ induces the standard external pairing

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}}^{q}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\prime}}^{p+q}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

by passage to cohomology.
When $\Gamma_{*}=\Gamma_{*}^{\prime}$ is a Hopf algebra, we can internalize the pairing above by composing $f$ with the chain map $C_{\Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)$ induced by the algebra multiplication $\phi: \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*}$. The composite chain map

$$
\phi f: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \otimes C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

takes

$$
\left[\gamma_{1}|\ldots| \gamma_{p}\right] n \otimes\left[\gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\right] n^{\prime}
$$

in $\Gamma_{*}^{\otimes p} \otimes N_{*} \otimes \Gamma_{*}^{\otimes q} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}$ to

$$
\pm\left[\gamma_{1}|\ldots| \gamma_{p}\right] n_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| n_{q} \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\left[n_{q+1} \otimes n^{\prime}\right.
$$

in $\Gamma_{*}^{\otimes p+q} \otimes N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}$. As before the sign is that induced by $\tau$, and the $q$-fold iterated coaction $\nu^{q}: N_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*}^{\otimes q} \otimes N_{*}$ is given by $\nu^{q}(n)=\sum n_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes n_{q} \otimes n_{q+1}$, with $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{q} \in \Gamma_{*}$ and $n_{q+1} \in N_{*}$. This defines the internal pairing

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p}\left(k, N_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{q}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{p+q}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

Finally, if $N_{*}=N_{*}^{\prime}$ is a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra, composition with the chain map

$$
\mu: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*} \otimes N_{*}\right) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right)
$$

induced by the multiplication $\mu: N_{*} \otimes N_{*} \rightarrow N_{*}$, defines a product that makes $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}\right)$ a bigraded algebra.

Remark 2.20. Formula (2.4) is given in [144, A1.2.15], and the special case with $M_{*}=k=M_{*}^{\prime}$ is given in $[\mathbf{1 2 3},(1.3)]$. If $N_{*}=k$, the product (2.5) simplifies to

$$
\left[\gamma_{1}|\ldots| \gamma_{p}\right] \otimes\left[\gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\right] n^{\prime} \longmapsto\left[\gamma_{1}|\ldots| \gamma_{p}\right| \gamma_{1}^{\prime}|\ldots| \gamma_{q}^{\prime}\left[n^{\prime}\right.
$$

so that the algebra structure in $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}(k, k)$ and the left module pairing

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}(k, k) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k, N_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

are induced by juxtaposition, as in [3, p. 33] and [126, §3].
We return to the situation where $\Gamma_{*}$ is a connected Hopf algebra, and $\Lambda_{*}$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. The right coaction $\nu: \Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Lambda_{*}$ and the left coaction $\nu: k \rightarrow \Lambda_{*} \otimes k$ are both algebra homomorphisms, so the equalizer diagram

$$
\Gamma_{*} \otimes k \xrightarrow[1 \otimes \nu]{\stackrel{\nu \otimes 1}{\longrightarrow}} \Gamma_{*} \otimes \Lambda_{*} \otimes k
$$

defining $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}=\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} k$ exhibits $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}$ as a sub $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$.

Proposition 2.21. Suppose that $R^{*}$ is a graded $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra, and that there are differentials $\delta^{\sigma}:(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \rightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma+1}$ making $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}$, with the diagonal $\Gamma_{*}$-coaction, a differential graded $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra. Suppose also that the unit map

$$
\eta: k \xrightarrow{\sim}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}
$$

is a quasi-isomorphism. Then there is a pairing of spectral sequences

$$
E_{r}^{\sigma, s, t}\left(M_{*}\right) \otimes E_{r}^{\sigma^{\prime}, s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow E_{r}^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}, s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

converging to

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(k, M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(k, M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

The pairing of $E_{1}$-terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \\
\left.\longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma+s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

is induced by the pairing

$$
(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \longrightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}
$$

obtained from the product on $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}$ and the multiplication $R^{\sigma} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \rightarrow R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$. In particular, if $M_{*}$ is a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra then

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \Longrightarrow{ }_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)
$$

is an algebra spectral sequence.
Proof. By assumption, the unit map $k \rightarrow R^{0}$, the multiplications $R^{\sigma} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \rightarrow$ $R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$ and the differential $\delta^{\sigma}:(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \rightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma+1}$ are $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule homomorphisms, the differential satisfies $\delta \delta=0$ and $\delta(x \cdot y)=\delta x \cdot y+(-1)^{|x|} x \cdot \delta y$ for $x$ in degree $|x|=t-\sigma$, and the cochain complex

$$
0 \rightarrow k \xrightarrow{\eta}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta^{0}}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta^{1}}(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{2} \xrightarrow{\delta^{2}} \ldots
$$

is exact. Hence

$$
C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}\right)
$$

is a differential graded algebra, and the unit map

$$
\eta: C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}(k, k) \longrightarrow C_{\Gamma_{*}}^{*}\left(k,(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}\right)
$$

is a quasi-isomorphism. The $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule pairing

$$
R^{*} \geq \sigma \otimes R^{*} \geq \sigma^{\prime} \longrightarrow R^{*} \geq \sigma+\sigma^{\prime}
$$

induces a pairing of cochain complexes

$$
F^{\sigma} C^{*}\left(M_{*}\right) \otimes F^{\sigma^{\prime}} C^{*}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow F^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} C^{*}\left(M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

For varying $\sigma$ and $\sigma^{\prime}$, these combine to a pairing of filtered cochain complexes. It follows, as in $[\mathbf{1 1 3}, \S 7, \S 8]$, that there is an induced pairing of the associated spectral sequences.

Lemma 2.22. If $\Gamma_{*}$ is commutative, then the pairing (2.6) corresponds under the twisting isomorphisms $\zeta_{*}$ for $R^{\sigma}, R^{\sigma^{\prime}}$ and $R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$ to the $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule pairing

$$
\left(\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} R^{\sigma}\right) \otimes\left(\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} R^{\sigma^{\prime}}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}
$$

induced by the product $\phi$ on $\Gamma_{*}$ and the pairing $\phi: R^{\sigma} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \rightarrow R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$.

Proof. When $\Gamma_{*}$ is commutative, the diagram
![img-63.jpeg](img-63.jpeg)
commutes. Here $\tau$ denotes the symmetry isomorphism. Hence the induced square
![img-64.jpeg](img-64.jpeg)
and its generalization

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*} \otimes(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime} \longrightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime} \\
& \zeta_{*} \otimes \zeta_{*} \mid \cong \mid \zeta_{*} \\
& \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \otimes \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

commute.
Lemma 2.23. Under the change-of-coalgebra isomorphisms, the pairing

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(k, R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(k, R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

induced by $R^{\sigma} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \rightarrow R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$ corresponds to the pairing

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right)\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(k, \Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

that is induced by (2.7) and its generalization.
Proof. This follows from the adjunctions underlying the change-of-coalgebra isomorphisms.

Theorem 2.24. Let $\Gamma_{*}$ be a connected, commutative Hopf algebra over a field $k$, and let $\Lambda_{*}$ be a quotient Hopf algebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. Suppose that $R^{*}$ is a graded $\Gamma_{*}$ comodule algebra, and that

$$
\eta: k \xrightarrow{\sim}\left((\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}, \delta\right)
$$

is a differential (cohomologically) graded $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra resolution of $k$, where each term $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{\sigma}$ has the diagonal $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule structure. Let $M_{*}$ and $M_{*}^{\prime}$ be $\Gamma_{*}$-comodules. Then there is a pairing of trigraded spectral sequences

$$
E_{r}^{\sigma, s, t}\left(M_{*}\right) \otimes E_{r}^{\sigma^{\prime}, s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow E_{r}^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}, s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

converging to

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(k, M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(k, M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
$$

The pairing of $E_{1}$-terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t^{\prime}} & \left(k, R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma+s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(k, R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M_{*} \otimes M_{*}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is induced by the component $R^{\sigma} \otimes R^{\sigma^{\prime}} \longrightarrow R^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}}$ of the graded algebra structure on $R^{*}$. In particular, if $M_{*}$ is a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra then

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}\left(M_{*}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(k, R^{\sigma} \otimes M_{*}\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(k, M_{*}\right)
$$

is an algebra spectral sequence.
Proof. Combine Proposition 2.21 with Lemmas 2.22 and 2.23.
Before we give the dual statement, note that the arrows in the coequalizer diagram defining $\Gamma / / \Lambda=\Gamma \otimes_{\Lambda} k$ are coalgebra homomorphisms, so that $\Gamma / / \Lambda$ is a quotient $\Gamma$-module coalgebra of $\Gamma$.

Theorem 2.25. Let $\Gamma$ be a connected, cocommutative Hopf algebra over a field $k$, and let $\Lambda$ be a sub Hopf algebra of $\Gamma$. Suppose that $N_{*}$ is a graded $\Gamma$-module coalgebra, and that

$$
\epsilon:\left(\Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{*}, \partial\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} k
$$

is a differential (homologically) graded $\Gamma$-module coalgebra resolution of $k$, where each term $\Gamma / / \Lambda \otimes N_{\sigma}$ has the diagonal $\Gamma$-module structure. Let $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ be $\Gamma$-modules. Then there is a pairing of trigraded spectral sequences

$$
E_{r}^{\sigma, s, t}(M) \otimes E_{r}^{\sigma^{\prime}, s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(M^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow E_{r}^{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}, s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(M \otimes M^{\prime}\right)
$$

converging to

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}\left(M^{\prime}, k\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s+s^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(M \otimes M^{\prime}, k\right)
$$

The pairing of $E_{1}$-terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t^{\prime}} & \left(N_{\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M^{\prime}, k\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma+s^{\prime}-\sigma^{\prime}, t+t^{\prime}}\left(N_{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \otimes M \otimes M^{\prime}, k\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is induced by the component $N_{\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}} \rightarrow N_{\sigma} \otimes N_{\sigma^{\prime}}$ of the graded coalgebra structure on $N_{*}$. In particular, if $M$ is a $\Gamma$-module coalgebra then

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}(M)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(N_{\sigma} \otimes M, k\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{s, t}(M, k)
$$

is an algebra spectral sequence.
We omit the proof, which is similar to that in the $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule case, using the bar construction in place of the cobar construction. When $\Gamma$ is finite-dimensional over $k$, and each of $N_{\sigma}, M$ and $M^{\prime}$ is of finite type, then Lemma 2.6 shows that the two statements are equivalent. If $\Gamma$ is just of finite type, then we must also assume that $N_{\sigma}, M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are bounded below.

REMARK 2.26. When $(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*}=E_{*}=E\left(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\right)$ is an exterior algebra on $n$ generators we can let $R^{*}=k\left[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right]$ be a polynomial algebra on the same number of generators and equip

$$
E_{*} \otimes R^{*}=E\left(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\right) \otimes k\left[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right]
$$

with the differential $d$ given by $d\left(e_{i}\right)=x_{i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq n$. From $d^{2}=0$ it follows that $d\left(x_{i}\right)=0$. If we give $E_{*} \otimes R^{*}$ a homological grading, with each $e_{i}$ in degree 1 and each $x_{i}$ in degree 0 , then the underlying exact chain complex

$$
0 \rightarrow E_{n} \otimes R^{*} \xrightarrow{d} E_{n-1} \otimes R^{*} \xrightarrow{d} \ldots \xrightarrow{d} E_{1} \otimes R^{*} \xrightarrow{d} E_{0} \otimes R^{*} \xrightarrow{\epsilon} k \rightarrow 0
$$

is the Koszul resolution associated to the regular sequence $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$. If we instead give $E_{*} \otimes R^{*}$ a cohomological grading, with each $e_{i}$ in degree 0 and each $x_{i}$ in degree 1 , then the underlying exact cochain complex

$$
0 \rightarrow k \xrightarrow{\eta} E_{*} \otimes R^{0} \xrightarrow{d} E_{*} \otimes R^{1} \xrightarrow{d} E_{*} \otimes R^{2} \xrightarrow{d} \ldots
$$

is a resolution of the sort considered by Davis-Mahowald. In this sense a DavisMahowald resolution can arise as a modified Koszul resolution, and justifies the name "Koszul spectral sequence" used in [106]. We use the name "Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence" to acknowledge the origin of its construction, and to allow for the more general case where $\eta: k \rightarrow(\Gamma / / \Lambda)_{*} \otimes R^{*}$ is not necessarily a Koszul resolution.

# 2.5. The spectral sequence for $A(1)$ 

As a warm-up to the calculation in Chapter 3, we first consider a simpler case. Let $k=\mathbb{F}_{2}$, and consider the subalgebras $A(1)=\left\langle S q^{1}, S q^{2}\right\rangle$ and $A(0)=E\left(S q^{1}\right)$ of the $\bmod 2$ Steenrod algebra $A$, which are generated by $S q^{1}$ and $S q^{2}$, and by $S q^{1}$, respectively. These are connected, cocommutative sub Hopf algebras of $A$, with dual Hopf algebras

$$
A(1)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\xi_{1}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{4}, \bar{\xi}_{2}^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
A(0)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{2}\right)=E\left(\xi_{1}\right)
$$

The coproduct in $A(1)_{*}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi\left(\xi_{1}\right)=1 \otimes \xi_{1}+\xi_{1} \otimes 1 \\
& \psi\left(\bar{\xi}_{2}\right)=1 \otimes \bar{\xi}_{2}+\xi_{1} \otimes \xi_{1}^{2}+\bar{\xi}_{2} \otimes 1
\end{aligned}
$$

so that $(A(1) / / A(0))_{*}=E\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right)$ as a sub $A(1)_{*}$-comodule algebra of $A(1)_{*}$. In this section, let $R^{*}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{2}, x_{3}\right]$ be the graded $A(1)_{*}$-comodule algebra with $x_{i}$ in internal degree $i$ and cohomological degree 1 , having coaction given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nu\left(x_{2}\right)=1 \otimes x_{2} \\
& \nu\left(x_{3}\right)=1 \otimes x_{3}+\xi_{1} \otimes x_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We equip

$$
(A(1) / / A(0))_{*} \otimes R^{*}=E\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right) \otimes \mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{2}, x_{3}\right]
$$

with the diagonal $A(1)_{*}$-comodule algebra structure. It becomes a differential graded $A(1)_{*}$-comodule algebra with the differential $\delta$ given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta\left(\xi_{1}^{2}\right)=x_{2} \\
& \delta\left(\bar{\xi}_{2}\right)=x_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the resulting cochain complex

$$
0 \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2} \xrightarrow{\eta} E\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right) \otimes R^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta^{0}} E\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right) \otimes R^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta^{1}} E\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right) \otimes R^{2} \xrightarrow{\delta^{2}} \ldots
$$

is exact. Here

$$
R^{\sigma}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{x_{2}^{i} x_{3}^{j} \mid i+j=\sigma\right\}
$$

is the $A(1)_{*}$-comodule of homogeneous polynomials in $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{2}, x_{3}\right]$ of degree $\sigma$.
The Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence for $A(1)_{*} \rightarrow A(0)_{*}$ with coefficients in $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ is thus the algebra spectral sequence

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, R^{\sigma}\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

Recall that for a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule $M_{*}$ the group $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{0, *}\left(k, M_{*}\right)$ consists of the $\Gamma_{*^{-}}$ comodule primitives in $M_{*}$, i.e., the elements $x \in M_{*}$ with $\nu(x)=1 \otimes x$. We note that $x_{2}$ and $x_{3}^{2}$ are $A(0)_{*}$-comodule primitives, and that $R^{*}$ is free as a module over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{3}^{2}\right]$. We obtain an extension of graded $A(0)_{*}$-comodule algebras

$$
\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{3}^{2}\right] \longrightarrow R^{*} \longrightarrow \bar{R}^{*}
$$

where, by definition,

$$
\bar{R}^{*}=R^{*} \otimes_{\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{3}^{2}\right]} \mathbb{F}_{2}=R^{*} /\left(x_{3}^{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{2}, x_{3}\right] /\left(x_{3}^{2}\right)
$$

Here $\bar{R}^{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\{1\} \cong \mathbb{F}_{2}$, and

$$
\bar{R}^{\sigma}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{x_{2}^{\sigma}, x_{2}^{\sigma-1} x_{3}\right\} \cong \Sigma^{2 \sigma} A(0)_{*}
$$

for $\sigma \geq 1$. Hence we obtain an extension of trigraded algebras

$$
\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{3}^{2}\right] \longrightarrow E_{1}^{*, *, *} \longrightarrow \bar{E}_{1}^{*, *, *}
$$

where $E_{1}^{*, *, *}$ is free as a module over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[x_{3}^{2}\right]$. By abuse of notation,

$$
\bar{E}_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \bar{R}^{\sigma}\right)
$$

is given by

$$
\bar{E}_{1}^{0, *, *} \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{s, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}\right]
$$

and

$$
\bar{E}_{1}^{\sigma, *, *} \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{s-\sigma, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{2 \sigma} A(0)_{*}\right) \cong \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{x_{2}^{\sigma}\right\}
$$

for $\sigma \geq 1$. Here $h_{0} \in \bar{E}_{1}^{0,1,1}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{1,1}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ corresponds to the coalgebra primitive $\xi_{1}$ dual to $S q^{1}$. We write $x_{2}^{\sigma}$ for the class in $\bar{E}_{1}^{\sigma, \sigma, 2 \sigma}$ that corresponds to $x_{2}^{\sigma} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(0)_{*}}^{0,2 \sigma}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \bar{R}^{\sigma}\right)$. Thus,

$$
E_{1}^{*, *, *}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, x_{2}, x_{3}^{2}\right] /\left(h_{0} x_{2}\right)
$$

with generators in $(\sigma, s, t)$-degrees $\left|h_{0}\right|=(0,1,1),\left|x_{2}\right|=(1,1,2)$ and $\left|x_{3}^{2}\right|=(2,2,6)$. The algebra extension $E_{1} \rightarrow \bar{E}_{1}$ splits, because $h_{0} x_{2}$ lies in weight $\sigma=1$, where $\left(x_{3}^{2}\right)$ is trivial.

Lemma 2.27. $d_{1}\left(h_{0}\right)=0, d_{1}\left(x_{2}\right)=0$ and $d_{1}\left(x_{3}^{2}\right)=x_{2}^{3}$.
Proof. The target groups of the first two differentials, $E_{1}^{1,2,1}$ and $E_{1}^{2,2,2}$, are both zero. The differential $d_{1}: E_{1}^{2,2,6} \rightarrow E_{1}^{3,3,6}$ is the homomorphism

$$
\delta_{*}^{2}: \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{0,6}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2},(A(1) / / A(0))_{*} \otimes R^{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{0,6}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2},(A(1) / / A(0))_{*} \otimes R^{3}\right)
$$

induced by $\delta^{2}$. In internal degree 6 the only nonzero $A(1)_{*}$-comodule primitive in $(A(1) / / A(0))_{*} \otimes R^{2}$ is $\xi_{1}^{2} x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}$, which is mapped by $\delta^{2}$ to the nonzero $A(1)_{*^{-}}$ comodule primitive $\delta\left(\xi_{1}^{2}\right) x_{2}^{2}+0=x_{2}^{3}$ in $(A(1) / / A(0))_{*} \otimes R^{3}$. Hence $d_{1}\left(x_{3}^{2}\right)=x_{2}^{3}$.

LEMMA 2.28.

$$
E_{2}^{*, *, *}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, x_{2}, h_{0} x_{3}^{2}, x_{3}^{4}\right] /\left(h_{0} x_{2}, x_{2}^{3}, x_{2}\left(h_{0} x_{3}^{2}\right),\left(h_{0} x_{3}^{2}\right)^{2}-h_{0}^{2}\left(x_{3}^{4}\right)\right)
$$

is equal to $E_{\infty}^{*, *, *}$.

Proof. See Figures 2.1 and 2.2. The differentials $d_{r}\left(x_{2}\right)$ lie in the groups $E_{r}^{1+r, 2,2}$, which are trivial.

# Proposition 2.29. 

$\operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, h_{1}, v, w_{1}\right] /\left(h_{0} h_{1}, h_{1}^{3}, h_{1} v, v^{2}-h_{0}^{2} w_{1}\right)$
with $(t-s, s)$-bigradings $\left|h_{0}\right|=(0,1),\left|h_{1}\right|=(1,1),|v|=(4,3)$ and $\left|w_{1}\right|=(8,4)$.
Proof. There are unique classes $h_{0}, h_{1}, v$ and $w_{1}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ that are detected by $h_{0}, x_{2}, h_{0} x_{3}^{2}$ and $x_{3}^{4}$ in $E_{\infty}^{*, *}$, respectively. Each multiplicative relation in $E_{\infty}^{\sigma, s, t}$ lifts unchanged to $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, since in each case there are no classes in $E_{\infty}^{*, s, t}$ of higher weight than $\sigma$. See Figure 2.3.

### 2.6. Real, quaternionic and complex $K$-theory spectra

Having calculated $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, we round off this chapter with some examples of spectra with $\bmod 2$ cohomology induced up from various $A(1)$-modules, namely the connective topological $K$-theory spectra. To each permutative (or symmetric monoidal) topological category $(\mathcal{C}, \oplus)$ one can associate a $K$-theory spectrum $K(\mathcal{C})[\mathbf{1 5 1}],[\mathbf{1 2 0}],[\mathbf{5 9}$, Thm. 1.1]. When $(\mathcal{C}, \oplus, \otimes)$ is bipermutative (or symmetric bimonoidal), the $K$-theory spectrum becomes an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $[\mathbf{1 2 1}]$, [59, Thm. 1.2]. Furthermore, if $\mathcal{D}$ is a suitably defined module category over $\mathcal{C}$, then $K(\mathcal{D})$ is a module spectrum over $K(\mathcal{C})$, see $[\mathbf{5 9}, \S 9]$.

Example 2.30. The connective real $K$-theory spectrum $k o$ is the $K$-theory spectrum of a bipermutative topological category $\mathcal{G} \mathcal{L}(\mathbb{R})[\mathbf{1 2 1}$, Ex. VI.5.4] equivalent to the symmetric bimonoidal topological category of finite dimensional real vector spaces, with respect to the usual direct sum and tensor product. It is an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum with $\bmod 2$ cohomology

$$
H^{*}(k o)=A / A\left(S q^{1}, S q^{2}\right)=A \otimes_{A(1)} \mathbb{F}_{2}=A / / A(1)
$$

and $\bmod 2$ homology

$$
H_{*}(k o)=A_{*} \square_{A(1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\xi_{1}^{4}, \bar{\xi}_{2}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{i} \mid i \geq 3\right]
$$

see [163, Thm. A] or Proposition 16.6 of [9, Part III]. The Adams spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}(k o)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(k o)\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(k o)_{2}^{\wedge}
$$

is an algebra spectral sequence with $E_{2}$-term

$$
\begin{aligned}
k o^{*, *} & =\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, A_{*} \square_{A(1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, h_{1}, v, w_{1}\right] /\left(h_{0} h_{1}, h_{1}^{3}, h_{1} v, v^{2}-h_{0}^{2} w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

See Figure 2.3. The classes $h_{0}$ and $h_{1}$ in $(t-s, s)$-bidegrees $(0,1)$ and $(1,1)$ are dual to $S q^{1}$ and $S q^{2}$, respectively. The Adams spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{2}$-term, and converges to

$$
\pi_{*}(k o)_{2}^{\wedge}=\mathbb{Z}_{2}[\eta, A, B] /\left(2 \eta, \eta^{3}, \eta A, A^{2}-4 B\right)
$$

where $\eta, A$ and $B$, in topological degrees 1,4 and 8 , are detected by $h_{1}, v$ and $w_{1}$, respectively. By real Bott periodicity, $\Sigma^{8} k o$ is equivalent to the 7 -connected cover bstring of real $K$-theory, and $\pi_{*}(k o)=\mathbb{Z}[\eta, A, B] /\left(2 \eta, \eta^{3}, \eta A, A^{2}-4 B\right)$, before 2 -adic completion.

\begin{aligned}
k s p^{*, *} & =\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, A_{*} \square_{A(1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, \xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right\}\right) \\
& \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(1)_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, \xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right\}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{1}\right]\left\{h_{0}^{i}, h_{0}^{i} v^{\prime}, h_{1} v^{\prime}, h_{1}^{2} v^{\prime} \mid i \geq 0\right\} \\
& =k o^{*, *}\left\{1, v^{\prime}\right\} /\left(h_{1} \cdot 1, v \cdot 1-h_{0}^{2} \cdot v^{\prime}, v \cdot v^{\prime}-w_{1} \cdot 1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $v^{\prime}$ has $(t-s, s)$-bidegree $\left|v^{\prime}\right|=(4,1)$, see Figure 2.5. (This can be verified using the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence for $A(1)_{*} \rightarrow A(0)_{*}$ with coefficients in $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{1, \xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right\}$, which we leave as an exercise for the interested reader.) The Adams spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{2}$-term, and converges to

$$
\pi_{*}(k s p)_{2}^{\wedge}=\pi_{*}(k o)_{2}^{\wedge}\left\{1, A^{\prime}\right\} /\left(\eta \cdot 1, A \cdot 1-4 \cdot A^{\prime}, A \cdot A^{\prime}-B \cdot 1\right)
$$

where 1 and $A^{\prime}$ are detected by 1 and $v^{\prime}$, respectively.

![img-72.jpeg](img-72.jpeg)

Figure 2.6. $E_{2}$-term $k u^{*, *}=\operatorname{Ext}_{E(1)}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ of Adams spectral sequence for $k u$

Example 2.33. The connective complex $K$-theory spectrum $k u$ is the $K$-theory spectrum of a bipermutative topological category $\mathcal{G} \mathcal{L}(\mathbb{C})$ [121, Ex. VI.5.4] equivalent to the symmetric bimonoidal topological category of finite dimensional complex vector spaces, with respect to their usual direct sum and tensor product. It is an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum with $\bmod 2$ cohomology

$$
H^{*}(k u)=A / A\left(Q_{0}, Q_{1}\right)=A \otimes_{E(1)} \mathbb{F}_{2}=A / / E(1)
$$

and $\bmod 2$ homology

$$
H_{*}(k u)=A_{*} \square_{E(1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[\xi_{1}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{2}^{2}, \bar{\xi}_{i} \mid i \geq 3\right]
$$

see [4, Lem. 4], [163, Thm. B] or Proposition 16.6 of [9, Part III]. Here $E(1)=$ $E\left(Q_{0}, Q_{1}\right)$ denotes the sub Hopf algebra of $A(1) \subset A$ generated by the Milnor primitives $Q_{0}=S q^{1}$ and $Q_{1}=\left[S q^{2}, S q^{1}\right]$. The dual Hopf algebra is $E(1)_{*}=$ $E\left(\xi_{1}, \bar{\xi}_{2}\right)$, where $\bar{\xi}_{2}=\xi_{2}+\xi_{1}^{3} \equiv \xi_{2}$. The Adams spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}(k u)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(k u)\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(k u)_{2}^{\wedge}
$$

is an algebra spectral sequence with $E_{2}$-term

$$
\begin{aligned}
k u^{*, *} & =\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, A_{*} \square_{E(1)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \\
& \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{E(1)_{*}}^{*, *}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[v_{0}, v_{1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

See Figure 2.6. The classes $v_{0}$ and $v_{1}$ in $(t-s, s)$-bidegrees $(0,1)$ and $(2,1)$ are dual to $Q_{0}$ and $Q_{1}$, respectively. The spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{2}$-term, and converges to

$$
\pi_{*}(k u)_{2}^{\wedge}=\mathbb{Z}_{2}\left[v_{1}\right]
$$

By complex Bott periodicity, $\Sigma^{2} k u \simeq b u$ is equivalent to the 1 -connected cover of complex $K$-theory. Hence $\pi_{*}(k u)=\mathbb{Z}[u]$ integrally, with $u$ in degree 2 mapping to $v_{1}$ under 2-completion. The homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
b u \xrightarrow{i} k u \xrightarrow{j} H \mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow{k} \Sigma b u
$$

induces a long exact sequence in cohomology, which breaks up into a short exact sequence of $A$-modules

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma H^{*}(b u) \xrightarrow{k^{*}} H^{*}(H \mathbb{Z}) \xrightarrow{j^{*}} H^{*}(k u) \rightarrow 0
$$

induced up along $E(1) \subset A$ from the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{3} \mathbb{F}_{2} \longrightarrow E(1) / / A(0) \longrightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

of $E(1)$-modules.
