# CHAPTER 5 

## The Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$

We calculate the $d_{r}$-differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for the topological modular forms spectrum. These are nontrivial for $r \in\{2,3,4\}$, and zero for $r \geq 5$, so the spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{5}$-term. The $E_{\infty}$ (or $H_{\infty}$ ) ring structure on $t m f$ suffices to determine most of these differentials, due to their interaction with the Steenrod operations in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. Two further differentials are determined by naturality with respect to the unit map $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$. The resulting $E_{\infty}$-term is the associated graded of a complete Hausdorff filtration of $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{2}^{c}$.

### 5.1. The $E_{2}$-term for $t m f$

The initial term

$$
E_{2}=E_{2}(t m f) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

of the $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for the topological modular forms spectrum $t m f$ was calculated in Part I. The groups $E_{2}^{s, t}$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 192$ are displayed in Figures 1.11 to 1.18. As a bigraded commutative algebra, the $E_{2}$-term is generated by the 13 classes

$$
h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}, c_{0}, \alpha, \beta, d_{0}, e_{0}, \gamma, \delta, g, w_{1}, w_{2}
$$

listed in Tables 1.3 and 3.3. These are subject to the ideal of relations generated by the 54 relations listed in Table 3.4. A Gröbner basis for this ideal is given by the 77 relations listed in Table 3.5.

The $E_{2}$-term is free as a module over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$, and is finitely generated as a module over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$, but we choose to primarily keep track of its module structure over the intermediate algebra $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$ will be seen to be infinite cycles in the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$, meaning that they are $d_{r}$-cycles for all $r \geq 2$, but there are nonzero differentials $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g$ and $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=\beta g^{4}$. We will therefore consider the $E_{3}$-term as a module over $R_{1}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2}\right]$, and regard the $E_{r}$-terms for $r \geq 4$ as modules over $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$

Definition 5.1. For $i \in\{0,1,2\}$ let $R_{i}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2^{i}}\right]$. Then $R_{0} \cong R_{1}\left\{1, w_{2}\right\}$ and $R_{1} \cong R_{2}\left\{1, w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ as $R_{1}$ - and $R_{2}$-modules, respectively.

A presentation of the $E_{2}$-term as a direct sum of cyclic $R_{0}$-modules is given in Table 5.1, most of which is obtained from Table 3.6 by combining a few of the rows. By Proposition 3.45 we have an isomorphism

$$
E_{2}=E_{2}(t m f) \cong \bigoplus_{x} \frac{R_{0}}{\operatorname{Ann}(x)}\{x\}
$$

of $R_{0}$-modules, where $x$ ranges over the generators listed in Table 5.1 and $\operatorname{Ann}(x) \subset$ $R_{0}$ denotes the annihilator ideal of $x$. The $R_{0}$-module generators are indicated

by large dots $(\bullet)$ in Figures 3.12 and 3.13. The four $h_{0}$-towers, in topological degrees $t-s \in\{0,12,24,36\}$, continue indefinitely. When enumerating the infinitely repeating parts of such $h_{0}$-towers we will always use an index $i$ that runs over the non-negative integers. In other words, we systematically let $i \geq 0$ in these tables. The columns $t-s$ and $s$ give the topological degree and Adams filtration of the generator $x$, respectively. The column $g$ gives the generator number in the minimal $A(2)$-module resolution calculated by ext, see Definition 1.8, so that $x$ corresponds to the cocycle denoted $s_{g}$. In the case of an $h_{0}$-tower of the form $\left\{h_{0}^{i} x\right\}$ with $i \geq 0$, the generator number $g$ is given for the element corresponding to $i=0$.

# 5.2. The $d_{2}$-differentials for $t m f$ 

The main purpose of this section is to determine the $d_{2}$-differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$. We will see that $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{2}$-cycles, so that the $d_{2}$-differential is $R_{1}$-linear. Hence it suffices to determine $d_{2}(x)$ and $d_{2}\left(x w_{2}\right)$ as $x$ ranges through a set of $R_{0}$-module generators for the $E_{2}$-term, since the classes $x$ and $x w_{2}$ will then range through a set of $R_{1}$-module generators for the same $E_{2}$-term. We first determine $d_{2}$ on the 13 algebra generators of $E_{2}$. The values of $d_{2}$ on the remaining $R_{1}$-module generators will then follow by the Leibniz rule

$$
d_{r}(x y)=d_{r}(x) y+x d_{r}(y)
$$

(for $r=2$ ), which holds because the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ is an algebra spectral sequence.

Inspection of the $E_{2}$-term quickly shows that ten of the algebra generators are $d_{2}$-cycles. The three remaining generators are $\alpha, \beta$ and $w_{2}$. The $d_{2}$-differentials

on $\alpha$ and $\beta$ follow from the known interaction between differentials and Steenrod operations in the $E_{2}$-term. To determine $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$ we will rely on some external input, given by a comparison of the Adams spectral sequences for $S$ and $t m f$. The first two hidden $\eta$-multiplications in the Adams spectral sequence for $S$ (showing that $\eta \rho$ is detected by $P c_{0}$ and $\eta^{2} \bar{\kappa}$ is detected by $P d_{0}$ ) lead to two key differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ (namely, $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$ and $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$ ), and the value of $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$ follows from this.

First we have some easy vanishing results.
LEMMA 5.2.
(1) $h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}, c_{0}, w_{1}$ and $d_{0}$ are infinite cycles.
(2) $\alpha, \beta$ and $w_{2}$ may support nonzero $d_{2}$-differentials.
(3) $e_{0}$ survives to $E_{3}$.
(4) $g$ survives (at least) to $E_{5}$.
(5) $\gamma$ survives (at least) to $E_{6}$.
(6) $\delta$ survives (at least) to $E_{4}$.

Proof. This follows by inspection of Figures 3.12 and 3.13. There are no nonzero targets for $d_{r}$-differentials for $r \geq 2$ on $h_{0}, h_{2}, c_{0}, w_{1}$ and $d_{0}$. By $h_{0^{-}}$ linearity and induction $d_{r}\left(h_{1}\right)=0$ for each $r \geq 2$, since $h_{0} h_{1}=0$ and $h_{0}^{r+2} \neq 0$ at the $E_{r}$-term. The target groups for $d_{2}\left(e_{0}\right), d_{r}(g)$ for $r \in\{2,3,4\}$, and $d_{r}(\delta)$ for $r \in\{2,3\}$, are all trivial. Finally, multiplication by $h_{0}$ acts injectively on the target groups of $d_{r}(\gamma)$ for $r \in\{2,3,4,5\}$, and $h_{0} \gamma=0$, so $d_{r}(\gamma)=0$ for these values of $r$.

Next, we use the Steenrod operations in

$$
E_{2}(t m f)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A}\left(H^{*}(t m f), \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

By Lemma 1.22 applied to $A(2) \subset A$, these are unambiguously defined. The operations

$$
S q^{i}: \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s+i, 2 t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

were calculated on the algebra generators of the $E_{2}$-term in Theorem 1.20, and can be evaluated on the remaining classes by means of the Cartan formula

$$
S q^{k}(x y)=\sum_{i+j=k} S q^{i}(x) S q^{j}(y)
$$

By its construction as the connective cover of the global sections of a sheaf of $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra, see Section 0.1 , the topological modular forms spectrum is an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum. Hence it is also an $H_{\infty}$ ring spectrum in the sense of $[\mathbf{4 5}, \S \mathrm{I} .3]$. This implies a number of relations between the differentials $d_{r}$ in its Adams spectral sequence and the Steenrod operations $S q^{i}$ in its $E_{2}$-term. These results are due, in increasing generality, to Daniel Kahn [85], James Milgram [122], Jukka Mäkinen [109] and the first author [37]. We now recall the first author's theorems from [45, §VI.1], translated to the cohomological indexing of the Steenrod squaring operations used in Section 1.3 and equation (5.1). (In [45] a different indexing convention was used, under which $S q^{j}$ denotes the operation that increases the topological degree $t-s$ by $j$.) The theory will be more fully reviewed in Chapter 11, where we study the Adams spectral sequence for $S$.

Definition 5.3 ([45, Def. V.2.15]). For $n \geq 0$, let $v=v(n)$ denote the "vector field number", i.e., the maximal number $v$ such that the attaching map of the $n$-cell in the real projective $n$-space $P^{n}$ factors up to homotopy as

$$
S^{n-1} \xrightarrow{\alpha} P^{n-v} \subset P^{n-1}
$$

Let $a=a(n) \in \pi_{v-1}(S)$ denote the top component

$$
S^{n-1} \xrightarrow{\alpha} P^{n-v} \longrightarrow S^{n-v}
$$

of a maximal compression. Let $\bar{a} \in E_{ \infty}^{f, f+v-1}(S)$ be the infinite cycle that detects $a$ in the $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for $S$. Here $f$ is the Adams filtration of $a$.

Adams' solution of the vector-field problem for spheres [5] leads to the following formulas.

Proposition 5.4 ([45, Prop. V.2.16 and V.2.17]). Let the 2-adic valuation of $n+1$ be $4 q+r$, with $0 \leq r \leq 3$. Then $v=v(n)=8 q+2^{r}$.

If $n$ is even, then $v=1, a=2$ and $\bar{a}=h_{0}$. If $n$ is odd, then $v \geq 2$ and $a$ generates the image of the J-homomorphism in $\pi_{v-1}(S)_{2}^{\wedge}$. In particular, if $n \equiv 1$ $\bmod 4$ then $v=2, a=\eta$ and $\bar{a}=h_{1}$. If $n \equiv 3 \bmod 8$ then $v=4, a \equiv \nu \bmod 2 \nu$ and $\bar{a}=h_{2}$.

Definition 5.5. Let $A \in E_{2}^{s, t}, B_{1} \in E_{2}^{s+r_{1}, t+r_{1}-1}$ and $B_{2} \in E_{2}^{s+r_{2}, t+r_{2}-1}$ be classes in a spectral sequence with differentials $d_{r}: E_{r}^{s, t} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s+r, t+r-1}$. The notation

$$
d_{*}(A)=B_{1} \dot{+} B_{2}
$$

means that $d_{r}(A)=0$ for $2 \leq r<\min \left\{r_{1}, r_{2}\right\}$, while

$$
\begin{cases}d_{r_{1}}(A)=B_{1} & \text { if } r_{1}<r_{2} \\ d_{r}(A)=B_{1}+B_{2} & \text { if } r_{1}=r=r_{2} \\ d_{r_{2}}(A)=B_{2} & \text { if } r_{1}>r_{2}\end{cases}
$$

Theorem 5.6 ([45, Thm. VI.1.1 and VI.1.2]). Let $E_{r}(Y)$ be the mod 2 Adams spectral sequence for an $H_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $Y$, and let $x \in E_{2}^{s, t}(Y)$ be an element that survives to the $E_{r}$-term, where $r \geq 2$. Let $0 \leq i \leq s$, and let $v=v(t-i)$, $a=a(t-i)$ and $\bar{a}$ be as just defined. Then

$$
d_{*}\left(S q^{i}(x)\right)=S q^{i+r-1}\left(d_{r}(x)\right) \dot{+} \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } v>s-i+1 \\ \bar{a} x d_{r}(x) & \text { if } v=s-i+1 \\ \bar{a} S q^{i+v}(x) & \text { if } v \leq \min \{s-i, 10\}\end{cases}
$$

REMARK 5.7. If $r_{1}<r_{2}$ and $B_{1}=0$, then $B_{1} \dot{+} B_{2}$ denotes the zero element in filtration $s+r_{1}$. In this case the theorem does not give information about $d_{r}\left(S q^{i}(x)\right)$ for $r>r_{1}$. Similar remarks apply if $r_{1}>r_{2}$ and $B_{2}=0$. However, in the (first) case $v>s-i+1$ of the theorem the summand $B_{2}=0$ should be interpreted as lying in arbitrarily high Adams filtration $s+r_{2}$, so that

$$
d_{2 r-1}\left(S q^{i}(x)\right)=S q^{i+r-1}\left(d_{r}(x)\right)
$$

# Proposition 5.8. 

(1) $d_{2}(\alpha)=h_{2} w_{1}$ and $d_{2}(\beta)=h_{0} d_{0}$.
(2) $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}$.
(3) $d_{3}\left(\beta^{2}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1}$.

(4) $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=S q^{9}\left(d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)$.

Proof. We apply Theorem 5.6 for classes $x \in E_{2}^{s, t}=E_{2}^{s, t}(t m f)$ with $r=2$.
(1) For $x=c_{0} \in E_{2}^{3,11}$ and $i=1$ we get $v=1, s-i+1=3$ and

$$
d_{*}\left(S q^{1}\left(c_{0}\right)\right)=S q^{2}\left(d_{2}\left(c_{0}\right)\right)+h_{0} S q^{2}\left(c_{0}\right)=h_{0} S q^{2}\left(c_{0}\right)
$$

so that $d_{2}\left(h_{2} \beta\right)=h_{0}^{2} e_{0}$ by Proposition 1.21. Here $d_{2}\left(h_{2} \beta\right)=h_{2} \cdot d_{2}(\beta), h_{0}^{2} e_{0}=$ $h_{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}$ and $h_{2}$-multiplication acts injectively on the group $E_{2}^{5,19}$ containing $d_{2}(\beta)$, so $d_{2}(\beta)=h_{0} d_{0}$. By $h_{0^{-}}$and $h_{2}$-linearity $h_{2} \cdot d_{2}(\alpha)=h_{0} \cdot d_{2}(\beta)=h_{0}^{2} d_{0}=h_{2} \cdot h_{2} w_{1}$. Multiplication by $h_{2}$ acts injectively on the group $E_{2}^{5,16}$ containing $d_{2}(\alpha)$, so $d_{2}(\alpha)=$ $h_{2} w_{1}$.
(2) For $x=\alpha \in E_{2}^{3,15}$ and $i=3$ we get $v=1, s-i+1=1$ and

$$
d_{*}\left(S q^{3}(\alpha)\right)=S q^{4}\left(d_{2}(\alpha)\right)+h_{0} \alpha d_{2}(\alpha)=S q^{4}\left(d_{2}(\alpha)\right)+h_{0} \alpha d_{2}(\alpha)
$$

Hence $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2}\right)=S q^{4}\left(h_{2} w_{1}\right)+h_{0} \alpha h_{2} w_{1}=0+h_{0} h_{2} \alpha w_{1}=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}$, by Theorem 1.20 and case (1).
(3) For $x=\beta \in E_{2}^{3,18}$ and $i=3$ we get $v=9, s-i+1=1$ and

$$
d_{*}\left(S q^{3}(\beta)\right)=S q^{4}\left(d_{2}(\beta)\right)+0=S q^{4}\left(d_{2}(\beta)\right)
$$

Hence $d_{3}\left(\beta^{2}\right)=S q^{4}\left(h_{0} d_{0}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1}$, by Theorem 1.20 and case (1).
(4) For $x=w_{2} \in E_{2}^{8,56}$ and $i=8$ we get $v=1, s-i+1=1$ and

$$
d_{*}\left(S q^{8}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)=S q^{9}\left(d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)+h_{0} w_{2} d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=S q^{9}\left(d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)+h_{0} w_{2} d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)
$$

Hence $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=S q^{9}\left(d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)+h_{0} w_{2} d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$. Here $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right) \in E_{2}^{10,57}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\{\alpha \beta g\}$, and $h_{0} \cdot \alpha \beta g=0$, so $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=S q^{9}\left(d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)\right)$.

REMARK 5.9. Once we show that $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g$, we can deduce that $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=$ $S q^{9}(\alpha \beta g)=\gamma \beta^{2} g^{2}=\beta g^{4}$, using Theorem 1.20 and Table 3.5. In order to show that $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$ is nonzero, we first use naturality with respect to $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ to determine the differentials $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)$ and $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)$, and then make use of the relation $\gamma^{2}=\beta^{2} g+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$.

THEOREM 5.10. $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$.
Proof. This is a consequence of the first hidden $\eta$-multiplication in the Adams spectral sequence for $S$, from $h_{0}^{3} h_{4}$ detecting $\rho \in \pi_{15}(S)$ to $P c_{0}$ detecting $\eta \rho \in$ $\pi_{16}(S)$. See Figure 1.9 and case (16) of Theorem 11.61.

Let $\kappa \in \pi_{14}(S)$ be detected by $d_{0}$, so that $\eta \kappa$ is detected by $h_{1} d_{0}$. The differentials $d_{2}(\beta)=h_{0} d_{0}$ and $d_{2}\left(h_{0} \beta\right)=h_{0}^{2} d_{0}=h_{2}^{2} w_{1}$ in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$ show that $\pi_{15}(t m f)=\mathbb{Z} / 2\{\iota(\eta \kappa)\}$. See Figure 1.19. Hence $\iota(\rho)$ is 0 or $\iota(\eta \kappa)$. In either case $\iota(\eta \rho)$ is 0 , since $\eta^{2} \kappa=0$ in $\pi_{16}(S)$. Again, see case (16) of Theorem 11.61.

By Proposition 1.14, $\iota\left(P c_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$. It follows that $c_{0} w_{1}$ is an infinite cycle that detects zero in $\pi_{16}(t m f)$, i.e., it is a $d_{r}$-boundary for some $r \geq 2$. Here $d_{2}\left(h_{0} e_{0}\right)=$ $h_{0} d_{2}\left(e_{0}\right)=0$ in $E_{2}(t m f)$, so the only remaining possibility is $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$.

Corollary 5.11. $\alpha \beta$ survives (at least) to $E_{8}$.
Proof. See Figure 3.13. By the Leibniz rule, $d_{2}(\alpha \beta)=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot \beta+\alpha \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=0$. To see that $d_{3}(\alpha \beta)=0$, note that in its bidegree the $E_{2}$-term is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{h_{1} e_{0} w_{1}\right\}$. By the theorem above, $d_{3}\left(h_{1} e_{0} w_{1}\right)=h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}^{2} \neq 0$, since $h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ cannot be a $d_{2}$-boundary. Hence $d_{3} \circ d_{3}=0$ implies $d_{3}(\alpha \beta) \neq h_{1} e_{0} w_{1}$. The differentials $d_{r}(\alpha \beta)$ for $4 \leq r \leq 7$ land in trivial groups, hence are zero.

THEOREM 5.12. $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$.
Proof. This is a consequence of the second hidden $\eta$-multiplication in the Adams spectral sequence for $S$, from $h_{1} g$ detecting $\eta \bar{\kappa}$ to $P d_{0}$ detecting $\eta^{2} \bar{\kappa}$. See Figure 1.9 and case (22) of Theorem 11.61.

Let $\bar{\kappa} \in \pi_{20}(S)$ be detected by $g$. Then $\kappa \cdot \eta^{2} \bar{\kappa} \in \pi_{36}(S)$ is detected by $d_{0}$. $P d_{0}$ in $E_{2}(S)$, which must be a boundary because $\eta^{2} \kappa=0$. Likewise, the image $\iota\left(d_{0} \cdot P d_{0}\right)=d_{0} \cdot d_{0} w_{1}=g w_{1}^{2}$ in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$ must be a boundary, and in this spectral sequence the only possible source of such a differential is $e_{0} g$, with $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$. See Figure 3.14.

COROLLARY 5.13. $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ and $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ are nonzero.
Proof. See Figures 3.13 and 3.14. We deduce $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ by $w_{1^{-}}$and $d_{0}$-linearity from $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$ and the relation $d_{0}^{2}=g w_{1}$. First, $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{1}\right)=$ $g w_{1}^{3}$ remains nonzero at $E_{4}$ because it cannot be a $d_{2^{-}}$or $d_{3}$-boundary. Hence $d_{0} \cdot d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{1}\right)$ is nonzero, which implies that $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)$ is nonzero. The only possible nonzero value is $d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$.

Similarly, $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ follows from $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ by $w_{1^{-}}$and $\alpha \beta$ linearity at $E_{4}$ and the relations $\beta d_{0}=\alpha e_{0}$ and $\alpha d_{0} e_{0}=\beta g w_{1}$. Here $d_{4}\left(\alpha \beta\right.$. $\left.d_{0} e_{0}\right)=\alpha \beta \cdot d_{0} w_{1}^{2}=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(57,18)$ remains nonzero at $E_{4}$ because there is no source for a $d_{2^{-}}$or $d_{3}$-differential that could hit it. Hence $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right) \cdot w_{1}=d_{4}\left(\alpha \beta \cdot d_{0} e_{0}\right)$ is nonzero, which implies that $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right)$ is nonzero. The only possible value is $\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$.

Proposition 5.14. $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g, d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)=g^{2} w_{1}$ and $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ are nonzero.

Proof. We use the relation $\gamma^{2}=\beta^{2} g+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(50,10)$, see Figure 3.14. From Lemma 5.2 and Corollary 5.13 we deduce that $d_{4}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)$ is zero and $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ is nonzero.

If $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$ were zero, then $d_{3}\left(w_{2}\right)=0$ and $d_{4}\left(w_{2}\right)=0$ because these lie in trivial groups, so $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=h_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(w_{2}\right)$ would be zero. This contradiction show that $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)$ is nonzero, and $\alpha \beta g$ is the only possible value.

It follows that $d_{2}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)=h_{1} \cdot \alpha \beta g=0$. If $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)$ were zero, then $d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)$ is defined and lies in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(48,13)$. Multiplication by $h_{1}$ acts trivially on this bidegree, already at $E_{2}$, so $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=h_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)=0$. This is again a contradiction, so $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)$ is nonzero. Since $h_{0} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}=0$ we must have $h_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)=0$ at $E_{3}$, and $g^{2} w_{1}$ is therefore the only possible value. Alternatives involving $h_{0}^{4} w_{2}$ are excluded because $d_{2}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)$ must be $h_{0}$-torsion, hence is zero, so that $h_{0}^{5} w_{2}$ remains nonzero at $E_{3}$.

THEOREM 5.15. The $d_{2}$-differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is $R_{1}$-linear. Table 5.1 gives its values on a list of $R_{1}$-module generators.

Proof. Lemma 5.2, Proposition 5.8 and Proposition 5.14 give the values of $d_{2}$ on the algebra generators of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$. In particular, $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{2^{-}}$ cycles, which gives $R_{1}$-linearity. The $d_{2}$-differentials on the $R_{0}$-module generators $x$ of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$ can then be calculated with the Leibniz rule, using the relations in Table 3.5 to express them in normal form:

- $d_{2}\left(h_{0} \beta\right)=h_{0} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=h_{2}^{2} w_{1}$
- $d_{2}\left(h_{2} \beta\right)=h_{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=h_{0}^{2} e_{0}$

- $d_{2}\left(\alpha d_{0}\right)=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot d_{0}=h_{0} e_{0} w_{1}$
- $d_{2}(\alpha \beta)=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot \beta+\alpha \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=0$
- $d_{2}\left(\alpha e_{0}\right)=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot e_{0}=h_{0} g w_{1}$
- $d_{2}\left(\alpha^{3}\right)=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot \alpha^{2}=h_{0} \alpha \beta w_{1}=h_{1}^{2} \gamma w_{1}$.

The other cases are easier. The $d_{2}$-differentials on the remaining $R_{1}$-module generators $x w_{2}$ are also calculated with the Leibniz rule, in the form

$$
d_{2}\left(x w_{2}\right)=d_{2}(x) w_{2}+x d_{2}(w)=w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)+\alpha \beta g \cdot x
$$

The first summand, $w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)$, can be written down directly. The second summand, $\alpha \beta g \cdot x$, vanishes when $g \in \operatorname{Ann}(x) \subset R_{0}$. In the other cases, we calculate as follows:

- $\alpha \beta g \cdot 1=\alpha \beta g$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha=d_{0} \gamma g$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot d_{0}=\alpha^{2} e_{0} g$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \beta=e_{0} \gamma g$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot e_{0}=\alpha^{2} g^{2}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha^{2}=\alpha d_{0} \gamma g=d_{0} e_{0} g^{2}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \gamma=\alpha g^{3}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha d_{0}=d_{0}^{2} \gamma g=\gamma g^{2} w_{1}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha \beta=\beta d_{0} \gamma g=d_{0} g^{3}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha e_{0}=\alpha^{3} g^{2}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \beta^{2}=e_{0} \beta \gamma g=e_{0} g^{3}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot d_{0} e_{0}=\beta^{2} g^{2} w_{1}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha^{3}=\alpha^{2} d_{0} \gamma g=\beta^{2} \gamma g w_{1}=\beta g^{3} w_{1}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot d_{0} \gamma=\alpha^{2} e_{0} \gamma g=\alpha e_{0}^{2} g^{2}=\alpha d_{0} g^{3}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot \alpha^{2} e_{0}=\alpha^{3} \beta e_{0} g=\beta \gamma g^{2} w_{1}=g^{4} w_{1}$
- $\alpha \beta g \cdot e_{0} \gamma=\alpha e_{0} g^{3}$.

REMARK 5.16. To use ext to assist in the calculation of the products $\alpha \beta g \cdot x$, use cocycle tmf 1018 and dolifts to lift the cocycle $10_{18}$ corresponding to $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g$. The nonzero products $\alpha \beta g \cdot x$ can then be read off from the output of collect.

of $E_{3}(t m f)$, where $\operatorname{Ann}(x) \subset R_{1}$ is the annihilator ideal of $x$. The remaining cases are indicated by a dash $(-)$ in the $\operatorname{Ann}(x)$-column, and the non-cyclic summand that contains $x$ is displayed in Table 5.3.

In this section we determine the $d_{3}$-differentials in $E_{3}(t m f)$. Since $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$ are $d_{3}$-cycles, we know that this differential is $R_{2}$-linear. When $x$ ranges through a set of $R_{1}$-module generators for the $E_{3}$-term, the classes $x$ and $x w_{2}^{2}$ will range through a set of $R_{2}$-module generators for the same $E_{3}$-term, so it will suffice to determine $d_{3}(x)$ and $d_{3}\left(x w_{2}^{2}\right)$ for the generators $x$ in Table 5.2. To do this, we first determine $d_{3}$ on a set of algebra generators for $E_{3}(t m f)$, and then use the Leibniz rule.

Proposition 5.17. A set of 24 algebra generators for $E_{3}(t m f)$ is listed in Table 5.4.

Proof. The remaining $R_{1}$-module generators in Table 5.2 can be expressed as polynomials in these elements. This is evident from their (Gröbner) normal forms at the $E_{2}$-term in almost all cases, and follows from the factorizations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta g^{2} & =\beta^{2} \cdot \gamma \\
\alpha^{3} g+h_{0} w_{1} w_{2} & =\alpha^{2} \cdot \alpha g+w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

in the two remaining cases.

THEOREM 5.18. The $d_{3}$-differential in $E_{3}(t m f)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of algebra generators are as listed in Table 5.4, and its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are as listed in Table 5.2.

Proof. Lemma 5.2 (on $h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}, c_{0}, w_{1}, d_{0}, g, \gamma$ and $\delta$ ), Proposition 5.8 (on $\alpha^{2}$ and $\beta^{2}$ ), Remark 5.9 (on $w_{2}^{2}$ ), Theorem 5.10 (on $e_{0}$ ), Corollary 5.11 (on $\alpha \beta$ ) and Proposition 5.14 (on $h_{1} w_{2}$ ) have already given us the values of $d_{3}$ on many of the algebra generators of $E_{3}(t m f)$.

The $d_{3}$-differentials on $h_{0}^{3} \alpha, \alpha g, h_{0} \alpha^{3}, h_{0} w_{2}, h_{2} w_{2}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}, \delta w_{2}$ and $h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}$ all vanish because the target groups are trivial, already at $E_{2}$, as can be seen from Figures 1.11 to 1.14 .

Only $c_{0} w_{2}$ remains. In the bidegree $(t-s, s)=(55,14)$ of $d_{3}\left(c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ the $E_{2}$-term is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\alpha \beta g w_{1}\right\}$, but $d_{2}\left(w_{1} w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g w_{1}$, so the $E_{3}$-term is trivial in this bidegree. Hence $d_{3}\left(c_{0} w_{2}\right)=0$.

This verifies the formulas for $d_{3}(x)$ with $x$ one of the algebra generators in Table 5.4. We use the Leibniz rule to evaluate $d_{3}(x)$ for the decomposable $R_{1^{-}}$ module generators $x$ in Table 5.2:

- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot e_{0}\right)=d_{0} \cdot c_{0} w_{1}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot \gamma\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot e_{0}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot e_{0}+\alpha^{2} \cdot c_{0} w_{1}=h_{0}^{2} \alpha g w_{1}+h_{0}^{2} \alpha g w_{1}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \gamma\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \gamma=h_{1} \delta w_{1}$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha g\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \alpha g\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha g=0$
- $d_{3}\left(\beta g^{2}\right)=d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot \gamma\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \gamma=0$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot \alpha g+w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha g+0=0$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}\right)=d_{0} \cdot g^{2} w_{1}$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}+e_{0} \cdot g^{2} w_{1}=h_{1} c_{0} w_{1} w_{2}+e_{0} g^{2} w_{1}$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(\gamma \cdot h_{1} w_{2}\right)=\gamma \cdot g^{2} w_{1}$.

The remaining cases follow by $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$and $h_{2^{-}}$linearity, keeping in mind that $h_{0} \delta=$ $h_{0} \alpha g$. For the $R_{2}$-module generators of the form $x w_{2}^{2}$, we use the Leibniz rule in the form

$$
d_{3}\left(x w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{3}(x) w_{2}^{2}+x d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)+\beta g^{4} \cdot x
$$

The first summand is easy to write down in terms of our $R_{2}$-module generators. The second summand vanishes whenever $g^{4} \in \operatorname{Ann}(x) \subset R_{1}$. In the four other cases we can calculate $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ using the known relations in $E_{2}(t m f)$ from Table 3.5, as follows:

- $\beta g^{4} \cdot 1=g^{2} \cdot \beta g^{2}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \gamma=g^{6} \cdot 1$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \beta^{2}=g^{5} \cdot \gamma$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \beta g^{2}=g^{6} \cdot \beta^{2}$.

REMARK 5.19. We can use ext to aid in the calculation of the products $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ by using cocycle tmf 1956 and dolifts to calculate all products with the cocycle $19_{56}$ (which corresponds to $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)=\beta g^{4}$ ). The nonzero products $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ can then be read off from the output of collect.

# 5.4. The $d_{4}$-differentials for $t m f$

The Adams bidegree $(t-s, s)$ and ext-index $g$ of each $R_{2}$-module generator $x$ is shown as before. In most cases, $x$ generates a cyclic summand

$$
\langle x\rangle \cong \Sigma^{s, t} R_{2} / \operatorname{Ann}(x)
$$

of $E_{4}(t m f)$, where now $\operatorname{Ann}(x) \subset R_{2}$. The remaining cases are indicated by a dash $(-)$ in the $\operatorname{Ann}(x)$-column, and the non-cyclic summand that contains $x$ is displayed in Table 5.6.

Proposition 5.21. The following classes are $d_{4}$-cycles:
(1) $h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}, c_{0}, w_{1}, d_{0}, g$ and $\gamma$.
(2) $h_{0}^{3} \alpha, h_{0} \alpha^{2}, \alpha \beta, h_{0} \alpha^{3}, c_{0} w_{2}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}, w_{1} w_{2}^{2}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}^{2}, d_{0} w_{2}^{2}, \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$.
(3) $\delta, \alpha g, \delta w_{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}, h_{0} w_{2}^{2}, h_{2} w_{2}^{2}, c_{0} w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{2}, \delta w_{2}^{2}, \alpha g w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{2}$, $c_{0} w_{2}^{3}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}^{3}$ and $h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{3}$.
(4) $h_{2} w_{2}, h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ and $\delta w_{2}^{3}$.

Proof. (1) We proved that $d_{4}(x)=0$ for $x=h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}, c_{0}, w_{1}, d_{0}, g$ and $\gamma$ in Lemma 5.2.
(2) By inspection of Figures 1.11 to 1.18 we see that $d_{4}(x)=0$ for $x=h_{0}^{3} \alpha$, $h_{0} \alpha^{2}, \alpha \beta, h_{0} \alpha^{3}, c_{0} w_{2}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}, w_{1} w_{2}^{2}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}^{2}, d_{0} w_{2}^{2}, \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$, because the target groups are trivial at the $E_{2}$-term.
(3) We can read off from Table 5.1 that $d_{4}(x)=0$ for $x=\delta, \alpha g, \delta w_{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}$, $h_{0} w_{2}^{2}, h_{2} w_{2}^{2}, c_{0} w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{2}, \delta w_{2}^{2}, \alpha g w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{2}, c_{0} w_{2}^{3}, h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}^{3}$ and $h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{3}$, because the target groups become trivial at the $E_{3}$-term:

- For $x=\delta$, and for $x=\alpha g$, the $E_{2}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}(x)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta\right\}$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta\right)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0} \neq 0$.
- For $x=\delta w_{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$. $e_{0} \gamma+w_{1}^{2} w_{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0} \neq 0$.

- For $x=h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta$.
- For $x=h_{0} w_{2}^{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \gamma w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \gamma w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{3} w_{1} \cdot \alpha d_{0} \neq 0$.
- For $x=h_{2} w_{2}^{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{3} w_{1} \cdot \alpha e_{0} \neq 0$.
- For $x=c_{0} w_{2}^{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{4} w_{1} \cdot \beta\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g \cdot \alpha^{3} w_{2}\right)=g^{4} w_{1} \cdot$ $\beta+g w_{1} w_{2} \cdot h_{1}^{2} \gamma=g^{4} w_{1} \cdot \beta$.
- For $x=h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{3} w_{1}^{2} \cdot e_{0} \gamma+g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=g^{3} w_{1}^{2} \cdot e_{0} \gamma \neq 0$.
- For $x=\delta w_{2}^{2}$, and for $x=\alpha g w_{2}^{2}$, the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \beta\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \beta\right)=w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0} \neq 0$.
- For $x=h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{2}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{5} w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} \neq 0$.
- For $x=c_{0} w_{2}^{3}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{4} w_{1} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g^{4} w_{1} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{5} w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma+g^{4} w_{1} w_{2} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=g^{5} w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma \neq 0$.
- For $x=h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}^{3}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{6} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \beta\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g^{5} w_{1} \cdot w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{6} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \beta$.
- For $x=h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{3}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta\right\}$ at $E_{2}$, and $d_{2}\left(g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot w_{2}\right)=$ $g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \alpha \beta$.
(4) Similarly, we see from Table 5.2 that $d_{4}(x)=0$ for $x=h_{2} w_{2}, h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ and $\delta w_{2}^{3}$, because the target groups become trivial at the $E_{4}$-term:
- For $x=h_{2} w_{2}$ the $E_{2}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}(x)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma\right\}$, and $d_{3}\left(w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \gamma\right)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot h_{1} \delta \neq 0$
- For $x=h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot e_{0} \gamma\right\}$ at $E_{2}$ and $E_{3}$, and $d_{3}\left(w_{1}\right.$. $\left.e_{0} \gamma w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot h_{1} \delta \neq 0$
- For $x=\delta w_{2}^{3}$ the target is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{8} \cdot \beta, w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right\}$ at $E_{2}$. Here $d_{2}\left(g^{8} \cdot \beta\right)=$ $g^{8} \cdot h_{0} d_{0}=0$ and $d_{2}\left(w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \beta w_{2}\right)=g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot e_{0} \gamma+w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3} \cdot h_{0} d_{0} \neq 0$. Hence the target at $E_{3}$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g^{6} \cdot \beta g^{2}\right\}$, and $d_{3}\left(g^{4} \cdot w_{2}^{2}\right)=g^{6} \cdot \beta g^{2}$.


# Proposition 5.22. 

(1) $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$.
(2) $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$.
(3) $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$.
(4) $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g\right)=\alpha \beta w_{1}^{2}$.
(5) $d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}\right)=d_{0} \gamma w_{1}$.
(6) $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)=(\delta+\alpha g) w_{1}^{2}=\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2}$.
(7) $d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2}\right)=\alpha d_{0} g w_{1}$.
(8) $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)=0$.
(9) $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)=0$.
(10) $d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$.
(11) $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$.
(12) $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$.
(13) $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=\alpha \beta w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$.
(14) $d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)=d_{0} \gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$.
(15) $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=(\delta+\alpha g) w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}=\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$.
(16) $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$.

Proof. The differentials on $x=d_{0} e_{0}, e_{0} g$ and $h_{1}^{2} w_{2}$ have already been identified. For $x=\alpha^{2} g, h_{0} w_{2}, \alpha e_{0} g$ and $\beta g^{2}$ we use multiplicative relations in the Adams spectral sequence to determine $d_{4}(x)$. For $x=h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}$ and $h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{3}$ we use $d_{4} \circ d_{4}=0$ to show that $d_{4}(x)=0$. Finally, for the remaining classes $x=h_{1} w_{2}^{2}$, $d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}, e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}, \alpha^{2} g w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} w_{2}^{3}, \alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}$ and $h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}$ we use $w_{1}$ - and $w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$-linearity to determine $d_{4}(x)$. In many cases we (implicitly) refer to Table 5.5 to determine whether a class is nonzero at $E_{4}$.
(1)-(3) We know that $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$ by Theorem 5.12, $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ by Corollary 5.13, and $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ by Proposition 5.14.
(4) From $d_{4}\left(w_{1}\right)=0, d_{4}\left(d_{0}\right)=0, d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ (by Corollary 5.13) and the relation

$$
d_{0} \cdot \alpha^{2} g=w_{1} \cdot \beta^{2} g
$$

we deduce that $d_{0} \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g\right)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha^{2} e_{0}$. A glance at Table 5.5 shows that this is nonzero at $E_{4}$, because $w_{1}^{2}$ is not in the annihilator ideal of $\alpha^{2} e_{0}$. Hence $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g\right) \neq 0$, and $\alpha \beta w_{1}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(5) From $d_{4}(\gamma)=0, d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ and the relation

$$
\gamma \cdot d_{0} e_{0}=\alpha^{3} g
$$

we deduce that $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{3} g\right)=d_{0} \gamma w_{1}^{2}$. From the differential

$$
d_{2}\left(\alpha e_{0} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{3} g^{2}+h_{0} g w_{1} w_{2}
$$

we know that $g \cdot \alpha^{3} g=g w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}$ at the $E_{4}$-term. Hence $g w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}\right)=$ $g \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha^{3} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} \gamma$, which is nonzero at $E_{4}$ (by Table 5.6). Thus $d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}\right) \neq 0$, and $d_{0} \gamma w_{1}$ is the only possible value.
(6) The ( $E_{2}$ - and) $E_{4}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\delta w_{1}^{2}, \alpha g w_{1}^{2}, h_{0}^{7} w_{2}\right\}$. Multiplication by $h_{0}$ annihilates only the subgroup $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2}\right\}$, where $\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2}=\delta w_{1}^{2}+$ $\alpha g w_{1}^{2}$. From $d_{4}(g)=0, d_{4}(\alpha g)=0, d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$ and the factorization

$$
g \cdot \alpha e_{0} g=\alpha g \cdot e_{0} g
$$

we deduce that $g \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)=\alpha g \cdot d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=\alpha g^{2} w_{1}^{2} \neq 0$. Furthermore, $h_{0} \cdot \alpha e_{0} g=0$. Hence $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)$ is nonzero and $h_{0}$-annihilated, leaving $\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2}$ as the only possible value.
(7) From $d_{4}(g)=0, d_{4}(\gamma)=0, d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ and the relation

$$
\gamma^{3}=g \cdot \beta g^{2}+\gamma \cdot h_{1}^{2} w_{2}
$$

we deduce that $g \cdot d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2}\right)=\gamma \cdot \alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}=g w_{1} \cdot \alpha d_{0} g \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. Hence $d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2}\right)$ is nonzero, and $\alpha d_{0} g w_{1}$ is the only possible value.
(8) The ( $E_{2}$ - and) $E_{4}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2}\right\}$, and

$$
d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2}\right)=w_{1}^{3} \cdot \alpha d_{0} g \neq 0
$$

by the previous case. We cannot have $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)=\beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2}$, because $d_{4} \circ d_{4}=0$. Hence $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)=0$.
(9) The ( $E_{2}$ - and) $E_{4}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$, and

$$
d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1}^{3} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \alpha d_{0} g \neq 0
$$

Hence $d_{4} \circ d_{4}=0$ implies $d_{4}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right) \neq \beta g^{2} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$, leaving 0 as the only possible value.
(10) The $E_{2}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\alpha^{3} g^{3}, h_{0}^{5} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$, and

$$
d_{2}\left(g \cdot \alpha e_{0} w_{2}\right)=g \cdot\left(\alpha^{3} g^{2}+h_{0} g w_{1} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{3} g^{3}
$$

so the target $E_{4}$-term is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{h_{0}^{5} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$. We have $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(w_{1} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=$ $d_{4}\left(w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot h_{1}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{1}\right)=0$, since $w_{1}$ and $w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{4}$-cycles. Furthermore, $w_{1} \cdot h_{0}^{3} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$, so $d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$.
(11) From $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=$ $w_{1}^{3} \cdot d_{0} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. It follows that $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is nonzero, and $d_{0} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(12) The $E_{2}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{h_{0}^{3} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{2}, g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$, which equals the $E_{4}$-term in this bidegree. From $h_{0} \cdot h_{0}^{3} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ and

$$
h_{0} \cdot g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}=d_{2}\left(w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \alpha e_{0}\right)
$$

we see that multiplication by $h_{0}$ annihilates only the subgroup $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ of the $E_{4}$-term. From $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=g w_{1}^{2}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(e_{0} g\right)=$ $g w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. Furthermore, $h_{0} \cdot e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}=0$. Hence $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is nonzero and $h_{0}$-annihilated, and $g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(13) From $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g\right)=\alpha \beta w_{1}^{2}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g\right)=$ $w_{1}^{3} \cdot \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. It follows that $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is nonzero, and $\alpha \beta w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(14) From $d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}\right)=d_{0} \gamma w_{1}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}\right)=$ $w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} \gamma w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. It follows that $d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)$ is nonzero, and $d_{0} \gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(15) The $E_{2}$-term in the bidegree of $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\delta w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}, \alpha g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}, h_{0}^{7} w_{2}^{3}\right\}$. At the $E_{4}$-term, multiplication by $h_{0}$ annihilates only the subgroup $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left\{\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right\}$. From $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)=\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)=$ $\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{3} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. Furthermore, $h_{0} \cdot \alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}=0$. Hence $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{3}\right)$ is nonzero and $h_{0}$-annihilated, and $\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.
(16) From $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$ we deduce that $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)=w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=$ $w_{1}^{2} \cdot \alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$. It follows that $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)$ is nonzero, and $\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ is the only possible value.

THEOREM 5.23. The $d_{4}$-differential in $E_{4}(t m f)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of algebra generators are as listed in Table 5.7, and its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are as listed in Table 5.5.

Proof. The first two claims follow from Propositions 5.21 and 5.22. As before, the Leibniz rule lets us calculate $d_{4}(x)$ for the remaining $R_{2}$-module generators $x$, using the factorizations given in the proof of Proposition 5.20:

- $d_{4}\left(h_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{4}\left(h_{2} \cdot d_{0}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot \gamma\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} e_{0}\right)=d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha \beta\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha g\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g\right)=d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot \gamma+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)=0+\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}$
- $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{3} g+h_{0} w_{1} w_{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot d_{0} e_{0}+w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}\right)=\gamma \cdot d_{0} w_{1}^{2}+w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \gamma w_{1}=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \delta^{\prime}\right)=d_{4}(\gamma \cdot(\delta+\alpha g))=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot e_{0} g\right)=\gamma \cdot g w_{1}^{2}$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot h_{2} w_{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma^{3}\right)=0 \cdot \gamma^{2}=0$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(h_{2} \cdot d_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot d_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$

- $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha g w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{3} g w_{2}^{2}+h_{0} w_{1} w_{2}^{3}\right)=d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2}+w_{1} \cdot h_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)=\gamma \cdot d_{0} w_{1}^{3} w_{2}^{2}+w_{1}$. $d_{0} \gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot\left(\delta w_{2}^{2}+\alpha g w_{2}^{2}\right)\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\beta^{2} g \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=\gamma \cdot g w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2}$
- $d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2} \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=\alpha d_{0} g w_{1} \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)=d_{4}\left(d_{0} \cdot h_{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma \cdot h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right)=\gamma \cdot \alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}=\alpha e_{0}^{2} g w_{1} w_{2}^{2}=\alpha d_{0} g^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$.

The other cases follow easily by $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$and $h_{2^{-}}$-linearity.

# 5.5. The $E_{\infty}$-term for $t m f$ 

Given Theorem 5.23, it is elementary to calculate $E_{5}(t m f)$ as an $R_{2}$-module. The details are given in Appendix A.3, and with two minor modifications, explained in Remark 5.24, the results are recorded in Table 5.8. The non-cyclic summands are displayed in Table 5.9. We note that the $E_{5}$-term is free over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{2}^{4}\right]$ and finitely generated over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$. The class $g$ is nilpotent, with $g^{6}=0$.

REMARK 5.24. We rewrite the direct sum

$$
\left\langle e_{0} g^{2}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle\gamma \delta^{\prime}\right\rangle \cong R_{2} /(g) \oplus R_{2} /\left(g, w_{1}\right)
$$

as

$$

This makes the $h_{1}$-multiplication from $(t-s, s)=(56,11)$ easier to display, since $h_{1} \cdot c_{0} w_{1}=h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}$. Likewise, we rewrite the direct sum

$$

$$

as

$$
\left\langle\gamma \delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right\rangle \cong R_{2} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \oplus R_{2} /(g)
$$

Theorem 5.27. $E_{5}(t m f)=E_{\infty}(t m f)$.
Proof. To prove that the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ collapses at the $E_{5}$-term, we show that each algebra generator $x$ listed in Table 5.10 is an infinite cycle, i.e., that $d_{r}(x)=0$ for each $r \geq 5$. For most of these algebra generators all possible target groups are trivial, as can be seen by inspection of Figures 5.1 to 5.8 and 0.8 .

The remaining eight cases are $x=h_{1}, \gamma, \alpha \beta, h_{2} w_{2}, h_{1} w_{2}^{2}, h_{2} w_{2}^{2}, \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2}$ and $h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$. All differentials on $h_{1}$ and $\gamma$ vanish by $h_{0}$-linearity. All differentials on $h_{2} w_{2}^{2}$ vanish by $w_{1}$-linearity, since $w_{1} \cdot d_{r}\left(h_{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)=d_{r}\left(w_{1} \cdot h_{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$. This can only happen if $d_{r}\left(h_{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$, because $w_{1}$ acts injectively on $E_{5}^{s, t}(t m f)$ in all bidegrees with $t-s=98$, and no intermediate differentials can change this. Similarly, all differentials on $\alpha \beta, h_{2} w_{2}, \alpha \beta w_{2}^{2}$ and $h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ vanish by $w_{1}^{2}$-linearity.

Finally, all differentials vanish on $h_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ by $w_{1}$-linearity, since $w_{1} \cdot d_{r}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=$ $h_{1} \cdot d_{r}\left(w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$. Again, this can only happen if $d_{r}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)=0$, because $w_{1}$ acts injectively on $E_{5}^{s, t}(t m f)$ for $t-s=96$ and no earlier differentials can intervene.

Our discussion of the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ continues in Chapter 9, where we determine the additive and multiplicative extensions involved in the passage from $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ to $\pi_{*}(t m f)$.

# CHAPTER 6 

## The Adams spectral sequence for $t m f / 2$

We calculate the $d_{r}$-differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2=$ $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C 2$. These are nontrivial for $r \in\{2,3,4\}$, and zero for $r \geq 5$, so the spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{5}$-term. The module structure over the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ suffices to determine all of these differentials. The resulting $E_{\infty}{ }^{-}$ term is the associated graded of a degreewise finite length filtration of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$.

### 6.1. The $E_{2}$-term for $t m f / 2$

The initial term

$$
E_{2}=E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{1}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

of the $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ was calculated in Part I. The groups $E_{2}^{s, t}$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 96$ are displayed in Figures 1.24 to 1.27. By Corollary 4.3 the $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ is generated as a module over $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ by the eleven classes listed in Table 6.1. As a module over $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$, the $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ is presented in Tables 6.2 and 6.3 as a direct sum of cyclic modules, together with one non-cyclic module, and illustrated in Figure 4.1. Most entries in these tables are reproduced from Tables 4.2 and 4.3, but the information about $d_{2}$-differentials will be obtained in the next section. We note that the $E_{2^{-}}$ term is free over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{2}\right]$, but not over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$, and is finitely generated over $R_{0}$. Following the strategy of Chapter 5 we will keep track of $R_{0}$-module structure on the $E_{2}$-term, $R_{1}$-module structure on the $E_{3}$-term, and $R_{2}$-module structure on the $E_{4^{-}}$and $E_{5}=E_{\infty}$-terms of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$. Here $R_{1}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2}\right]$ and $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$, as introduced in Definition 5.1.

# 6.2. The $d_{2}$-differentials for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ 

To determine the $d_{2}$-differentials for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$, we use the following preliminary estimate. See Figures 1.25, 1.26 and 4.1.

Lemma 6.1. If $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=i\left(\beta w_{1}^{2}\right)$ then $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left((\delta+\alpha g) w_{1}\right)=i\left(\delta^{\prime} w_{1}\right)$. Otherwise, $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=0$ and $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta w_{1}\right)$.

Proof. From $w_{1} \cdot \beta \widetilde{\gamma}=12_{14}=e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}$ with $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$ and $d_{3}\left(w_{1}\right)=0$ we get $w_{1} \cdot d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}+e_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)$. Here $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}=15_{9}=i\left(\delta w_{1}^{2}\right)$. Note that $E_{2}=E_{3}$ in the bidegree generated by $15_{8}$ and $15_{9}$.

If $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=i\left(\beta w_{1}^{2}\right)$ then $e_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=i\left(\beta e_{0} w_{1}^{2}\right)=i\left(\alpha g w_{1}^{2}\right)=15_{8}$, and $w_{1} \cdot d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta w_{1}^{2}\right)+i\left(\alpha g w_{1}^{2}\right)=15_{9}+15_{8}$. This implies $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta w_{1}\right)+$ $i\left(\alpha g w_{1}\right)=11_{9}+11_{8}$.

Otherwise, $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=0$, so $e_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=0$ and $w_{1} \cdot d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta w_{1}^{2}\right)=15_{9}$. This implies $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta w_{1}\right)=11_{9}$.

THEOREM 6.2. The $d_{2}$-differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is $R_{1}$-linear. Its values on a set of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators are listed in Table 6.1, and its values on a set of $R_{1}$-module generators are listed in Table 6.2.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{2}$-cycles in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$, so the Leibniz rule implies that multiplication by each of these elements commutes with the $d_{2^{-}}$ differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$. Hence $d_{2}$ is $R_{1}$-linear.

The $d_{2}$-differentials on the $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators $i(1), \widetilde{h_{1}}, \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}, \widetilde{c_{0}}, \widetilde{\gamma}, \widetilde{\beta^{2}}$, $\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}$ and $\widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ are zero because the target groups are trivial.

The $d_{3}$-differential $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$ in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$ (see Table 5.2) implies $d_{3}\left(i\left(e_{0}\right)\right)=$ $i\left(c_{0} w_{1}\right)$ in $E_{3}=E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$, by naturality with respect to $i$. Here $i\left(h_{1} e_{0}\right)=0$, so $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}\right)=0$ at $E_{3}$. Since $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}\right) \neq 0$ at $E_{2}$, we must have $d_{2}(x)=i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}\right)$ for some nonzero $x$. The only possibility is $x=\widetilde{h_{0}^{2} e_{0}}$.

The $d_{2}$-boundary $d_{2}(\widetilde{\beta g})$ maps by $j$ to $d_{2}(\beta g)=h_{0} d_{0} g \neq 0$ in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$, using Table 5.1. Hence $d_{2}(\widetilde{\beta g})$ is nonzero, and $h_{1}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ is the only possible value.

To determine $d_{2}\left(\widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}\right)$ we use Lemma 6.1, showing that $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta^{\prime} w_{1}\right)$ or $i\left(\delta w_{1}\right)$. From $h_{1} \cdot \beta \widetilde{\gamma}=0$ and $h_{1} \delta^{\prime}=h_{1} \delta$ we deduce that $0=d_{3}\left(h_{1} \cdot \beta \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=$ $h_{1} \cdot d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{1}\right)$ at $E_{3}$. But $i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{1}\right) \neq 0$ at $E_{2}$, so $i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{1}\right)=d_{2}(y)$ for some nonzero $y$. The only possibility is $y=\widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}$.

We use Table 5.1 and the Leibniz rule to calculate $d_{2}(x)$ for $x$ ranging through the $R_{0}$-module generators for $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ listed in Table 6.2. The less obvious cases are:

- $d_{2}(\alpha \cdot \widetilde{\gamma})=h_{2} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=0$
- $d_{2}(\beta \cdot \widetilde{\gamma})=h_{0} d_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=0$
- $d_{2}\left(d_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\beta g}\right)=d_{0} \cdot h_{1}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=0$.

The vanishing of these products is readily seen in Figure 4.1.
To finish the proof we calculate $d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)=\alpha \beta g \cdot x+$ $w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)$, for the same generators $x$, so that $x w_{2}$ ranges through the remaining $R_{1^{-}}$ module generators for $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$. This is easy when $g \in \operatorname{Ann}(x)$. Proposition 6.5. The $d_{3}$-differentials on the $E_{3}(t m f)$-module generators of $E_{3}(t m f / 2)$ are as listed in Table 6.6.

Proof. The target groups of $d_{3}$ on $i(1), \widetilde{h_{1}}, \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}, \widetilde{c_{0}}, i(\beta)$ are trivial.
Since $d_{3} \circ d_{3}=0$ and $d_{3}\left(i\left(e_{0} w_{1}\right)\right)=i\left(c_{0} w_{1}^{2}\right) \neq 0$, we cannot have $d_{3}(\widetilde{\gamma})=$ $i\left(e_{0} w_{1}\right)$. The only alternative is $d_{3}(\widetilde{\gamma})=0$.

The $d_{3}$-boundary $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)$ maps by $j$ to $d_{3}\left(\beta^{2}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \neq 0$ in $E_{3}(t m f)$, so $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right) \neq 0$ and $g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}$ is the only possible value.

To determine $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)$ we use the relation $\beta^{2} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}=14_{22}=d_{0} e_{0} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}$. We find that $d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}+\beta^{2} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=\beta^{2} d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)$ since $h_{1}$ annihilates $E_{2}(t m f / 2)$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(60,16)$. This must equal $d_{3}\left(d_{0} e_{0} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{0} e_{0}$. $g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}=17_{15}=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot i(\gamma) \neq 0$. Therefore $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)$ is nonzero, and $i\left(\beta w_{1}^{2}\right)$ is the only possible value.

Lemma 6.1 then shows that $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta^{\prime} w_{1}\right)$.
From the relation $e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=11_{16}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$ and the differentials $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$, $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}$ and $d_{3}(\widetilde{\gamma})=0$ we obtain $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}+e_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$. Here $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=0$ and $h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=0$, so $e_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(\widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=0$. On the other hand, $e_{0} \cdot i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{1}\right)=i\left(\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}\right)=14_{11} \neq 0$ cannot be a $d_{2}$-boundary, hence remains nonzero at $E_{3}(t m f / 2)$. Thus $d_{3}\left(\widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right) \neq i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{1}\right)$, and 0 is the only possible value.

From the relation $e_{0} \cdot \alpha \widetilde{\gamma}=12_{18}=d_{0} \cdot \beta \widetilde{\gamma}$ and the differentials $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$, $d_{3}\left(d_{0}\right)=0$ and $d_{3}(\beta \widetilde{\gamma})=i\left(\delta^{\prime} w_{1}\right)$ we deduce that $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \widetilde{\gamma}+e_{0} \cdot d_{3}(\alpha \widetilde{\gamma})=d_{0} \cdot i\left(\delta^{\prime} w_{1}\right)=$ $i\left(\alpha d_{0} g w_{1}\right)=15_{13}$. Here $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \widetilde{\gamma}=0$, so $e_{0} \cdot d_{3}(\alpha \widetilde{\gamma})=15_{13} \neq 0$ at $E_{2}(t m f / 2)$. This class is not a $d_{2}$-boundary, hence remains nonzero at $E_{3}(t m f / 2)$, so $d_{3}(\alpha \widetilde{\gamma}) \neq 0$. The only possible value is $g w_{1} \widetilde{c_{0}}$.

THEOREM 6.6. The $d_{3}$-differential in $E_{3}(t m f / 2)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are listed in Table 6.4.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$ are $d_{3}$-cycles in $E_{3}(t m f)$, so the Leibniz rule implies that multiplication by each of these elements commutes with the $d_{3^{-}}$ differential in $E_{3}(t m f / 2)$. Hence $d_{3}$ is $R_{2}$-linear.

The $d_{3}$-differential on the $R_{1}$-module generators $x$ in Table 6.4 is given by the Leibniz rule applied to the (implicit and explicit) factorizations in the proof of Proposition 6.4, and the $d_{3}$-differentials from Tables 5.2 and 6.6. The less obvious cases are:

- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}=8_{2}=w_{1} \cdot h_{1} \widetilde{c_{0}}$
- $d_{3}\left(i\left(\alpha^{2}\right)\right)=i\left(h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}\right)=0$

- $d_{3}\left(i\left(\alpha d_{0}\right)\right)=d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{c_{0}}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{c_{0}}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(i\left(\beta^{2}\right)\right)=i\left(h_{1} g w_{1}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=h_{1} \cdot i\left(\beta w_{1}^{2}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=12_{10}=h_{1} w_{1} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}+e_{0} \cdot g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}=0+e_{0} g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \widetilde{\beta g}\right)=d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}+\alpha^{2} \cdot g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}=0+15_{13}=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(\alpha d_{0}\right)$
- $d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{c_{0}}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{c_{0}}=0$ at $E_{3}$
- $d_{3}\left(g \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}\right)=d_{3}\left(d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{0} e_{0} \cdot g w_{1} \widetilde{h_{1}}=17_{15}=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot i(\gamma)$
- $d_{3}\left(i\left(h_{1} \gamma w_{2}\right)\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot i(\gamma)=0$ at $E_{3}$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}+h_{1} w_{2} \cdot i\left(\beta w_{1}^{2}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=0$ at $E_{3}$.

It remains to determine $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)=\beta g^{4} \cdot x+w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)$ for the same generators $x$. This is easy when $g^{4} \in \operatorname{Ann}(x)$. In the other cases we use ext to calculate the product $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ and to present it in terms of our $R_{2}$-module generators for $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ :

- $\beta g^{4} \cdot i(\gamma)=24_{73}=g^{6} \cdot i(1)$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot i\left(\beta^{2}\right)=25_{78}=g^{5} \cdot i(\gamma)$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}=25_{80}=g^{5} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \beta^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}=30_{110}=g^{6} \cdot \widetilde{\beta^{2}}$.

REMARK 6.7. To calculate the products $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ with ext, use cocycle, dolifts and collect as in Remark 6.3. The nonzero products with $\beta g^{4}=19_{56}$ then appear as lines containing ( 1956 F 2 ) in the file all. If the product is a $g^{5}$-multiple, there will also appear a line containing ( 2067 F 2 ) in the same block, since $g^{5}=20_{67}$ in the minimal $A(2)$-module resolution for $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. Similarly, $g^{6}$-multiples appear with (24 90 F2).

# 6.4. The $d_{4}$-differentials for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ 

The calculation of $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ as the homology of $\left(E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2), d_{3}\right)$ is carried out in Appendix B. 2 and the results are recorded in Tables 6.7 and 6.8.

At this stage of the calculation it is convenient to change generators in order to simplify the calculation of the next stage of the spectral sequence and to give more informative or convenient names for some of the elements. This happens in bidegrees $(58,12)$ and $(154,28)$, where we change basis and also change names of elements. In bidegrees $(51,10)$ and $(81,16)$ we simply change the names of the generators.

In bidegree $(t-s, s)=(58,12)$, we will replace $\alpha g \widetilde{\gamma}=12_{22}$ by $\delta^{\prime} \widetilde{\gamma}=12_{22}+$ $12_{23}=(\alpha g+\delta) \widetilde{\gamma}$ so that the differential $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \delta^{\prime} \widetilde{\gamma}$ is simply a map between cyclic summands. We treat its $w_{2}^{2}$-multiple in $(t-s, s)=(154,28)$ similarly: we replace $\alpha g w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}=28_{116}$ by $\delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}=28_{116}+28_{117}=(\alpha g+\delta) w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$.

It is then also convenient to change the names of $h_{1} w_{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}=12_{23}=\delta \widetilde{\gamma}$ and $h_{1} w_{2}^{3} \widetilde{c_{0}}=28_{117}=\delta w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$.

As in Appendix B.2, in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(51,10)$ we use the relation $\gamma \widetilde{\gamma}=$ $g \widetilde{\beta^{2}}+h_{1} w_{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}$ to replace the latter expression. In bidegree $(t-s, s)=(81,16)$ we use the relation $\gamma^{2} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}=\beta g^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}+i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)$ to replace the latter sum.

Proposition 6.9. The $d_{4}$-differentials on the $E_{4}(t m f)$-module generators of $E_{4}(t m f / 2)$ are as given in Table 6.9.

Proof. For $x \in\left\{i(1), \widetilde{h_{1}}, \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}, \widetilde{c_{0}}, i(\beta), \widetilde{\gamma}, \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right\}$ the bidegree of $d_{4}(x)$ is zero at $E_{2}$.
For $x=w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}, x=w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ and $x=w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$ the target of $d_{4}$ on $x$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $21_{47}=g^{2} d_{0} e_{0} \widetilde{\gamma}=d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{\beta g}\right), 22_{51}=g^{3} \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}=d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot \alpha^{2} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)$ and $23_{51}=g^{3} w_{1} \widetilde{\beta g}=d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot d_{0} e_{0} \widetilde{\gamma}\right)$, respectively. For $x=w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$, the target is generated at $E_{2}$ by $y=27_{77}=i\left(\alpha g^{3} w_{1} w_{2}\right)$, and $d_{2}(y)=g^{5} w_{1} \cdot e_{0} \widetilde{h_{1}} \neq 0$. Hence the target is zero at $E_{3}$ for $x \in\left\{w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}, w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}, w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}, w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right\}$.

The remaining differentials are consequences of the differential $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2}$ in $E_{4}(t m f)$, cf. Corollary 5.13 , or of naturality with respect to $j: \operatorname{tmf} / 2 \rightarrow \Sigma \operatorname{tmf}$, as we now show.

For $x=i\left(\alpha^{2}\right)$ the relation $d_{0} \cdot x=10_{9}=d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$, verified by ext, gives $d_{0} \cdot d_{4}(x)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$, so $d_{4}(x) \neq 0$ and $10_{2}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ is the only possible value.

For $x=i\left(\alpha d_{0}\right)$ the relation $\gamma \cdot x=12_{15}=i\left(d_{0} e_{0} g\right)$, verified by ext, gives $\gamma \cdot d_{4}(x)=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot i\left(d_{0}\right) \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$, so $d_{4}(x) \neq 0$ and $11_{2}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{c_{0}}$ is the only possible value.

For $x=i\left(\beta^{2}\right)$ the relation $w_{1} \cdot x=10_{9}=d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$, verified by ext, gives $w_{1} \cdot d_{4}(x)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}} \neq 0$ at $E_{4}$, so $d_{4}(x) \neq 0$ and $10_{4}=w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ is the only possible value.

For $x=d_{0} \widetilde{\beta g}$ naturality with respect to $j$, and $j(x)=d_{0} \cdot \beta g=\alpha e_{0} g$, show that $d_{4}(x)$ maps by $j$ to $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g\right)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \delta^{\prime} \neq 0$, so $d_{4}(x)=15_{10}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ is the only possibility.

For $x=\beta^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$ naturality with respect to $j$, and $j(x)=\beta^{2} \gamma=\beta g^{2}$, show that $d_{4}(x)$ maps to $d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2}\right)=w_{1} \cdot \alpha d_{0} g \neq 0$, and $d_{4}(x)=15_{14}=w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ is the only possibility.

For $x=i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)$ the target bidegree of $d_{4}$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $26_{65}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ and $26_{66}=g^{4} w_{1} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}=d_{2}\left(g^{2} \cdot w_{2} d_{0} e_{0}\right)$. Hence $w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ is the only nonzero class at $E_{3}$ and $E_{4}$. The relation $d_{0} \cdot x=d_{0} e_{0} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ gives $d_{0} \cdot d_{4}(x)=w_{1}^{2} \cdot d_{0} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}} \neq 0$, so $d_{4}(x)=26_{65}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$

For $x=i\left(\alpha d_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right)$ the target bidegree of $d_{4}$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $27_{65}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$ and $27_{66}=g^{4} w_{1} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}=d_{2}\left(g^{2} w_{1} \cdot w_{2} \widetilde{\gamma}\right)$. Hence $w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$ is the only nonzero class at $E_{3}$ and $E_{4}$. The relation $\gamma \cdot x=i\left(d_{0} e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)$ gives $\gamma \cdot d_{4}(x)=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot i\left(d_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right) \neq 0$, so $d_{4}(x)=27_{65}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$

For $x=d_{0} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\beta g}$ the target bidegree of $d_{4}$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $31_{94}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ and $y=31_{95}=g^{4} w_{1} \cdot w_{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$. Here $d_{2}(y)=g^{6} w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{h_{1}} \neq 0$. Hence $w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ is the only nonzero class at $E_{3}$ and $E_{4}$. Naturality with respect to $j$, and $j(x)=$ $d_{0} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \beta g=\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}$, show that $d_{4}(x)$ maps to $d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}\right)=\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$, which implies that $d_{4}(x)=31_{94}=w_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$.

THEOREM 6.10. The $d_{4}$-differential in $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are listed in Table 6.7.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$ are $d_{4}$-cycles in $E_{4}(t m f)$, so multiplication by each of these commutes with the $d_{4}$-differential in $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$.

The $d_{4}$-differential on the $E_{4}(t m f)$-module generators was computed in Proposition 6.9. The Leibniz rule then gives the value of $d_{4}$ on the remaining elements in terms of $E_{4}(t m f)$-multiples of the $R_{2}$-module generators. We use ext to rewrite these as $R_{2}$-multiples of the $R_{2}$-module generators, leaving out some straightforward cases:

- $d_{4}\left(i\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right)\right)=i\left(\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1}\right)=14_{11}=g w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}=15_{11}=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot i(\beta)=0$ at $E_{4}$
- $d_{4}\left(d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=d_{0} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$

- $d_{4}\left(e_{0} g \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=g w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$
- $d_{4}\left(d_{0} g \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{4}\left(\delta^{\prime} \cdot \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{2} w_{2} \cdot i(\beta)\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{1} g w_{2}\right)=d_{4}\left(h_{2}^{2} w_{2} \cdot i(\beta)\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(g^{2} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=d_{4}\left(\alpha d_{0} g \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=0$
- $d_{4}\left(i\left(h_{1} \gamma w_{2}\right)\right)=d_{4}\left(h_{0} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=d_{0} \gamma w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=18_{25}=w_{1} \cdot d_{0} g \widetilde{\beta^{2}}$
- $d_{4}\left(\alpha^{2} g \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{4}\left(\alpha e_{0} g \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=\delta^{\prime} w_{1}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}$
- $d_{4}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}\right)=\alpha^{2} e_{0} w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}=19_{25}=g w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$
- $d_{4}\left(\gamma^{2} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{4}\left(\beta g^{2} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}+i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)\right)=\alpha d_{0} g w_{1} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}+0=20_{28}=w_{1} \cdot g^{2} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}=0$ at $E_{4}$

- $d_{4}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}}\right)=d_{4}\left(i\left(\gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)+d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}\right)=0+d_{0} w_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{2} \cdot \widetilde{h_{1}}$

# 6.5. The $E_{\infty}$-term for $t m f / 2$ 

The calculation of $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ as the homology of $\left(E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2), d_{4}\right)$ is carried out in Appendix B.3, and the result is displayed in Tables 6.10 and 6.11. In this section we show that the twelve classes in Table 6.12 generate $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ as a module over $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf})=E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf})$, and use this to deduce that $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)=E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$.

Passing from $E_{4}$ to $E_{5}$, we introduced shorter monomial names for some $d_{4^{-}}$ cycles which were sums in $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$. These were

$$
\begin{aligned}

\gamma^{2} \widetilde{d_{0} e_{0}} & =18_{34}+18_{35}=w_{1} \cdot i\left(h_{1} \gamma w_{2}\right)+g^{2} \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}} \\
i\left(\gamma^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right) & =30_{115}+30_{116}=g \cdot i\left(\beta^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)+w_{1} \cdot i\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3}\right) \\
\gamma^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma} & =35_{153}+35_{154}=g \cdot \beta^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}+w_{1} \cdot h_{1}^{2} w_{2}^{3} \widetilde{\gamma}
\end{aligned}
$$

In order to make the $h_{1}$-action on $i\left(c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ more visible, we now make a change of basis, replacing $i\left(e_{0} g^{2}\right)=12_{20}$ by $i\left(e_{0} g^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}=12_{21}=i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ and keeping $\gamma^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$

as a generator. Similarly, we replace $i\left(e_{0} g^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)=28_{114}$ by $i\left(e_{0} g^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}=$ $28_{115}=i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)$, while keeping $\gamma^{2} w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$.

The sources for differentials that could have hit $w_{1}^{2} y$ in these cases are $i\left(\gamma w_{1}^{12}\right)$ and three $h_{1}$-multiples of elements that are infinite cycles because the 119 -stem of $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is 0 above filtration 23 .

For $x=w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\mathcal{P}}$ we must rule out $d_{r}(x)=y \neq 0$ for $r=9,16,24,32$ and 41 . The sources for differentials that could have hit $w_{1}^{2} y$ are $i\left(\gamma w_{1}^{3} w_{2}^{2}\right), i\left(\gamma w_{1}^{15}\right)$ and three $h_{1^{-}}$ multiples of elements that are infinite cycles because the 143 -stem of $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is 0 above filtration 27. The first two possible sources are also infinite cycles, because $\gamma, w_{1}$ and $w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ are infinite cycles for $\operatorname{tmf}$.

For the remaining two generators, $\widetilde{\gamma}$ and $w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}$, we use the long exact sequence

$$
\cdots \longrightarrow \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf}) \xrightarrow{2} \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf}) \xrightarrow{i} \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2) \xrightarrow{j} \pi_{n-1}(\operatorname{tmf}) \longrightarrow \ldots
$$

Our knowledge of $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf})$ and $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ will allow us to deduce sufficient information about this sequence. The charts of $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf})$ in Figures 5.1 to 5.5 will be helpful in following the argument.

In the 25 -stem, $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is generated by $\gamma$ and $h_{1} w_{1}^{3}$, while $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is generated by $i(\gamma)$ and $i\left(h_{1} w_{1}^{3}\right)$. The group $\pi_{25}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2$ rather than $\mathbb{Z} / 4$, because multiplication by $\eta$ acts nontrivially on the homotopy class $\left\{h_{1} w_{1}^{3}\right\}$ detected by $h_{1} w_{1}^{3}$, so this class cannot be a multiple of 2 . Hence $\pi_{25}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ has order (at least) 4 , so both $i(\gamma)$ and $i\left(h_{1} w_{1}^{3}\right)$ survive to $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$. In particular, $d_{8}(\widetilde{\gamma}) \neq i\left(h_{1} w_{1}^{3}\right)$ must be zero.

In the 97 -stem, we also claim that $\pi_{97}(\operatorname{tmf}) \cong(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{5}$ has exponent 2. Multiplication by $\eta$ acts nontrivially on the homotopy class $\left\{h_{1} w_{1}^{12}\right\}$ in Adams filtration 49, so the Adams filtration $\geq 41$ part of $\pi_{97}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is $(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{2}$. The $h_{1}$-multiples in Adams filtration 32 and 24 can be represented by $\eta$-multiples, which must have order 2 . Thus the Adams filtration $\geq 24$ part of $\pi_{97}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is $(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{4}$. The same argument shows that the Adams filtration $\geq 28$ part of $\pi_{105}(\operatorname{tmf})$ has exponent 2 . The class $h_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ in Adams filtration 17 is not an $h_{1}$-multiple at $E_{\infty}$, but $w_{1} \cdot h_{1} w_{2}^{2}=h_{1} \cdot w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$. Since multiplication by $\left\{w_{1}\right\}$ acts injectively from $\pi_{97}(\operatorname{tmf})$ to $\pi_{105}(\operatorname{tmf})$, it follows that $\left\{h_{1} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ and $\left\{h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ have order 2 , proving the claim.

Hence $\pi_{97}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ has order (at least) $2^{5}$. In particular, all five generators of $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ in degree 97 must remain nonzero at $E_{\infty}$, and none of them can be hit by a differential from $w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}$. This finishes the proof that $w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}$ is an infinite cycle.

# CHAPTER 7 

## The Adams spectral sequence for $t m f / \eta$

We calculate the $d_{r}$-differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta=$ $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \eta$. These are nontrivial for $r \in\{2,3\}$, and zero for $r \geq 4$, so the spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{4}$-term. The module structure over the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf}$ suffices to determine almost all of these differentials. There is one exceptional case, concerning $d_{3}\left(h_{2}^{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)$, for which we also use the hidden $\eta$-extension to $d_{0} w_{1}$ for $\operatorname{tmf}$. The resulting $E_{\infty}$-term is the associated graded of a complete Hausdorff filtration of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)_{2}^{\wedge}$.
