# 7.2. The $d_{2}$-differentials for $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta$ 

Theorem 7.1. The $d_{2}$-differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ is $R_{1}$-linear. Its values on a set of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators are listed in Table 7.1, and its values on a set of $R_{1}$-module generators are listed in Table 7.2.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{2}$-cycles in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$, so the Leibniz rule implies that multiplication by each of these elements commutes with the $d_{2^{-}}$ differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$.

Next, we determine $d_{2}$ on the module generators of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ over $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$. See Figures 1.28 and 1.29. The $d_{2}$-differentials on $i(1), \widehat{h_{0}}$ and $\widehat{h_{2}}$ are zero because the target groups are trivial. The $d_{2}$-differential on $\widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$ is zero by $h_{0}$-linearity. The map $j: C \eta \rightarrow S^{2}$ induces a morphism of Adams spectral sequences

$$
E_{r}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta) \xrightarrow{j} E_{r}^{*, *-2}(\operatorname{tmf})
$$

By Proposition 5.8 (or Table 5.1) the classes $\alpha$ and $\beta$ both support nontrivial $d_{2^{-}}$ differentials. Hence their lifts $\widehat{\alpha}$ and $\widehat{\beta}$ must also support nonzero $d_{2}$-differentials, and the only possible values are $5_{6}=w_{1} \widehat{h_{2}}$ and $5_{9}=d_{0} \widehat{h_{0}}$, respectively.

The case of $d_{2}(\widehat{d_{0} g})$ remains. Here we use the relation $e_{0} \cdot \widehat{d_{0} g}=12_{41}=d_{0} \gamma \cdot \widehat{\alpha}$ and the Leibniz rule to calculate $e_{0} \cdot d_{2}\left(\widehat{d_{0} g}\right)=d_{0} \gamma \cdot d_{2}(\widehat{\alpha})=d_{0} \gamma \cdot w_{1} \widehat{h_{2}}=14_{40}=$ $g w_{1} \cdot i\left(\alpha^{2}\right) \neq 0$. Hence $d_{2}\left(\widehat{d_{0} g}\right) \neq 0$, and the only possible value is $10_{22}=w_{1} \cdot i(\alpha \beta)$.

Finally, we use Table 5.1 and the Leibniz rule to calculate $d_{2}$ for $x$ and $x w_{2}=$ $w_{2} \cdot x$, with $x$ ranging through the list of $R_{0}$-module generators for $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$. (These elements then range through a list of $R_{1}$-module generators for the same $E_{2}$-term.) In particular $d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)=\alpha \beta g \cdot x+w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)$. In this finite range, the action of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$ on $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ is calculated using ext.

# 7.3. The $d_{3}$-differentials for $t m f / \eta$

This is carried out in Appendix C. 1 and the results are recorded in Tables 7.3 and 7.4, where we also record the results of this section, calculating the $d_{3}$-differential. Among the new relations that appear at the $E_{3}$-term we emphasize

$$
i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right)=g^{3} \cdot \widehat{h_{0}}
$$

in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(62,13)$, which follows from the $d_{2}$-differential on $i\left(\beta w_{2}\right)$.

THEOREM 7.3. The $d_{3}$-differential in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are listed in Table 7.3.

Proof. The $E_{3}$-term is so sparse that the only $R_{1}\left[h_{0}\right]$-module generators whose $d_{3}$ lies in a nonzero bidegree are:
$(3,1): \frac{i\left(h_{2}\right)}{}$
$(11,4): \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$
$(20,5): h_{0} h_{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(23,5): h_{2}^{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(27,6): i(\alpha \beta)$
$(51,9): i\left(h_{2} w_{2}\right)$
$(59,12): \gamma g \widehat{\alpha}+w_{2} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$
$(65,13): i\left(h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right)$
$(68,13): h_{0} h_{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(71,13): h_{2}^{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}$.
Those of the form $i(x)$, where $x \in E_{3}(t m f)$, are immediate by naturality. Eliminating these, we have only the following left to consider:
$(11,4): \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$
$(20,5): h_{0} h_{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(23,5): h_{2}^{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(59,12): \gamma g \widehat{\alpha}+w_{2} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$
$(68,13): h_{0} h_{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}$
$(71,13): h_{2}^{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}$.
We deal with these individually.
Applying $j: E_{3}^{s, t}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta) \rightarrow E_{3}^{s, t-2}(\operatorname{tmf})$, we get $j\left(d_{3}\left(h_{0} h_{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)\right)=d_{3}\left(h_{0} h_{2} \beta\right)=$ $d_{3}\left(h_{1} e_{0}\right)=h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}$. The only lift is $d_{3}\left(h_{0} h_{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)=w_{1} \cdot \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$. This then eliminates the only possibility of a nonzero differential on $\widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}$, which is $d_{3}\left(\widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)=h_{0}^{2} w_{1} \widehat{h_{0}}$, since this would imply that $d_{3}\left(w_{1} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)=h_{0}^{2} w_{1}^{2} \widehat{h_{0}} \neq 0$.

Similarly, naturality with respect to $j$ implies that $d_{3}\left(h_{0} h_{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)=w_{1} \cdot(\gamma g \widehat{\alpha}+$ $\left.w_{2} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)$ and $d_{3}\left(\gamma g \widehat{\alpha}+w_{2} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)=0$.

Again, by naturality with respect to $j$ we have that $d_{3}\left(h_{2}^{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)$ must map to $d_{3}\left(h_{2}^{2} \beta w_{2}\right)=d_{3}\left(h_{1} g w_{2}\right)=g^{3} w_{1}=\beta \gamma g w_{1} \neq 0$, and $d_{3}\left(h_{2}^{2} w_{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)=w_{1} \cdot(\gamma g \widehat{\beta}+$ $\left.i\left(d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right)$ is the only possibility.

Finally, by Theorem 11.71 due to Mimura and Mahowald-Tangora, we know that $\eta^{2} \bar{\kappa} \in \pi_{22}(S)$ is detected by $P d_{0}$ in $E_{\infty}(S)$. Hence $\eta^{2} \bar{\kappa} \in \pi_{22}(t m f)$ is detected by $d_{0} w_{1}$ in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$, as a consequence of Proposition 1.14 due to Adams. This $\eta$ multiple must map to zero in $\pi_{22}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$, so $i\left(d_{0} w_{1}\right)=8_{9}+8_{10}$ must be a boundary. The only possibility is that $d_{3}\left(h_{2}^{2} \widehat{\beta}\right)=w_{1} \cdot i\left(d_{0}\right)$.

The $w_{2}^{2}$-multiples now follow by the Leibniz rule, $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2}^{2}$. $d_{3}(x)=\beta g^{4} \cdot x+w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)$. The second summand is straightforward to write down. The first summand vanishes whenever $g^{4} \in \operatorname{Ann}(x)$. In the remaining eight cases we use ext to calculate $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ and to express it in terms of our module generators, as follows:

- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot i(1)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot i(1)=19_{103}=g^{3} \cdot i(\beta g)$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot \widehat{h_{2}}\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot \widehat{h_{2}}=20_{117}=g^{5} \cdot i(1)$.

- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot i\left(\beta^{2}\right)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot i\left(\beta^{2}\right)=25_{176}=g^{6} \cdot \widehat{h_{2}}$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot i(\beta g)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot i(\beta g)=26_{180}=g^{5} \cdot i\left(\beta^{2}\right)$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot\left(\gamma g \widehat{\beta}+i\left(d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot\left(\gamma g \widehat{\beta}+i\left(d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right)=31_{251}+31_{252}=g^{4}$. $\left(g^{3} \widehat{\beta}+\alpha \beta w_{2} \widehat{h_{0}}\right)$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot\left(\beta^{2} g \widehat{\beta}+d_{0} w_{2} \widehat{h_{2}}\right)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot\left(\beta^{2} g \widehat{\beta}+d_{0} w_{2} \widehat{h_{2}}\right)=32_{271}+32_{272}=$ $g^{5} \cdot\left(\gamma g \widehat{\beta}+i\left(d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right)$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot\left(\beta g^{2} \widehat{\beta}+i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)\right)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot\left(\beta g^{2} \widehat{\beta}+i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)\right)=33_{289}+33_{290}=$ $g^{5} \cdot\left(\beta^{2} g \widehat{\beta}+d_{0} w_{2} \widehat{h_{2}}\right)$.
- $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot\left(g^{3} \widehat{\beta}+\alpha \beta w_{2} \widehat{h_{0}}\right)\right)=\beta g^{4} \cdot\left(g^{3} \widehat{\beta}+\alpha \beta w_{2} \widehat{h_{0}}\right)=34_{300}+34_{301}=$ $g^{5} \cdot\left(\beta g^{2} \widehat{\beta}+i\left(\alpha^{2} w_{2}\right)\right)$.

# 7.4. The $E_{\infty}$-term for $t m f / \eta$ 

It is now a simple matter to compute the $E_{4}$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta$, as a direct sum of $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$-modules. This is carried out in Appendix C. 2 and the results are recorded in Tables 7.5 and 7.6. We show in Theorem 7.6 that there are no further nonzero differentials, so that $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)=E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$.

We make one pair of basis changes. We replace $i(\alpha g)=7_{19}+7_{20}$ by $i(\delta)=7_{20}$. This has the same $R_{2}$-annihilator and is consistent with the basis chosen for $\operatorname{tmf}$. Similarly, we replace $i\left(\alpha g w_{2}^{2}\right)=23_{163}+23_{164}$ by $i\left(\delta w_{2}^{2}\right)=23_{164}$. Note that already at $E_{2}, i\left(h_{0} \alpha g\right)=i\left(h_{0} \delta\right)$, so we also make this name change in degrees $32,80,128$ and 176 .

Proposition 7.5. Charts showing $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 192$ are given in Figures 7.1 to 7.8. All nonzero $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$and $h_{2}$-multiplications are displayed. The red dots indicate $w_{1}$-power torsion classes, and black dots indicate $w_{1}$-periodic classes. All $R_{2}$-module generators are labeled, except those that are also $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$or $h_{2}$-multiples.

Proof. The $R_{2}$-module structure shown in these charts is made explicit in Tables 7.5 and 7.6. The $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$and $h_{2}$-multiplications mostly follow by comparison with the $E_{2}$-term, shown for $0 \leq t-s \leq 96$ in Figures 1.28 to 1.31. This also shows that

$$
h_{2} \cdot\left(\gamma g \widehat{\alpha}+w_{2} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)=h_{0} \cdot\left(\gamma g \widehat{\beta}+i\left(d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right)=i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right)
$$

which we have noted becomes equal to $g^{3} \cdot \widehat{h_{0}}$ at the $E_{3}$-term. Similarly $h_{2} \cdot\left(\gamma g w_{2}^{2} \widehat{\alpha}+\right.$ $\left.w_{2}^{3} \widehat{h_{1} c_{0}}\right)=i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right)$ becomes equal to $g^{3} \cdot w_{2}^{2} \widehat{h_{0}}$ in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$.

THEOREM 7.6. $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)=E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$.
Proof. It suffices to verify that $d_{r}(x)=0$ for each $R_{2}$-module generator $x$ in Table 7.5, for each $r \geq 4$. In most cases this is clear because all target groups are trivial. In the remaining cases, $x$ is ( $w_{1}$ - or) $w_{1}^{2}$-torsion, so if $d_{r}(x)=y$ then $w_{1}^{2} y=0$ at the $E_{r}$-term. Moreover, in each of these cases the $E_{4}$-term is trivial in and above the bidegree of $w_{1}^{2} x$, so none of the differentials $d_{4}, \ldots, d_{r}$ can hit $w_{1}^{2} y$. Hence $w_{1}^{2} y=0$ in $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$. Furthermore, $w_{1}^{2}$ acts injectively on the $E_{4}$-term in the bidegree containing $d_{r}(x)$, and this implies that $y=0$.

We have also determined a set of $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators for $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$, and expressed the remaining $R_{2}$-module generators in terms of this module structure. The results are listed in the following proposition, and in the dec.-column of Table 7.5.

# CHAPTER 8 

## The Adams spectral sequence for $t m f / \nu$

We calculate the $d_{r}$-differentials in the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu=$ $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge C \nu$. These are nontrivial for $r \in\{2,3,4\}$, and zero for $r \geq 5$, so the spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{5}$-term. The module structure over the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf}$ suffices to determine almost all of these differentials. There is one exceptional case, concerning $d_{2}\left(\overline{\beta^{2}}\right)$, which we settle by means of an external smash product pairing. The resulting $E_{\infty}$-term is the associated graded of a complete Hausdorff filtration of $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)_{2}^{\wedge}$.

### 8.1. The $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$

The initial term

$$
E_{2}=E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{4}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

of the $\bmod 2$ Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ was calculated in Part I. The groups $E_{2}^{s, t}$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 96$ are displayed in Figures 1.32 to 1.35. By Corollary 4.16 the $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ is generated as a module over $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ by the 14 classes listed in Table 8.1. As a module over $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$ the $E_{2}$-term for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ is presented as a direct sum of cyclic modules in Table 8.2, most of which is reproduced from Table 4.7 and illustrated in Figure 4.3. We note that the $E_{2^{-}}$ term is free over $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$, and finitely generated over $R_{0}\left[h_{0}\right]=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[h_{0}, g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right]$. Recall Definition 5.1. Following the strategy of Chapter 5 we will keep track of $R_{0}$-module structure on the $E_{2}$-term, $R_{1}$-module structure on the $E_{3}$-term, and $R_{2^{-}}$ module structure on the $E_{4^{-}}$and $E_{5}=E_{\infty}$-terms of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$.

# 8.2. The $d_{2}$-differentials for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ 

Theorem 8.1. The $d_{2}$-differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ is $R_{1}$-linear. Its values on a set of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators are listed in Table 8.1, and its values on a set of $R_{1}$-module generators are listed in Table 8.2.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{2}$ are $d_{2}$-cycles in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$, so the Leibniz rule implies that multiplication by each of these elements commutes with the $d_{2}$ differential in $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$.

Next, we determine $d_{2}$ on the module generators of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ over $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf})$. See Figures 1.32 and 1.33. The $d_{2}$-differentials on $i(1), \overline{h_{0}^{3}}, \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}, \overline{c_{0}}, \bar{g}, \overline{\alpha \beta}$ and $\bar{\delta}$ are zero because the target groups are trivial. The $d_{2}$-differentials on $\overline{h_{1}}$ and $\bar{\gamma}$ are zero by $h_{0}$-linearity. The cofiber sequence

$$
S \xrightarrow{i} C \nu \xrightarrow{j} S^{4}
$$

induces maps of Adams spectral sequences

$$
E_{r}(\operatorname{tmf}) \xrightarrow{i} E_{r}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu) \xrightarrow{j} E_{r}^{*, *-4}(\operatorname{tmf})
$$

By Theorem 5.10 (or Table 5.2) the class $h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}$ is a $d_{3}$-boundary in the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf}$, so its image $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}\right)$ must be a $d_{2}$ - or $d_{3}$-boundary in the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$. For bidegree reasons, the only possibility

is $d_{2}\left(w_{1} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right)=i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{1}\right)$. It follows that $d_{2}\left(\overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right)=i\left(h_{1} c_{0}\right)$, by injectivity of the $w_{1}$-multiplication from bidegree $(t-s, s)=(9,4)$.

By Proposition 5.8 (or Table 5.1) the classes $h_{0}^{2} \alpha$ and $\alpha^{3}$ both support nontrivial $d_{2}$-differentials. Hence their lifts $\overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}$ and $\alpha^{3}$ must also support nonzero $d_{2}$-differentials, and the only possible values are $h_{0} w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$ and $h_{0} w_{1} \overline{\alpha \beta}$, respectively. The value of $d_{2}\left(\overline{h_{0} \alpha^{2}}\right)$ is either 0 or $d_{0} w_{1} \overline{h_{1}}$. It maps under $j$ to $d_{2}\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2}\right)$ in the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$, which is zero by the Leibniz rule (or Table 5.1). However, $j$ maps $d_{0} w_{1} \overline{h_{1}}$ to $h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}$, which is nonzero in $E_{2}(t m f)$. Hence $d_{2}$ vanishes on $\overline{h_{0} \alpha^{2}}$.

Only the case of $d_{2}\left(\overline{\beta^{2}}\right)$ remains. The cofiber sequence

$$
S \wedge C \nu \xrightarrow{i \wedge 1} C \nu \wedge C \nu \xrightarrow{j \wedge 1} S^{4} \wedge C \nu
$$

induces a long exact sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ldots \xrightarrow{\delta} E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu) \xrightarrow{i_{*}} E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu \wedge C \nu) \\
\xrightarrow{j_{*}} E_{2}\left(t m f \wedge S^{4} \wedge C \nu\right) \xrightarrow{\delta}
\end{aligned}
$$

of Adams $E_{2}$-terms. The connecting homomorphism $\delta$ induces multiplication by $h_{2}$ on $E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{4}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. We know from Lemma 1.39 that this $E_{2}$-term is a graded algebra over $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, with $h_{2} \cdot i(1)=0$, so the $h_{2}$-multiplication is zero and the homomorphism $i_{*}$ is injective. Alternatively, we can see directly from Figures 1.32 and 1.33 that $h_{2}$-multiplication is zero, in the range of bidegrees shown.

The smash product of $t m f$-modules induces an external pairing

$$
\wedge: E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu) \otimes E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu) \longrightarrow E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu \wedge C \nu)
$$

of Adams spectral sequences, taking $\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \otimes \bar{g}$ to $\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g}$ in $(t-s, s)=(34,6)$, with

$$
d_{2}\left(\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g}\right)=d_{2}\left(\overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right) \wedge \bar{g}+\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge d_{2}(\bar{g})=i\left(h_{1} c_{0}\right) \wedge \bar{g}+\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge 0=i_{*}\left(h_{1} c_{0} \bar{g}\right)
$$

in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(33,8)$. An ext-calculation shows that $h_{1} c_{0} \bar{g}=8_{17}=$ $i\left(h_{1} \delta\right)$, which is nonzero in $E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu)$. Hence $i_{*}\left(h_{1} c_{0} \bar{g}\right) \neq 0$ and $\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g} \neq 0$ in $E_{2}(t m f \wedge C \nu \wedge C \nu)$. Note that $j_{*}\left(\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g}\right)=\Sigma^{4} h_{2}^{2} \bar{g}=0$ in $E_{2}\left(t m f \wedge S^{4} \wedge C \nu\right)$, by the vanishing of the $h_{2}$-multiplication. It follows that $\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g}=i_{*}(x)$ for a nonzero class $x$ in $(t-s, s)=(34,6)$, and the only possibility is $x=\overline{\beta^{2}}$. Thus $i_{*} d_{2}\left(\overline{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{2}\left(i_{*}\left(\overline{\beta^{2}}\right)\right)=d_{2}\left(\overline{h_{2}^{2}} \wedge \bar{g}\right)=i_{*}\left(h_{1} c_{0} \bar{g}\right)$. The injectivity of $i_{*}$ then implies that $d_{2}\left(\overline{\beta^{2}}\right)=h_{1} c_{0} \bar{g}=i\left(h_{1} \delta\right)$.

Finally, we use Table 5.1 and the Leibniz rule to calculate $d_{2}$ for $x$ and $x w_{2}=$ $w_{2} \cdot x$, with $x$ ranging through the list of $R_{0}$-module generators for $E_{2}(t m f / \nu)$. These elements then range through a list of $R_{1}$-module generators for the same $E_{2^{-}}$ term. In particular $d_{2}\left(w_{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2} \cdot d_{2}(x)$, with $d_{2}\left(w_{2}\right)=\alpha \beta g=10_{18}$ as in Table 5.1. In this finite range, the action of $E_{2}(t m f)$ on $E_{2}(t m f / \nu)$ is calculated using ext.

REMARK 8.2. To use ext to assist in calculating the products $\alpha \beta g \cdot x$ for $x \in E_{2}(t m f / \nu)$, use cocycle tmfCnu $00, \ldots$, cocycle tmfCnu 12 38, dolifts 040 maps and collect maps all. The nonzero products with $\alpha \beta g=10_{18}$ then appear as lines containing ( 1018 F 2 ) in the file all. If the product is a $g^{2}$ multiple, there will also appear a line containing ( 818 F 2 ) in the same block, since

$g^{2}=8_{18}$ in the minimal $A(2)$-module resolution for $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. Similarly, $g^{2} w_{1}$-multiples appear with ( 1222 F 2 ), $g^{3}$-multiples appear with ( 1229 F 2 ), etc.

This is carried out in Appendix D. 1 and the results are recorded in Tables 8.3 and 8.4, where we also record the results of this section, calculating the $d_{3}$-differential.

which we verify by calculating the relevant Yoneda products using ext.
Proposition 8.4. The $d_{3}$-differentials on the $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators for $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ are as listed in Table 8.5.

Proof. To determine $d_{3}$ on the $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generators of $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ we refer to Figures 1.32 to 1.35 , keeping in mind that the $E_{3}$-term is a subquotient of the $E_{2}$-term shown in these charts. The $d_{3}$-differentials on $i(1), \overline{h_{0}^{3}}, \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}, \overline{c_{0}}$, $i(\alpha), h_{0} \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}, \overline{h_{0} \alpha^{2}}, h_{0} \overline{\alpha^{3}}, w_{2} \overline{h_{0}^{3}}$ and $h_{0} w_{2} \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}$ are zero because the target groups are trivial, already at the $E_{2}$-term.

The $d_{3}$-differentials on $\bar{g}, w_{2} \overline{h_{0} \alpha^{2}}, w_{2} \overline{\delta}$ and $h_{0} w_{2} \overline{\alpha^{3}}$ are zero because the target groups are trivial at the $E_{3}$-term:

- The bidegree $(t-s, s)=(23,7)$ of $d_{3}(\bar{g})$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $w_{1} \cdot i(\beta)$, and $d_{2}\left(w_{1} \cdot i(\beta)\right)=w_{1} \cdot i\left(h_{0} d_{0}\right) \neq 0$.
- The bidegree $(75,18)$ of $d_{3}\left(w_{2} \overline{h_{0} \alpha^{2}}\right)$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $g^{3} w_{1} \cdot \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}=$ $d_{2}\left(g w_{1} \cdot i\left(w_{2}\right)\right)$.
- The bidegree $(83,18)$ of $d_{3}\left(w_{2} \bar{\delta}\right)$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $g w_{1} \cdot w_{2} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$, and $d_{2}\left(g w_{1} \cdot w_{2} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}\right)=g^{3} w_{1} \cdot i\left(d_{0}\right) \neq 0$.
- The bidegree $(87,21)$ of $d_{3}\left(h_{0} w_{2} \overline{\alpha^{3}}\right)$ is generated at $E_{2}$ by $g^{3} w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \overline{h_{1}}=$ $d_{2}\left(g w_{1} \cdot i\left(\alpha w_{2}\right)\right)$.
The $d_{3}$-differential on $\overline{h_{1}}$ is zero by $h_{0}$-linearity.
We show that $d_{3}(\bar{\gamma})=i\left(g w_{1}\right)$ as a consequence of the relations $g \bar{\gamma}=9_{30}=$ $\gamma \bar{g}+i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)$ and $h_{0} \bar{\gamma}=0$. We know from Table 5.2 that $d_{3}(g)=0, d_{3}(\gamma)=0$ and $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)=g^{2} w_{1}$, and we have just seen that $d_{3}(\bar{g})=0$. Hence $g d_{3}(\bar{\gamma})=i\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right) \neq$ 0 in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$. It follows that $d_{3}(\bar{\gamma})$ is nonzero and annihilated by $h_{0}$, and the only possible value is $i\left(g w_{1}\right)$.

Furthermore, we show that $d_{3}(\alpha \bar{g})=g w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$ as a consequence of the relation $e_{0} \cdot \alpha \bar{g}=11_{36}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \bar{\gamma}$. We know from Table 5.2 that $d_{3}\left(e_{0}\right)=c_{0} w_{1}$ and $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2}\right)=$ $h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}$, and we have just seen that $d_{3}(\bar{\gamma})=i\left(g w_{1}\right)$. Hence

$$
d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \alpha \bar{g}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \bar{g}+e_{0} \cdot d_{3}(\alpha \bar{g})=e_{0} \cdot d_{3}(\alpha \bar{g})
$$

is equal to

$$
d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}+\alpha^{2} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(\alpha^{2}\right) \neq 0
$$

where $c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \alpha \bar{g}=0$ and $h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}=0$ can be verified with ext. Hence $d_{3}(\alpha \bar{g})$ is nonzero, and $g w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$ is the only possible value.

For $\overline{\alpha \beta}$ we use naturality with respect to $j: C \nu \rightarrow S^{4}$. We know that $d_{3}(\overline{\alpha \beta}) \in$ $\left\{0, e_{0} w_{1} \overline{h_{1}}\right\}$ maps by $j$ to $d_{3}(\alpha \beta)=0$ in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$. However, $j\left(e_{0} w_{1} \overline{h_{1}}\right)=w_{1} \cdot h_{1} e_{0} \neq$ 0 . Hence $d_{3}(\overline{\alpha \beta})=0$.

For $\bar{\delta}$ and $w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}$ we use $d_{0}$-linearity of $d_{3}$, which follows from $d_{3}\left(d_{0}\right)=0$. We know that $d_{3}(\bar{\delta}) \in\left\{0, g w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}\right\}$, and $d_{0} \cdot g w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}=g w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}} \neq 0$. Since $d_{0} \cdot \bar{\delta}=0$ we must have $d_{0} \cdot d_{3}(\bar{\delta})=0$. Hence $d_{3}(\bar{\delta})=0$.

Finally, $d_{3}\left(w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}\right) \in\left\{0, g w_{1} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\}$, where $d_{0} \cdot g w_{1} \overline{\alpha \beta}=g w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \overline{\alpha \beta} \neq 0$. From $d_{0} \cdot w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}=0$ we deduce $d_{0} \cdot d_{3}\left(w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}\right)=0$. Hence $d_{3}\left(w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}\right)=0$.

THEOREM 8.5. The $d_{3}$-differential in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ is $R_{2}$-linear. Its values on a set of $R_{2}$-module generators are listed in Table 8.3.

Proof. The classes $g, w_{1}$ and $w_{2}^{4}$ are $d_{3}$-cycles in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$, so multiplication by each of these commutes with the $d_{3}$-differential in $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$.

The $d_{3}$-differential on the $R_{1}$-module generators $x$ in Table 8.3 is given by the Leibniz rule applied to the (implicit and explicit) factorizations in the proof of Proposition 8.3, and the $d_{3}$-differentials from Tables 5.2 and 8.5. In several of the following cases we use ext to rewrite the output of the Leibniz rule in terms of the $R_{1}$-module presentation of $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$.

- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}=8_{9}=w_{1} \cdot h_{1} \overline{c_{0}}$
- $d_{3}\left(i\left(\alpha^{2}\right)\right)=i\left(h_{1} d_{0} w_{1}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot i(\alpha)\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot i(\alpha)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right)=d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot i(1)\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot i(1)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} \bar{\gamma}\right)=h_{1} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}(i(\beta g))=d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(g \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}\right)=d_{3}\left(d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \bar{g}\right)=c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{g}=11_{24}=w_{1} \cdot i(\delta)$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=d_{0} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(d_{0}\right)$
- $d_{3}\left(e_{0} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=e_{0} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)+c_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}=12_{28}+12_{29}=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(e_{0}\right)+w_{1} \cdot h_{1} \bar{\delta}$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot \bar{g}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{g}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(d_{0} \cdot \alpha \bar{g}\right)=d_{0} \cdot g w_{1} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}=g w_{1} \cdot d_{0} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$
- $d_{3}\left(\alpha^{2} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=h_{1} d_{0} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}+\alpha^{2} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=14_{36}=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(\alpha^{2}\right)$
- $d_{3}\left(g \overline{\beta^{2}}\right)=d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot \bar{g}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \bar{g}=0$
- $d_{3}(\beta g \bar{g})=d_{3}\left(\beta^{2} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=h_{1} g w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}+\beta^{2} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=14_{42}=g w_{1} \cdot g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{0} w_{2} \cdot i(\alpha)\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(g \overline{\alpha^{3}}\right)=d_{3}\left(d_{0} e_{0} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=d_{0} e_{0} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=g w_{1} \cdot i\left(d_{0} e_{0}\right)$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2} \cdot \overline{c_{0}}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \overline{c_{0}}=0$
- $d_{3}\left(i\left(h_{1} \gamma w_{2}\right)\right)=d_{3}\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2} \cdot \bar{g}\right)=0$
- $d_{3}\left(h_{1} w_{2} \cdot \bar{\gamma}\right)=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}+h_{1} w_{2} \cdot i\left(g w_{1}\right)=17_{69}=g^{2} w_{1} \cdot \bar{\gamma}$.

It remains to determine $d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2} \cdot x\right)=d_{3}\left(w_{2}^{2}\right) \cdot x+w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)=\beta g^{4} \cdot x+w_{2}^{2} \cdot d_{3}(x)$ for the same generators $x$. If $g^{4} \in \operatorname{Ann}(x)$ this takes no effort. Otherwise we use ext to calculate:

- $\beta g^{4} \cdot i(1)=g^{3} \cdot i(\beta g)$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}=20_{106}=g^{5} \cdot i(1)$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \bar{g}=23_{144}=g^{3} \cdot \beta g \bar{g}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \bar{\gamma}=24_{155}=g^{5} \cdot \bar{g}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}=25_{160}=g^{6} \cdot \overline{h_{1}}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot i(\beta g)=26_{171}=g^{5} \cdot g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$

- $\beta g^{4} \cdot g \overline{\beta^{2}}=29_{219}=g^{6} \cdot \bar{\gamma}$
- $\beta g^{4} \cdot \beta g \bar{g}=30_{232}=g^{5} \cdot g \overline{\beta^{2}}$.

REMARK 8.6. To calculate the products $\beta g^{4} \cdot x$ with ext, use cocycle, dolifts and collect as in Remark 8.2. The nonzero products with $\beta g^{4}=19_{56}$ then appear as lines containing ( 1956 F 2 ) in the file all. If the product is a $g^{3}$-multiple, there will also appear a line containing ( 1229 F 2 ) in the same block, since $g^{3}=12_{29}$ in the minimal $A(2)$-module resolution for $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. Similarly, $g^{5}$-multiples appear with (20 67 F2), and $g^{6}$-multiples appear with (24 90 F2).

# 8.4. The $d_{4}$-differentials for $t m f / \nu$ 

It is now an elementary matter to compute the $E_{4}$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$, as a direct sum of $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$-modules. This is carried out in Appendix D. 2 and the results are recorded in Tables 8.6 and 8.7. In this section we determine the $d_{4}$-differentials on these $R_{2}$-module generators, and the results are also recorded in these tables.

Proof. Most of the factorizations are evident from Tables 5.8 and 8.9. Using ext, we find the following less obvious factorizations, which are valid at $E_{2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
i\left(c_{0}\right) & =3_{3}=h_{1} \cdot \overline{h_{0} h_{2}} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha\right) & =4_{4}=h_{0} \cdot \overline{c_{0}} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2}\right) & =7_{11}=h_{0}^{3} \cdot \bar{g} \\
i\left(h_{1} \gamma\right) & =6_{12}=h_{1}^{2} \cdot \bar{g} \\
i\left(\alpha d_{0}\right) & =7_{12}=d_{0} \cdot\left(\overline{c_{0}}+i(\alpha)\right) \\
i(\delta) & =7_{17}=h_{1} \cdot \overline{\alpha \beta} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha^{3}\right) & =10_{20}=h_{0}^{3} \cdot \bar{\delta} \\
i\left(\alpha^{2} g\right) & =10_{27}=d_{0} \gamma \cdot \overline{h_{1}} \\
i\left(h_{1}^{2} w_{2}\right) & =10_{33}=h_{1} \gamma \cdot \bar{g} \\
i\left(d_{0} e_{0} g\right) & =12_{34}=\alpha d_{0} g \cdot \overline{h_{1}} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha w_{2}\right) & =12_{44}=h_{0} \cdot w_{2} \overline{c_{0}} \\
i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right) & =13_{48}=h_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2} \overline{c_{0}} \\
d_{0} g \bar{\gamma} & =13_{49}=d_{0} \gamma \cdot \bar{g} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{2}\right) & =15_{61}=h_{0}^{3} w_{2} \cdot \bar{g} \\
i\left(h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}\right) & =18_{80}=h_{0}^{3} \cdot w_{2} \bar{\delta} \\
h_{0} d_{0} w_{2} \bar{g} & =17_{83}=h_{1}^{2} \cdot w_{2} \bar{\delta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we use the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{0} g^{2} \overline{h_{1}} & =i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right)+d_{2}\left(i\left(\beta w_{2}\right)\right) \\
e_{0} g^{2} \bar{g} & =h_{1} \cdot i\left(\delta w_{2}\right)+d_{2}\left(w_{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}\right) \\
e_{0} g^{2} \bar{\gamma} & =h_{0} d_{0} w_{2} \bar{g}+d_{2}\left(\beta w_{2} \bar{g}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and their $w_{2}^{2}$-multiples, which can be read off from Table 8.2.
Proposition 8.11. Charts showing $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ for $0 \leq t-s \leq 192$ are given in Figures 8.1 to 8.8. All nonzero $h_{0}$ - and $h_{1}$-multiplications are displayed. All $h_{2}$ multiplications are zero. The red dots indicate $w_{1}$-power torsion classes, and black dots indicate $w_{1}$-periodic classes. All $R_{2}$-module generators are labeled, except those that are also $h_{0^{-}}, h_{1^{-}}$or $h_{2}$-multiples.

Proof. Table 8.9 exhibits the $E_{5}$-term as a direct sum of cyclic $R_{2}$-modules. Most of the nontrivial $h_{0^{-}}$and $h_{1}$-multiplications are evident from the $x$ - and dec.columns of that table. The remaining nonzero $h_{0^{-}}$and $h_{1}$-multiplications are found by inspection of the $E_{2}$-term, as calculated by ext and displayed in Figures 1.32 to 1.35 . Those valid at the $E_{2}$-term are:

The $h_{2}$-multiplications are zero, because $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(M_{4}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is a bigraded algebra by Lemma 1.39.

THEOREM 8.12. $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)=E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$.
Proof. To prove that the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ collapses at the $E_{5}$-term, we use Theorem 5.27 and show that each $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module generator $x$ listed in Table 8.10 is an infinite cycle, i.e., that $d_{r}(x)=0$ for each $r \geq 5$. In most cases this is clear because all target groups are trivial. Furthermore, all differentials on $\overline{h_{1}}$ must vanish by $h_{0}$-linearity.

The remaining cases are $x=\overline{\alpha \beta}, \gamma^{2} \bar{\gamma}, w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}$ and $w_{2}^{2} \overline{\alpha \beta}$, each of which is $\left(w_{1}\right.$- or) $w_{1}^{2}$-torsion. If $d_{r}(x)=y$, then $w_{1}^{2} y=0$ at the $E_{r}$-term. Since $E_{5}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ is trivial in the topological degree of $w_{1}^{2} x$, this can only happen if $w_{1}^{2} y=0$ at the $E_{5}$-term. Since all possible targets $y$ are $w_{1}$-torsion free at $E_{5}$, this implies $y=0$.

# CHAPTER 9 

## The homotopy groups of $t m f$

In this chapter we use our mod 2 Adams spectral sequence calculations, together with the known image of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ in the ring of modular forms, to determine the structure of $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{2}^{<} \cong \pi_{*}(t m f) \otimes \mathbb{Z}_{2}$ as a graded ring, or more precisely, as a graded $\mathbb{Z}_{2}$-algebra. All spectra are hereafter implicitly completed at the prime 2 (until Chapter 13), but we shall omit this from the notation.

The algebra generators fall into eight families, parameterized, roughly speaking, by the powers $\Delta^{k}, 0 \leq k \leq 7$, of the discriminant $\Delta$. These are then made periodic with period 192 by an element $M \in \pi_{192}(t m f)$ detected by $\Delta^{8}$. We name " $M$ " for Mark Mahowald, who first saw much of this structure. These generators are listed in Figure 9.1. The $k$-th term in a family is written with the subscript $k$, except that we usually omit the subscript 0 since the classes $\eta, \nu, \epsilon, \kappa$ and $\bar{\kappa}$ are the images under the unit map $S \rightarrow t m f$ of classes known by those names in $\pi_{*}(S)$. The remaining classes $\eta_{k}, \nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}$ and $\kappa_{k}$ are higher analogs of these. The classes in the left part of Figure 9.1 have finite additive order, while those in the right part are of infinite additive order.

These two sets of generators are intimately related. For example, in Chapter 10 we will see that the duality exhibited by $t m f$ implies that the order of the subgroup $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle$ generated by $\nu_{k}$ is equal to the index of $\left\langle B D_{7-k}\right\rangle$ in $\left\langle B_{7-k}\right\rangle$. For this formula to apply for all $0 \leq k \leq 7$, we will introduce the notations $\nu_{3}=\eta_{1}^{3}$ and $\nu_{7}=0$, even though these classes are not algebra generators. We also extend the notation above by the rule $x_{k+8}=x_{k} M$ for any generator $x$, for convenience in making general statements.

The classes $B=B_{0}$ and $C=C_{0}$ map to generators of $\pi_{8}(k o)$ and $\pi_{12}(k o)$ under a natural map $t m f \rightarrow k o$, see Proposition 9.21. Accordingly, we refer to the

class $B$ as the "Bott element". The classes $\nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}$ and $\bar{\kappa}$ are $B$-power torsion, while the classes $\eta_{k}, B_{k}, C_{k}, D_{k}$ and $M$ are $B$-periodic. The classes $B_{k}, C_{k}$ and $D_{k}$ map to the modular forms $c_{4} \Delta^{k}, 2 c_{6} \Delta^{k}$ and an appropriate 2-power multiple of $\Delta^{k}$, respectively.

The classes $B_{k}$ have a kind of dual aspect. Many of them have a 2-torsion class in the same degree whose action on the $B$-power torsion submodule of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ is the same. Mahowald referred to this with his statement that " $\epsilon$ tries to act like the Bott element." (See Proposition 9.40 for a precise statement of this.) For example, there is a hidden relation $\epsilon \kappa=B \kappa \in \pi_{22}(t m f)$. Since $B$ is not in the image of $\pi_{*}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f)$, this takes the subtler form $\epsilon \kappa=\left\{P d_{0}\right\}$ in $\pi_{*}(S)$, but is already present there. Replacing $B$ by the sum $\widetilde{B}=B+\epsilon$ simplifies this to the relation $\widetilde{B} \kappa=0$. Since $B \epsilon=\epsilon^{2}=0$, we have $\widetilde{B}^{2}=B^{2}$, so that a class is $B$-power torsion if and only if it is $\widetilde{B}$-power torsion. Both $B$ and $\widetilde{B}$ map to $c_{4}$ in the ring of modular forms, and are hard to distinguish in the elliptic [75] and Adams-Novikov [23] spectral sequences. One of the virtues of the Adams spectral sequence for $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ is that the $B$-power torsion classes lie in low Adams filtration, making it relatively easy to establish relations that are difficult to detect with other tools.

The classes $B_{k}$ are the easiest to work with in the Adams spectral sequence, but in the end we will find that using the $\widetilde{B}_{k}$ gives the cleanest expression for the algebra structure. In particular, the $\mathbb{Z}[M]$-subalgebra generated by the $\widetilde{B}_{k}, C_{k}$ and $D_{k}$ is isomorphic to its image in the ring of modular forms. It also has an extremely simple action on the $B$-power torsion generators. For example, the $\widetilde{B}_{k}$ and $C_{k}$ annihilate them all, and the $C_{k}$ annihilate the $\eta_{k}$ as well.

The final section in this chapter gives a complete description of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ as a $\mathbb{Z}_{2}$-algebra. This can be found in Theorems 9.51, 9.53 and 9.54, Figures 9.6 through 9.13 , and Tables 9.8 and 9.9. In the end, there is one sign which we have not determined: $\nu_{4} \nu_{6}=s \nu \nu_{2} M$, where $s \in\{ \pm 1\}$. This same sign appears in $\nu_{4} D_{4}=2 s \nu M$ and $\nu_{6} D_{4}=2 s \nu_{2} M$.

The plan of the chapter is as follows.
In Section 9.1 we start by recalling the structure of $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ as a graded $\mathbb{F}_{2}{ }^{-}$ algebra. It has the 43 generators shown in Table 9.1. As a preliminary definition, we specify the $\mathbb{Z}_{2}$-algebra generators of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ displayed in Figure 9.1 by the classes in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ that detect them, as shown in the $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ and $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ columns of Table 9.1. This determines the generators of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ modulo higher Adams filtration. We also compute certain Massey products in the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term, which stem from multiplication by the discriminant $\Delta$. They show that our grouping into families is consistent, whether done in terms of the detecting classes at $E_{\infty}$ or in terms of the image in modular forms.

In the next section, we determine all the hidden $2-$, $\eta$ - and $\nu$-extensions in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$. Our calculations of the Adams spectral sequences for $t m f / 2$ and $t m f / \nu$ are key to our determination of the hidden 2 - and $\nu$-extensions. The $\eta$-extensions follow from these. In the process, we refine our specification of the algebra generators so that the $\eta_{k}$ and $\epsilon_{k}$ all have additive order 2, see Lemma 9.7. The last result in this section is the interesting relation

$$
\nu^{2} \nu_{4}=\eta \epsilon_{4}+\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}
$$

It exhibits a hidden $\nu$-extension from the $E_{\infty}$-class detecting $\nu \nu_{4}$ to the $E_{\infty}$-class detecting $\eta \epsilon_{4}$. However, this is not the whole relation in homotopy: there is also

the higher filtration term $\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}$. A hidden extension is simply the lowest filtration part of a nonzero product that is zero at $E_{\infty}$.

In Section 9.3, we recall the homomorphism from $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ to the ring of integral modular forms. Next, in Section 9.4 we refine our definition of the 40 algebra generators of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ : For each generator we specify its image in modular forms, together with its detecting class in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$. This leaves some ambiguity in a number of cases. Where possible, we eliminate this immediately. For example, when we define $\eta_{1}$ it will be apparent that we can add a term of higher Adams filtration to ensure that $\eta_{1} B=\eta B_{1}$, and we do this. Where indeterminacy remains we make it explicit, and note where in the succeeding sections it will be reduced or eliminated.

We determine the remaining multiplicative structure in Section 9.5, and in Section 9.6 we put our description of the algebra $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ in its final form.

9.1.1. The Massey products $\Delta$ and $\Delta^{\prime}$. The discriminant $\Delta=\left(c_{6}^{2}-\right.$ $\left.c_{4}^{3}\right) / 1728$ is not in the image of the map $t m f_{*} \rightarrow m f_{*/ 2}$. There is a class in the $E_{2}$-term of the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence that would have mapped to the discriminant had it survived, but which supports a differential $d_{5}(\Delta)=h_{2} g$ imposing the relation $\nu \bar{\kappa}=0$. In the Adams spectral sequence, there is no such class at $E_{2}$, but precursor spectral sequences like the May spectral sequence (where $d_{4}\left(b_{30}^{2}\right)=h_{12} b_{21}^{2}$ by $[\mathbf{1 4 4}, \S 3.2]$ or $[\mathbf{8 1}, \S 3.2]$ ) and the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence (where $d_{1}\left(x_{\tau}^{2}\right)=h_{2} g$ by Lemma 3.28) have differentials that impose the relation $h_{2} g=0$. Any such class gives rise to a Massey product at $E_{2}$ (Adams spectral sequence) or $E_{6}$ (Adams-Novikov spectral sequence) which, in favorable cases, detects the Toda bracket $\langle\nu, \bar{\kappa},-\rangle$. In the Adams spectral sequence this Massey product is $\Delta(x)=\left\langle h_{2}, g, x\right\rangle$. Here, we compute this Massey product and a related one at $E_{2}$ of the Adams spectral sequence, and show that they group the generators of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ into a small number of families, explaining and justifying our notations for these generators.

Definition 9.1. Let $E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. For $x \in E_{2}$ satisfying $g x=0$, let

$$
\Delta(x)=\left\langle h_{2}, g, x\right\rangle \in E_{2} /\left(h_{2} E_{2}+E_{2} x\right)
$$

For $x \in E_{2}$ satisfying $h_{2} x=0$, let

$$
\Delta^{\prime}(x)=\left\langle x, h_{2}, g\right\rangle \in E_{2} /\left(x E_{2}+E_{2} g\right)
$$

As is customary, we regard these as subsets of $E_{2}$, but when they are singletons $\{y\}$ we will write them simply as $y$. Since $E_{2}(t m f)=0$ in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(24,4)$, the contributions $E_{2} x$ and $x E_{2}$ to the indeterminacy always vanish. Hence the indeterminacy of $\Delta(x)$ is $h_{2} E_{2}$, and that of $\Delta^{\prime}(x)$ is $E_{2} g$.

THEOREM 9.2. The Massey products $\Delta(x)$ are shown for classes detecting the algebra generators of $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ in Table 9.1, and for the other elements here in Table 9.2. Repeated application of $\Delta$ gives classes detecting the following sequences of elements of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ :

- $8 D \mapsto D_{1} \mapsto 2 D_{2} \mapsto D_{3} \mapsto 4 D_{4} \mapsto D_{5} \mapsto 2 D_{6} \mapsto D_{7} \mapsto 8 M$.
- $C \mapsto C_{1} \mapsto C_{2} \mapsto C_{3} \mapsto C_{4} \mapsto C_{5} \mapsto C_{6} \mapsto C_{7} \mapsto C M$.
- $B+\epsilon \mapsto B_{1}+\epsilon_{1} \mapsto B_{2} \mapsto B_{3} \mapsto B_{4}+\epsilon_{4} \mapsto B_{5}+\epsilon_{5} \mapsto B_{6} \mapsto B_{7} \mapsto(B+\epsilon) M$.
- $8 B \mapsto 8 B_{1} \mapsto 8 B_{2} \mapsto 8 B_{3} \mapsto 8 B_{4} \mapsto 8 B_{5} \mapsto 8 B_{6} \mapsto 8 B_{7} \mapsto 8 B M$.

Proof. These calculations are a simple matter for ext: We compute the chain map for the cocycle $s_{g}=$ s_g and inspect the file s_g/brackets.sym. The lines which record the Massey products $\left\langle h_{2}, g,-\right\rangle$ are all of the form

$$
\text { s1_g1 in < h2, 8, s_g >. }
$$

where $s_{1}-s=4$. This difference in degrees tells us that the middle term is $g=4_{8}=4_{-} 8$, and the presence of this line says that the coefficient of s1_g1 in the Massey product is nonzero, if the Massey product is defined. Thus, for example

$$
7 \_7 \text { in < h2, 8, } 3 \_0>
$$

tells us that the coefficient of the generator $7_{7}=7_{-} 7$, detecting $h_{0} \alpha^{2}$, in the Massey product $\left\langle h_{2}, g, h_{0}^{3}\right\rangle$ is nonzero. The Massey product is defined and there are no other lines indicating that other terms occur in the Massey product, so we conclude that $\Delta\left(h_{0}^{3}\right)=\left\langle h_{2}, g, h_{0}^{3}\right\rangle=h_{0} \alpha^{2}$ with 0 indeterminacy.

The $B$-, $C$ - and $D$-families merit special attention. In each case, we have $\Delta\left(x w_{2}\right)=w_{2} \Delta(x)$, since there are no nonzero $h_{2}$-multiples in the bidegrees in which these 24 values of $\Delta$ lie. Therefore, it is necessary to calculate only the first two Massey products in each family of eight elements. In addition they are all defined with 0 indeterminacy.

For the "discriminant" family we have $\Delta\left(h_{0}^{3}\right)=h_{0} \alpha^{2}$ and $\Delta\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2}\right)=h_{0}^{3} w_{2}$. The coefficients $8,4,2$ and 1 of the $D_{k}$ reflect the $h_{0}$-divisibility of these classes in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$.

Second, the " $2 c_{6}$ " family is much more uniform: the Massey products $\Delta\left(h_{0}^{3} \alpha\right)=$ $h_{0} \alpha^{3}$ and $\Delta\left(h_{0} \alpha^{3}\right)=h_{0}^{3} \alpha w_{2}$ imply that $C_{k} \mapsto C_{k+1}$ for each $k$, with $C_{0}=C$ and $C_{k+8}=C_{k} M$.

Third, we consider two sequences of elements of Ext which contain information about the "Bott", or " $c_{4}$ " family. In degree 8 , either $B$, detected by $w_{1}$, or $B+\epsilon$, detected by $c_{0}$, generates a $\mathbb{Z}$-summand and maps to $c_{4} \in m f_{*/ 2}$. The Massey product $\Delta$ is not defined on $w_{1}$, but is defined on $c_{0}$, where we get $\Delta\left(c_{0}\right)=\delta$. In degree 32 , similarly, either $B_{1}$, detected by $\alpha g=\delta+\delta^{\prime}$, or $B_{1}+\epsilon_{1}$, detected by $\delta$, generates a $\mathbb{Z}$-summand and maps to $c_{4} \Delta \in m f_{*/ 2}$. However, the Massey product $\Delta$ is not defined on $\alpha g$ or $\delta^{\prime}$, but is defined on $\delta$, where it gives $\Delta(\delta)=c_{0} w_{2}$. The sequence of Massey products $c_{0} \mapsto \delta \mapsto c_{0} w_{2} \mapsto \cdots$ detects the $B+\epsilon \mapsto B_{1}+\epsilon_{1} \mapsto$ $B_{2} \mapsto B_{3} \mapsto B_{4}+\epsilon_{4} \mapsto \cdots$ sequence.

Due to hidden extensions, the 2-power multiples of these classes are mostly not detected by their $h_{0}$-power multiples. Accordingly, we also calculate $\Delta$ on $E_{2}$-classes detecting 8 times each of these classes. The Massey products $\Delta\left(h_{0}^{3} w_{1}\right)=h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{1}$

and $\Delta\left(h_{0} \alpha^{2} w_{1}\right)=h_{0}^{3} w_{1} w_{2}$, together with $w_{2}$-linearity, then give the sequence of Massey products detecting the very uniform sequence $8 B \mapsto 8 B_{1} \mapsto 8 B_{2} \mapsto \cdots$.

On $B$-power torsion classes the operator $\Delta$ is often undefined or zero modulo indeterminacy. For these classes, the closely related Massey product $\Delta^{\prime}(x)=$ $\left\langle g, h_{2}, x\right\rangle$ plays the role of tying them together into systematic families. It is not as simple to calculate, because the ext program as currently constituted only calculates the Massey products $\left\langle x, y, h_{i}\right\rangle=\left\langle h_{i}, y, x\right\rangle$. (It calculates this from the chain map lifting $x$.) Identities for the relevant Massey products are used to get around this.

Because of the identities $h_{1}^{3}=h_{0} h_{2}^{2}$ and $h_{1}^{2} \gamma=h_{0} \alpha \beta$, we consider the elements in the $\eta$ - and $\nu$-families together. At the $E_{2}$-term, the behavior is quite uniform. These results and their meaning for the $\eta_{k}$ and $\nu_{k}$ are shown in Figures 9.2 and 9.3.

Theorem 9.3. The following Massey products are defined in $E_{2}(t m f)$ with 0 indeterminacy:
(1) $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1} w_{2}^{i}\right)=\gamma w_{2}^{i}$.
(2) $\Delta^{\prime}\left(\gamma w_{2}^{i}\right)=h_{1} w_{2}^{i+1}$.
(3) $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}^{i}\right)=\alpha \beta w_{2}^{i}$.
(4) $\Delta^{\prime}\left(\alpha \beta w_{2}^{i}\right)=h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}^{i+1}$.

Proof. The ext program can calculate that $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}\right)=\left\langle h_{1}, h_{2}, g\right\rangle=\gamma$.
We can then write $\Delta^{\prime}(\gamma)=a_{0} h_{1} w_{2}$ and $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1} \gamma\right)=\left\{a_{1} h_{1}^{2} w_{2}, a_{1} h_{1}^{2} w_{2}+\beta^{2} g\right\}$ for some coefficients $a_{i} \in \mathbb{F}_{2}$. Since $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1} \gamma\right) \supseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}\right) \gamma=\left\{\gamma^{2}\right\}=\left\{h_{1}^{2} w_{2}+\beta^{2} g\right\}$, we conclude that $a_{1}=1$. Since $h_{1} \Delta^{\prime}(\gamma) \subseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1} \gamma\right)=\left\{h_{1}^{2} w_{2}, \gamma^{2}\right\}$, we conclude that $a_{0}=1$ also. Now we will show that multiplication by $w_{2}$ is an isomorphism in the relevant degrees, establishing the first two formulas claimed. The elements $h_{1} w_{2}^{i}$ and $\gamma w_{2}^{i}$ lie in bidegrees $(s, t)=(1+4 k, 2+28 k)$, where $k=2 i$ or $k=2 i+1$, respectively. A monomial

$$
h_{0}^{n_{1}} h_{1}^{n_{2}} h_{2}^{n_{3}} c_{0}^{n_{4}} \alpha^{n_{5}} \beta^{n_{6}} d_{0}^{n_{7}} e_{0}^{n_{8}} \gamma^{n_{9}} \delta^{n_{10}} g^{n_{11}} w_{1}^{n_{12}} w_{2}^{n_{13}}
$$

has
$s=\left(n_{1}+n_{2}+n_{3}\right)+3\left(n_{4}+n_{5}+n_{6}\right)+4\left(n_{7}+n_{8}+n_{11}+n_{12}\right)+5 n_{9}+7 n_{10}+8 n_{13}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
t=n_{1}+2 n_{2}+4 n_{3}+11 n_{4}+15 n_{5}+18 n_{6}+18 n_{7}+ \\
21 n_{8}+24 n_{11}+12 n_{12}+30 n_{9}+39 n_{10}+56 n_{13}
\end{aligned}
$$

so that, if it lies in a bidegree $(s, t)=(1+4 k, 2+28 k)$, then
$7 s-t=5=6 n_{1}+5 n_{2}+3 n_{3}+10 n_{4}+6 n_{5}+3 n_{6}+10 n_{7}+7 n_{8}+4 n_{11}+16 n_{12}+5 n_{9}+10 n_{10}$.
Evidently $n_{1}=n_{4}=n_{5}=n_{7}=n_{8}=n_{12}=n_{10}=0$ and

$$
5=5 n_{2}+3 n_{3}+3 n_{6}+4 n_{11}+5 n_{9}
$$

The only non-negative integer solutions have $n_{2}$ or $n_{9}$ equal to 1 and all other terms 0 , corresponding to the $h_{1} w_{2}^{i}$ and $\gamma w_{2}^{i}$. Therefore $w_{2}$-multiplication acts isomorphically on these bidegrees, as claimed.

Similarly, we can write $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} h_{2}\right)=b_{0} \alpha \beta$ and $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0}^{2} h_{2}\right)=\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}^{3}\right)=b_{1} h_{0} \alpha \beta$ for some coefficients $b_{i} \in \mathbb{F}_{2}$. From $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}^{3}\right) \supseteq h_{1}^{2} \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}\right)=h_{1}^{2} \gamma=h_{0} \alpha \beta$ we conclude that $b_{1}=1$. Then $h_{0} \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} h_{2}\right) \subseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0}^{2} h_{2}\right)=h_{0} \alpha \beta$ implies that $b_{0}=1$ also.

We can write $\Delta^{\prime}(\alpha \beta)=b_{2} h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}$ for some coefficient $b_{2} \in \mathbb{F}_{2}$. We then have $h_{0} \Delta^{\prime}(\alpha \beta) \subseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} \alpha \beta\right)=\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}^{2} \gamma\right)$, which must be either $h_{1} \gamma^{2}$ or 0 . Since it contains $h_{1} \gamma \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}\right)$, it is $h_{1} \gamma^{2}$, and $\Delta^{\prime}(\alpha \beta)=h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}$.

Next we can write $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}\right)=b_{3} \alpha \beta w_{2}$ and

$$
\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}\right)=\left\{b_{4} h_{0} \alpha \beta w_{2}, b_{4} h_{0} \alpha \beta w_{2}+\beta g^{3}\right\}
$$

for some coefficients $b_{i} \in \mathbb{F}_{2}$. Then $\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}\right)=\Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1} \gamma^{2}\right) \supseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{1}\right) \gamma^{2}=\gamma^{3}=$ $h_{0} \alpha \beta w_{2}+\beta g^{3}$ implies that $b_{4}=1$. Then $h_{0} \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}\right) \subseteq \Delta^{\prime}\left(h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}\right)$ implies that $b_{3}=1$ also.

As above, multiplication by $w_{2}$ is an isomorphism in the relevant degrees, establishing the last two formulas claimed, as follows. The classes $h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}^{i}$ and $\alpha \beta w_{2}^{i}$ lie in bidegrees $(s, t)=(2+4 k, 5+28 k)$. A monomial lying in such a degree must satisfy
$7 s-t=9=6 n_{1}+5 n_{2}+3 n_{3}+10 n_{4}+6 n_{5}+3 n_{6}+10 n_{7}+7 n_{8}+4 n_{11}+16 n_{12}+5 n_{9}+10 n_{10}$.
Evidently $n_{4}=n_{7}=n_{12}=n_{10}=0$ and

$$

$$

It is easily verified that there are six non-negative integer solutions to this, corresponding to $w_{2}^{i}$-multiples of the five elements $h_{0} h_{2}, h_{0} \beta=h_{2} \alpha, \alpha \beta, h_{1} g$ and $\gamma g$. Of these, only $h_{0} h_{2}$ and $\alpha \beta$ have $(s, t)$ of the form $(2+4 k, 5+28 k)$.

The elements produced by iterating the Massey product $\Delta^{\prime}$ on the set of $h_{0}$ - and $h_{1}$-multiples of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ then fit into the very simple pattern shown in Figures 9.2 and 9.3. This could be used as a means to detect such hidden extensions, but we have been able to determine them all using primary information and induced maps.

# 9.2. Hidden extensions 

In this section we determine all of the hidden 2-, $\nu$ - and $\eta$-extensions, in turn. The results are displayed as dashed or dotted lines in Figures 9.6 through 9.13.

Isaksen [82, Def. 4.2] has given a precise clarification of the notion of a hidden extension in the Adams spectral sequence for a ring spectrum, such as tmf. The definition easily extends to the case of a pairing of spectra, such as the module action of $t m f$ on $t m f / 2$.

Definition 9.5. Let $X \wedge Y \rightarrow Z$ be a pairing of spectra, with induced pairings $\pi_{*}(X) \otimes \pi_{*}(Y) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(Z)$ of homotopy groups and $E_{\infty}(X) \otimes E_{\infty}(Y) \rightarrow E_{\infty}(Z)$ of Adams $E_{\infty}$-terms. Let $\alpha \in \pi_{*}(X)$ be detected by $a \in E_{\infty}(X)$, and consider classes $b \in E_{\infty}(Y)$ and $c \in E_{\infty}(Z)$. We say that there is a hidden $\alpha$-extension from $b$ to $c$ if
(1) $a b=0$,
(2) there is an element $\beta \in \pi_{*}(Y)$ detected by $b$ such that $\alpha \beta \in \pi_{*}(Z)$ is detected by $c$, and
(3) there is no element $\beta^{\prime} \in \pi_{*}(Y)$ of higher Adams filtration than $\beta$ such that $\alpha \beta^{\prime}$ is detected by $c$.

Remark 9.6. If conditions (1) and (2) hold, but an element $\beta^{\prime}$ exists that makes condition (3) fail, then we will say (in Chapter 12) that the $\alpha$-multiplication

from $b$ (detecting $\beta$ ) to $c$ is eclipsed by the $\alpha$-multiplication from $b^{\prime}$ (detecting $\beta^{\prime}$ ) to $c$.
9.2.1. Hidden 2-extensions. We now determine the graded group structure of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ using the structure of $i: E_{\infty}(t m f) \rightarrow E_{\infty}(t m f / 2)$ obtained in Sections 5.5 and 6.5 .

Lemma 9.7. We can (and do) choose $\eta_{1}, \epsilon_{1}, \eta_{4}, \epsilon_{4}$ and $\epsilon_{5}$ to have additive order 2 .

Proof. We use the homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{2} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{i} \operatorname{tmf} / 2 \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma \operatorname{tmf}
$$

and the associated short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{n}(t m f) / 2 \xrightarrow{i} \pi_{n}(t m f / 2) \xrightarrow{j}{ }_{2} \pi_{n-1}(t m f) \rightarrow 0
$$

where ${ }_{2} A=\operatorname{ker}(2: A \rightarrow A)$ and $A / 2=\operatorname{cok}(2: A \rightarrow A)$ for any abelian group $A$. Consider classes $x$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f / 2)$ that are detected by $\widetilde{\gamma}, \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}, w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}, w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}$ and $w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ in $E_{\infty}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$. Their images $j(x) \in{ }_{2} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ are of additive order 2 , and are detected by $j(\widetilde{\gamma})=\gamma, j\left(\widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=\delta^{\prime}, j\left(w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{h_{1}}\right)=h_{1} w_{2}^{2}, j\left(w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{c_{0}}\right)=c_{0} w_{2}^{2}$ and $j\left(w_{2}^{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}\right)=\delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2}$, respectively. These images show that $\eta_{1}, \epsilon_{1}, \eta_{4}, \epsilon_{4}$ and $\epsilon_{5}$ can be chosen to have order 2 .

(32) First we determine $\pi_{33}(t m f)$ from $E_{\infty}(t m f)$. From $E_{\infty}(t m f / 2)$ we see that $\pi_{33}(t m f / 2)$ has order $2^{4}$. Using the exact sequence (9.1) we deduce that ${ }_{2} \pi_{32}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$. This shows that $\epsilon_{1}$ is the unique element of order 2 in $\pi_{32}(t m f)$.

Clearly $\pi_{31}(t m f)=0$, so $\pi_{32}(t m f) / 2 \cong \pi_{32}(t m f / 2)$, which has order $2^{3}$. Lemma 9.9. When viewed as an $\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$-module, $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ splits as a direct sum of cyclic modules with annihilator ideals $(0),\left(w_{1}\right)$ or $\left(w_{1}^{2}\right)$. All $w_{1}$-power torsion is $w_{1}$ - or $w_{1}^{2}$-torsion.

Consider the $B$-power torsion submodule $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f) \subset \pi_{*}(t m f)$. The Adams filtration $F^{s} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ restricts to a filtration

$$
F^{s} \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)=F^{s} \pi_{*}(t m f) \cap \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)
$$

of $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$, and the filtration subquotient

$$
\frac{F^{s} \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)}{F^{s+1} \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)} \subset \frac{F^{s} \pi_{*}(t m f)}{F^{s+1} \pi_{*}(t m f)}
$$

corresponds under the isomorphism $F^{s} \pi_{*}(t m f) / F^{s+1} \pi_{*}(t m f) \cong E_{\infty}^{s, *}(t m f)$ to the classes that can be represented by $B$-power torsion elements. These classes are all $w_{1}$-power torsion. In the case of $t m f$ the converse holds, so that the $w_{1}$-power torsion in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ is precisely the associated graded of the restriction of the Adams filtration to $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$.

Proposition 9.10. Each $w_{1}$-torsion class in $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ is represented by a $B$ torsion class in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$, each $w_{1}^{2}$-torsion class is represented by a $B^{2}$-torsion class, and $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ is $w_{2}^{4}$-torsion free. Hence there are no hidden $B$ - or $M$-extensions in the Adams spectral sequence for tmf.

Proof. Each class $b$ in the $x$-column of Table 9.3 is represented by a class $\beta \in \pi_{*}(t m f)$, as listed in the "rep."-column. We claim that if $w_{1}^{k} b=0$ then $B^{k} \beta=0$, for $k \in\{1,2\}$.

In view of the multiplicative structure, it suffices to verify that $B$ annihilates $\beta=\nu, \epsilon, \eta \kappa, 2 \bar{\kappa}, \eta \bar{\kappa}, 2 \nu_{1}, \eta \epsilon_{1}, \eta_{1} \kappa, \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \nu_{1} \kappa, \epsilon_{1} \kappa, 2 \nu_{2}, \eta_{1} \epsilon_{1}, \nu_{2} \kappa, \eta_{1}^{2} \bar{\kappa}, \eta_{1}^{3}=\nu_{3}$, $\nu_{4}, \epsilon_{4}, \eta \kappa_{4}, \bar{\kappa} D_{4}, 2 \nu_{5}, \kappa \kappa_{4}, \eta \epsilon_{5}, \eta_{1} \kappa_{4}, \nu_{5} \kappa, 2 \nu_{6}, \eta_{1} \epsilon_{5}, \nu_{6} \kappa$ and $\epsilon_{5} \kappa \bar{\kappa}$, and that $B^{2}$ annihilates $\beta=\kappa, \bar{\kappa}, \nu_{1}, \epsilon_{1}, \nu_{2}, \kappa_{4}, \nu_{5}, \epsilon_{5}$ and $\nu_{6}$. In most cases, this holds because $B^{k} \beta$ lies in a trivial Adams filtration. This is most easily seen from Figures 5.1 to 5.8 or Figures 9.6 through 9.13 .

For $\beta=\epsilon, 2 \bar{\kappa}, \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \epsilon_{4}, \bar{\kappa} D_{4}, \kappa \kappa_{4}, \bar{\kappa}, \epsilon_{1}$ and $\epsilon_{5}$ it holds because $\beta$ is 2 -power torsion (by our choices in Lemma 9.7), and $B^{k} \beta$ lies in a 2-torsion free Adams filtration.

In the remaining cases, $\beta=\eta \epsilon_{1}, \nu_{1} \kappa, \eta_{1} \epsilon_{1}, \nu_{2} \kappa, \eta \epsilon_{5}, \nu_{5} \kappa, \eta_{1} \epsilon_{5}, \nu_{6} \kappa$ and $\epsilon_{5} \kappa \bar{\kappa}$, it holds because $\beta$ is $B$-power torsion (by what we have already established for $\kappa, \epsilon_{1}$ and $\epsilon_{5}$ ), and $B \beta$ lies in a $B$-torsion free Adams filtration (because $w_{1}$ acts injectively on that part of the $E_{\infty}$-term).

In the course of the previous proof, we also established the following lemma.
Lemma 9.11. The classes $\nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}$ and $\bar{\kappa}$ are $B$-power torsion. The minimal power of $B$ annihilating each is as follows:
(1) $B \cdot \nu_{k}=0$ for $k \in\{0,3,4\}$ and $B^{2} \cdot \nu_{k}=0$ for $k \in\{1,2,5,6\}$.
(2) $B \cdot \epsilon_{k}=0$ for $k \in\{0,4\}$ and $B^{2} \cdot \epsilon_{k}=0$ for $k \in\{1,5\}$.
(3) $B^{2} \cdot \kappa=0$ and $B^{2} \cdot \kappa_{4}=0$.
(4) $B^{2} \cdot \bar{\kappa}=0$.

Proposition 9.12. The $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ is the ideal

$$
\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)=\left(\nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}, \bar{\kappa}\right)
$$

generated by the $\nu-, \epsilon-, \kappa$ - and $\bar{\kappa}$-families, including $\nu_{3}=\eta_{1}^{3}$. It is contained in the 2-power torsion ideal

$$
\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*}(t m f)=\left(\eta_{k}, \nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}, \bar{\kappa}\right)
$$

generated by the $\eta-, \nu-, \epsilon-, \kappa$ - and $\bar{\kappa}$-families.
Proof. The first claim follows from the "rep."-column of Table 9.3 and the previous lemma. The second claim follows because the $\nu-, \epsilon-, \kappa$ - and $\bar{\kappa}$-families consist of 2-power torsion, and the remaining ( $B$-periodic) 2 -power torsion consists of multiples of $\eta, \eta_{1}$ and $\eta_{4}$. For example, the infinite cycles $\gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ and $\gamma^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$ in bidegrees $(t-s, s)=(129,25)$ and $(154,30)$ detect $\eta_{1} B_{4}$ and $\eta_{1}^{2} B_{4}$, respectively.

9.2.3. Hidden $\nu$-extensions. We proceed to determine the action of $\nu$ on $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ using the structure of $i: E_{\infty}(t m f) \rightarrow E_{\infty}(t m f / \nu)$ obtained in Sections 5.5 and 8.5 .

Lemma 9.13. The relations $\nu \cdot\left(B_{1}+\epsilon_{1}\right)=0, \nu \cdot B_{2}=0, \nu \cdot\left(B_{5}+\epsilon_{5}\right)=0$ and $\nu \cdot B_{6}=0$ hold in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$.

Proof. We use the homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\Sigma^{3} t m f \xrightarrow{\nu} t m f \xrightarrow{i} t m f / \nu \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{4} t m f
$$

and the associated short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{n}(t m f) / \nu \xrightarrow{i} \pi_{n}(t m f / \nu) \xrightarrow{j}{ }_{\nu} \pi_{n-4}(t m f) \rightarrow 0
$$

where ${ }_{\nu} A=\operatorname{ker}\left(\nu: A \rightarrow \Sigma^{-3} A\right)$ and $A / \nu=\operatorname{cok}\left(\nu: \Sigma^{3} A \rightarrow A\right)$. Consider classes $x \in \pi_{*}(t m f / \nu)$ detected by $\bar{\delta}, w_{2} \overline{c_{0}}, w_{2}^{2} \bar{\delta}$ and $w_{2}^{3} \overline{c_{0}}$ in $E_{\infty}(t m f / \nu)$. Their images $j(x) \in{ }_{\nu} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ are detected by $\delta, c_{0} w_{2}, \delta w_{2}^{2}$ and $c_{0} w_{2}^{3}$, respectively.

In degree 32 we note that $\{\delta\}$ is the set of 2 -adic units times $B_{1}+\epsilon_{1}$, plus Adams filtration $\geq 16$. For filtration reasons, $\nu$ annihilates Adams filtration $\geq 16$ in $\pi_{32}(t m f)$, so from $\nu \cdot j(x)=0$ for some $j(x) \in\{\delta\}$ we can deduce that $\nu$ annihilates $B_{1}+\epsilon_{1}$.

In degree 56 we observe that $\left\{c_{0} w_{2}\right\}$ is the set of 2 -adic units times $B_{2}$, plus Adams filtration $\geq 19$. For filtration reasons, $\nu$ annihilates Adams filtration $\geq 19$ in $\pi_{56}(t m f)$, so from $\nu \cdot j(x)=0$ for some $j(x) \in\left\{c_{0} w_{2}\right\}$ we can deduce that $\nu$ annihilates $B_{2}$.

The proofs for $B_{5}+\epsilon_{5}$ and $B_{6}$ are very similar.
Theorem 9.14. The Adams spectral sequence for tmf contains precisely the following 19 hidden $\nu$-extensions, together with their $w_{2}^{4}$-power multiples.

Proof. We first determine the hidden $\nu$-extensions from $n=51$ and $n=147$, and their multiplicative consequences.
(51) By Theorem 9.8 there is a hidden 2 -extension from $h_{2}^{2} w_{2}$ to $d_{0} g^{2}$. The ordinary $\nu$-extension from $h_{2} w_{2}$ to $h_{2}^{2} w_{2}$ thus implies a hidden $\nu$-extension from $h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}$ detecting $2 \nu_{2}$ to $d_{0} g^{2}$ detecting $2 \nu \nu_{2}$.
(147) By Theorem 9.8 there are hidden 2-extensions from $h_{2}^{2} w_{2}^{3}$ to $d_{0} g^{2} w_{2}^{2}$, and from $d_{0} g^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ to $d_{0} \delta^{\prime} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$. The ordinary $\nu$-extension from $h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ to $h_{2}^{2} w_{2}^{3}$ thus implies hidden $\nu$-extensions from $h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ to $d_{0} g^{2} w_{2}^{2}$, and from $h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ to $d_{0} \delta^{\prime} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$.
(50) Multiplying $\eta_{1}^{2} \in\left\{\gamma^{2}\right\}$ by $\eta_{4} \in\left\{h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1}^{2} \eta_{4}=4 \nu_{6} \in\left\{h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}^{3}\right\}$, since $h_{1} \gamma^{2} w_{2}^{2}=h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}^{3}$ already at the $E_{2}$-term and there are no classes of higher Adams filtration in $\pi_{147}(t m f)$. Since $\nu \cdot 4 \nu_{6} \neq 0$ by case (147), it follows that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1}^{2} \neq 0$, and this product can only be detected by $\gamma g w_{1}$.
(25) Multiplying $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ by $\eta_{1}$ we obtain $\eta_{1}^{2} \in\left\{\gamma^{2}\right\}$. Since $\nu \cdot \eta_{1}^{2} \neq 0$ by case (50), we deduce that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \neq 0$, and being a homotopy class of order 2 , this product can only be detected by $g w_{1}$.
(39) Multiplying $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ by $\kappa \in\left\{d_{0}\right\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \kappa \in\left\{d_{0} \gamma\right\}$. Since $\eta_{1} \nu \in$ $\left\{g w_{1}\right\}$ by case (25) we find that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \kappa=\kappa \cdot \eta_{1} \nu$ is detected by $d_{0} g w_{1} \neq 0$.
(57) Multiplying $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ by $\epsilon_{1} \in\left\{\delta^{\prime}\right\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \epsilon_{1} \in\left\{\gamma \delta^{\prime}\right\}$. Since $\eta_{1} \nu \in$ $\left\{g w_{1}\right\}$, it follows that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \epsilon_{1}$ is detected by $\delta^{\prime} g w_{1} \neq 0$.
(122) Multiplying $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ by $\eta_{4} \in\left\{h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \eta_{4} \in\left\{h_{1} \gamma w_{2}^{2}\right\}$. (135) Multiplying $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ by $\kappa_{4} \in\left\{d_{0} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \kappa_{4} \in\left\{d_{0} \gamma w_{2}^{2}\right\}$. Since $\eta_{1} \nu \in\left\{g w_{1}\right\}$, we find that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \kappa_{4}$ is detected by $d_{0} g w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$.

Since $\eta_{1} \nu \in\left\{g w_{1}\right\}$, it follows that $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \epsilon_{5}$ is detected by $\delta^{\prime} g w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \neq 0$.
(32) Multiplying $\epsilon_{1} \in\left\{\delta^{\prime}\right\}$ by $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \epsilon_{1} \in\left\{\gamma \delta^{\prime}\right\}$. Since $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \epsilon_{1} \neq$ 0 by case (57), we deduce that $\nu \cdot \epsilon_{1} \neq 0$ must be detected by $\alpha \beta w_{1}$. Lemma 9.13 now shows that $B_{1} \in\{\alpha g\}$ supports a hidden $\nu$-extension with the same target as $\epsilon_{1} \in\left\{\delta^{\prime}\right\}$.
(97) Multiplying $\eta_{4} \in\left\{h_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ by $\eta_{1} \in\{\gamma\}$ we obtain $\eta_{1} \eta_{4} \in\left\{h_{1} \gamma w_{2}^{2}\right\}$. Since $\nu \cdot \eta_{1} \eta_{4} \neq 0$ by case (122), we find that $\nu \cdot \eta_{4} \neq 0$ must be detected by $g^{5}$, e.g. because the Adams filtration $\geq 26$ part of $\pi_{100}(t m f)$ is 2-torsion free.

Lemma 9.13 now shows that $B_{5} \in\left\{\alpha g w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ supports a hidden $\nu$-extension with the same target as $\epsilon_{5} \in\left\{\delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$.

Next, we use the short exact sequence (9.2) to determine the hidden $\nu$-extensions on $h_{2}^{2}$ and its $w_{2}$-power multiples.
(6) We claim that $\nu$ times the generator $\nu^{2} \in\left\{h_{2}^{2}\right\}$ of $\pi_{6}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$ is detected by $h_{1} c_{0}$. The $E_{\infty}$-terms show that $\pi_{9}(t m f) \cong(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{2}, \pi_{9}(t m f / \nu) \cong$ $\mathbb{Z} / 2$, and $\pi_{5}(t m f)=0$, which implies that $\nu: \pi_{6}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{9}(t m f)$ has image of order 2 . Since $B \cdot \nu^{2}=0$, the image $\nu \cdot \nu^{2}=\nu^{3}$ cannot be detected by the $w_{1}$-periodic class $h_{1} w_{1}$. Hence $\nu^{3}$ must be detected by $h_{1} c_{0}$.
(54) The $E_{\infty}$-terms show that $\pi_{57}(t m f) \cong(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{4}, \pi_{57}(t m f / \nu)$ has order $2^{4}$, and $\pi_{53}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$. Since $\pi_{56}(t m f)$ is 2-torsion free, $\pi_{53}(t m f)$ is $\nu$ torsion, so $\nu: \pi_{54}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{57}(t m f)$ has image of order 2 . Since $\pi_{54}(t m f) \cong$

$\mathbb{Z} / 4$ is generated by $\nu \nu_{2}$, and $B \cdot \nu \nu_{2}=0$, it follows that $\nu \cdot \nu \nu_{2}=\nu^{2} \nu_{2} \neq 0$ cannot be detected by a $w_{1}$-periodic class. Hence $\nu^{2} \nu_{2} \in\left\{\gamma \delta^{\prime}\right\}$.
(102) We claim that $\nu$ times the generator $\nu \nu_{4} \in\left\{h_{2}^{2} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$ of $\pi_{102}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$ is detected by $h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}^{2}$. The $E_{\infty}$-terms show that $\pi_{105}(t m f) \cong(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{7}$, $\pi_{105}(t m f / \nu)$ has order $2^{6}$, and $\pi_{101}(t m f)=0$, which implies that the homomorphism $\nu: \pi_{102}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{105}(t m f)$ has image of order 2. Since $B^{2} \cdot \nu \nu_{4}=0$, the image $\nu \cdot \nu \nu_{4}=\nu^{2} \nu_{4}$ cannot be detected by a $w_{1}$-periodic class. It can also not be detected by $\gamma g^{4}$, since $i\left(\gamma g^{4}\right)=g^{5} \overline{h_{1}} \neq 0$ in $E_{\infty}(t m f / \nu)$. (This relation holds already in $E_{2}(t m f / \nu)$.) Hence $\nu^{2} \nu_{4}$ must be detected by $h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}^{2}$.
(150) The $E_{\infty}$-terms show that $\pi_{153}(t m f) \cong(\mathbb{Z} / 2)^{8}, \pi_{153}(t m f / \nu)$ has order $2^{8}$, and $\pi_{149}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$. Since $\pi_{152}(t m f)$ is 2-torsion free, $\pi_{149}(t m f)$ is $\nu$-torsion, so $\nu: \pi_{150}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{153}(t m f)$ has image of order 2. Since $\pi_{150}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 8$ is generated by $\nu \nu_{6}$, and $B \cdot \nu \nu_{6}=0$, it follows that $\nu \cdot \nu \nu_{6}=\nu^{2} \nu_{6} \neq 0$ cannot be detected by a $w_{1}$-periodic class. Hence $\nu^{2} \nu_{6} \in\left\{\gamma \delta^{\prime} w_{2}^{2}\right\}$.
To finish the proof, we must show there are no further hidden $\nu$-extensions. In most degrees, the result is evident from the fact that $E_{\infty}(t m f)=0$ in the relevant bidegrees (e.g., $\nu B_{i}=0$ for $i=0,3,4$ or 7 ), or the fact that $\nu$-multiples are $B$-torsion, hence cannot be detected by $w_{1}$-periodic classes. The remaining cases, $\nu \cdot B_{2}=0$ and $\nu \cdot B_{6}=0$, were handled in Lemma 9.13.

This also determined most of the hidden $\nu$-extensions, except those on $\nu \nu_{k}$ for $k=0,2,4,6$, for which we used the spectral sequence map induced by $i: \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf} / \nu$. It turns out that this information also suffices to determine the hidden $\eta$-extensions.

Proposition 9.17. $\nu^{2} \nu_{4}=\eta \epsilon_{4}+\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}$.
