THEOREM 9.54. We can (and do) choose $\nu_{4}$ so that $\nu D_{4}=2 \nu_{4}$. This determines $\nu_{4}$ up to a factor in $\{1,5\} \subset \mathbb{Z} / 8^{\times}$.

The products with 2-power torsion elements in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ are then as shown in Tables 9.8 and 9.9, where $s \in\{ \pm 1\}$ is the sign in the product $\nu_{4} \nu_{6}=s \nu \nu_{2} M$. The rows for the $\widetilde{B}_{k}, C_{k}$ and odd-indexed $D_{2 j+1}$ are omitted, because all products in these rows are zero with the exception of

$$
\eta_{i} \widetilde{B}_{j}=\eta \widetilde{B}_{i+j}
$$

Proof. These tables are largely the same as those at the end of the preceding section. There are three sets of changes. First, each row of $B_{k}$-products is replaced by the corresponding row of $\widetilde{B}_{k}$-products. Having done this, we no longer need the rows we have omitted, as they contain only 0 entries with the exception of the $\eta_{i} \widetilde{B}_{j}$. We retain the rows for the products by the even-indexed $D_{2 j}$ because a number of these products are nonzero.

Second, the $B$-multiples of $B$-power torsion classes are rewritten as $\epsilon$-multiples, which is justified by Proposition 9.40 .

Third, the signs $s_{i}$ for $i \in\{0,2,4,6\}$ are all replaced by the appropriate multiple of $s$ : see case $[S]$ of the proof of Theorem 9.47. There we saw that $\nu D_{4}=2 s_{0} \nu_{4}$ with $s_{0} \in\{ \pm 1\}$. Thus far the generator $\nu_{4}$ of $\pi_{99}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 8$ was only determined by its detecting class $h_{2} w_{2}^{2}$ in the Adams spectral sequence. Hence, by possibly changing the sign of $\nu_{4}$, we may arrange that $s_{0}=1$ and $\nu D_{4}=2 \nu_{4}$. This then gives the remaining $\nu_{2 j} D_{4}$ as in Theorem 9.47.

This theorem contains the following generalization of Mahowald's dictum that $B x=\epsilon x$ for $B$-power torsion classes $x$.

Corollary 9.55. If $x$ is $B$-power torsion then $\widetilde{B}_{k} \cdot x=0$ for all $k$. Equivalently,

$$
B_{k} x= \begin{cases}\epsilon_{k} x & \text { for } k=0,1,4,5 \\ \bar{\kappa}^{4} x & \text { for } k=3 \\ 0 & \text { for } k=2,6,7\end{cases}
$$

Proof. In other words, $\widetilde{B}_{k} \cdot x=0$ for all $0 \leq k \leq 7$ and $x \in \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)=$ $\left(\nu_{k}, \epsilon_{k}, \kappa_{k}, \bar{\kappa}\right)$. The honorary case $\widetilde{B}_{k} \cdot \nu_{3}=0$ is not made explicit in our tables, but $\eta_{1}^{3} \widetilde{B}_{k}=\eta^{3} \widetilde{B}_{k+3}=4 \nu \widetilde{B}_{k+3}=0$.

It also confirms the following heuristic relationship between the products $x_{i} y_{j}$, including the $\widetilde{B}$-family but excluding the $D$-family.

Corollary 9.56.
(1) When $x, y \in\{\eta, \nu, \epsilon, \kappa, \bar{\kappa}, \widetilde{B}, C\}$ and $x_{i}$ and $y_{j}$ are defined, then $x_{i} y_{j}$ depends only on $x, y$ and $i+j$, except when $x=y=\nu$.
(2) For $x=y=\nu$,

$$
\nu_{i} \nu_{j}=(i+1) \nu \nu_{i+j}
$$

except when $\{i, j\}=\{4,6\}$ if $s=-1$.
(3) When $x, y, z \in\{\eta, \nu, \epsilon, \kappa, \bar{\kappa}, \widetilde{B}, C\}$ and $x_{i}, y_{j}$ and $z_{k}$ are defined, then $x_{i} y_{j} z_{k}$ depends only on $x, y, z$ and $i+j+k$, except when two or more of $x, y$ and $z$ equal $\nu$.
(4) $\eta_{1}^{4}=\eta \nu_{4} \neq 0$ while $\eta^{3} \eta_{4}=0$, so $x_{i} y_{j} z_{k} w_{\ell}$ does sometimes depend on more than $x, y, z, w$ and $i+j+k+\ell$.

REMARK 9.57. The only nonzero products between the 2-power torsion classes $\eta_{i}, \nu_{i}, \epsilon_{i}, \kappa_{i}$ and $\bar{\kappa}$ and the 2-torsion free classes $\widetilde{B}_{j}, C_{j}$ and $D_{j}$ (other than $D_{0}=1$ ) are the following:

- $\eta_{i} \cdot \widetilde{B}_{j}=\eta \widetilde{B}_{i+j}$.
- $\nu_{i} \cdot D_{j}=4 \nu_{i+j}$ for $i$ even and $j \in\{2,6\}$.
- $\nu_{i} \cdot D_{4}= \pm 2 \nu_{i+4}$, with a sign depending on $i$.
- $\kappa \cdot D_{4}=2 \kappa_{4}$.
- $\bar{\kappa} \cdot D_{j}=\nu \nu_{j} \kappa$ for $j \in\{2,6\}$.
- $\bar{\kappa} \cdot D_{4}=\bar{\kappa} D_{4}$, one of our generators.

REMARK 9.58. Most of this multiplicative structure was very concisely described by Henriques in [54, Ch. 13], on pages 190-192. We offer the following concordance between his presentation and our results.
(1) The (nonzero) 2 - and $\eta$-multiplications, and almost all $\nu$-multiplications, are shown in the picture on page 190, which repeats $M$-periodically. The missing $\nu$-multiplications from degrees $0,51,96$ and 147 are easily deduced from the ones shown, by means of the additive group structure.
(2) The action by $\widetilde{B}$ is trivial in the upper part of Henriques' picture (including all classes in degrees $* \equiv 3 \bmod 24$ ), and is periodic in the lower part. The $\mathbb{Z}[\widetilde{B}]$-module generators of infinite order correspond to our $\widetilde{B}-, C$ and $D$-families.
(3) The products among 2-torsion free classes are determined up to 2-power torsion classes by the ring homomorphism to modular forms, as stated on page 191. The fact that a multiplicative section can be chosen so that there are no 2 -power torsion correction terms is not made explicit, and may be new.
(4) Most $\epsilon$-, $\kappa$ - and $\bar{\kappa}$-multiplications are also shown in the picture on page 190. The remaining degrees supporting nonzero products with these classes, as well as with $\eta_{1}=\{\eta \Delta\}, \nu_{1}=\{2 \nu \Delta\}, \epsilon_{1}=q$ and $\nu_{2}=\left\{\nu \Delta^{2}\right\}$, are listed in the table on pages 191 and 192. We note the following deviations from our conclusions:
$(\kappa)$ A nonzero product from degree 3 is missing.
$(\bar{\kappa})$ Some products from degrees $0,20,40$ and 96 are not shown. The sign of the product from degree 130 is left undetermined.
$\left(\eta_{1}\right)$ A nonzero product from degree 17 is missing.
$\left(\nu_{1}\right)$ The sign of the product from degree 123 is left undetermined.
$\left(\epsilon_{1}\right)$ A nonzero product from degree 98 is missing.
$\left(\nu_{2}\right)$ Nonzero products from degrees $48,144,147,150$ and 161 are missing. The indicated product from degree 116 should be omitted. The sign of the product from degree 96 , and the coefficient in $\mathbb{Z} / 8^{\times}$of the product from degree 99 , are not determined.
(5) The products with $\eta_{4}, \nu_{4}, \nu_{5}, \nu_{6}, \epsilon_{4}, \epsilon_{5}$ and $\kappa_{4}$ are not listed.
Henriques also shows the Adams $E_{\infty}$-term for $t m f$ on pages 196-197, with hidden $2-$, $\eta$ - and $\nu$-multiplications indicated. Our results appear to agree, except near degrees 32 and 128. Henriques indicates a class " $c_{4} \Delta+q$ " in degree 32 of Adams filtration 7 , equal to our class $B_{1}$, such that $\eta\left(c_{4} \Delta+q\right)$ has Adams filtration 9 and $\nu\left(c_{4} \Delta+q\right)=0$. As our calculations show, the latter $\nu$-product should be nonzero. The same issue occurs in degree 128 and Adams filtration 23.

REMARK 9.59. The multiplicative structure in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $t m f$ does not seem to suffice to determine the common sign $s$ in the relations $\nu_{4} \nu_{6}=s \nu \nu_{2} M, \nu_{4} D_{4}=2 s \nu M$ and $\nu_{6} D_{4}=2 s \nu_{2} M$. In the notation of $[\mathbf{2 3}$, $\S 8]$, the classes $\nu_{4} \nu_{6}$ and $\nu \nu_{2} M$ are both detected by $h_{2}^{2} \Delta^{10}$, but this only tells us that they agree modulo the higher filtration class $2 \nu \nu_{2} M$. Likewise, the classes $\nu_{4} D_{4}$ and $2 \nu M$ are both detected by $2 h_{2} \Delta^{8}$, and must agree modulo $4 \nu M$, while $\nu_{6} D_{4}$ and $2 \nu_{2} M$ are both detected by $2 h_{2} \Delta^{10}$, and must agree modulo $4 \nu_{2} M$. Similarly, in the elliptic spectral sequence for $T M F$, and in the homotopy fixed point spectral sequence for $L_{K(2)} T M F=E O_{2}$, the sign in these products is invisible at the $E_{\infty}{ }^{-}$ term.

# Duality 

### 10.1. Pontryagin duality in the $B$-power torsion of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$

The $B$-power torsion in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ repeats 192-periodically, and is shown in red in Figures 9.6 through 9.13, and again in Figures 10.1 and 10.2. In the latter illustrations the groups in degrees $3 \leq * \leq 90$ are shown in the upper halves with degrees increasing toward the right, while the groups in degrees $75 \leq * \leq 164$ are shown in the lower halves with degrees increasing toward the left. As usual, 2-, $\eta$ - and $\nu$-extensions are shown by solid or dashed lines increasing degree by 0,1 and 3 , respectively, but the vertical coordinate has no specific meaning. The mirror symmetry across the "fold line" in these pictures makes it clear that for $0 \leq n<192$ the $B$-power torsion in degree $n$ is abstractly isomorphic to the $B$-power torsion in degree $170-n$, except in degrees $n \equiv 3 \bmod 24$.

More precisely, we will see in Theorem 10.25 that these finite groups are naturally Pontryagin dual, so that there is a perfect pairing

$$
(-,-): \Theta \pi_{n}(t m f) \times \Theta \pi_{170-n}(t m f) \longrightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

for $0 \leq n<192$. Here $\Theta \pi_{n}(t m f) \subset \Gamma_{B} \pi_{n}(t m f)$ denotes the self-dual part of the $B$-power torsion, i.e., the part in degrees $n \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$. A less ad hoc characterization of $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ is given in Definition 10.18, which makes it clear that this is a $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-submodule of $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$. The omitted groups in degrees $n \equiv 3$ $\bmod 24$ are generated by the classes $\nu_{k}$ for $0 \leq k \leq 6$, and we will see that there is a more comprehensive spectral expression of the duality, for which the order $d_{7-k} \in\{2,4,8\}$ of the cyclic group $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle$ corresponds to the index of $\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{7-k}\right\}$ in $\mathbb{Z}\left\{B_{7-k} / B\right\}$. The spectrum level statement

$$
\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

is given in Theorem 10.6, and the duality between $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle$ and $\mathbb{Z}\left\{B_{7-k} / B\right\} / \mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{7-k}\right\}$ appears in Theorem 10.25. We explain the notation $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$ in Section 10.2 and recall the Brown-Comenetz duality functor $I$ in Section 10.3, where we also establish the spectrum level duality by a descent argument along $\iota^{\prime}: \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3) \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle$.

The duality theorem can be re-expressed in terms of local cohomology spectra and Anderson duality, as we spell out in Proposition 10.12 of Section 10.4:

$$
\Sigma^{22} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\Gamma_{(B, M)} \operatorname{tmf}\right)
$$

By construction, $t m f$ is the connective cover of an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $T m f$, and the equivalence above extends to an Anderson self-duality of $T m f$ :

$$
\Sigma^{21} \operatorname{Tmf} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\operatorname{Tmf})
$$

See Theorem 10.13 for a proof following $[\mathbf{6 7}]$ of the 2 -complete part of this result. Finally, in Section 10.5 we translate the spectrum level duality equivalence into a series of algebraic duality isomorphisms, which are summarized in Theorem 10.26.

# 10.2. Torsion submodules and divisible quotients 

Definition 10.1. Let $R$ be a commutative $S$-algebra ( $=E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum), let $M$ be an $R$-module spectrum, and let $x \in \pi_{d}(R)$. Let $M / x$ be the homotopy cofiber of the multiplication-by- $x$ map

$$
\Sigma^{d} M \xrightarrow{x} M
$$

let $M[1 / x]$ be the homotopy colimit of the sequence

$$
M \xrightarrow{x} \Sigma^{-d} M \xrightarrow{x} \Sigma^{-2 d} M \xrightarrow{x} \ldots
$$

and let $M / x^{\infty}$ be the homotopy cofiber of the structure map $M \rightarrow M[1 / x]$. Note that $\pi_{*}(M[1 / x])=\pi_{*}(M)[1 / x]$, so that there is a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{*}(M) / x^{\infty} \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(M / x^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{x} \pi_{*-1}(M) \rightarrow 0
$$

where $\Gamma_{x} M_{*}$ and $M_{*} / x^{\infty}$ denote the kernel and cokernel of the localization homomorphism $M_{*} \rightarrow M_{*}[1 / x]$, for any $\pi_{*}(R)$-module $M_{*}$. In other words, $\Gamma_{x} M_{*}$ is the $x$-power torsion submodule of $M_{*}$, and $M_{*} / x^{\infty}$ is an $x$-divisible quotient of $M_{*}[1 / x]$. By reversal of priorities, we can also view $M / x^{\infty}$ as the homotopy colimit of the homotopy cofibers of the maps $x^{n}: M \rightarrow \Sigma^{-n d} M$, so that

$$
M / x^{\infty} \simeq \operatorname{hocolim}_{n} \Sigma^{-n d} M / x^{n}
$$

We shall also make use of the evident homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
M / x \longrightarrow \Sigma^{d} M / x^{\infty} \xrightarrow{x} M / x^{\infty}
$$

We are interested in cases such as $M=R, M=R[1 / x]$ and $M=R / x^{\infty}$. If also $y \in \pi_{e}(R)$, we obtain a square of homotopy cofiber sequences
![img-150.jpeg](img-150.jpeg)
in the category of $R$-modules, where $R /\left(x^{\infty}, y^{\infty}\right)=R / x^{\infty} \wedge_{R} R / y^{\infty}$ is the iterated homotopy cofiber of the upper left hand square. Likewise, if $z \in \pi_{f}(R)$ then there is a cube of homotopy cofiber sequences, with

$$
R /\left(x^{\infty}, y^{\infty}, z^{\infty}\right)=R / x^{\infty} \wedge_{R} R / y^{\infty} \wedge_{R} R / z^{\infty}
$$

being the iterated homotopy cofiber of the initial cube
![img-151.jpeg](img-151.jpeg)

Remark 10.2. Following Greenlees-May [66, §3], one can work with the homotopy $x$-power torsion ( $=$ local cohomology) spectrum $\Gamma_{x} M$, defined as the homotopy fiber of $M \rightarrow M[1 / x]$, in place of the homotopy cofiber $M / x^{\infty}$. Since $\Sigma \Gamma_{x} M \simeq M / x^{\infty}$ this only amounts to a shift in grading, which, however, may be convenient for the discussion of multiplicative structure. There is a natural short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{*+1}(M) / x^{\infty} \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(\Gamma_{x} M\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{x} \pi_{*}(M) \rightarrow 0
$$

Iterating, $\Gamma_{(x, y)} R=\Gamma_{x}\left(\Gamma_{y} R\right)$ is the double homotopy fiber of the initial square above, with $\Sigma^{2} \Gamma_{(x, y)} R \simeq R /\left(x^{\infty}, y^{\infty}\right)$. Similarly, $\Gamma_{(x, y, z)} R=\Gamma_{x}\left(\Gamma_{y}\left(\Gamma_{z} R\right)\right)$ is the triple homotopy fiber of the displayed cube, with $\Sigma^{3} \Gamma_{(x, y, z)} R \simeq R /\left(x^{\infty}, y^{\infty}, z^{\infty}\right)$.

Lemma 10.3 ([66]). Let $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in \pi_{*}(R)$. The homotopy type of the $R$ module $R /\left(x_{1}^{\infty}, \ldots, x_{n}^{\infty}\right)$ only depends on $n$ and the radical $\sqrt{J}$ of the ideal $J=$ $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ in $\pi_{*}(R)$.

Proof. In view of the equivalence $R /\left(x_{1}^{\infty}, \ldots, x_{n}^{\infty}\right) \simeq \Sigma^{n} \Gamma_{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)} R$, this is a restatement of the fact that $\Gamma_{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)} R$ only depends on the radical of $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, which is explained in $[\mathbf{6 6}$, p. 266].

# 10.3. Brown-Comenetz duality 

Recall the Bott element $B \in \pi_{8}(t m f)$ with $B \in\left\{w_{1}\right\}$, and the Mahowald element $M \in \pi_{192}(t m f)$ with $M \in\left\{w_{2}^{4}\right\}$. We shall study $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-modules obtained by restriction along $\mathbb{Z}[B, M] \rightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f)$, or by induction along $\mathbb{Z}[B] \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}[B, M]$. Recall also the following notation from Section 9.4.

Definition 10.4. Let $N_{*} \subset \pi_{*}(t m f)$ be the $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-submodule generated by the classes in degrees $0 \leq *<192$, or equivalently, by the classes in degrees $0 \leq * \leq 180$.

By the results of the previous chapter, cf. Theorem 9.26, the $B$-power torsion $\Gamma_{B} N_{*}$ is finite in degrees $3 \leq * \leq 164$ and is trivial outside this range. Furthermore, the $B$-divisible quotient $N_{*} / B^{\infty}$ is concentrated in degrees $\leq 172$. The group in degree 172 is a copy of $\mathbb{Z}$ generated by $C_{7} / B$, where $C_{7} \in\left\{h_{0} \alpha^{3} w_{2}^{3}\right\}$, and the group in degree 171 is trivial.

Since $w_{2}^{4}$ acts freely on the Adams $E_{\infty}$-term for $t m f$, the composite homomorphism

$$
N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] \longrightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f) \otimes \pi_{*}(t m f) \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{*}(t m f)
$$

is an isomorphism of $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-modules. In particular, $\Gamma_{M} \pi_{*}(t m f)=0$ and

$$
\pi_{*}\left(t m f / M^{\infty}\right) \cong \pi_{*}(t m f) / M^{\infty}=N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty}
$$

where $\mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty}=\mathbb{Z}\left[M, M^{-1}\right] / \mathbb{Z}[M] \cong \mathbb{Z}\left[M^{-1}\right]\{1 / M\}$. Hence there is a short exact sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 0 \rightarrow N_{*} / B^{\infty} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty} \\
& \quad \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{B} N_{*-1} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty} \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that $\pi_{*}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ is concentrated in degrees $* \leq-20$, with the group in degree -20 being a copy of $\mathbb{Z}$ generated by $C_{7} / B M$, and the group in degree -21 being zero. Using the short exact sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 0 \rightarrow \pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) / 2^{\infty} \\
& \quad \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

we conclude that $\pi_{*}\left(t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ is concentrated in degrees $* \leq-20$, with the group in degree -20 being a copy of $\mathbb{Z} / 2^{\infty}$.

Definition 10.5. Let $I=I_{\mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}}$ be the Brown-Comenetz dual of the sphere spectrum $[\mathbf{3 6}]$. This is the spectrum representing the generalized cohomology theory

$$
X \longmapsto I^{n}(X)=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{n}(X), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)
$$

Let $I(X)=F(X, I)$, so that $\pi_{-n} I(X)=I^{n}(X)$. If $M$ is an $R$-module spectrum, then $I(M)=F(M, I)$ is naturally an $R$-module spectrum.

Here is our formulation of the duality theorem.
THEOREM 10.6. There is a duality equivalence of (implicitly 2-completed) tmfmodules

$$
\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

Proof. By the discussion at the beginning of this section, the homotopy groups of $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$ are concentrated in degrees $* \leq-20$, with the group in degree -20 being a copy of $\mathbb{Z} / 2^{\infty}$. Hence the homotopy groups of the BrownComenetz dual $I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ are concentrated in degrees $* \geq 20$, with the group in degree 20 being isomorphic to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{Z} / 2^{\infty}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)=\mathbb{Z}_{2}$. Representing a (2-adic) generator for this group by a map from $S^{20}$, we obtain a tmf-module map

$$
a: \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \longrightarrow I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

between 19-connected spectra, which induces an isomorphism on $\pi_{20}$. We will show that $a$ is in fact an equivalence, as a consequence of an easier duality result for the truncated Brown-Peterson spectrum $B P\langle 2\rangle$.

Recall from Remark 1.16 and Equation (9.5) in the proof of Proposition 9.19 that Lawson and Naumann $[\mathbf{9 1}]$ constructed a map of (implicitly 2-complete) commutative $S$-algebras $\iota^{\prime}: \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3) \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle$, where $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)=\mathbb{Z}\left[v_{1}, v_{2}\right]$ maps isomorphically to $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3)\right)=\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{1}, a_{3}\right]$ by $v_{1} \mapsto-a_{1} \equiv a_{1} \bmod 2$ and $v_{2} \mapsto-7 a_{3} \equiv a_{3} \bmod \left(2, a_{1}\right)$. The map $\iota^{\prime}$ induces $B \mapsto c_{4}=a_{1}\left(a_{1}^{3}-24 a_{3}\right)$ and $M \mapsto \Delta^{8}$ with $\Delta=a_{3}^{3}\left(a_{1}^{3}-27 a_{3}\right)$. It is straightforward to check that the radical of the ideal $J=\left(2, c_{4}, \Delta^{8}\right)$ in $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{1}(3)\right)$ equals $\sqrt{J}=\left(2, a_{1}, a_{3}\right)$, which corresponds to $\left(2, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ in $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$.

The main step is to show that the coinduced $B P\langle 2\rangle$-module map

$$
\begin{aligned}
b=F_{t m f}(B P\langle 2\rangle, a): F_{t m f}(B P\langle 2\rangle, & \left.\Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \\
& \left.\longrightarrow F_{t m f}\left(B P\langle 2\rangle, I\left(t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is an equivalence. We start with the target of $b$. Induction along $\iota^{\prime}: t m f \rightarrow B P\langle 2\rangle$ takes $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$ to

$$
\begin{aligned}
B P\langle 2\rangle \wedge_{t m f} t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) & \cong B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) \\
& =B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, c_{4}^{\infty},\left(\Delta^{8}\right)^{\infty}\right) \\
& \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The middle identity uses that $\iota_{*}^{\prime}: \pi_{*}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$ maps $B$ and $M$ to $c_{4}$ and $\Delta^{8}$, respectively. The final equivalence uses that $B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, c_{4}^{\infty},\left(\Delta^{8}\right)^{\infty}\right)$ and $B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)$ are equivalent as $B P\langle 2\rangle$-modules because $\left(2, c_{4}, \Delta^{8}\right)$ and $\left(2, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ have the same radical in $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)=\mathbb{Z}\left[v_{1}, v_{2}\right]$, cf. Lemma 10.3.

Applying the Brown-Comenetz duality functor $I$, we see that coinduction along $\iota^{\prime}$ takes $I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ to

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{t m f}\left(B P\langle 2\rangle, I\left(t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)\right) & \cong I\left(B P\langle 2\rangle \wedge_{t m f} t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \\
& \simeq I\left(B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The homotopy groups of $B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)$ are

$$
\mathbb{Z}\left[v_{1}, v_{2}\right] /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)=\mathbb{Z} / 2^{\infty}\left[v_{1}^{-1}, v_{2}^{-1}\right]\left\{1 / v_{1} v_{2}\right\}
$$

with $1 / v_{1} v_{2}$ in degree -8 . Hence the target

$$
\pi_{*}\left(I\left(B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)\right)\right) \cong \Sigma^{8} \pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)
$$

of $\pi_{*}(b)$ is a free module over $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$, on a single generator in degree 8 .
Next, we consider the source of $b$. Let $\Phi=\Phi A(1)$ be a finite (8-cell) 12dimensional CW spectrum with cohomology realizing $A(2) / / E(2)$, i.e., the double of $A(1)=\left\langle S q^{1}, S q^{2}\right\rangle$. We saw in Lemma 1.42 that such spectra exist. Then $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Phi \simeq B P\langle 2\rangle$ as $t m f$-modules, because $A / / A(2) \otimes A(2) / / E(2) \cong A / / E(2)$. The Spanier-Whitehead dual $D \Phi=F(\Phi, S)$ has cohomology realizing $\Sigma^{-12} A(2) / / E(2)$ as an $A(2)$-module, so there is also an equivalence of $t m f$-modules $F(\Phi, t m f) \simeq$ $\Sigma^{-12} B P\langle 2\rangle$. Coinduction along $\iota^{\prime}$ therefore takes $\Sigma^{20} t m f$ to

$$
F_{t m f}\left(B P\langle 2\rangle, \Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \simeq F\left(\Phi, \Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \simeq \Sigma^{8} B P\langle 2\rangle
$$

in the category of $t m f$-modules. Hence the source of the homomorphism $\pi_{*}(b)$ is isomorphic to $\Sigma^{8} \pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$ as a $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-module, and, in particular, as a graded abelian group.

The coinduced $B P\langle 2\rangle$-module map

$$
b=F_{t m f}(B P\langle 2\rangle, a): \Sigma^{8} B P\langle 2\rangle \longrightarrow I\left(B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

can be written as $F(\Phi, a)$, hence is a map between 7 -connected spectra that induces an isomorphism on $\pi_{8}$. It follows that

$$
\pi_{*}(b): \Sigma^{8} \pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle) \longrightarrow \Sigma^{8} \pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)
$$

is surjective, since it is $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$-linear and maps onto the $\pi_{*}(B P\langle 2\rangle)$-module generator of the target. Furthermore, its source and target are abstractly isomorphic and of finite type as (implicitly 2-completed) graded abelian groups, so the surjectivity implies that $\pi_{*}(b)$ is in fact an isomorphism.

It follows that $b$ is an equivalence and the homotopy cofiber $C b$ is contractible. The Hurewicz theorem then implies that $C a$ is contractible, and that $a$ is an equivalence, since $D \Phi \wedge C a \simeq F(\Phi, C a) \simeq C b$ and $H_{-12}(D \Phi ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H^{12}(\Phi ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.

REMARK 10.7. The theorem can be reformulated as saying that there is a perfect (Brown-Comenetz duality) pairing

$$
\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \wedge \operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow I
$$

When smashed with the perfect (Spanier-Whitehead duality) pairing

$$
D \Phi \wedge \Phi \longrightarrow S
$$

it gives the perfect pairing

$$
\Sigma^{8} B P\langle 2\rangle \wedge B P\langle 2\rangle /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}, v_{2}^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow I
$$

Lemma 10.8. The $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$-module isomorphism

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{*}: \pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \xrightarrow{\cong} \pi_{*} I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \\
\quad=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{-*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is adjoint to a perfect pairing

$$
\langle-,-\rangle: \pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \times \pi_{-*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \longrightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

with $\langle x, y\rangle=a_{*}(x)(y)$, such that

$$
\langle r \cdot x, y\rangle=(-1)^{|r||x|}\langle x, r \cdot y\rangle
$$

for $r \in \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf}), x \in \pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right)$ and $y \in \pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)$ with $|r|+|x|+$ $|y|=0$.

Proof. The formula $\langle r \cdot x, y\rangle=(-1)^{|r||x|}\langle x, r \cdot y\rangle$ follows by adjunction from $a_{*}(r \cdot x)=r \cdot a_{*}(x)$, where $\left(r \cdot a_{*}(x)\right)(y)=(-1)^{|r||x|} a_{*}(x)(r \cdot y)$.

REMARK 10.9. A similar argument proves that $\Sigma^{4} k o \simeq I\left(k o /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right)$, using $k o \wedge C \eta \simeq k u$ and $\Sigma^{2} k u \simeq I\left(k u /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}\right)\right)$. The smash product of the perfect pairings

$$
\Sigma^{4} k o \wedge k o /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow I
$$

and

$$
D C \eta \wedge C \eta \longrightarrow S
$$

gives the perfect pairing

$$
\Sigma^{2} k u \wedge k u /\left(2^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow I
$$

The $\pi_{*}(k o)$-module isomorphism

$$
\left.\pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{4} k o\right) \xrightarrow{\cong} \pi_{*} I\left(k o /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right)=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{-*}\left(k o /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)\right)
$$

is adjoint to a perfect pairing

$$
\langle-.-\rangle: \pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{4} k o\right) \times \pi_{-*}\left(k o /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right) \longrightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

# 10.4. Anderson duality 

The natural double duality map $\rho: X \rightarrow I(I(X))$ is an equivalence whenever each group $\pi_{n}(X)$ is finite. There is a modification $I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)$ of the BrownComenetz dual, known as the Anderson dual [180], such that the natural map $\rho: X \rightarrow I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)\right)$ is an equivalence whenever each group $\pi_{n}(X)$ is finitely generated. The modification is defined by the homotopy fiber sequence

$$
I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X) \longrightarrow I_{\mathbb{Q}}(X) \longrightarrow I_{\mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}}(X)
$$

where $I_{\mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}}(X)=I(X)$ is the Brown-Comenetz dual of $X$ and $I_{\mathbb{Q}}(X)=F(X, H \mathbb{Q})$. Here $H \mathbb{Q}$ represents ordinary rational cohomology

$$
X \longmapsto H^{n}(X ; \mathbb{Q}) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{n}(X), \mathbb{Q}\right)
$$

The associated long exact sequence of homotopy groups breaks up into short exact sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}\left(\pi_{n-1}(X), \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow \pi_{-n} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{n}(X), \mathbb{Z}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

Lemma 10.10. For each prime $p$, there is a natural chain of equivalences

$$
I\left(X / p^{\infty}\right) \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)_{p}^{\wedge}
$$

Proof. Applying the contravariant duality functors to the homotopy cofiber sequence $X \xrightarrow{p^{n}} X \longrightarrow X / p^{n}$ we obtain a commutative diagram of horizontal and vertical homotopy (co-)fiber sequences
![img-152.jpeg](img-152.jpeg)

Here $I_{\mathbb{Q}}\left(X / p^{n}\right) \simeq *$, so

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(X / p^{\infty}\right) & \simeq I\left(\operatorname{hocolim}_{n} X / p^{n}\right) \simeq \operatorname{holim}_{n} I\left(X / p^{n}\right) \\
& \simeq \operatorname{holim}_{n} \Sigma I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(X / p^{n}\right) \simeq \operatorname{holim}_{n} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X) / p^{n} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(X)_{p}^{\wedge}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using local cohomology spectra and/or Anderson duality, we can reformulate the duality equivalence of Theorem 10.6 in various ways.

Definition 10.11. For brevity, let $t m f^{\prime}=t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$, so that $t m f^{\prime} \simeq$ $\Sigma^{2} \Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f$

Proposition 10.12. There are equivalences of (implicitly 2-completed) tmfmodules

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Sigma^{20} t m f \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right)=I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right) \\
& \Sigma^{22} t m f \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f\right) \\
& \Sigma^{23} t m f \simeq I\left(\Gamma_{(2, B, M)} t m f\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. This follows directly from the $t m f$-module equivalences

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(t m f^{\prime} / 2^{\infty}\right) & \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right)_{2}^{\wedge} \\
t m f^{\prime}=t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) & \simeq \Sigma^{2} \Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f \\
t m f /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) & \simeq \Sigma^{3} \Gamma_{(2, B, M)} t m f
\end{aligned}
$$

The topological modular forms spectrum $t m f$ is defined as the connective cover of an $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $T m f$, which can be constructed using Goerss-HopkinsMiller obstruction theory [62], [54, Ch. 12], or Lurie's spectral orientation and deformation theories for $p$-divisible groups and formal groups [96, §4], [97] and [98]. In either case $T m f$ is defined as the global sections in a sheaf of $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra over a compactified moduli stack $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$ of generalized elliptic curves. This moduli stack is covered by the two open substacks of ordinary generalized elliptic curves (where $c_{4}$ and $B$ are invertible), and of non-generalized elliptic curves (where $\Delta$ and $M$ are invertible). It follows that there is a homotopy pullback square
![img-153.jpeg](img-153.jpeg)

Since the covering map $i: t m f \rightarrow T m f$ induces equivalences after inverting $B, M$ or both, it also follows that we have a homotopy (co-)fiber sequence of $t m f$-modules

$$
\Sigma^{-2} t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow t m f \xrightarrow{i} T m f \longrightarrow \Sigma^{-1} t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)
$$

which we can write in terms of local cohomology spectra as

$$
\Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f \longrightarrow t m f \xrightarrow{i} T m f \longrightarrow \Sigma \Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f
$$

Using the duality equivalence, we can rewrite this as

$$
\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f) \xrightarrow{\partial} t m f \xrightarrow{i} T m f \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{-21} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f)
$$

Vesna Stojanoska [161, Thm. 13.1] showed that $T m f$ is Anderson self-dual in the sense that there is an equivalence $\Sigma^{21} T m f \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(T m f)$. More precisely, the cited reference shows this as an equivalence after inverting $p=2$, while the corresponding 2-local calculations have not been fully published. In [67, Prop. 4.1], Greenlees and Stojanoska show how to deduce integral Anderson self-duality for $T m f$ from Gorenstein duality for $t m f \rightarrow H \mathbb{Z}$, and later work [43] by Greenlees and the current two authors establishes this Gorenstein duality property, also at $p=2$. Using our present notation, the 2-complete part of Stojanoska's theorem can be demonstrated as follows. The argument is essentially that of $[\mathbf{6 7}]$.

THEOREM 10.13. There is a duality equivalence of (implicitly 2-completed) tmfmodules

$$
\Sigma^{21} \operatorname{Tmf} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\operatorname{Tmf})
$$

Proof. Applying $\Sigma^{-21} I_{\mathbb{Z}}$ to (10.4) we obtain a homotopy (co-)fiber sequence of $t m f$-modules

$$
\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f) \xrightarrow{\delta} t m f \longrightarrow \Sigma^{-21} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(T m f) \longrightarrow \Sigma^{-21} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f)
$$

where $\delta=\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\partial)$. It suffices to prove that $\delta$ is homotopic to $\partial$, up to sign, since then $\operatorname{Tmf} \simeq C \partial \simeq C \delta \simeq \Sigma^{-21} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\operatorname{Tmf})$. The homotopy classes of $\partial$ and $\delta$ lie in the abelian group

$$
G=\left[\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f), t m f\right]_{0}^{t m f}=\pi_{0} F_{t m f}\left(\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f), t m f\right)
$$

and the functor $\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}$ induces an involution on $G$, interchanging $\partial$ and $\delta$. For any $t m f$-module $X$ there are equivalences

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{t m f}\left(\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f), X\right) & \simeq F_{t m f}\left(\Gamma_{(B, M)} t m f, X\right) \\
& \simeq F_{t m f}\left(\operatorname{hocolim}_{k, \ell} \Sigma^{-8 k-192 \ell-2} t m f /\left(B^{k}, M^{\ell}\right), X\right) \\
& \simeq \operatorname{holim}_{k, \ell} F_{t m f}\left(\Sigma^{-8 k-192 \ell-2} t m f /\left(B^{k}, M^{\ell}\right), X\right) \\
& \simeq \operatorname{holim}_{k, \ell} X /\left(B^{k}, M^{\ell}\right)=X_{(B, M)}^{\wedge}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the final homotopy limit defines the $(B, M)$-completion of $X$. For $X=t m f$, the completion map $X \rightarrow \operatorname{holim}_{k, \ell} X /\left(B^{k}, M^{\ell}\right)=X_{(B, M)}^{\wedge}$ is an equivalence, since $t m f$ is bounded below and both $B$ and $M$ have positive degree. Hence $G=$ $\pi_{0} F_{t m f}\left(\Sigma^{-22} I_{\mathbb{Z}}(t m f), t m f\right) \cong \pi_{0}\left(t m f_{(B, M)}^{\wedge}\right) \cong \pi_{0}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z}$ (up to implicit 2completion), and the only possible involutions on $G$ are given by multiplication by 1 or -1 . This proves that $\delta \simeq \pm \partial$.

# 10.5. Explicit formulas 

We now turn the spectrum level duality equivalence from Theorem 10.6 into a series of algebraic duality statement about $\pi_{*}(t m f)$, or more precisely, about the subquotients of a filtration

$$
0 \subset \Theta \pi_{*}(t m f) \subset \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f) \subset \Gamma_{2} \pi_{*}(t m f) \subset \pi_{*}(t m f)
$$

We will use the following variant of (10.3).
Lemma 10.14. For any $R$-module spectrum $M$ there is a natural short exact sequence of $\pi_{*}(R)$-modules

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}(M), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow \pi_{-*} I\left(M / 2^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M), \mathbb{Z}_{2}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

Proof. The short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{*}(M) / 2^{\infty} \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(M / 2^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}(M) \rightarrow 0
$$

is Pontryagin dual to a short exact sequence of $\pi_{*}(R)$-modules

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 0 \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}(M), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}\left(M / 2^{\infty}\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M) / 2^{\infty}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}\left(M / 2^{\infty}\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)=\pi_{-*} I\left(M / 2^{\infty}\right)$, by definition, and there is a natural chain of isomorphisms

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M) / 2^{\infty}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\operatorname{colim}_{n} \pi_{*}(M) / 2^{n}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \\
& \quad \cong \lim _{n} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M) / 2^{n}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \cong \lim _{n} \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M), \mathbb{Z} / 2^{n}\right)=\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}(M), \mathbb{Z}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall our notation $t m f^{\prime}=t m f /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)$.

THEOREM 10.15. There are short exact sequences of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-modules

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f) /\left(B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*-1}(t m f) / M^{\infty} \rightarrow 0
$$

and

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow \pi_{-*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right), \mathbb{Z}_{2}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

Proof. The first exact sequence follows from (10.1), since $\pi_{*}(t m f) \cong N_{*} \otimes$ $\mathbb{Z}[M]$ implies $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}\left(t m f / M^{\infty}\right) \cong \Gamma_{B} N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty}$.

The second exact sequence follows from the duality theorem, in the formulation $\Sigma^{20} t m f \simeq I\left(t m f^{\prime} / 2^{\infty}\right)$, and Lemma 10.14.

Recall the $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-module identification $\pi_{*}(t m f) \cong N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]$. As we saw in Theorem 9.26, the $B$-torsion free image of $N_{*}$ in $N_{*}[1 / B]$ is the direct sum

$$
N_{*} / \Gamma_{B} N_{*}=\bigoplus_{k=0}^{7} k o[k]
$$

of the following eight $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules, with $k o[k]$ concentrated in degrees $* \geq 24 k$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& k o[0]=\mathbb{Z}[B]\{1, C\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta, \eta^{2}\right\} \\
& k o[1]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{1}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{1}, C_{1}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta_{1}, \eta \eta_{1}\right\} \\
& k o[2]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{2}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{2}, C_{2}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta B_{2}, \eta_{1}^{2}\right\} \\
& k o[3]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{3}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{3}, C_{3}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta B_{3}, \eta^{2} B_{3}\right\} \\
& k o[4]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{4}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{4}, C_{4}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta_{4}, \eta \eta_{4}\right\} \\
& k o[5]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{5}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{5}, C_{5}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta B_{5}, \eta_{1} \eta_{4}\right\} \\
& k o[6]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{6}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{6}, C_{6}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta B_{6}, \eta^{2} B_{6}\right\} \\
& k o[7]=\mathbb{Z}\left\{D_{7}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z}[B]\left\{B_{7}, C_{7}\right\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2[B]\left\{\eta B_{7}, \eta^{2} B_{7}\right\}
\end{aligned}

The $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module structures are specified by $B \cdot D_{k}=d_{k} B_{k}$ for each $1 \leq k \leq$ 7, where the numbers $d_{k} \in\{2,4,8\}$ are as in Definition 9.18. In each case, $k o[k][1 / B] \cong \pi_{*}(K O)$. It follows that

is the direct sum of the following eight $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules, with $k o[k] / B^{\infty}$ concentrated in degrees $* \leq 4+24 k$ :

& k o[4] / B^{\infty}=\mathbb{Z}\left[B^{-1}\right]\left\{B_{4} / B, C_{4} / B\right\} /\left(2 B_{4} / B\right) \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 2\left[B^{-1}\right]\left\{\eta_{4} / B, \eta \eta_{4} / B\right\} \\

The following lemma specifies a $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module extension $N_{*}^{\prime}$, uniquely up to isomorphism. It will play an important role in the following calculations. The notation $N_{*}^{\prime}$ is chosen to parallel that of $t m f^{\prime}$.

Lemma 10.16. The restriction of the $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-module extension

$$
0 \rightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f) / B^{\infty} \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(t m f / B^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*-1}(t m f) \rightarrow 0
$$

to a $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-module extension is induced up from a unique $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module extension

$$
0 \rightarrow N_{*} / B^{\infty} \longrightarrow N_{*}^{\prime} \longrightarrow \Gamma_{B} N_{*-1} \rightarrow 0
$$

Hence $\pi_{*}\left(t m f / B^{\infty}\right)=N_{*}^{\prime} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]$ and $\pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right)=N_{*}^{\prime} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty}$ as $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$ modules.

Proof. We claim that the induction homomorphism

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B]}^{1}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}, N_{*} / B^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B, M]}^{1}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M], N_{*} / B^{\infty} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]\right) & \\
& \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B]}^{1}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}, N_{*} / B^{\infty} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is bijective. This follows from the observation that

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B]}^{s}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}, N_{*} / B^{\infty} \otimes(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})\right)=0
$$

for $s \in\{0,1\}$, since $\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}$ is concentrated in degrees $* \leq 165$, and $N_{*} / B^{\infty} \otimes$ $(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})$ agrees with $N_{*}[1 / B] \otimes(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})$ in degrees $*<192$. In more detail, the groups

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B]}^{s}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}, N_{*}[1 / B] \otimes(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})\right)
$$

vanish because $B$ acts nilpotently on $\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}$ and invertibly on $N_{*}[1 / B]$. The groups

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathbb{Z}[B]}^{s+1}\left(\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}, N_{*} / \Gamma_{B} N_{*} \otimes(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})\right)
$$

vanish because $\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}$ admits a projective $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module resolution with generators in degrees $* \leq 173$, and $N_{*} / \Gamma_{B} N_{*} \otimes(\mathbb{Z}[M] / \mathbb{Z})$ is concentrated in degrees $* \geq$ 192 .

Lemma 10.17. $\pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right)$ is bounded above and of finite type.
Proof. It is clear from the formulas for the $k o[k] / B^{\infty}$ that $N_{*}^{\prime}$ is of finite type and bounded above, hence so is its tensor product with $\mathbb{Z}[M] / M^{\infty}$.

We can now define the Pontryagin self-dual part of $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f) \subset \pi_{*}(t m f)$.

and let the $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module $\Theta N_{*-1}$ be the image of the composite homomorphism

of $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-modules. When we later use the notation $\Theta \pi_{-*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right)$, we mean the same as $\Theta \pi_{-*-20}(t m f)$.

of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules. Here

$$

and

Proof. This is clear with the definitions above. Precise formulas for the $\Gamma_{2} k o[k]$ and $k o[k] / \Gamma_{2} k o[k]$ can be read off from the formulas (10.5) for $k o[k]$.

Lemma 10.20. There is a filtration of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-modules

0 \subset\left(\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*}(t m f)\right) / B^{\infty} \subset \Gamma_{2}\left(\pi_{*}(t m f) / B^{\infty}\right) \subset \Gamma_{2} \pi_{*}\left(t m f / B^{\infty}\right) \subset \pi_{*}\left(t m f / B^{\infty}\right)

of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules. Here

$$
\begin{gathered}

\frac{\Gamma_{2}\left(N_{*} / B^{\infty}\right)}{\left(\Gamma_{2} N_{*}\right) / B^{\infty}} \cong \bigoplus_{k=1}^{7}\left\langle B_{k} / B\right\rangle

with $\left\langle B_{k} / B\right\rangle$ cyclic of order $d_{k}$,

of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules.
Proof. Formulas for

\left(\Gamma_{2} N_{*}\right) / B^{\infty} \cong\left(\Gamma_{2} N_{*} / \Gamma_{B} N_{*}\right) / B^{\infty}=\bigoplus_{k=0}^{7}\left(\Gamma_{2} k o[k]\right) / B^{\infty}
$$

and

$$
\Gamma_{2}\left(N_{*} / B^{\infty}\right)=\bigoplus_{k=0}^{7} \Gamma_{2}\left(k o[k] / B^{\infty}\right)

can be read off from the formulas for $k o[k]$ and $k o[k] / B^{\infty}$, respectively. This gives the stated seven-term sum for $\Gamma_{2}\left(N_{*} / B^{\infty}\right)$ modulo $\left(\Gamma_{2} N_{*}\right) / B^{\infty}$.

Theorem 10.22. The duality isomorphism

a_{*}: \pi_{-*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime} / 2^{\infty}\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)

of Theorem 10.6 specializes to isomorphisms of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-modules

Hence there are isomorphisms

and a short exact sequence

all in the category of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules.
Proof. By Lemma 10.17, $\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right)$ is finite in each degree, so the second short exact sequence in Theorem 10.15 specializes to a $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-isomorphism $\Gamma_{2} a_{*}$ between $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Gamma_{2} \pi_{*-1}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right), \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)$ and the 2 -power torsion in $\pi_{-*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right)$, as well as a $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-isomorphism between the 2-torsion free quotient of $\pi_{-*}\left(\Sigma^{20} t m f\right)$ and $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{*}\left(t m f^{\prime}\right), \mathbb{Z}_{2}\right)$.

of Lemma 10.20, combined with the facts that $N_{*}^{\prime} / \Gamma_{2} N_{*}^{\prime}$ is free in each degree and $\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1} / \Theta N_{*-1}$ is finite in each degree, leads to a short exact sequence

and

$$

yields the required short exact sequence.
Definition 10.23. For $0 \leq k \leq 6$ let $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle \subset \Gamma_{B} N_{*} \subset \Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ denote the finite abelian group generated by the class $\nu_{k}$ in degree $3+24 k$, subject to the interpretations $\nu_{0}=\nu$ and $\nu_{3}=\eta_{1}^{3}$. Note that $\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle$ is cyclic of order $d_{7-k} \in\{2,4,8\}$.

Proposition 10.24. The $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-submodule $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ of $\Gamma_{B} \pi_{*}(t m f)$ consists precisely of the classes in degrees $* \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$. Likewise, the $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-submodule $\Theta N_{*}$ of $\Gamma_{B} N_{*}$ consists precisely of the classes in degrees $* \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$. Hence

$$

as $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-modules and

$$
\frac{\Gamma_{B} N_{*}}{\Theta N_{*}} \cong \bigoplus_{k=0}^{6}\left\langle\nu_{k}\right\rangle
$$

as $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules (with trivial $B$-action).

Proof. For the moment we only prove that $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f) \cong \Theta N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[M]$ is trivial in degrees $* \equiv 3 \bmod 24$. By inspection of $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ (or $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ ), it is clear that $\pi_{*}(t m f)=0$ for $* \equiv-1 \bmod 24$. Hence $\Gamma_{2} N_{*}=N_{*}=0$ for $* \equiv-1 \bmod 24$. By Theorem 10.22 it follows that $\Gamma_{2} N_{*}^{\prime}=0$ for $* \equiv 4 \bmod 24$. Thus the image $\Theta N_{*-1}$ of this group in $\Gamma_{B} N_{*-1}$ is also trivial, for each $*-1 \equiv 3 \bmod 24$.

The proof that all classes in degrees $* \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$ lie in $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ will be completed by a counting argument, in the course of the proof of Theorem 10.25.

between the $B$-power torsion submodules, and an isomorphism

The specialization of $\Gamma_{2} a_{*}$ to the $B$-power torsion submodules takes the form

$$

so that there is a short exact sequence

of $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-modules. Viewed as $\mathbb{Z}[B, M]$-modules, it can be rewritten as

hence is induced up, after regrading by $192-2=190$, from a short exact sequence

of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules.
We now complete the proof of Proposition 10.24. The total order of the graded finite abelian group $\Theta N_{*}$ is equal to the total order of $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Theta N_{*}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)$, and the total order of $\Gamma_{B} N_{*}$ is equal to the total order of $\Gamma_{B} N_{170-*}$. of $\Gamma_{B} N_{*} / \Theta N_{*}$ is equal to the total order of $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\bigoplus_{k=1}^{7}\left\langle B_{k} / B\right\rangle_{*+1}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)$, which is $8 \cdot 4 \cdot 8 \cdot 2 \cdot 8 \cdot 4 \cdot 8=2^{17}$. The two remaining $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-module isomorphisms are obtained by specializing the $B$-power torsion isomorphism $\Gamma_{B} a_{*}$ to degrees $-*-20 \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$ and degrees $-*-20 \equiv 3 \bmod 24$, respectively. When combined with the previous expressions for $K_{*}^{1}$ and $K_{*}^{2}$, this completes the proof of the three $\pi_{*}(t m f)$-module isomorphisms. The three $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module isomorphisms follow easily from this.

REMARK 10.28. In the proof of Theorem 10.6 we made an arbitrary choice of a 2-adic generator of $\pi_{20} I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(2^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, M^{\infty}\right)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z}_{2}$. Multiplying by any 2 -adic unit $u$ gives another generator, and would multiply the duality equivalence $a$ and the associated pairings $\langle-,-\rangle$ and $(-,-)$ by the same unit $u$. Hence we can only expect to give well-defined expressions for the pairings $(x, y) \in \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}$ when the values are 0 or $1 / 2 \bmod 1$.

Once a choice of $a$ is fixed, it is possible to specify a choice of generator $\nu_{6} \in$ $\pi_{147}(\operatorname{tmf}) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 8$ in terms of a choice of $\bar{\kappa} \in \pi_{20}(\operatorname{tmf})$, e.g., by demanding that $\left(\bar{\kappa}, \nu \nu_{6}\right) \equiv 1 / 8 \bmod 1$ (as opposed to $3 / 8,5 / 8$ or $7 / 8$ ). In view of our conventions $\nu_{2} \nu_{4}=3 \nu \nu_{6}$ and $\nu D_{4}=2 \nu_{4}$ from Definition 9.22 , this would reduce the combined multiplicative indeterminacy in $\nu_{2}$ and $\nu_{4}$ by a factor of $\mathbb{Z} / 8^{\times}$.

\begin{aligned}
\left(\nu_{2} \kappa, \eta \epsilon_{4}\right) & =\left(\eta \nu_{2} \kappa, \epsilon_{4}\right)=1 / 2 \bmod 1 \\
\left(\nu_{2} \kappa, \nu^{2} \nu_{4}\right) & =\left(\nu \nu_{2} \kappa, \nu \nu_{4}\right)=1 / 2 \bmod 1 \\
\left(\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \eta \epsilon_{4}\right) & =\left(\eta \eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \epsilon_{4}\right)=1 / 2 \bmod 1 \\
\left(\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \nu^{2} \nu_{4}\right) & =\left(\eta_{1} \nu \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \nu \nu_{4}\right)=0 \bmod 1
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows by bilinearity that $\left(\nu_{2} \kappa, \eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}\right)=0 \bmod 1$ and $\left(\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{2}, \eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}\right)=1 / 2 \bmod 1$, since $\eta_{1} \bar{\kappa}^{4}=\eta \epsilon_{4}+\nu^{2} \nu_{4}$.

REMARK 10.30. Heuristically, we have $(x, y)=1 / 2 \bmod 1$ when $x$ and $y$ formally multiply to

$$
(\eta \nu \epsilon \kappa)_{6}=\left(\nu^{4} \kappa\right)_{6}=\left(\eta^{3} \nu \bar{\kappa}\right)_{6}=\left(\epsilon^{2} \kappa \bar{\kappa}\right)_{5}=\eta_{1}^{2} \bar{\kappa}^{6}=2 \kappa_{4} \bar{\kappa}^{3}=\kappa \bar{\kappa}^{3} D_{4}

By analogy, $\pi_{*}(k o) \cong N_{*}^{1} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[B]$ as a $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module, where $N_{*}^{1}=\mathbb{Z}\{1, A\} \oplus$ $\mathbb{Z} / 2\left\{\eta, \eta^{2}\right\}$.
