# 12.6. Modified Adams spectral sequences 

Let $f: X \rightarrow Y$ be a map of spectra, and consider the homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{i} C f \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma X
$$

Also fix a homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\Sigma^{-1} \bar{H} \xrightarrow{\alpha} S \xrightarrow{\beta} H \xrightarrow{\gamma} \bar{H}
$$

and form the canonical Adams resolution
![img-243.jpeg](img-243.jpeg)
of $S=S_{0}$, with $S_{s}=\left(\Sigma^{-1} \bar{H}\right)^{\wedge s}$ and $S_{s, 1}=H \wedge\left(\Sigma^{-1} \bar{H}\right)^{\wedge s}$. There are several ways to combine the canonical Adams resolutions $X_{\star}=S_{\star} \wedge X$ and $Y_{\star}=S_{\star} \wedge Y$ into a tower ending at $C f$. The resulting spectral sequences are often referred to as "modified Adams spectral sequences", but as we shall clarify below there are a couple of different modifications involved. We therefore begin by reviewing the "ordinary" and "delayed" approaches that we have already made use of in this work, and then discuss a "hastened" modification of the Adams resolution.

First, the canonical Adams resolution $(C f)_{\star}=S_{\star} \wedge C f$ sits in a diagram
![img-244.jpeg](img-244.jpeg)
with vertical homotopy cofiber sequences, where $f_{s}=S_{s} \wedge f$ and $(C f)_{s}=C\left(f_{s}\right)$. If $f_{*}=H_{*}(f)=0$, so that $f$ has Adams filtration $\geq 1$, then the associated Adams $E_{1}$-terms for $Y, C f$ and $\Sigma X$ form a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \xrightarrow{i} C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(C f)\right) \xrightarrow{j} C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma H_{*}(X)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

of cobar complexes, as in Definition 2.12. (Strictly speaking, each $\left(E_{1}, d_{1}\right)$-term is most directly identified with the $A_{*}$-comodule primitives in the version for left $A_{*}$ comodules of the canonical injective resolution of [45, Def. IV.1.1], but the latter

is isomorphic to the cobar resolution, with primitives given by the cobar complex.) The associated long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms takes the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \cdots \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s-1}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma H_{*}(X)\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \\
& \xrightarrow{i} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(C f)\right) \xrightarrow{j} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma H_{*}(X)\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

where the connecting homomorphism $\delta$ is given by Yoneda composition with the class in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{1}\left(\Sigma H_{*}(X), H_{*}(Y)\right)$ of the extension $H_{*}(Y) \rightarrow H_{*}(C f) \rightarrow \Sigma H_{*}(X)$. Similar considerations apply (under the usual finite type hypotheses) (a) for the opposite variance, replacing homology and $A_{*}$-comodules with cohomology and $A$-modules, (b) for maps of tmf-modules, replacing $A_{*}$ with $A(2)_{*}$, and (c) at other primes, replacing $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ with $\mathbb{F}_{p}$. We leave to the reader to make the notational substitutions needed in these cases. We made use of this long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms in Chapters $4,6,7,8$ and 11. If $f$ has Adams filtration $\sigma \geq 2$, then

$$
0 \rightarrow E_{r}(Y) \xrightarrow{i} E_{r}(C f) \xrightarrow{j} E_{r}(\Sigma X) \rightarrow 0
$$

remains short exact up to and including the case $r=\sigma$, so that the $d_{r}$-differentials for $C f$ are more-or-less determined by those for $X$ and $Y$ when $r<\sigma$, and only the differentials with $r \geq \sigma$ are directly affected by $f$.

Second, we have seen in Chapter 11, cf. Definition 11.10, and in Sections 12.4 and 12.5 , that we can delay the effect of $f$ on the differentials in the spectral sequence by $d \geq 1$ terms, by the device of replacing the canonical Adams resolution of $C f$ with the convolution product $(S \wedge Z)_{*}$ of $S_{*}$ and $Z_{*}$, where now $Z_{*}$ is the tower

$$
C f \stackrel{i}{\longleftarrow} Y \stackrel{=}{\longleftarrow} \ldots \stackrel{=}{\longleftarrow} Y \longleftarrow *
$$

with $Z_{0}=C f, Z_{k}=Y$ for $1 \leq k \leq d$, and $Z_{k}=*$ for $k>d$. We then have a diagram
![img-245.jpeg](img-245.jpeg)
with vertical homotopy cofiber sequences, so that $(S \wedge Z)_{s}=C\left(f \alpha^{s}\right)$ for $0 \leq s \leq d$ and $(S \wedge Z)_{s}=C\left(f_{s-d} \alpha^{d}\right)$ for $s \geq d$. The associated $E_{1}$-terms form a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{*-d}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{d} H_{*}(Y)\right) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime}} E_{1}^{*}\left((S \wedge Z)_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{j^{\prime}} C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma H_{*}(X)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

If $f$ has Adams filtration $\sigma \geq 1$, then the associated long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms splits into short exact sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s-d}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{d} H_{*}(Y)\right) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime}} E_{2}^{s}\left((S \wedge Z)_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{j^{\prime}} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma H_{*}(X)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

and

$$
0 \rightarrow E_{r}^{s-d}\left(\Sigma^{d} Y\right) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime}} E_{r}^{s}\left((S \wedge Z)_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{j^{\prime}} E_{r}^{s}(\Sigma X) \rightarrow 0
$$

remains short exact as long as $r \leq \sigma+d$, so that only the $d_{r}$-differentials with $r \geq \sigma+d$ are directly affected by $f$. In this sense, the interaction between $f$ and the differentials internal to $E_{r}(X)$ and $E_{r}(Y)$ is delayed to only influence the differentials in $E_{r}\left((S \wedge Z)_{*}\right)$ for $r \geq \sigma+d$. This can be advantageous if one already has a good understanding of the differential structure and hidden extensions in the ordinary Adams spectral sequences for $X$ and $Y$.

Lemma 12.30. The maps $\alpha^{d}: Y_{s} \rightarrow Y_{s-d}$ induce a morphism from the ordinary Adams spectral sequence for $C f$ to the delayed one.

Proof. This is the morphism of spectral sequences induced by the following map of towers, where the top row is the canonical Adams resolution of $C f$.
![img-246.jpeg](img-246.jpeg)

Third, we come to a modification of the Adams spectral sequence for $C f$ where the effect of $f$ on the differentials is hastened by $e \geq 1$ terms. This is the "modified Adams spectral sequence" of Behrens, Hill, Hopkins and Mahowald [26]. Suppose that we have factored $f=\alpha^{e} g$ for some map $g: X \rightarrow Y_{e}=S_{e} \wedge Y$, and that $e=\sigma$ equals the Adams filtration of $f$. This implies that the composite $\beta g: X \rightarrow H \wedge Y_{e}$ is essential, so that $g_{*}: H_{*}(X) \rightarrow H_{*}\left(Y_{e}\right)$ is nonzero. We extend $g$ to a map of canonical Adams resolutions with $g_{s}=S_{s} \wedge g$, and obtain the diagram
![img-247.jpeg](img-247.jpeg)
with vertical homotopy cofiber sequences.
Definition 12.31. Let $W_{*}$ denote the tower ending at $C f$, displayed above, with $W_{s}=C\left(\alpha^{e-s} g\right)$ for $0 \leq s \leq e$ and $W_{s}=S_{s-e} \wedge C g$ for $s \geq e$. We call the spectral sequence obtained by applying $\pi_{*}(-)$ the hastened Adams spectral sequence for $C f$.

Lemma 12.32. The maps $\alpha^{e}: X_{s} \rightarrow X_{s-e}$ induce a morphism from the ordinary Adams spectral sequence for $C f$ to the hastened one.

Proof. This is the morphism of spectral sequences induced by the following map of towers.
![img-248.jpeg](img-248.jpeg)

The top row is an Adams resolution of $C f$, but not the canonical one. Its associated spectral sequence therefore agrees with the ordinary Adams spectral sequence from the $E_{2}$-term and onward.

In general there is no direct connection between the delayed and hastened Adams spectral sequences. Returning to diagram (12.6), the associated $E_{1}$-terms fit into vertical long exact sequences, as in the following diagram.
![img-249.jpeg](img-249.jpeg)

We now make the additional assumption that $g_{*}: H_{*}(X) \rightarrow H_{*}\left(Y_{e}\right)$ is a monomorphism. This ensures that the vertical long exact sequences break up into a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{s-e}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right) \xrightarrow{g} C_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime \prime}} E_{1}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

of cochain complexes. In the induced long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cdots \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s-e}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right) & \xrightarrow{g} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \\
& \xrightarrow{i^{\prime \prime}} E_{2}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s+1-e}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

the homomorphism $g$ is given by Yoneda composition with the infinite cycle in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{e, e}\left(H_{*}(X), H_{*}(Y)\right)$ detecting the lift $g$ of $f$. In the spectral sequence $E_{r}\left(W_{*}\right)$, the role of the map $f$ of Adams filtration $e$ has thus been hastened to have a direct effect on the $E_{1}$-term, rather than affecting the $d_{e}$-differential and $E_{e+1}$-term, as for the ordinary Adams spectral sequence $E_{r}(C f)$. This has the advantage that information about $f$ enters at a stage where the determination of the $E_{r}$-term is still a purely algebraic problem.

This algebraic connection can be made more explicit. The homotopy cofiber $W_{s, 1}=\operatorname{cof}\left(W_{s+1} \rightarrow W_{s}\right)$ has the form $H \wedge Y_{s}$ for $0 \leq s<e$, and the form $H \wedge W_{s}$ for $s \geq e$, so that its homotopy

$$
E_{1}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right)=\pi_{*-s}\left(W_{s, 1}\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{A_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*-s}\left(W_{s, 1}\right)\right)
$$

is given by the $A_{*}$-comodule primitives in its homology. Our assumption that $g_{*}: H_{*}(X) \rightarrow H_{*}\left(Y_{e}\right)$ is a monomorphism implies that the homologies of $X_{s-e, 1}$, $Y_{s, 1}$ and $W_{s, 1}$ form a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{s-e}\left(A_{*}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right) \xrightarrow{g} C_{A_{*}}^{s}\left(A_{*}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime \prime}} Q^{*} \rightarrow 0
$$

of $A_{*}$-comodule cochain complexes, where $Q^{*}=H_{*-s}\left(W_{s, 1}\right)$ is extended, hence injective, and $\delta: Q^{s} \rightarrow Q^{s+1}$ is the usual composite homomorphism $H_{*-s}\left(W_{s, 1}\right) \rightarrow$ $H_{*-s-1}\left(W_{s+1}\right) \rightarrow H_{*-s-1}\left(W_{s+1,1}\right)$. Furthermore, $\eta: H_{*}(Y) \rightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(A_{*}, H_{*}(Y)\right)$ is an injective resolution of the $A_{*}$-comodule $H_{*}(Y)$, whereas $\eta: \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)[-e] \rightarrow$ $C_{A_{*}}^{*-e}\left(A_{*}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right)$ is an injective resolution of $\Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)$ shifted to cohomological degree $e$. In the derived category $\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)$ of $A_{*}$-comodules, we thus have a distinguished triangle

$$
\Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)[-e] \xrightarrow{g} H_{*}(Y) \xrightarrow{i^{\prime \prime}} Q^{*} \xrightarrow{j^{\prime \prime}} \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)[1-e]
$$

Proposition 12.33 ([26, §3]). Let $f=\alpha^{e} g: X \rightarrow Y_{e} \rightarrow Y$, and assume that $g_{*}: H_{*}(X) \rightarrow H_{*}\left(Y_{e}\right)$ is a monomorphism. The hastened Adams spectral sequence for $C f$ has $E_{2}$-term

$$
E_{2}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, Q^{*}\right)
$$

where $Q^{*}$ is the homotopy cofiber in $\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)$ of the morphism $g: \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)[-e] \rightarrow$ $H_{*}(Y)$ corresponding to the class in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{e, e}\left(H_{*}(X), H_{*}(Y)\right)$ that detects the lift $g$ of $f$.

Proof. We have arranged that $Q^{*}$ is injective in each cohomological degree. Therefore the hastened $E_{2}$-term

$$
E_{2}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right) \cong H^{*}\left(\operatorname{Hom}_{A_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, Q^{*}\right)\right)
$$

calculates, by definition, the hyper-Ext groups

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, Q^{*}\right)=\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, Q^{*}[s]\right)
$$

of the $A_{*}$-comodule complex $Q^{*}$.
It follows that we can calculate the hastened $E_{2}$-term as the hyper-Ext of any other $A_{*}$-comodule complex that is isomorphic in $\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)$ to $Q^{*}$. Thus, let $\eta: H_{*}(Y) \rightarrow P^{*}$ be any injective $A_{*}$-comodule resolution of $H_{*}(Y)$, pick a chain equivalence $\theta: C_{A_{*}}^{*}\left(A_{*}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \rightarrow P^{*}$ under $H_{*}(Y)$, and suppose that the composite $e$-cocycle

$$
h=\theta g \eta: \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X) \longrightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{0}\left(A_{*}, \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X)\right) \longrightarrow C_{A_{*}}^{e}\left(A_{*}, H_{*}(Y)\right) \longrightarrow P^{e}
$$

in $\operatorname{Hom}_{A_{*}}\left(\Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X), P^{*}\right)$ is also a monomorphism. Clearly $h$ represents the same class in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{e, e}\left(H_{*}(X), H_{*}(Y)\right)$ as $g \eta$. Let

$$
\tilde{h}: \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X) \longrightarrow J^{e}=\operatorname{im}\left(\delta: P^{e-1} \rightarrow P^{e}\right)=\operatorname{ker}\left(\delta: P^{e} \rightarrow P^{e+1}\right)
$$

be the unique lift of $h$ through the $e$-coboundaries in $P^{*}$, and form the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{e} H_{*}(X) \xrightarrow{\tilde{h}} J^{e} \longrightarrow \bar{J}^{e} \longrightarrow 0
$$

We then have a zig-zag of quasi-isomorphisms connecting $Q^{*}$ to the $A_{*}$-comodule complex

$$
0 \rightarrow P^{0} \xrightarrow{\delta} P^{1} \xrightarrow{\delta} \ldots \xrightarrow{\delta} P^{e-1} \longrightarrow \bar{J}^{e} \rightarrow 0
$$

with cohomology concentrated in degrees 0 and $e-1$. If $\eta: \bar{J}^{e} \rightarrow \bar{P}^{*+e}$ is another injective $A_{*}$-comodule resolution, then we can form an injective complex $\bar{P}^{*}$ by splicing $P^{*<e}$ with $\bar{P}^{* \geq e}$, using the composite

$$
P^{e-1} \longrightarrow J^{e} \longrightarrow \bar{J}^{e} \longrightarrow \bar{P}^{e}
$$

to connect the two parts of the complex. Then $Q^{*}$ and $\bar{P}^{*}$ are isomorphic in the derived category, and we can calculate the hastened $E_{2}$-term as

$$
E_{2}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, Q^{*}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{D}\left(A_{*}\right)}^{s}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \bar{P}^{*}\right)=H^{s}\left(\operatorname{Hom}_{A_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \bar{P}^{*}\right)\right)
$$

In particular, if $P^{*}$ and $\bar{P}^{*+e}$ were chosen as minimal resolutions, then $\bar{P}^{*}$ is also a minimal complex, which makes it trivial to pass to cohomology in the right hand term above.

We illustrate this method by two examples, working in cohomology and in the context of $t m f$-modules. In each case we use a method discovered by Mahowald, which tricks ext into calculating a minimal complex $\tilde{P}_{*}$ by carefully interrupting the machine computation of a minimal free $A(2)$-module resolution $\epsilon: P_{*} \rightarrow H^{*}(Y)$ and adjusting the boundary homomorphism $\partial: P_{e} \rightarrow P_{e-1}$ to have image $\tilde{J}_{e}=$ $\operatorname{ker}\left(\bar{h}: J_{e} \rightarrow \Sigma^{e} H^{*}(X)\right)$ in place of $J_{e}=\operatorname{im}\left(\partial: P_{e} \rightarrow P_{e-1}\right) \cong \operatorname{cok}\left(\partial: P_{e+1} \rightarrow P_{e}\right)$.

Example 12.34. Let $f=B: \Sigma^{8} t m f \rightarrow t m f$ be given by multiplication with the Bott element $B \in \pi_{8}(t m f)$. This map has Adams filtration $e=4$, and we can pick a lift $g: \Sigma^{8} t m f \rightarrow t m f_{4}$ with $B \simeq \alpha^{4} g$, which is detected by $w_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{4,12}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. The hastened Adams spectral sequence for $C f=t m f / B$ has $E_{2}$-term

$$
E_{2}^{s}\left(W_{*}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{D}(A(2))}^{s}\left(Q_{*}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

where $Q_{*}$ is the homotopy fiber in $\mathcal{D}(A(2))$ of the morphism $g: \mathbb{F}_{2} \rightarrow \Sigma^{12} \mathbb{F}_{2}[4]$ corresponding to $w_{1}$. The inclusion $i^{\prime \prime}: Y_{*}=t m f_{*} \rightarrow W_{*}$ induces a map of spectral sequences from the Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ to the hastened spectral sequence for $t m f / B$, which appears in the long exact sequence of $E_{2}$-terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cdots \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s-4, t-12}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \xrightarrow{w_{1}} & \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \\
& \xrightarrow{i^{\prime \prime}} E_{2}^{s, t}\left(W_{*}\right) \xrightarrow{j^{\prime \prime}} \operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}^{s-3, t-12}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) \longrightarrow \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

In this case we know that $w_{1}$ acts injectively on $E_{2}(t m f)=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$, so that $j^{\prime \prime}=0$ and $\operatorname{Ext}_{A(2)}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right) / w_{1} \cong E_{2}\left(W_{*}\right)$.

To use ext to calculate a minimal free complex $\tilde{P}_{*}$ that is derived isomorphic to $Q_{*}$, we work in the context of Remark 1.9, call on newmodule tmfmodB tmf.def in the directory A2, and execute dims 012 in A2/tmfmodB to compute a minimal free $A(2)$-module resolution $P_{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{2}$ in internal degrees $t \leq 12$. # CHAPTER 13 

## Odd primes

After inverting $2 \cdot 3=6$, the edge homomorphism $e$ from connective topological modular forms to integral modular forms becomes an isomorphism

$$
e: \pi_{*}(t m f)[1 / 6] \xrightarrow{\cong} m f_{*/ 2}[1 / 6]=\mathbb{Z}[1 / 6]\left[c_{4}, c_{6}\right]
$$

with $\Delta=\left(c_{4}^{3}-c_{6}^{2}\right) / 1728$, and the spectral enrichment from algebra to topology carries little new information. At primes $p \geq 5$ the Hurewicz image of $\pi_{*}(S)_{(p)}$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{(p)}$ is necessarily trivial in positive degrees. The main interest in the study of topological modular forms at odd primes is therefore concentrated at $p=3$. At this prime, the homotopy of $t m f$ (in its $K(2)$-localized form $E O_{p-1}$ ) was first calculated by Hopkins and Miller, cf. [64, Thm. 3.7] and [137, Thm. 2.1].

We shall follow Hill $[\mathbf{6 8}]$ and study $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{3}^{\wedge}$ by means of the Baker-Lazarev [20] mod 3 Adams spectral sequence built in the category of $t m f$-modules, as opposed to the classical Adams spectral sequence built in the category of spectra ( $=$ $S$-modules). Its $E_{2}$-term

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}^{t m f}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \mathbb{F}_{3}\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(t m f)_{3}^{\wedge}
$$

is given by the comodule Ext-groups for the tmf-module analogue

$$
A_{*}^{t m f}=H_{*}^{t m f}(H)=\pi_{*}\left(H \wedge_{t m f} H\right)
$$

of the dual Steenrod algebra, with coefficients in the $t m f$-module mod 3 homology groups

$$
H_{*}^{t m f}(t m f)=\pi_{*}\left(H \wedge_{t m f} t m f\right)=\mathbb{F}_{3}
$$

of $t m f$. Here $H=H \mathbb{F}_{3}$ denotes the mod 3 Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectrum, with its unique commutative $t m f$-algebra structure. Our first task is to determine the structure of $A_{*}^{t m f}$. Next, we shall use the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence to calculate the $t m f$-module Adams $E_{2}$-term above. Thereafter, we use the $H_{\infty}$ ring structure on $t m f$ to determine the differential structure in this Adams spectral sequence. Finally, we shall resolve the extension questions to pass from $E_{\infty}(t m f)$ to $\pi_{*}(t m f)$, implicitly completed at $p=3$.

The calculation of $\Gamma_{*}=A_{*}^{t m f}$ is due to Henriques and Hill, using results of Hopkins-Mahowald (unpublished) and Behrens [25]. We supplement these arguments with later work of Hill and Lawson [70], and Mathew [114]. The calculation of $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \mathbb{F}_{3}\right)$ was done by Hill using the May spectral sequence. We offer an alternative argument using the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence of Chapter 2, based on a surjection $\Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Lambda_{*}$ of commutative Hopf algebras, with $\Lambda_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right)$ dual to the subalgebra $\Lambda=\left\langle P^{1}\right\rangle \subset A$ of the mod 3 Steenrod algebra. Hill determined the differentials in the $t m f$-module Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ at $p=3$ by a comparison with the calculation of the corresponding Adams-Novikov spectral

sequence made by Bauer [23]. We instead give direct arguments for these differentials in the style of our discussion at $p=2$, starting from the $H_{\infty}$ ring structure on $t m f$. Bauer determined the hidden $\nu$-extensions in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence by Toda bracket arguments. We shall give a different argument for these hidden extensions, based on our understanding of $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi$, where $\Psi=S \cup_{\nu} e^{4} \cup_{\nu} e^{8}$ is a 3 -local CW spectrum with cohomology realizing the subalgebra $\Lambda=\left\langle P^{1}\right\rangle$ mentioned above.

We conclude in Section 13.4 that $\pi_{*}(t m f)_{3}^{\wedge}$ is generated as a $\mathbb{Z}_{3}$-algebra by the three 3-torsion classes

and the following nine 3-torsion free classes.

The 3-torsion is equal to the $B$-torsion, where $B$ is the Bott element, and the (Hopkins-Miller) element $H$ acts freely, so that $\pi_{*}(t m f) \cong N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[H]$, where $N_{*} \subset \pi_{*}(t m f)$ is the $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-submodule generated by the classes in degrees $0 \leq *<72$. We express $N_{*}$ as a $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-module, hence also $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ as a $\mathbb{Z}[B, H]$-module, in Theorem 13.18, and evaluate the product in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ in Theorem 13.19. Only one product remains uncertain: we know that

$$

$$

for some number $t \in \mathbb{Z} / 3$, but we do not know this coefficient. If $t=0$ then the surjection $\pi_{*}(t m f) \rightarrow \operatorname{im}(e)$ admits a multiplicative section, otherwise it does not.

We also show that $t m f$ satisfies duality at $p=3$ : there are equivalences of 3 -completed $t m f$-modules

$$
a: \Sigma^{20} t m f \xrightarrow{\simeq} I\left(t m f /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

and $\Sigma^{21} \operatorname{Tmf} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}(\operatorname{Tmf})$, where the latter was proved earlier by Stojanoska. In particular, the $B$-torsion in degrees $* \not \equiv 3 \bmod 24$ in $N_{*}$ is

$$
\Theta N_{*}=\mathbb{Z} / 3\left\{\beta, \nu \beta, \beta^{2}, \beta^{3}, \nu_{1} \beta, \beta^{4}\right\}
$$

and $a$ induces a perfect pairing

$$
\Theta N_{50-n} \otimes \Theta N_{n} \longrightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

for all $n$. Finally we show in Theorem 13.32 that for $*>3$ the Hurewicz image of $\pi_{*}(S)$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ is contained in $\Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)=\Theta N_{*} \otimes \mathbb{Z}[H]$, and that this upper bound is achieved at least up to degree 154 .

Remark 13.1. At the prime $p=2$, the tmf-module mod 2 Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ agrees with the classical mod 2 Adams spectral sequence, since

$H_{*}(t m f)=A_{*} \square_{A(2)_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{2}$ and $A_{*}^{t m f}=\pi_{*}\left(H \wedge_{t m f} H\right) \cong A(2)_{*}$ at $p=2$, so that the natural map

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, H_{*}(t m f)\right) \xrightarrow{\cong} \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}^{t m f}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}, \mathbb{F}_{2}\right)
$$

is equal to the coalgebra version of the change-of-rings isomorphism along $A(2) \subset A$. Hence our discussion in the previous chapters can be interpreted to be all about the Baker-Lazarev tmf-module Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$, also for $p=2$.

REMARK 13.2. The classical mod 3 Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$ has $E_{2^{-}}$ term

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, H_{*}(t m f)\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(t m f)_{3}^{\wedge}
$$

Dominic Culver [49] has worked out the rather elaborate structure of this spectral sequence, deducing several differentials and extensions from the known structure of the abutment. This approach does not seem to determine the unknown coefficient $t \in \mathbb{Z} / 3$, since $\beta^{4} H$ has higher classical Adams filtration than $B_{2}^{2}$ and $B B_{1} H$.

# 13.1. The $t m f$-module Steenrod algebra and its dual 

We implicitly localize all spectra, abelian groups and stacks at 3 in this section. Hence $S, \mathbb{Z}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}$ denote $S_{(3)}, \mathbb{Z}_{(3)}$ and $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}\right)_{(3)}$, respectively. In particular, $3 \nu=0$ and $\nu^{2}=0$ in $\pi_{*}(S)$, where $\nu$ is the stable homotopy class of the quaternionic Hopf fibration.

Definition 13.3. Let $P(0)=\left\langle P^{1}\right\rangle, E(1)=\left\langle\beta, Q_{1}\right\rangle$ and $A(1)=\left\langle\beta, P^{1}\right\rangle$ be sub Hopf algebras of the mod 3 Steenrod algebra $A$, each generated by the listed elements. As usual, $Q_{1}=\left[P^{1}, \beta\right]$. These are dual to the quotient Hopf algebras $P(0)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right), E(1)_{*}=E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}\right)$ and $A(1)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right) \otimes E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}\right)$, respectively, of the mod 3 dual Steenrod algebra $A_{*}$. Let

$$
\Psi=S \cup_{\nu} e^{4} \cup_{\nu} e^{8}
$$

be a 3 -cell CW spectrum with $H^{*}(\Psi)=P(0)$ and $H_{*}(\Psi)=P(0)_{*}$, and let

$$
V(1)=\operatorname{cof}\left(\Sigma^{4} S / 3 \xrightarrow{v_{1}} S / 3\right)=S \cup_{3} e^{1} \cup_{\nu} e^{5} \cup_{3} e^{6}
$$

be a type 2 Smith-Toda complex with $H^{*}(V(1))=E(1)$ and $H_{*}(V(1))=E(1)_{*}$. The smash product $V(1) \wedge \Psi$ has cohomology $E(1) \otimes P(0)$, which is free of rank 1 as an $A(1)$-module.

Hill [68, Prop. 2.3] credits the following result to Hopkins-Mahowald and Behrens [25]. Our outline of proof also relies on later work by Hill-Lawson [70] and Mathew $[\mathbf{1 1 4}]$.

THEOREM 13.4. There is a map $\operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)=\operatorname{tmf}_{1}(2)$ of connective $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra, with $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$, and an equivalence of tmf-modules

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi \simeq \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)
$$

The complex orientation associated to the Weierstrass curve $y^{2}=x^{3}+a_{2} x^{2}+a_{4} x$ induces $v_{1} \mapsto a_{2} \bmod 3$ and $v_{2} \mapsto 2 a_{4}^{2} \bmod \left(3, a_{2}\right)$.

SKetch proof. Following Behrens [25, §1.2.1] and Mahowald-Rezk [105], we first consider the moduli stack $\mathcal{M}_{0}(2)$ of elliptic curves with level structure of type $\Gamma_{0}(2)=\Gamma_{1}(2)$, i.e., with a chosen subgroup of order 2. There is an étale map $\mathcal{M}_{0}(2) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}$ that represents forgetting the level structure, and the Goerss-Hopkins-Miller sheaf of $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra over $\mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}$ pulls back to a similar sheaf

over $\mathcal{M}_{0}(2)$. We let $T M F_{0}(2)=T M F_{1}(2)$ be the global sections ( $=$ homotopy limit) of this sheaf, so that there is a canonical map $T M F \rightarrow T M F_{0}(2)$ of $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra.

Since we are working locally at 3 , each elliptic curve with $\Gamma_{0}(2)$ structure is uniquely strictly isomorphic to a non-singular Weierstrass curve of the form

$$
y^{2}=x^{3}+a_{2} x^{2}+a_{4} x
$$

with $a_{1}=a_{3}=a_{6}=0$. This defines an elliptic curve with a vertical tangent at $(x, y)=(0,0)$, which gives the point of order 2 . The classical modular invariants are $c_{4}=16\left(a_{2}^{2}-3 a_{4}\right), c_{6}=32 a_{2}\left(9 a_{4}-2 a_{2}^{2}\right)$ and $\Delta=16 a_{4}^{2}\left(a_{2}^{2}-4 a_{4}\right)$. Hence $\pi_{*}\left(T M F_{0}(2)\right) \cong M F_{0}(2)_{* / 2}=\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right][1 / \Delta]$.

The 3 -series of the associated formal group law begins

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[3](z)=3 z-8 a_{2} z^{3}+\left(24 a_{2}^{2}-96 a_{4}\right) z^{5}-} & \left(72 a_{2}^{3}-288 a_{2} a_{4}\right) z^{7} \\
& +\left(216 a_{2}^{4}-1472 a_{2}^{2} a_{4}+2432 a_{4}^{2}\right) z^{9}+\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

as can be verified with a computer algebra system such as sage, so that $v_{1} \mapsto$ $-8 a_{2} \equiv a_{2} \bmod 3$ and $v_{2} \mapsto 216 a_{2}^{4}-1472 a_{2}^{2} a_{4}+2432 a_{4}^{2} \equiv 2 a_{4}^{2} \bmod \left(3, a_{2}\right)$. Here we use that $v_{n}$ maps to the coefficient of $z^{3^{n}}$ in the 3 -series, modulo $\left(3, \ldots, v_{n-1}\right)$, both for the Araki and the Hazewinkel generators [144, A2.2.4 and p. 371]. In particular, $\pi_{*}\left(T M F_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{4}^{ \pm 1}\right]$ is a quadratic extension of $\pi_{*}(K(2))=\mathbb{Z} / 3\left[v_{2}^{ \pm 1}\right]$.

The unit map $S \rightarrow T M F_{0}(2)$ extends over $\Psi$, since $\pi_{*}\left(T M F_{0}(2)\right)$ is concentrated in even degrees, so we obtain a $T M F$-module map

$$
T M F \wedge \Psi \xrightarrow{\simeq} T M F_{0}(2)
$$

The descent spectral sequence for $\pi_{*}(T M F \wedge \Psi)$ based on the étale cover $T M F \rightarrow$ $T M F_{0}(2)$ collapses at the $E_{2}$-term, which is concentrated on the 0 -line, and implies that the map above is an equivalence. See $[\mathbf{2 3}, \S 5]$ and $[\mathbf{2 5}$, p. 383].

Next, we follow Hill and Lawson [70, Thm. 5.17], who show that the Goerss-Hopkins-Miller étale sheaf over $\mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}$ extends to a log-étale sheaf over the compactification $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$. The direct image log structure from $\mathcal{M}_{\text {ell }}$ gives $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$ the structure of a (Deligne-Mumford) log stack [70, Def. 3.1], and the extended sheaf can be pulled back along any log-étale cover of $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$.

In particular, there is a compactification $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{0}(2)$ of $\mathcal{M}_{0}(2)$ classifying generalized elliptic curves with $\Gamma_{0}(2)$ level structure. When the compactification is equipped with the direct image log structure, the forgetful map $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{0}(2) \rightarrow \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{\text {ell }}$ is log-étale. Passing to global sections, Hill and Lawson obtain a map $\operatorname{Tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{Tmf}_{0}(2)$ of $E_{\infty}$ ring spectra. Its localization away from (a power of) $\Delta$ is the map $T M F \rightarrow$ $T M F_{0}(2)$ discussed above. The log stack $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{0}(2)$ is equivalent to the subscheme of $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$ given by the union of the two open subschemes $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]\left[1 / c_{4}\right]$ and $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right][1 / \Delta]$, equipped with the direct image log structure from the latter subscheme. Since the radical of $\left(c_{4}, \Delta\right)$ is $\left(a_{2}, a_{4}\right)$, the associated descent spectral sequence collapses at the $E_{2}$-term, which is concentrated along the 0 - and 1 -lines, and $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{Tmf}_{0}(2)\right)$ agrees with $\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$ in non-negative degrees.

By definition, $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)$ is the connective cover of $\operatorname{Tmf}_{0}(2)$. Hence $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right) \cong$ $m f_{0}(2)_{* / 2}=\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$, and it follows that $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{4}\right]$ is a quadratic extension of $\pi_{*}(k(2))=\mathbb{Z} / 3\left[v_{2}\right]$. The unit maps $S \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \rightarrow \operatorname{Tmf}_{0}(2)$ also extend over $\Psi$, and Mathew $[\mathbf{1 1 4}, \S 4.6]$ shows that the equivalence $T M F \wedge \Psi \simeq$

$T M F_{0}(2)$ globalizes to an equivalence

$$
\operatorname{Tmf} \wedge \Psi \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Tmf}_{0}(2)
$$

of $T m f$-modules. By the Gap Theorem for $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{Tmf})$, it follows that there is also an equivalence

$$
\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)
$$

of $t m f$-modules.
The following two results are very similar to [68, Thm. 2.2]. Our proofs are perhaps a little more direct.

Lemma 13.5. The unit map $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ is 7 -connected, and $\pi_{7}(\operatorname{tmf})=0$.
Proof. The $v_{1}$-map $\Sigma^{4} S / 3 \rightarrow S / 3$ acts on $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge S / 3\right)=\mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$ as multiplication by $a_{2}$, so $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)\right)=\mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{4}\right]$. Hence multiplication by $a_{4}$ induces a homotopy cofiber sequence of $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)$-modules

$$
\Sigma^{8} \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{a_{4}} \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{i} H \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{9} \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)
$$

where $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) / a_{4} \wedge V(1) \simeq H$ is characterized by its single nontrivial homotopy group. Note that $i_{*}: \mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{4}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{Z} / 3 \cong \mathbb{F}_{3}$ is 8 -connected.

Smashing the unit map $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ with $\Psi \wedge V(1)$ yields the left hand map in the following diagram:

$$
\Psi \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{\iota \wedge i d} \operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi \wedge V(1) \simeq \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{i} H
$$

The composite $i \circ(\iota \wedge i d)$ induces the monomorphism $A(1)_{*} \cong H_{*}(\Psi \wedge V(1)) \rightarrow$ $H_{*}(H)=A_{*}$ in homology, which is 11-connected since the lowest-degree class in its cokernel is $\xi_{1}^{3}$. Hence $\iota \wedge i d$ must be 7 -connected. It follows that $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ is 7 -connected, as a map of 3 -local connective spectra of finite type.

We take as known that

$$
\pi_{*}(S)=\left(\mathbb{Z}, 0,0, \mathbb{Z} / 3\left\{\alpha_{1}\right\}, 0,0,0, \mathbb{Z} / 3\left\{\alpha_{2}\right\}, 0,0, \mathbb{Z} / 3\left\{\beta_{1}\right\}, \ldots\right)
$$

with $\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}=0$, see e.g. [144, Fig. 1.2.15]. It remains to prove that the surjection $\pi_{7}(\iota): \pi_{7}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{7}(\operatorname{tmf})$ maps $\alpha_{2}$ to zero. Consider the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{s, t}^{2} & =H_{s}\left(\Psi ; \pi_{t}(\operatorname{tmf})\right) \cong H_{s}(\Psi ; \mathbb{Z}) \otimes \pi_{t}(\operatorname{tmf}) \\
& \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{s+t}(\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi) \cong \pi_{s+t}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $H_{*}(\Psi ; \mathbb{Z})=\mathbb{Z}\left\{g_{0}, g_{4}, g_{8}\right\}$ with $\left|g_{s}\right|=s$. We have $d^{2}=d^{3}=0$ and

$$
d^{4}\left(g_{s} \otimes x\right)=g_{s-4} \otimes \alpha_{1} \cdot x
$$

for $s \in\{4,8\}$, since the 4 - and 8 -cells are attached by $\nu=\alpha_{1}$ to the 0 - and 4 -cells, respectively. Since the abutment $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$ is concentrated in degrees $* \equiv 0 \bmod 4$, the $E^{\infty}$-term must be trivial in the remaining total degrees. Hence, if $\iota\left(\alpha_{2}\right) \neq 0$ then $g_{4} \otimes \iota\left(\alpha_{2}\right) \in E_{4,7}^{2}$ must either support a nonzero differential, or be hit by a nonzero differential. The latter is impossible, since $E_{8,4}^{4}=0$. Thus $d_{4}\left(g_{4} \otimes \iota\left(\alpha_{2}\right)\right)=g_{0} \otimes \alpha_{1} \cdot \iota\left(\alpha_{2}\right)$ must be nonzero in $E_{0,10}^{4}$. This contradicts the relation $\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}=0$, so we can deduce that $\iota\left(\alpha_{2}\right)=0$.

THEOREM 13.6 (Henriques-Hill). The tmf-module dual Steenrod algebra $A_{*}^{t m f}=$ $\pi_{*}\left(H \wedge_{t m f} H\right)$ is isomorphic to the commutative Hopf algebra

$$
\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right) \otimes E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)
$$

with coproducts

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi\left(\xi_{1}\right)=1 \otimes \xi_{1}+\xi_{1} \otimes 1 \\
& \psi\left(\tau_{0}\right)=1 \otimes \tau_{0}+\tau_{0} \otimes 1 \\
& \psi\left(\tau_{1}\right)=1 \otimes \tau_{1}+\xi_{1} \otimes \tau_{0}+\tau_{1} \otimes 1 \\
& \psi\left(\theta_{2}\right)=1 \otimes \theta_{2}+\xi_{1} \otimes \tau_{1}-\xi_{1}^{2} \otimes \tau_{0}+\theta_{2} \otimes 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\left|\xi_{1}\right|=4,\left|\tau_{0}\right|=1,\left|\tau_{1}\right|=5$ and $\left|\theta_{2}\right|=9$. The unit map $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ induces an 8-connected Hopf algebra homomorphism

$$
k_{*}: A_{*}=\pi_{*}(H \wedge H) \longrightarrow \pi_{*}\left(H \wedge_{t m f} H\right)=A_{*}^{t m f}
$$

taking $\xi_{1}, \tau_{0}$ and $\tau_{1} \in A_{*}$ to the classes with the same names in $A_{*}^{t m f}$, and sending $\xi_{i}$ and $\tau_{i}$ to zero for each $i \geq 2$. Hence the image of $k_{*}$ is the sub Hopf algebra $A(1)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right) \otimes E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}\right)$ of $A_{*}^{t m f}$.

Proof. Lemma 13.5 implies that

$$
k=i d \wedge_{\iota} i d: H \wedge H=H \wedge_{S} H \longrightarrow H \wedge_{t m f} H
$$

is at least 8 -connected, since the homotopy type of $H \wedge_{t m f} H$ can be calculated using the 2 -sided bar construction $B_{\bullet}(H, t m f, H)$. The induced Hopf algebra homomorphism $k_{*}: A_{*} \rightarrow A_{*}^{t m f}$ therefore maps the classes $\tau_{0}, \xi_{1}$ and $\tau_{1}$ in $A_{*}$ to indecomposable classes in $A_{*}^{t m f}$, with coproducts given by the usual formulas.

Applying $H \wedge_{t m f}(-)$ to (13.1) we obtain a homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\Sigma^{8} H \wedge \Psi \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{a_{4}} H \wedge \Psi \wedge V(1) \xrightarrow{i} H \wedge_{t m f} H \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{9} H \wedge \Psi \wedge V(1)
$$

in the category of module spectra over the $E_{\infty}$ ring spectrum $H \wedge_{t m f} t m f_{0}(2) \simeq$ $H \wedge \Psi$. We claim that $a_{4 *}=0$ in the associated long exact sequence
$\cdots \longrightarrow \Sigma^{8} H_{*}(\Psi \wedge V(1)) \xrightarrow{a_{4 *}} H_{*}(\Psi \wedge V(1)) \xrightarrow{\iota_{*}} A_{*}^{t m f} \xrightarrow{j_{*}} \Sigma^{9} H_{*}(\Psi \wedge V(1)) \longrightarrow \ldots$.
To see this, note that $H_{*}(\Psi \wedge V(1)) \cong P(0)_{*} \otimes E(1)_{*}$ has dimension 12, and degree considerations show that $a_{4 *}$ has rank $\leq 4$. Hence $A_{*}^{t m f}$ is a commutative Hopf algebra over $\mathbb{F}_{3}$, of dimension between 16 and 24 , with indecomposable classes in degrees 1, 4 and 5. By Armand Borel's classification [32, §6] it follows that the dimension is 24 , the rank of $a_{4 *}$ is 0 , and there is one more indecomposable class in degree 9. Thus

$$
A_{*}^{t m f} \cong \mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right) \otimes E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)
$$

as an algebra, with $\theta_{2}$ in degree 9 defined modulo the image of $k_{*}$, i.e., modulo $\mathbb{F}_{3}\left\{\xi_{1} \tau_{1}, \xi_{1}^{2} \tau_{0}\right\}$. (Hill writes $a_{2}$ for the class we denote $\theta_{2}$.)

To show that we can choose $\theta_{2}$ so that

$$
\psi\left(\theta_{2}\right)=1 \otimes \theta_{2}+\xi_{1} \otimes \tau_{1}-\xi_{1}^{2} \otimes \tau_{0}+\theta_{2} \otimes 1
$$

we use the fact that $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$ maps $\alpha_{2} \in \pi_{7}(S)$ to zero in $\pi_{7}(t m f)$. Here $\alpha_{2}=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, 3\right\rangle$ is detected in the classical Adams spectral sequence for $S$ by $\Pi_{0} a_{0}=\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, a_{0}\right\rangle \in \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{2,9}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \mathbb{F}_{3}\right)$ [95, Table 1], [144, Thm. 3.4.2]. Recall that

$d_{1}([\gamma])=-\sum\left[\gamma^{\prime} \mid \gamma^{\prime \prime}\right]$ in the cobar complex, where $\psi(\gamma)=1 \otimes \gamma+\sum \gamma^{\prime} \otimes \gamma^{\prime \prime}+\gamma \otimes 1$. Hence $\Pi_{0} a_{0}$ is represented by the 2 -cocycle

$$
y=\left[\xi_{1}^{2} \mid \tau_{0}\right]-\left[\xi_{1} \mid \tau_{1}\right]
$$

in the cobar complex for $A_{*}$. Applying base change along $\iota: S \rightarrow t m f$, it follows that $k_{*}(y)$ detects zero in $\pi_{7}(t m f)$ in the $t m f$-module Adams spectral sequence for $t m f$, meaning that it is a coboundary in the cobar complex for $A_{*}^{t m f}$. Hence there is a class $x \in A_{*}^{t m f}$ with $d_{1}([x])=k_{*}(y)=\left[\xi_{1}^{2} \mid \tau_{0}\right]-\left[\xi_{1} \mid \tau_{1}\right]$, and we let $\theta_{2}=x$.

For degree reasons the Hopf algebra homomorphism $k_{*}: A_{*} \rightarrow A_{*}^{t m f}$ maps $\xi_{i}$ and $\tau_{i}$ to zero for $i \geq 2$, with the possible exception of $\tau_{2}$, which maps to a multiple of $\xi_{1}^{2} \theta_{2}$. In $A_{*}$ we have

$$
\psi\left(\tau_{2}\right)=1 \otimes \tau_{2}+\xi_{1}^{3} \otimes \tau_{1}+\xi_{2} \otimes \tau_{0}+\tau_{2} \otimes 1
$$

Since $\xi_{1}^{3}$ and $\xi_{2}$ map to zero in $A_{*}^{t m f}$ this implies that $k_{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ must be primitive, which eliminates the nonzero multiples of $\xi_{1}^{2} \theta_{2}$.

Corollary 13.7 ([54, §13.3]). The tmf-module Steenrod algebra $A_{t m f}$ is generated by classes $\beta$ and $P^{1}$ in degrees 1 and 4, respectively, subject to the relations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta^{2} & =0 \\
\beta\left(P^{1}\right)^{2} \beta & =\left(\beta P^{1}\right)^{2}+\left(P^{1} \beta\right)^{2} \\
\left(P^{1}\right)^{3} & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

The image of $k^{*}: A_{t m f}=H_{t m f}^{*}(H) \rightarrow H^{*}(H)=A$ is $A(1)$. The surjection $A_{t m f} \rightarrow$ $A(1)$ introduces the Adem relation

$$
\beta\left(P^{1}\right)^{2}+P^{1} \beta P^{1}+\left(P^{1}\right)^{2} \beta=0
$$

for $P^{1} \beta P^{1}$, which implies and replaces the relation for $\beta\left(P^{1}\right)^{2} \beta$.
Proof. By dualization, the Hopf algebra homomorphism $k^{*}: A_{t m f} \rightarrow A$ has image $A(1)$, and $A_{t m f} \rightarrow A(1)$ is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq 8$. Let $\beta$ and $P^{1}$ in $A_{t m f}$ map to the classes with the same names in $A(1)$. Then $\beta^{2}=0$ and $\left(P^{1}\right)^{3}=0$, since $A_{*}^{t m f}$, hence also $A_{t m f}$, is trivial in degrees 2 and 12. A calculation with the coproduct in $A_{*}^{t m f}$ shows that $\left(\beta P^{1}\right)^{2}+\left(P^{1} \beta\right)^{2}-\beta\left(P^{1}\right)^{2} \beta$ evaluates to zero on $\xi_{1} \tau_{0} \tau_{1}$ and $\tau_{0} \theta_{2}$, hence is zero in $A_{t m f}$. It is then elementary to verify that these two generators and three relations give a presentation of $A_{t m f}$. The Adem relation is of course known to hold in $A(1) \subset A$.

One can check that $\beta\left(P^{1}\right)^{2}+P^{1} \beta P^{1}+\left(P^{1}\right)^{2} \beta$ evaluates nontrivially on $\theta_{2}$. It squares to zero in $A_{t m f}$, so $A_{t m f} \rightarrow A(1)$ is a square-zero extension.

# 13.2. The Adams $E_{2}$-term 

For brevity, let $\Gamma_{*}=A_{*}^{t m f}$. We use the Davis-Mahowald spectral sequence from Chapter 2 to calculate the $E_{2}$-term of the $t m f$-module Adams spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{s, t}(t m f)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \mathbb{F}_{3}\right) \Longrightarrow_{s} \pi_{t-s}(t m f)
$$

where $t m f$ is now implicitly completed at $p=3$.
Let

$$
\Lambda_{*}=P(0)_{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[\xi_{1}\right] /\left(\xi_{1}^{3}\right)
$$

There is an evident surjection $\Gamma_{*} \rightarrow \Lambda_{*}$ of commutative Hopf algebras, and

$$
\Omega_{*}=\Gamma_{*} \square_{\Lambda_{*}} \mathbb{F}_{3}=E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)
$$

is a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule subalgebra of $\Gamma_{*}$. There is a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra resolution

$$
\mathbb{F}_{3} \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left(\Omega_{*} \otimes R^{*}, d\right)
$$

where $R^{*}=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[x_{1}, x_{5}, x_{9}\right]$ with $\left|x_{1}\right|=1,\left|x_{5}\right|=5,\left|x_{9}\right|=9$ has $\Gamma_{*}$-coaction

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nu\left(x_{1}\right)=1 \otimes x_{1} \\
& \nu\left(x_{5}\right)=1 \otimes x_{5}+\xi_{1} \otimes x_{1} \\
& \nu\left(x_{9}\right)=1 \otimes x_{9}+\xi_{1} \otimes x_{5}-\xi_{1}^{2} \otimes x_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and differential $d\left(\tau_{0}\right)=x_{1}, d\left(\tau_{1}\right)=x_{5}, d\left(\theta_{2}\right)=x_{9}$. The associated DavisMahowald spectral sequence is

$$
E_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, R^{\sigma}\right) \Longrightarrow_{\sigma} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \mathbb{F}_{3}\right)
$$

cf. Definition 2.15. To analyze this $E_{1}$-term we note that $\Delta=x_{9}^{3}$ is $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule primitive, and let

$$
\bar{R}^{*}=R^{*} /\left(x_{9}^{3}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left[x_{1}, x_{5}, x_{9}\right] /\left(x_{9}^{3}\right)

There is then a $\Gamma_{*}$-comodule algebra extension

where $\bar{E}_{1}^{\sigma, s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}^{s-\sigma, t}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \bar{R}^{\sigma}\right)$.
Here $R^{0}=\bar{R}^{0}=\mathbb{F}_{3}$ with

$$
\bar{E}_{1}^{0}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \bar{R}^{0}\right)=E\left(h_{0}\right) \otimes \mathbb{F}_{3}\left[b_{0}\right]

where $h_{0}=\left[\xi_{1}\right]$ lies in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(3,1)$ and $b_{0}=\left[\xi_{1} \mid \xi_{1}^{2}\right]+\left[\xi_{1}^{2} \mid \xi_{1}\right]$ lies in bidegree $(t-s, s)=(10,2)$; see $[\mathbf{1 4 4}$, Lem. 3.2.4] for these cobar representatives. The Massey products and Steenrod operations in Ext relate these two generators, so that $\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{0}\right\rangle=b_{0}$ and $\beta P^{2}\left(h_{0}\right)=-b_{0}$, with the sign conventions of $[\mathbf{1 1 8}$, Rem. 11.11].

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{1}= & \bar{R}^{1} \cong \Sigma \Lambda_{*} \\
R^{2}= & \bar{R}^{2} \cong \Sigma^{2} \Lambda_{*} \oplus \Sigma^{10} \Lambda_{*} \\
& \bar{R}^{3} \cong \Sigma^{3} \Lambda_{*} \oplus \Sigma^{11} \Lambda_{*} \oplus \Sigma^{15} \Lambda_{*}

are dual to free modules, with

$$

& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \bar{R}^{2}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left\{x_{1}^{2}, x_{5}^{2}+x_{1} x_{9}\right\} \\
& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \bar{R}^{3}\right)=\mathbb{F}_{3}\left\{x_{1}^{3}, x_{1} x_{5}^{2}+x_{1}^{2} x_{9}, x_{5}^{3}\right\}

all concentrated in Ext ${ }^{0}$. Letting $a_{0}=x_{1}, c_{4}=x_{5}^{2}+x_{1} x_{9}, c_{6}=x_{5}^{3}$ the pattern continues $a_{0^{-}}$and $c_{4}$-periodically, as one can prove by filtering each $\bar{R}^{\sigma}$ by the powers of $x_{1}$ present. It follows that

$$
\bar{E}_{1}^{*}=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Lambda_{*}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{3}, \bar{R}^{*}\right) \equiv \mathbb{F}_{3}\left[a_{0}, c_{4}, c_{6}\right] /\left(c_{4}^{3}=c_{6}^{2}\right)
$$

modulo the term with $\sigma=0$. The relation $c_{4}^{3}=c_{6}^{2}$ in $\bar{E}_{1}^{*}$ lifts to $c_{4}^{3}=c_{6}^{2}+a_{0}^{3} \Delta$ in $E_{1}^{*}$, since $\left(x_{5}^{2}+x_{1} x_{9}\right)^{3}=\left(x_{5}^{3}\right)^{2}+x_{1}^{3} x_{9}^{3}$ in $R^{*}$. The Davis-Mahowald spectral

sequence collapses at $E_{1}=E_{\infty}$ for degree reasons, leading to the Adams $E_{2}$-term shown in Figure 13.1.

### 13.4. The graded ring $\pi_{*}(t m f)$

We can now specify the remaining algebra generators for $\pi_{*}(t m f)$, implicitly completed at 3 . As at the prime 2 , they occur in families whose members are formally related by scalar multiples of the discriminant.

| $\nu$ | $\beta$ | $B$ | $C$ | $H$ |

Proposition 13.14. There are hidden $\nu$-extensions from $h_{0} \Delta$ to $\pm b_{0}^{3}$ and from $h_{0} b_{0} \Delta$ to $\pm b_{0}^{4}$, which propagate $\Delta^{3}$-periodically.

Proof. The three-column Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence

$$
E_{*, *}^{2}=H_{*}\left(\Psi ; \pi_{*}(t m f)\right) \Longrightarrow \pi_{*}(t m f \wedge \Psi) \cong \pi_{*}\left(t m f_{0}(2)\right)
$$

has $d^{4}$-differentials $d_{4, t}^{4}: \pi_{t}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{t+3}(t m f)$ and $d_{8, t}^{4}: \pi_{t}(t m f) \rightarrow \pi_{t+3}(t m f)$ given by multiplication by $\nu$. The abutment is concentrated in degrees $* \equiv 0 \bmod 4$, so $\beta^{3} \in E_{0,30}^{2} \cong \pi_{30}(t m f)$ must be a boundary. Since $E_{4,27}^{2} \cong \pi_{27}(t m f) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 3$ is generated by $\nu_{1}=\left\{h_{0} \Delta\right\}$, and $E_{8,23}^{2} \cong \pi_{23}(t m f)=0$, the only possibility is $d_{4}\left(\nu_{1}\right)= \pm \beta^{3}$, which implies $\nu \cdot \nu_{1}= \pm \beta^{3}$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$. It follows by $\beta$-linearity that $\nu \cdot \nu_{1} \beta= \pm \beta^{4}$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$.

By inspection of bidegrees, there is no room for any other hidden $\nu$-extensions. The extensions we have found propagate $\Delta^{3}$-periodically, since this class detects $H$ and acts freely on the $E_{\infty}$-term.

# 13.5. Brown-Comenetz and Anderson duality 

THEOREM 13.20. There is an (implicitly 3-complete) equivalence of tmf-modules

$$
\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

Hence there is a perfect Brown-Comenetz duality pairing

$$
\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \wedge \operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right) \longrightarrow I
$$

Proof. The proof is, of course, similar to that of Theorem 10.6. The $B$-power torsion $\Gamma_{B} N_{*}$ is finite and concentrated in degrees $3 \leq * \leq 40$. The $B$-divisible quotient $N_{*} / B^{\infty}$ is the direct sum of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& k o[0] / B^{\infty}=\mathbb{Z}\left[B^{-1}\right]\{1 / B, C / B\} \\
& k o[1] / B^{\infty}=\mathbb{Z}\left[B^{-1}\right]\left\{B_{1} / B, C_{1} / B\right\} /\left(3 B_{1} / B\right) \\
& k o[2] / B^{\infty}=\mathbb{Z}\left[B^{-1}\right]\left\{B_{2} / B, C_{2} / B\right\} /\left(3 B_{2} / B\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and is concentrated in degrees $* \leq 52$. The group in degree 52 is a copy of $\mathbb{Z}$ generated by $C_{2} / B$, and the group in degree 51 is trivial. Hence the homotopy groups of $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)$ are concentrated in degrees $* \leq-20$, with the group in degree -20 being a copy of $\mathbb{Z} / 3^{\infty}$. Passing to Brown-Comenetz duals, $I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)$ is a 19 -connected $t m f$-module with homotopy group in degree 20 isomorphic to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{Z} / 3^{\infty}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right)=\mathbb{Z}_{3}$. We represent a generator of this group by a $t m f$-module map

$$
a: \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \longrightarrow I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

We show that $a$ is an equivalence, by first showing that the coinduced $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)$ module map

$$
\begin{aligned}
b=F_{\operatorname{tmf}}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2), a\right): F_{\operatorname{tmf}}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2),\right. & \left.\Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf}\right) \\
& \longrightarrow F_{\operatorname{tmf}}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2), I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is an equivalence. The target of $b$ is equivalent to

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge_{\operatorname{tmf}} \operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right) & \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right) \\
& \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) /\left(3^{\infty}, a_{2}^{\infty}, a_{4}^{\infty}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we use that the ideal $J=\left(3, c_{4}, \Delta^{8}\right)$ generated by the images of $3, B$ and $H$ in $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right) \cong \mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right]$ has the same radical as $\left(3, a_{2}, a_{4}\right)$. The homotopy groups of $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) /\left(3^{\infty}, a_{2}^{\infty}, a_{4}^{\infty}\right)$ are

$$
\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right] /\left(3^{\infty}, a_{2}^{\infty}, a_{4}^{\infty}\right)=\mathbb{Z} / 3^{\infty}\left[a_{2}^{-1}, a_{4}^{-1}\right]\left\{1 / a_{2} a_{4}\right\}
$$

with $1 / a_{2} a_{4}$ in degree -12 , so

$$
\pi_{*} I\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) /\left(3^{\infty}, a_{2}^{\infty}, a_{4}^{\infty}\right)\right) \cong \Sigma^{12} \pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right)
$$

is a free module over $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right)$ on one generator in degree 12. The source of $b$ is equivalent as a $t m f$-module to

$$
F_{\operatorname{tmf}}\left(\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi, \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf}\right) \simeq F\left(\Psi, \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf}\right) \simeq \Sigma^{12} \Psi \wedge \operatorname{tmf} \simeq \Sigma^{12} \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)
$$

where the finite 3 -local CW spectrum $\Psi=S \cup_{\nu} e^{4} \cup_{\nu} e^{8}$ is Spanier-Whitehead self-dual in the sense that $F(\Psi, S)=D \Psi \simeq \Sigma^{-8} \Psi$. Hence $\pi_{*}(b)$ is a surjective $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)\right)$-module homomorphism, with abstractly isomorphic source and target (as graded abelian groups). It follows that $b$ is an equivalence. Since $b$ is obtained

by smashing $a$ with $D \Psi$, with lowest homology group $H_{-8}(D \Psi) \cong H^{8}(\Psi) \cong \mathbb{Z}$, it follows that $a$ is an equivalence.

As in the case $p=2$ we can rewrite the duality theorem in terms of local cohomology spectra and/or Anderson duality. Let $\operatorname{tmf}^{\prime}=\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)$.

Proposition 13.21. There are equivalences of tmf-modules

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)=I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\operatorname{tmf}^{\prime}\right) \\

& \Sigma^{23} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I\left(\Gamma_{(3, B, H)} \operatorname{tmf}\right)

Proof. This follows from $I\left(\operatorname{tmf}^{\prime} / 3^{\infty}\right) \simeq I_{\mathbb{Z}}\left(\operatorname{tmf}^{\prime}\right)_{3}^{\wedge}, \operatorname{tmf}^{\prime}=\operatorname{tmf} /\left(B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right) \simeq$ $\Sigma^{2} \Gamma_{(B, H)} \operatorname{tmf}$ and $\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right) \simeq \Sigma^{3} \Gamma_{(3, B, H)} \operatorname{tmf}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\beta, \beta^{4}\right) & = \pm 1 / 3 \\
\left(\nu \beta, \nu_{1} \beta\right) & = \pm 1 / 3
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\left(\beta^{2}, \beta^{3}\right)= \pm 1 / 3
$$

In other words, $(x, y)= \pm 1 / 3$ if $x$ and $y$ formally multiply to $\beta^{5}$.
REMARK 13.27. Here is how Pontryagin self-duality of $\Theta N_{*}$ at $p=3$ arises from Theorem 13.20. Let $N=\operatorname{tmf} / H$ be the homotopy cofiber of $H: \Sigma^{72} \operatorname{tmf} \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}$, so that the composite homomorphism $N_{*} \subset \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf}) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(N)$ is an isomorphism of $\mathbb{Z}[B]$-modules. Substituting $a: \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \simeq I\left(\operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)\right)$ in the homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
\Sigma^{92} \operatorname{tmf} \xrightarrow{H} \Sigma^{20} \operatorname{tmf} \longrightarrow \Sigma^{20} N
$$

and applying Brown-Comenetz duality, we obtain a homotopy cofiber sequence

$$
I\left(\Sigma^{20} N\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right) \xrightarrow{H} \Sigma^{-72} \operatorname{tmf} /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}, H^{\infty}\right)
$$

The homotopy fiber of the right hand map is $\Sigma^{-72} N /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)$, so we get an equivalence

$$
\Sigma^{52} I(N) \simeq N /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)
$$

of $\operatorname{tmf}$-modules. We can view each homomorphism $\phi: \pi_{k}(N) \rightarrow \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}$ as a homotopy class $\phi \in \pi_{-k} I(N)$, and $\Sigma^{52} \phi$ then corresponds under the equivalence above to a class $\psi \in \pi_{52-k}\left(N /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right)$. Its image $\partial^{2}(\psi)$ under the two connecting homomorphisms

$$
\left.\pi_{52-k}\left(N /\left(3^{\infty}, B^{\infty}\right)\right) \xrightarrow{\partial} \pi_{51-k}\left(N / B^{\infty}\right) \xrightarrow{\partial} \pi_{50-k}(N)\right)
$$

lies in $\Theta N_{50-k}$. As for $p=2, \partial^{2}(\psi)$ only depends on the restriction $\phi \mid: \Theta N_{k} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}$, and the correspondence $\phi \mid \leftrightarrow \partial^{2}(\psi)$ defines an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\Theta N_{k}, \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Z}\right) \cong \Theta N_{50-k}
$$

# 13.7. The $\operatorname{tmf}$-Hurewicz image 

The image of the Hurewicz homomorphism $\iota: \pi_{*}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$ lies mostly in the Pontryagin self-dual part. Integrally, it contains $\pi_{0}(\operatorname{tmf}) \cong \mathbb{Z}\{\iota\}$ and $\pi_{3}(\operatorname{tmf}) \cong$ $\mathbb{Z} / 24\{\nu\}$. The remainder of the 3-primary Hurewicz image is asserted in $[\mathbf{5 4}, \S 13.1]$ to be equal to the part of the $B$-power torsion that we denote $\Theta \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})_{3}^{\wedge}$. In this section we show that the former is contained in the latter, and that the two agree in degrees $*<154$. See Remark 13.33 for a discussion of what remains to be proved.

We proceed in the 3 -complete setting. Let $j$ be the connective image-of- $J$ spectrum, which can be defined as the homotopy fiber of a lift $\tilde{\psi}: k u \rightarrow b u$ of $\psi^{r}-1: k u \rightarrow k u$, where $r$ is any topological generator of the 3 -adic units. Let $e: S \rightarrow j$ be the unit map representing the Adams $e$-invariant, and let the cokernel-of- $J$ spectrum $c$ be defined as its homotopy fiber. Adams [8, Thm. 7.16] proved that $e: \pi_{*}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(j)$ is surjective, so that $\pi_{*}(c) \cong \operatorname{ker}(e)$. As a consequence of a theorem of Miller [124, Thm. 4.11], Bousfield [33, Thm. 4.3] showed that the map $e$ is a $K U$-equivalence, so $c$ is $K U$-acyclic. As for $p=2$, a simpler proof can be given by calculating that $e^{*}: K U^{*}(j) \rightarrow K U^{*}(S)$ is an isomorphism [131, p. 201]. The 3 -primary analogue of Proposition 11.81 is also true, with a similar proof.

Proposition 13.28. $\operatorname{tmf}[1 / B]$ is Bousfield $K U$-local.
Proof. Recall our notations from Definition 13.3. By Bousfield's criterion [33, Thm. 4.8] it suffices to check that

$$
\operatorname{tmf}[1 / B] \wedge Z \simeq *
$$

for $Z=V(1)$. By the Hopkins-Smith thick subcategory theorem [78], this is equivalent to verifying the condition for $Z=\Psi \wedge V(1)$, since both $V(1)$ and $\Psi \wedge V(1)$ are type 2 finite CW spectra. In view of the equivalence $\operatorname{tmf} \wedge \Psi \simeq \operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2)$ from Theorem 13.4, it suffices to prove that $\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)$ becomes trivial after inverting $B$. Here $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{tmf}_{0}(2) \wedge V(1)\right)=\mathbb{Z}\left[a_{2}, a_{4}\right] /\left(3, a_{2}\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 3\left[a_{4}\right]$ with $B$ acting as multiplication by $c_{4} \equiv 0 \bmod \left(3, a_{2}\right)$, so this is clear.

Proposition 11.82 is also valid as stated for $p=3$, replacing 2-power torsion and $\Gamma_{2}$ by 3 -power torsion and $\Gamma_{3}$, respectively, in its proof.

Proposition 13.29. For $0 \leq n<154$, the tmf-Hurewicz image of $\operatorname{ker}(e) \subset$ $\pi_{n}(S)$ is equal to $\Theta \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf})$.

Proof. Since $\iota: \pi_{*}(S) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is a graded ring homomorphism, mapping $\nu=\alpha_{1}$ to $\nu$ and $\beta_{1}$ to $\beta$, it is clear that $\nu \beta, \beta^{2}, \beta^{3}$ and $\beta^{4}$ are also in the Hurewicz image.

According to the 3-primary version of Proposition 11.82, $\nu_{1} \in \pi_{27}(\operatorname{tmf})$ is not in the Hurewicz image of $\operatorname{ker}(e)$, since any lift of it in $\pi_{28}\left(\operatorname{tmf} / B^{\infty}\right)$ has infinite order. Similarly, $\nu H \in \pi_{75}(t m f), \nu_{1} H \in \pi_{99}(t m f)$ and $\nu H^{2} \in \pi_{147}(t m f)$ are not in the Hurewicz image.

By [144, $\S 4.4, \S 7.4$, A3.4], there is a 3 -primary homotopy class traditionally denoted $\epsilon^{\prime}=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}^{3}\right\rangle \in \pi_{37}(S)$, with

$$
\alpha_{1} \epsilon^{\prime}=\alpha_{1}\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}^{3}\right\rangle=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle \beta_{1}^{3}=\beta_{1}^{4}
$$

by the shuffling formula [171, (3.6)]. The Toda bracket for $\epsilon^{\prime}$ is well defined, since $\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{3}=0$ in $\pi_{*}(S)$. Hence $\nu \iota\left(\epsilon^{\prime}\right)=\beta^{4}$, meaning that $\iota\left(\epsilon^{\prime}\right)$ must be $\pm \nu_{1} \beta$.

By the same calculations, there is a class in $\pi_{82}(S)$ detected by $\beta_{6 / 3} \in E_{\infty}^{2,84}$ in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}(S)=\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*} B P}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right) \Longrightarrow \pi_{*}(S)_{(p)}
$$

for $p=3$. We claim that $\iota\left(\beta_{6 / 3}\right)= \pm \beta H$ is nonzero in $\pi_{82}(\operatorname{tmf})$. Granting this, it is clear that $\iota$ maps $\nu \beta_{6 / 3}$ and $\beta^{i} \beta_{6 / 3}$ to $\pm \nu \beta H$ and $\pm \beta^{i+1} H$ for $i \in\{1,2,3\}$.

Furthermore, by [144, A3.4] the product $\alpha_{1} \cdot \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3} \in \pi_{105}(S)$ lies in a trivial group, so the Toda bracket $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3}\right\rangle$ is well-defined in $\pi_{109}(S)$, and

$$
\alpha_{1} \epsilon^{\prime \prime}=\alpha_{1}\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3}\right\rangle=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3}=\beta_{1}^{3} \beta_{6 / 3}
$$

Hence $\nu \iota\left(\epsilon^{\prime \prime}\right)= \pm \beta^{4} H$, which proves that $\iota\left(\epsilon^{\prime \prime}\right)= \pm \nu_{1} \beta H$. It follows that all of $\Theta \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$ for $0 \leq *<154$ is in the image of $\iota$ on $\operatorname{ker}(e) \subset \pi_{*}(S)$.

It remains to verify the claim that $\beta_{6 / 3} \in \pi_{82}(S)$ has nontrivial Hurewicz image in $\pi_{82}(\operatorname{tmf})$. This can be deduced from calculations of Katsumi Shimomura [156, Lem. 2.4], showing that the image of $\beta_{6 / 3}$ is detected by a class $-v_{2}^{3} b_{11}$ in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $L_{2} V(1)$, combined with calculations of Goerss, Henn and Mahowald [63, Thm. 9, Pf. of Lem. 17, Cor. 19], showing that $v_{2}^{3} b_{11}$ maps to $\pm v_{2}^{9 / 2} \beta$ in their spectral sequence for $\pi_{*}\left(E_{2}^{h N} \wedge V(1)\right)$, which remains nonzero in their spectral sequence for $\pi_{*}\left(E O_{2} \wedge V(1)\right)$. Since the map $S \rightarrow E O_{2} \wedge V(1)$ factors through $\iota: S \rightarrow \operatorname{tmf}$, it follows that $\beta_{6 / 3}$ is also detected in $\pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})$. We refer to these papers for further explanation of the notations used.

Remark 13.30. We are grateful to Paul Goerss, Hans-Werner Henn, Mike Hill and Guozhen Wang for near-simultaneous help with finding a reference for the proof that $\iota\left(\beta_{6 / 3}\right)= \pm \beta H$. A more direct proof may be possible, tracing

the Miller-Ravenel-Wilson [126, Thm. 1.1], [125, Thm. 2.6] construction of $\beta_{6 / 3}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}}^{2}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)$ via $\operatorname{Ext}_{M U_{*}}^{2}\left(M U_{*}, M U_{*}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{2}(A, A)$, where $(A, \Gamma)$ denotes the Weierstrass curve Hopf algebroid of $[\mathbf{2 3}, \S 3]$.

Let $U$ be the infinite unitary group. Localized at an odd prime $p$, the realification map $r: U \rightarrow S O$ induces an isomorphism $\pi_{*}(U) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(S O)$ in degrees $*=4 k-1$, so the image of the $J$-homomorphism is equal to the image of the complex $J$-homomorphism $J r: \pi_{*}(U) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(S)$ in these degrees.

Proposition 13.31. If $n \geq 2(p-1) k-1=\left|\alpha_{k}\right|$ and $n<2 p^{\ell}-1$ then the image of $J r: \pi_{n}(U) \rightarrow \pi_{n}(S)$ lies in Adams filtration $\geq k+1-\ell$.

Proof. Let $X[n]$ denote the $(n-1)$-connected cover of a space $X$. William Singer [158, Thm. 4.1] calculated the $\bmod p$ cohomology of each $U[2 m+1]$, showing that the $(p-1)$-fold fiber inclusion

$$
i^{p-1}: U[2(p-1)(\ell+1)-1] \longrightarrow U[2(p-1) \ell-1]
$$

induces the zero homomorphism in reduced cohomology in all degrees $*<2 p^{\ell}-1$. Hence, for integers $k$ and $\ell$ such that $n \geq 2(p-1) k-1$ and $n<2 p^{\ell}-1$, each map $f: S^{n} \rightarrow U$ factors as a composite

$$
\begin{aligned}
S^{n} \longrightarrow U[n] \longrightarrow & U[2(p-1) k-1] \xrightarrow{i^{p-1}} \ldots \\
& \ldots \xrightarrow{i^{p-1}} U[2(p-1)(\ell+1)-1] \xrightarrow{i^{p-1}} U[2(p-1) \ell-1] \longrightarrow U
\end{aligned}
$$

where each map $i^{p-1}$ induces the zero homomorphism in degrees $\leq n$. There are $k-\ell$ such maps, and each induced homomorphism $\pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{\infty} i^{p-1}\right)$ increases Adams filtration by at least 1 in degrees $\leq n$. The composite $J r f: S^{n} \rightarrow U \rightarrow S O \rightarrow Q S^{0}$ is adjoint to

$$
\Sigma^{\infty} S^{n} \xrightarrow{\Sigma^{\infty} f} \Sigma^{\infty} U \xrightarrow{\Sigma^{\infty} r} \Sigma^{\infty} S O \xrightarrow{\bar{J}} S
$$

and $\bar{J}$ has Adams filtration 1. It follows that $J r f$ has Adams filtration at least $k+1-\ell$.

Theorem 13.32. The image of the Hurewicz homomorphism

$$
\iota: \pi_{*}(S) \longrightarrow \pi_{*}(\operatorname{tmf})
$$

implicitly completed at $p=3$, is the direct sum of the following terms:
(1) The group $\mathbb{Z}\{\iota\} \cong \pi_{0}(\operatorname{tmf})$.
(2) The group $\mathbb{Z} / 3\{\nu\} \cong \pi_{3}(\operatorname{tmf})$.
(3) The groups $\Theta \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf}) \subset \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf})$ for $n<154$.
(4) A subgroup of $\Theta \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf}) \subset \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf})$ for the remaining $n \geq 154$.

Proof. Let $h: S \rightarrow H \mathbb{Z}$ be the unit map. We have inclusions

$$
\operatorname{ker}(e) \subset \operatorname{ker}(h) \subset \pi_{n}(S)
$$

By the 3-primary version of Proposition 11.82 the image of $\iota$ on $\operatorname{ker}(e)$ is contained in $\Theta \pi_{n}(\operatorname{tmf})$, and by Proposition 13.29 this containment is an equality for $n<154$. The image of $J: \pi_{n}(S O) \rightarrow \pi_{n}(S)$ gives a complementary summand $\operatorname{im}(J)$ in $\operatorname{ker}(h)$ to $\operatorname{ker}(e)$. We claim that $\iota(\operatorname{im}(J))=0$, except when $n=3$. When $n=4 k-1$ and $n<2 \cdot 3^{\ell}-1$ the image of $J$ lies in Adams filtration $\geq k+1-\ell$ in $\pi_{n}(S)$, by Proposition 13.31. Hence this is also a lower bound on the filtration of $\iota(\operatorname{im}(J))$ in the classical ( $S$-module) Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf}$, as well as in the

tmf-module Adams spectral sequence calculated in Figure 13.2. Since there are no infinite cycles in topological degree $n$ and filtration $\geq k+1-\ell$, except for $n=3$, the conclusion follows.

REMARK 13.33. In [54, $\S 13.1$ (2)] it is stated that the 3-primary Hurewicz image of $\pi_{*}(S)$ in $\pi_{*}(t m f)$ is equal to $\mathbb{Z}\{\iota\} \oplus \mathbb{Z} / 3\{\nu\} \oplus \Theta \pi_{*}(t m f)$ (using our notation for the 3 - and $B$-power torsion in degrees $* \neq 3 \bmod 24$ ). Our Theorem 13.32 confirms that this is an upper bound for the Hurewicz image, and shows that the bound is attained in the first 154 degrees. In order to extend this to all degrees, it is tempting to appeal to the self-map $v_{2}^{9}: \Sigma^{144} V(1) \rightarrow V(1)$ constructed by Behrens and Pemmaraju [28], where $V(1)=S /\left(3, v_{1}\right)$ as above. To show that a class $x: S^{n} \rightarrow S$ with nontrivial $t m f$-Hurewicz image repeats periodically, one would like to extend $x$ over $\Sigma^{n} V(1)$, and then compose with iterates of $v_{2}^{9}$. Each of the key classes $\beta_{1}, \epsilon^{\prime}, \beta_{6 / 3}$ and $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}$ has additive order 3 , hence extends over $S \rightarrow S / 3$, but in the case of $\beta_{6 / 3}$ there is no further extension over $S / 3 \rightarrow V(1)$, essentially because $\beta_{6 / 2} \in \pi_{86}(S)$ is nonzero. In order to propagate $\beta_{6 / 3}$ periodically, it would therefore seem necessary to extend the work of Behrens and Pemmaraju to construct a $v_{2}^{9}$ self-map of $S /\left(3, v_{1}^{3}\right)$, i.e., the mapping cone of $v_{1}^{3}: \Sigma^{12} S / 3 \rightarrow S / 3$. This appears to be an open problem.

The class $\alpha^{3} w_{2}$ does not survive, $\beta$ is replaced by $\beta g^{2}$, and $h_{0} d_{0}$ becomes zero, leaving the non-cyclic module

$$
\left\langle\beta g^{2}, h_{1}^{2} \gamma w_{2}\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

(For typographical reasons, we write the elements of $R_{1} \oplus R_{1}$ as pairs $(x, y)$ rather than as column vectors.) Complex (J) is

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle\beta^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle & \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\left\langle e_{0}\right\rangle \\
\\| & \quad \mid \\
R_{1} & \quad R_{1}
\end{array}
$$

The class $\beta^{2} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex (K) is

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle d_{0} \gamma w_{2}\right\rangle & \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\left\langle\alpha d_{0}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0} e_{0}\right\rangle \\
\\| & \quad \mid \\
R_{1} & \quad R_{1} & \left.\quad R_{1} /\left(g\right)\right.
\end{array}
$$

The class $d_{0} \gamma w_{2}$ does not survive, and $\alpha d_{0}$ is replaced by $\alpha d_{0} g$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{0} e_{0}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
& \left\langle\alpha d_{0} g\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex (L) is

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle h_{2} \beta\right\rangle \xrightarrow{1}\left\langle h_{0}^{2} e_{0}\right\rangle \\
\| & \| \\
R_{1} /(g) & R_{1} /(g)
\end{array}
$$

The class $h_{2} \beta$ does not survive, and $h_{0}^{2} e_{0}$ becomes zero. Complex (M) is

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle e_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle & \xrightarrow{g^{2}}\left\langle\alpha^{2}\right\rangle \\
\| & \| \\
R_{1} & R_{1}
\end{array}
$$

The class $e_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle\alpha^{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
$$

Complex (N) is

The class $\alpha d_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving the non-cyclic module

$$
\left\langle\gamma, h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g^{2} w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{O})$ is

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\left\langle w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g}\langle\alpha \beta\rangle \\
\| & \| \\
R_{1} & R_{1}
\end{array}
$$

The class $w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\langle\alpha \beta\rangle \cong R_{1} /(g)
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{P})$ is

The class $\alpha e_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, and $\alpha^{3}$ is replaced by $\alpha^{3} g+h_{0} w_{1} w_{2}$, leaving

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\left\langle h_{1}^{2} \gamma\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle h_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right) \\
\left\langle\alpha^{3} g+h_{0} w_{1} w_{2}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /(g)
\end{array}
$$

(We choose this replacement of $\alpha^{3}$ in order to present the $R_{1}$-module generated by $\alpha^{3} g$ and $h_{0} w_{2}$ as a direct sum of cyclic modules.) Complex $(\mathrm{Q})$ is

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{2} w_{1}}\left\langle\beta^{2}\right\rangle & \\
\| & \| \\
R_{1} & R_{1}
\end{array}
$$

The class $d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle\beta^{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (R) is

$$
\left\langle\alpha^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{2}}\left\langle d_{0} e_{0}\right\rangle
$$

The class $\alpha^{2} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle d_{0} e_{0}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
$$

Complex (S) is

$$
\left\langle\alpha w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(\begin{array}{c}
g \\
w_{1}
\end{array}\right)}\left\langle d_{0} \gamma\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle
$$

The class $\alpha w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving the non-cyclic module

$$
\left\langle d_{0} \gamma, h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex (T) is

$$
\left\langle d_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g}\left\langle\alpha^{2} e_{0}\right\rangle
$$

The class $d_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle\alpha^{2} e_{0}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /(g)
$$

Complex (U) is

$$
\left\langle\beta w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(\begin{array}{l}
g \\
1
\end{array}\right)}\left\langle e_{0} \gamma\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle
$$

The class $\beta w_{2}$ does not survive, and $h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}$ becomes equal to $g \cdot e_{0} \gamma$, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \gamma\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex (V) is

$$
\left\langle h_{0} \alpha e_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0}^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle
$$

The class $h_{0} \alpha e_{0} w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle h_{0}^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}, g w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (W) is

$$
\left\langle h_{0} \alpha w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle
$$

The class $h_{0} \alpha w_{2}$ is replaced by $h_{0} \alpha g w_{2}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{0} h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
& \left\langle h_{0} \alpha g w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex (X) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{0}^{2} \alpha w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \\
& \| \\
& R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right) \quad R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $h_{0}^{2} \alpha w_{2}$ is replaced by $h_{0}^{2} \alpha g w_{2}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{0}^{2} h_{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
& \left\langle h_{0}^{2} \alpha g w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{Y})$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{0} \beta w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{2}^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left.\| \quad\right\| \\
& R_{1} /(g) \quad R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $h_{0} \beta w_{2}$ does not survive, leaving

$$
\left\langle h_{2}^{2} w_{2}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (Z) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{2} \beta w_{2}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{1}\left\langle h_{0}^{2} e_{0} w_{2}\right\rangle \\
& \| \\
& R_{1} /(g) \quad R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $h_{2} \beta w_{2}$ does not survive, and $h_{0}^{2} e_{0} w_{2}$ becomes zero at the $E_{3}$-term.

Complex (A) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{1} \gamma w_{2}^{3}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)}\left\langle h_{1} w_{2}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle\gamma w_{2}^{2}, h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2} w_{1} g^{6} 0\right)}\langle 1\rangle \\
& R_{2} /(g) \quad R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right) \oplus \frac{\left\|R_{2} \oplus R_{2}\right.}{\left\langle\left(g^{2} w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle} \quad R_{2} /\left(g^{4} w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The classes $h_{1} \gamma w_{2}^{3}$ and $h_{1} w_{2}$ do not survive, and $\gamma w_{2}^{2}$ is replaced by $\gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle 1\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{6}, g^{2} w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle\gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right) \\
\left\langle h_{0} e_{0} w_{2}^{3}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g, w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{4}$. Complex (B) is

$$

& \text { (g) } \\
& \frac{R_{2} \oplus R_{2}}{\left\langle\left(g w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle} \quad R_{2} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right) \quad R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}

The classes $\beta^{2}$ and $\beta g^{2} w_{2}^{2}$ are replaced by $\beta^{2} g$ and $\beta g^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2}$, respectively, leaving

$$

at $E_{4}$. Complex (C) is

and

$$

Complex (J) is $w_{2}^{2}$ times complex (C). (We omit to display it.) The class $h_{1} e_{0} w_{2}^{3}$ does not survive, and $e_{0} w_{2}^{2}$ and $h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}^{3}$ are replaced by $e_{0} g w_{2}^{2}$ and

$$

respectively, leaving

at the $E_{4}$-term.

# APPENDIX B 

## Calculation of $E_{r}(t m f / 2)$ for $r=3,4,5$

Recall from Definition 5.1 that $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right], R_{1}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2}\right]$ and $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$. Our calculations show that $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ is a complex of $R_{1^{-}}$ modules, while $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ and $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$ are complexes of $R_{2}$-modules.

## B.1. Calculation of $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)=H\left(E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2), d_{2}\right)$

When regarded as a complex of $R_{1}$-modules, the $\left(E_{2}, d_{2}\right)$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ splits as a direct sum of 24 two-term complexes of the form

$$
R_{1}\{x\} \xrightarrow{a} R_{1}\{y\}
$$

eight other complexes labeled (A) to $(\mathrm{H})$, and a large summand with trivial differential. Table B. 1 gives, for each $R_{0}$-module generator $x$ of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$, the summands to which $x$ and $x w_{2}$ belong. Table B. 2 describes the two-term complexes, numbered $n=1$ to 24 . In each case, $R_{1}\{x\}$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $\langle y\rangle=R_{1} /(a)$ in $E_{3}$. The remaining complexes and their homology are described individually following these tables.
