We treat the remaining eight complexes individually. Complex (A) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(\gamma w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\langle i(\alpha)\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
\\| \\
R_{1}
\end{array} \quad \begin{array}{l}
\\| \\
R_{1}
\end{array} \quad R_{1} /(g)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $i\left(\gamma w_{2}\right)$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $i(\alpha)$ is replaced by $i(\alpha g)$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(h_{2}\right)\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
& \langle i(\alpha g)\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{3}$. Complex (B) is

The classes $\widetilde{h_{0}^{2} e_{0}}$ and $i\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right)$ do not survive to $E_{3}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle i\left(h_{1} c_{0}\right)\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle i\left(\beta^{2}\right)\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{3}$. Complex (C) is

The classes $i\left(\beta^{2} w_{2}\right)$ and $w_{2} \widetilde{h_{0}^{2} e_{0}}$ do not survive to $E_{3}$, while $i\left(e_{0}\right)$ and $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ do. Replacing $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ by the sum $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}+e_{0} g^{2}\right)$ gives a description of the result at $E_{3}$ as a sum of cyclic modules. We then use the relations $i\left(e_{0} g^{2}\right)=12_{20}=\beta^{2} g \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$, $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}\right)=12_{21}=h_{1}^{2} w_{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$ and $\gamma^{2}=\beta^{2} g+h_{1}^{2} w_{2}$ to shorten the name of this second generator from $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}+e_{0} g^{2}\right)$ to $\gamma^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}$. This gives the summands

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(e_{0}\right)\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right) \\
& \left\langle\gamma^{2} \widetilde{h_{2}^{2}}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{3}$. Complex (D) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(\alpha w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2}\right)}\left\langle e_{0} \widetilde{h_{1}}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle i\left(h_{2} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
& \left.\| \right\|_{R_{1}} \\
& R_{1} \oplus R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $i\left(\alpha w_{2}\right)$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $e_{0} \widetilde{h_{1}}$ and $i\left(h_{2} w_{2}\right)$ generate the non-cyclic summand

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \widetilde{h_{1}}, i\left(h_{2} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g^{2}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex (E) is

$$
\left\langle\alpha^{2} w_{2} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\left\langle\widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle i\left(h_{1} \delta\right)\right\rangle
$$

![img-272.jpeg](img-272.jpeg)
The class $\alpha^{2} w_{2} \widetilde{\beta^{2}}$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $\widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}$ is replaced by $g \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle i\left(h_{1} \delta\right)\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle g \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex (F) is

The class $d_{0} e_{0} w_{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $\widetilde{\beta g}$ is replaced by $g \widetilde{\beta g}$ and $h_{1}^{2} \widetilde{\delta}^{\prime}$ becomes 0 . We use the identity $g \widetilde{\beta g}=11_{21}=\beta^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$ to rewrite the element $g \widetilde{\beta g}$ as $\beta^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}$ henceforth, to simplify the rest of the calculation. This leaves only the summand

$$
\left\langle\beta^{2} \widetilde{\gamma}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (G) is

The class $w_{2} \widetilde{\alpha^{2} e_{0}}$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $\beta \widetilde{\gamma}$ and $i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)$ generate the non-cyclic summand

$$
\left\langle\beta \widetilde{\gamma}, i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g^{2} w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{H})$ is

The class $w_{2} \widetilde{\beta g}$ does not survive to $E_{3}$, while $h_{1}^{2} w_{2} \widetilde{\delta^{\prime}}$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot e_{0} \widetilde{\gamma}$, leaving only the summand

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \widetilde{\gamma}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

at $E_{3}$.

# B.2. Calculation of $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)=H\left(E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2), d_{3}\right)$ 

When regarded as a complex of $R_{2}$-modules, the $\left(E_{3}, d_{3}\right)$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / 2$ splits as a direct sum of six two-term complexes of the form

$$
R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right)\{x\} \xrightarrow{g w_{1}} R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right)\{y\}
$$

14 other complexes labeled (A) to (N), and a large summand with trivial differential. Table B. 3 gives, for each $R_{1}$-module generator $x$ of $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / 2)$, the summands to which $x$ and $x w_{2}^{2}$ belong. Table B. 4 describes the two-term complexes, numbered $n=1$ to 6 . In these, $x$ does not survive to $E_{4}$, but $g x$ and $y$ do, and generate $R_{2}$-summands

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle g x\rangle & =R_{2} /(g) \\
\langle y\rangle & =R_{2} /\left(g^{2}, g w_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The remaining complexes and their homology are described individually following these tables.

Note that we replace $i(\alpha g)$ in Table 6.4 by $i\left(\delta^{\prime}\right)=i(\delta+\alpha g)$ here, since this simplifies $d_{3}$.

# APPENDIX C 

## Calculation of $E_{r}(t m f / \eta)$ for $r=3,4$

Recall from Definition 5.1 that $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right], R_{1}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2}\right]$ and $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$. Our calculations show that $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ is a complex of $R_{1^{-}}$ modules, and $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$ is a complex of $R_{2}$-modules.

## C.1. Calculation of $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)=H\left(E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta), d_{2}\right)$

When regarded as a complex of $R_{1}$-modules, the $\left(E_{2}, d_{2}\right)$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \eta$ splits as a direct sum of twelve complexes of the form

$$
R_{1} \longrightarrow R_{1} \oplus R_{1} \longrightarrow R_{1}
$$

labeled (A1)-(A12), twenty-eight other complexes labeled (B1) to (I4), and a summand with trivial differential. Table C. 1 gives, for each $R_{0}$-module generator $x$ of $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \eta)$, the summands to which $x$ and $x w_{2}$ belong. Tables C. 2 and C. 3 describe the complexes (A1) to (A12) and their homology, respectively. The remaining complexes and their homology are described following this.

The complexes (A1) to (A12) have the form

$$
R_{1}\{z\} \xrightarrow{\binom{b_{0}}{b_{1}}} R_{1}\left\{y_{0}\right\} \oplus R_{1}\left\{y_{1}\right\} \xrightarrow{\left(a_{0} a_{1}\right)} R_{1}\{x\}
$$

with the $a_{i}$ and $b_{i}$ being monomials in $g$ and $w_{1}$. If we write $a_{i}=d \cdot a_{i}^{\prime}$, with $d$ the greatest common divisor of $a_{0}$ and $a_{1}$, then we must have

$$
\binom{b_{0}}{b_{1}}=c\binom{a_{1}^{\prime}}{a_{0}^{\prime}}
$$

for some $c \in R_{1}$. The homology of the complex is then the sum of

$$
\frac{R_{1}}{\left(a_{0}, a_{1}\right)}\{x\}
$$

and

$$
\frac{R_{1}}{(c)}\left\{a_{1}^{\prime} y_{0}+a_{0}^{\prime} y_{1}\right\}
$$

Of course, this second summand is 0 when $c=1$. When this occurs, the generator $x$ remains at the $E_{3}$-term and the generators $y_{0}, y_{1}$ and $z$ disappear. When $c \neq 1$, the generator $x$ remains at $E_{3}$, the generators $y_{0}$ and $y_{1}$ are replaced by $a_{1}^{\prime} y_{0}+a_{0}^{\prime} y_{1}$, and $z$ disappears. In Table C.3, the superfluous entry $a_{1}^{\prime} y_{0}+a_{0}^{\prime} y_{1}$ and its annihilator ideal (1) are replaced by dashes when $c=1$. Similarly, in cases (A8) and (A9), the superfluous generators $x=i\left(\alpha^{2} e_{0}\right)$ and $d_{0} \widehat{h_{0}}$, with annihilator ideal (1), are replaced by dashes. Note also that $\operatorname{Ann}(x)=\left(a_{0}, a_{1}\right)$ often has a simpler description, which we give in Table C.3.

# APPENDIX D 

## Calculation of $E_{r}(t m f / \nu)$ for $r=3,4,5$

Recall from Definition 5.1 that $R_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}\right], R_{1}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{2}\right]$ and $R_{2}=\mathbb{F}_{2}\left[g, w_{1}, w_{2}^{4}\right]$. Our calculations show that $E_{2}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ is a complex of $R_{1^{-}}$ modules, while $E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ and $E_{4}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu)$ are complexes of $R_{2}$-modules.

## D.1. Calculation of $E_{3}(t m f / \nu)=H\left(E_{2}(t m f / \nu), d_{2}\right)$

The $\left(E_{2}, d_{2}\right)$-term of the Adams spectral sequence for $\operatorname{tmf} / \nu$ splits as a direct sum of $32 R_{1}$-module complexes of length two or three, labeled (A1-4), (B1-18) and (C) to (L), plus a large summand with trivial differential. The Type-columns in Table D. 1 give the labels of the complexes containing the $R_{1}$-module generators $x$ and $x w_{2}$. For each complex we discuss the passage to homology with respect to the $d_{2}$-differential, giving the transition from the $E_{2}$-term to the $E_{3}$-term.

| 16 | $d_{0} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}$ | $\alpha d_{0} \bar{g}$ |
| 17 | $e_{0} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}$ | $\alpha^{2} \bar{\gamma}$ |
| 18 | $\alpha^{2} w_{2} \bar{g}$ | $d_{0} e_{0} \bar{g}$ |

Complex (C) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(\alpha e_{0} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\left\langle\overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}\right\rangle \\
& R_{1} \\
& R_{1} \\
& R_{1} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $i\left(\alpha e_{0} w_{2}\right)$ does not survive, and $\overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}$ is replaced by $g \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle h_{0} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle g \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex (D) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle i\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{2} w_{1}}\left\langle\overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{1}\left\langle i\left(h_{1} c_{0}\right)\right\rangle \\
& \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
\mid \\
R_{1}
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left.\quad R_{1} \quad R_{1} / g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The classes $i\left(h_{1} c_{0}\right)$ and $i\left(d_{0} e_{0} w_{2}\right)$ do not survive, and $\overline{h_{2}^{2}}$ is replaced by $g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle g \overline{h_{2}^{2}}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (E) is

The classes $i\left(h_{0} d_{0}\right)$ and $w_{2} \overline{h_{0}^{2} \alpha}$ do not survive, and $i(\beta)$ is replaced by $i(\beta g)$, leaving the non-cyclic module

$$
\left\langle i(\beta g), h_{0} w_{2} \overline{h_{0} h_{2}}\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex (F) is

The class $w_{2} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$ does not survive, and $i\left(h_{1} c_{0} w_{2}\right)$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot i\left(e_{0}\right)$, leaving

$$
\left\langle i\left(e_{0}\right)\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{G})$ is

$$
\left\langle i\left(\beta w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2}\right)}\left\langle e_{0} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle
$$

The class $i\left(\beta w_{2}\right)$ does not survive, and $i\left(h_{0} d_{0} w_{2}\right)$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot e_{0} \overline{h_{1}}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex $(\mathrm{H})$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle a^{2} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{g^{3}}\left\langle\overline{\alpha^{3}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\left\langle h_{0} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\rangle \\
& \left.\| \|_{R_{1}} \quad \right\rvert\, \quad \|_{R_{1}} \\
& \left.\quad R_{1} / g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The class $\alpha^{2} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}$ does not survive, and $\overline{\alpha^{3}}$ is replaced by $g \overline{\alpha^{3}}$, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle h_{0} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\left\langle g \overline{\alpha^{3}}\right\rangle & \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Complex (I) is

The classes $i\left(h_{1} \delta\right)$ and $d_{0} e_{0} w_{2} \bar{g}$ do not survive, and $\overline{\beta^{2}}$ is replaced by $g \overline{\beta^{2}}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle g \overline{\beta^{2}}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)
$$

Complex (J) is

The classes $h_{0} d_{0} \bar{g}$ and $w_{2} \overline{\alpha^{3}}$ do not survive, and $\beta \bar{g}$ is replaced by $\beta g \bar{g}$, leaving the non-cyclic module

$$
\left\langle\beta g \bar{g}, h_{0} w_{2} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\rangle \cong \frac{R_{1} \oplus R_{1}}{\left\langle\left(g w_{1}, w_{1}\right),(0, g)\right\rangle}
$$

Complex (K) is

The class $\left.w_{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}\right)$ does not survive, and $i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot e_{0} \bar{g}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \bar{g}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex (L) is

$$
\left\langle\beta w_{2} \bar{g}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2}\right)}\left\langle e_{0} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)\right\rangle
$$

The class $w_{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}$ does not survive, and $i\left(h_{1} \delta w_{2}\right)$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot e_{0} \bar{g}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \bar{g}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex (L) is

$$
\left\langle\beta w_{2} \bar{g}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g^{2}\right)}\left\langle e_{0} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle h_{0} d_{0} w_{2} \bar{g}\right\rangle
$$

The class $\beta w_{2} \bar{g}$ does not survive, and $h_{0} d_{0} w_{2} \bar{g}$ becomes equal to $g^{2} \cdot e_{0} \bar{\gamma}$, leaving

$$
\left\langle e_{0} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle \cong R_{1} /\left(g^{3}\right)
$$

Complex (A) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle h_{1} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}, g w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}, h_{1} w_{2}^{3} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(\begin{array}{cc}
g^{2} w_{1} & g^{0} \\
0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & g^{2} w_{1}
\end{array}\right)}\left\langle\bar{\gamma}, i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right), w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(g w_{1} g^{2} w_{1} g^{5}\right)}\langle i(1)\rangle \\
& \frac{R_{2}}{(g)} \oplus \frac{R_{2}}{\left(g^{2} w_{1}\right)} \oplus \frac{R_{2}}{(g)} \quad \frac{R_{2}}{\left(g^{3} w_{1}\right)} \oplus \frac{R_{2}}{(g)} \oplus \frac{R_{2}}{\left(g^{3} w_{1}\right)} \quad \frac{R_{2}}{\left(g^{3} w_{1}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

(For typographical reasons we write $\left\langle h_{1} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}, g w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}, h_{1} w_{2}^{3} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle$ and $\left\langle\bar{\gamma}, i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right), w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle$ in place of $\left\langle h_{1} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle g w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle h_{1} w_{2}^{3} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle$ and $\langle\bar{\gamma}\rangle \oplus\left\langle i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)\right\rangle \oplus\left\langle w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle$, respectively.) The classes $h_{1} w_{2} \bar{\gamma}$ and $h_{1} w_{2}^{3} \overline{h_{1}}$ do not survive, $g w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}$ is replaced by $g w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}, w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}$ is replaced by $w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}$, and the two classes $\bar{\gamma}$ and $i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)$ are replaced by the single class

$$
\gamma \bar{g}=9_{30}+9_{31}=g \bar{\gamma}+i\left(h_{1} w_{2}\right)

leaving the direct sum of the four cyclic modules

$$
\begin{aligned}

\left\langle w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{1}}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right) \\
\left\langle g w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{4}$. Complex (B) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle\beta g w_{2}^{2} \bar{g}, h_{0} w_{2}^{3} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{\left(\begin{array}{cc}

0 & 0 \\

\end{aligned}
$$

The classes $\beta g w_{2}^{2} \bar{g}$ and $h_{1} w_{2} \overline{h_{1}}$ do not survive, and $g w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$ is replaced by $g^{5} \overline{\beta^{2}}+$ $g w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{h_{2}^{2}}$, leaving

$$

\end{aligned}
$$

& \langle x\rangle \xrightarrow{g w_{1}}\langle y\rangle \\

$$

There are ten such summands in $\left(E_{3}(\operatorname{tmf} / \nu), d_{3}\right)$, with $x$ and $y$ as in Table D.5, leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle y\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}, g w_{1}\right) \\
\langle g x\rangle & \cong R_{2} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{4}$.

Complex (D) is

$$
\begin{aligned}

$$

and the class $e_{0} \bar{\gamma}$ is replaced by $e_{0} g^{2} \bar{\gamma}$, leaving

\left\langle e_{0} g^{2} \bar{\gamma}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

Type (E) complexes have the form

& \langle x\rangle \xrightarrow{w_{1}}\langle y\rangle \\
& \left.\| \\

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle y\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g, w_{1}\right) \\
\langle g x\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{4}$.

and $i\left(w_{2}^{2}\right)$ is replaced by $g^{4} \bar{g}+i\left(w_{1} w_{2}^{2}\right)$. This leaves

and the non-cyclic summand

and

\gamma^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \bar{g}=34_{302}+34_{303}=g^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \overline{\beta^{2}}+i\left(h_{1} \gamma w_{1} w_{2}^{3}\right)
$$

leaving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle d_{0} w_{2}^{2} \overline{\alpha \beta}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /\left(g^{2}, g w_{1}, w_{1}^{2}\right) \\
\left\langle\gamma^{2} w_{1} w_{2}^{2} \bar{g}\right\rangle & \cong R_{2} /(g)
\end{aligned}
$$

at $E_{5}$.

The connective topological modular forms spectrum, tmf, is in a sense initial among elliptic spectra, and as such is an important link between the homotopy groups of spheres and modular forms. A primary goal of this volume is to give a complete account, with full proofs, of the homotopy of $t m f$ and several tmf-module spectra by means of the classical Adams spectral sequence, thus verifying, correcting, and extending existing approaches. In the process, folklore results are made precise and generalized. Anderson and BrownComenetz duality, and the corresponding dualities in homotopy groups, are carefully proved. The volume also includes an account of the homotopy groups of spheres through degree 44, with complete proofs, except that the Adams conjecture is used without proof. Also presented are modern stable proofs of classical results which are hard to extract from the literature.
Tools used in this book include a multiplicative spectral sequence generalizing a construction of Davis and Mahowald, and computer software which computes the cohomology of modules over the Steenrod algebra and products therein. Techniques from commutative algebra are used to make the calculation precise and finite. The $H$-infinity ring structure of the sphere and of $t m f$ are used to determine many differentials and relations.
